fields.headline: Fighting dirty
fields.standfirst: Phillip Knightley changed our view of war and the media with his book The First Casualty. To mark its updating, he argues that the war correspondent has an easy choice: either become part of the military's propaganda machine - or quit
fields.trailText: When groups of old war correspondents gather in a bar - as they have been known to do - they shed a nostalgic tear for Vietnam, the days when they were heroes, famous and important.
fields.body:
When groups of old war correspondents gather in a bar - as they have been known to do - they shed a nostalgic tear for Vietnam, the days when they were heroes, famous and important.

In Vietnam the United States military accepted them and called on all ranks to give them full cooperation. Free from censorship, the journalists went where they chose, reported the truth as they saw it and, according to the military, thus lost the US the war.

Robert Elegant, a long-serving Asia expert, wrote later: "For the first time in modern history the outcome of war was determined not on the battlefield but on the printed page and, above all, on the television screen."

The military was bitter. War correspondents had been patriotic in the second world war and on side in Korea. What was wrong in Vietnam? "So you're Malcolm Browne," said Admiral Harry D Felt when he met the legendary Associated Press journalist. "Why the hell don't you get on the team?"

Fast-forward 25 years to Kosovo in March last year. More correspondents than ever were set to cover the conflict - an astonishing 2,700 media people accompanied Nato forces when they entered the province at the end of the bombing campaign.

Official arrangements for them were awe-inspiring. There was a daily briefing at Nato's headquarters in Brussels, a series of briefings at the Ministry of Defence (MoD) in London, media meetings at the Pentagon, press conferences at the White House and statement after statement from President Clinton, Prime Minister Blair and numerous other Allied ministers.

The revolution in communications technology; the satellite phone - the star of the war; instant television links from the front to the studio and between correspondents in the field; electronic transmission of photographs; and the internet; all were available to provide the public with an unprecedented overview of the war. The ordinary, literate citizen would be able to know more about the conflict than any war in history.

Instead, we drowned in wave after wave of words and images that added up to nothing. "Kosovo . . . turned out to be the most secret campaign in living memory," wrote the British war historian Alistair Horne. "We were given lots of material but no information," says Sky war correspondent Jake Lynch. British journalist Peter Dunn wrote that it was "the first international conflict fought by press officers."

What had changed between Vietnam and Kosovo? Basically, the military has won its 150-year battle with war correspondents: journalists want to tell the public everything; the military's attitude is: "Tell them nothing till the war's over, then tell them who won." Defeated by the military, governments and spin doctors, war correspondents now face an agonising choice. If they can no longer be heroes, do they want to continue as propagandists, subservient to those who wage the wars?

The turning point in the battle was the Falklands. The nature of the campaign - a seaborne task force sailing to invade a group of islands 13,000km from Britain and 650km from the nearest land mass - meant that correspondents could not get to the war unless the MoD took them. In return for access to the action the correspondents had to accept the MoD rules. These were crippling. British correspondents only; no impartial neutrals. The British applicants were vetted - no room, for example, for veteran photographer Don McCullin, because his photographs tended to be too realistic.

The 17 correspondents eventually accredited had to sign forms agreeing to accept censorship at source by six MoD "public relations officers". The result was that the war was reported exactly how the military wanted it to be.

From this success, a theory developed. If you confronted the media and told them that, unlike Vietnam, this was a war that they would not be allowed to cover, they would become so desperate that you could do a deal - they would be allowed coverage but only on the military's terms.

This theory was tested in the American invasions of Grenada and Panama, and worked well in the Gulf war. There the US and Britain operated a "pool system". Only a limited number of journalists would be allowed near the battlefield; they would be escorted by officers who would decide what they would see; and the journalists would have to make their reports available.

Media groups complained that this amounted to censorship more dangerous than "blue-pencil editing", but accepted the conditions because they had no choice. By the time Kosovo came around, the lies, manipulation, propaganda, spin, distortion, omission, slant and gullibility involved in trying to report the conflict brought war correspondents to their current crisis point. Their role has never been more insecure.

The most shameful event for the media during the Kosovo war was a US Congressional fact-finding mission to Yugoslavia between April 18 and 21. Congressmen felt they could trust neither the administration nor the media to tell them what was really happening - what an indictment of war correspondents. How did they allow this sorry state of affairs to come about?

One difficulty is that the media have little or no memory. War correspondents have short working lives and there is no tradition or means for passing on their knowledge and experience. The military, on the other hand, is an institution and goes on for ever. The military learned a lot from Vietnam and these days plans its media strategy with as much attention as its military strategy.

The Pentagon and the MoD have manuals, updated after every war, which serve to guide the way they will manage the media. These manuals follow basic principles - appear transparent and eager to help; never go in for summary repression or direct control; nullify rather than conceal undesirable news; control emphasis rather than facts; balance bad news with good; and lie directly only when certain the lie will not be found out during the course of the war.

We are learning only now what lies were told and what secrets kept from us during the Kosovo war. We were not told that the CIA helped train the Kosovo Liberation Army (KLA) before the bombing began. We were not told that the KLA realised its attacks on Serbian policemen would bring retaliation on ethnic Albanian civilians but it went ahead anyway because it hoped that Serbian atrocities would bring in the West - as they did.

We did not realise at the time that Nato was lying when it said it did not deliberately attack civilian targets. It was not until June that Nato's commander, General Wesley Clark, admitted that Nato planes were targeting "phase 3" [civilian] targets.

We believed Nato when it said that after the war it would disarm and disband the KLA. But Jonathan Dimbleby wrote in January that the KLA remained in control of the streets, Nato had delivered Kosovo from one catastrophe into another, and Western leaders had remained silent about outrages taking place there.

We believed Nato when it said it was systematically destroying the Serbian army in Kosovo, only to learn after the war that this was simply not so. We believed the figures the State Department and Pentagon released for the number of ethnic Albanians murdered by Serbs, only to see them come tumbling down - 500,000, then 100,000, then 10,000 - when Nato entered Kosovo and sufficient mass graves failed to materialise.

True, the nature of the war played into the military's hands in keeping the true face of battle from the public. It was fought entirely from the air by means of a high-altitude bombing campaign, so no one - except the victims - really knew what was happening on the ground.

Since they could not go to the fighting, correspondents either gathered at Nato headquarters or clustered along the borders of those countries surrounding Kosovo and tried to peer over. There they were interviewed on television by fellow journalists in studios in Europe and the US - who often had to brief them on the latest news before the interview started because the reporter on the spot usually knew nothing.

According to veteran correspondent Robert Fisk, one of the few heroes left, this lack of access to the war produced two types of journalists - the "frothers" who had "convinced themselves of the justice of the war and the wickedness of the other side" - and the "sheep" who blindly followed Nato's word.

The Russians watched and learned. When Moscow began its campaign against Chechnya, it used a system of news management based on Nato's. An information centre in Moscow offered Nato-style briefings that had to be accepted at face value, while at the front everything possible was done to hinder journalists and exclude them from battle zones.

The sad truth is that today government propaganda prepares its citizens for war so skilfully that it is quite likely they do not want the truthful, objective and balanced reporting war correspondents once did their best to provide.

Studies carried out after the Gulf war by Dr David Morrison, of the University of Leeds, showed that if there were a British mistake that caused a war to go badly, most people in the study felt that this mistake should never be reported, or only after the war was over.

Further, where reporting in the Gulf was dominated by television as in no other war, most viewers were quite content with the reporting and considered it to be accurate and fair. If viewers had any complaint at all, it was that television stations devoted too much time to the war.

Armed with information like this, the likelihood is that governments will find further justification for managing the media in wartime. In fact, I predict that control of war correspondents - both open and covert - will be even tighter, and that this will be accepted by most media groups because in wartime they consider their best commercial and political interests lie in supporting the government of the day.

webTitle: Decision to deploy paras 'came from top'

fields.headline: Decision to deploy paras 'came from top'
fields.standfirst: The Bloody Sunday inquiry: special report
fields.trailText: The longest serving senior army officer in Londonderry warned against deploying the Parachute Regiment in the city for a planned mass arrest operation after an illegal anti-internment parade, the Bloody Sunday inquiry heard yesterday.
fields.body:
The longest serving senior army officer in Londonderry warned against deploying the Parachute Regiment in the city for a planned mass arrest operation after an illegal anti-internment parade, the Bloody Sunday inquiry heard yesterday.

An unnamed colonel, commander of the Royal Anglians, was told two days before the march the decision to use paratroopers was taken at the highest level. He believed Edward Heath's government had made the ruling.

The officer, identified yesterday only with the number 1347, said in his statement to Lord Saville's inqury that he was surprised the first battalion of the Parachute Regiment, based in Belfast, was earmarked for a sweep-up arrest operation. Their uncompromising approach was well know.

He had demanded a meeting with Brigadier Pat MacLellan, in charge of the army in Derry, and suggested the Royal Anglians be used to carry out the arrest mission. He believed the paras should instead man the blockades to stop the march.

But Brigadier MacLellan told him the decision had been taken at the highest level.

The officer said: "I understood his reference to the 'highest level' to mean that the decision had been taken at government level as in my opinion no military commander would place a battalion in a situation where the troops did not know the ground."

Paratroopers had never been deployed in Londonderry. He believed Belfast and Derry were as different as chalk from cheese. They would be going in blind.

He said: "I was so unhappy with the situation that I contemplated contacting headquarters in Northern Ireland myself and considered what further action I could take. But if Brigadier MacLellan was in a no-win situation, then who would listen to me?"

Paratroopers shot dead 13 unarmed Catholics in Derry on January 30, 1972. A wounded man died five months later.

Christopher Clarke QC, counsel to the inquiry, said at Derry's Guildhall that there was no evidence in any of the documents amassed indicating a secret plan to use the civil rights demonstration to provoke the IRA or to teach the people of the Bogside a lesson.

Such a plan would have meant the prime minister and chief of general staff would have had to have been involved, deceived or left in ignorance, and it could not have been carried out without giving necessary instructions to the troops, Mr Clarke said.

General Robert Ford, then second in command of the army in Northern Ireland, said in his statement: "Never was it intended, as I have seen suggested in a document prepared by the Irish government, to make an example of the Bogside community. That is nonsense."

General Sir Michael Jackson, who led the British forces in Kosovo, was then a captain and adjutant to the Parachute Regiment. He said any secret plan would have required the involvement of both the British government and the Stormont administration. "Two cabinets, two prime ministers, two generals, Ford and [Sir Harry] Tuzo, would have had to know of such a concealed plan, as would Brigadier MacLellan, Lieutenant Colonel [Derek] Wilford, and indeed the entire battalion.

"Such an operation could not have been planned orally. There would have been a piece of paper. It's ridiculous to suggest that there was a plan of this nature but that nothing came out of it."

Mr Clarke outlined reports from two security service informers to their handlers immediately after Bloody Sunday. They said they had been told IRA gunmen had been firing at soldiers after the march. One spoke of men dumping four weapons in a gun-laden car.

One informer said in his heavily edited statement that an unidentified contact had told him that the first shot he heard was the "thud of a Thompson [submachine gun]" and that he was convinced the IRA had fired first.

fields.headline: Mugabe regime faces meltdown
fields.standfirst:
Hyper-inflation, strikes, international isolation and ruinous involvement in the Congo war spell the end for the father of Zimbabwe

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: More than 1,000 striking workers gathered amid the municipal rose bushes outside Harare's town hall yesterday for a third straight day. The effect of their stoppage so far is a city largely without water and with an increasing number of unburied dead.
fields.body:
More than 1,000 striking workers gathered amid the municipal rose bushes outside Harare's town hall yesterday for a third straight day. The effect of their stoppage so far is a city largely without water and with an increasing number of unburied dead.

Their immediate cause is a demand for a pay increase of at least 70% to keep pace with hyper-inflation. But behind their protest is discontent that is starting to fan out across the country. It is a crisis that is being imperfectly masked by a stand-off between white farmers and the war veterans who have been invading their land.

Harare is the least African of African cities, with its Woolworths, post-colonial hang-ups and a climate that produces little except perfect British summer days (before global warming mucked things up, even the rain was said to be considerate, and fell only at night).

And the mood here would be familiar to anyone who was in Britain in the spring of 1997. There is a feeling, of rare unanimity, that the government is in meltdown. After 20 years of power, Robert Mugabe, one of the world's most durable leaders, is on the brink. The question is not whether he will lose power but when and how.

Parliamentary elections are expected in May or June: they cannot be postponed much after that. For the first time the ruling Zanu-PF party is facing a plausible and reasonably united opposition in the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC), led by the labour leader Morgan Tsvangarai. Since a referendum last month in which Mr Mugabe failed to win backing for a new constitution, even cool-headed analysts believe he can be beaten.

Mr Mugabe's presidential term ends in two years, when he will be 78. Even supporters concede that another is unthinkable. The nature of the coming transition will be a defining moment not just for Zimbabwe but for Africa as a whole.

Crucial message

Theoretically, the country could face a period of cohabitation with Mr Mugabe as president and opponents holding the balance of power in parliament. If Mr Mugabe retires quietly, perhaps rescuing his own reputation as father of his country, it will send a crucial message to Africa's other uncertain democracies and quasi-democracies such as Kenya, Mozambique and Nigeria. Last week, President Abdou Diouf of Senegal lost an election after 19 years and stepped down at once, and gracefully.

A military coup is possible if not probable. But the Zimbabwean army is distracted by its intervention in the war-torn Democratic Republic of Congo, an adventure which is a prime cause of Zimbabwe's economic crisis.

The more general assumption is that the opposition will score a moral victory in the coming elections but be done down either by rural vote-rigging or the constitutional clause that allows the president to top up the 120 elected members of parliament with 30 of his own choices. That may well prove unacceptable to his increasingly confident, vocal and numerous opponents.

In a situation full of historic twists and ironies, the most bittersweet of all may be that President Mugabe's own greatest achievement could be his downfall. When he came to power in 1980 after the collapse of Ian Smith's rebel white regime, he instituted one of the best education systems in Africa (now in disarray). The under-35s who benefited are the ones suffering in the current crisis. Many of them were outside the town hall yesterday.

Mabasa Mashiri, a father of four who works in the treasurer's department, takes home 8,000 Zimbabwe dollars a year. The dollar, once on parity with the pound, is now artificially high at just under 2p.

"Everything has gone up except my wages. It has changed our way of living. I can't give the children pocket money any more. We used to have cereals and bacon and eggs for breakfast, but we can't afford that any more."

Everyone agreed what had to be done about it. "The biggest tomato is rotten," said Cosmo from the housing department. "It rots the whole barrel. The old man is tired."

"When you wear a shirt it gets dirty. You have to change it occasionally," said Louie the roadman.

Many of the strikers were carrying copies of a new anti-government paper, the Daily News, which on Tuesday listed many of the 270 officials said to have been given farms that might have gone to the landless protesters. They included the speaker, the deputy speaker, the defence secretary, the secretary to the president and two state governors.

Suffering

Even Bornwell Chakaodza, the editor of the government-owned and faithful Herald, accepts that all this is having an effect. "We are talking about a party that has been in power for 20 years. Given the economic hardship people are suffering, there is a mood that is particularly anti-government, especially in the urban areas."

This is a mood reflected only very warily in the Herald's columns. An editorial yesterday claimed the ruling party was fighting corruption and was being renewed in the current series of primaries, which have overturned several sitting members: "It has demonstrated its dy namism, its willingness to listen to the people's concerns and to make necessary changes."

This view has not had much resonance in the five-hour petrol queues that built up last week, which often turned into impromptu political mini-rallies. The queues have eased a little in the past couple of days, but yesterday drivers needing diesel still had to wait nearly three hours and were then limited to five litres each.

The national oil company (itself the subject of corruption allegations) has been forced to pay cash up front for its imports. At present, Zimbabwe is not earning enough overseas to pay the monthly petrol bill. This cannot wholly be blamed on homosexuals in the British cabinet, of ten the subject of tirades from Mr Mugabe.

The situation will ease slightly in a few weeks when the year's tobacco sales kick in. This is one good reason to delay the election.

However, tourism has, predictably, collapsed like a pit canary at the first whiff of international disfavour. The donor nations are standing aside. Relations with Britain are terrible and South Africa will not step in. Tobacco and gold, the basics of the Zimbabwean economy, are products with their own long term problems. There is no easy way out for Mr Mugabe.

The old electoral arithmetic was that his supporters from the Shona tribe would outvote the minority Ndebele. But the new generation is too sophisticated for that. His supporters trust that votes from the countryside (counted fairly or otherwise) will pull the party through come election-time. But rural Zimbabwe depends heavily on money from family members working in towns. If Harare is feeling the chill, the villages of the heartland will catch their death.

The whites, of course, are itching for Mr Mugabe's downfall. But it is Zimbabwe future, not Rhodesia past, that is making the position untenable.

"There is one thing we can thank Mugabe for," said Trevor Ncube, the editor of the anti-government Independent. "He has united the country. White, black, Indian, coloured, Shona, Ndebele. There is a resolve across this land to bring about change."

From freedom fighter to oppressor

1924 Born February 21

1963 Founds dominant movement for independence from Britain, Zimbabwe African National Union (Zanu), becoming secretary general

1964-74 Imprisoned by British as they attempt to check resentment at colonialism

1975 Escapes into Mozambique. The armed liberation struggle under Zimbabwe African National Liberation Army (Zanla), the armed wing of Zanu, begins to wear down Rhodesian regime. Within three years peace talks are held in London

1980 Zanu wins elections and Mugabe becomes first prime minister of independent Zimbabwe

1987 Made president. Opposition suppressed by ruthless security machine but growing economic problems, particularly over vexed question of land ownership by whites, begin to dog him

2000 Opposition wins shock victory in February referendum on draft constitution that would have given Mugabe greater powers. The worst defeat of his rule. Subsequent poll suggests 65% of Zimbabweans think he should step down

Harare is the least African of African cities, with its Woolworths, post-colonial hang-ups and a climate that produces little except perfect British summer days (before global warming mucked things up, even the rain was said to be considerate, and fell only at night). And the mood here would be familiar to anyone who was in Britain in the spring of 1997. There is a feeling, of rare unanimity, that the government is in meltdown. After 20 years of power, Robert Mugabe, one of the world's most durable leaders, is on the brink. The question is not whether he will lose power but when and how. Parliamentary elections are expected in May or June: they cannot be postponed much after that. For the first time the ruling Zanu-PF party is facing a plausible and reasonably united opposition in the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC), led by the labour leader Morgan Tsvangarai. Since a referendum last month in which Mr Mugabe failed to win backing for a new constitution, even cool-headed analysts believe he can be beaten. Mr Mugabe's presidential term ends in two years, when he will be 78. Even supporters concede that another is unthinkable. The nature of the coming transition will be a defining moment not just for Zimbabwe but for Africa as a whole. Crucial message Theoretically, the country could face a period of cohabitation with Mr Mugabe as president and opponents holding the balance of power in parliament. If Mr Mugabe retires quietly, perhaps rescuing his own reputation as father of his country, it will send a crucial message to Africa's other uncertain democracies and quasi-democracies such as Kenya, Mozambique and Nigeria. Last week, President Abdou Diouf of Senegal lost an election after 19 years and stepped down at once, and gracefully. A military coup is possible if not probable. But the Zimbabwean army is distracted by its intervention in the war-torn Democratic Republic of Congo, an adventure which is a prime cause of Zimbabwe's economic crisis. The more general assumption is that the opposition will score a moral victory in the coming elections but be done down either by rural vote-rigging or the constitutional clause that allows the president to top up the 120 elected members of parliament with 30 of his own choices. That may well prove unacceptable to his increasingly confident, vocal and numerous opponents. In a situation full of historic twists and ironies, the most bittersweet of all may be that President Mugabe's own greatest achievement could be his downfall. When he came to power in 1980 after the collapse of Ian Smith's rebel white regime, he instituted one of the best education systems in Africa (now in disarray). The under-35s who benefited are the ones suffering in the current crisis. Many of them were outside the town hall yesterday. Mabasa Mashiri, a father of four who works in the treasurer's department, takes home 8,000 Zimbabwe dollars a year. The dollar, once on parity with the pound, is now artificially high at just under 2p. "Everything has gone up except my wages. It has changed our way of living. I can't give the children pocket money any more. We used to have cereals and bacon and eggs for breakfast, but we can't afford that any more." Everyone agreed what had to be done about it. "The biggest tomato is rotten," said Cosmo from the housing department. "It rots the whole barrel. The old man is tired." "When you wear a shirt it gets dirty. You have to change it occasionally," said Louie the roadman. Many of the strikers were carrying copies of a new anti-government paper, the Daily News, which on Tuesday listed many of the 270 officials said to have been given farms that might have gone to the landless protesters. They included the speaker, the deputy speaker, the defence secretary, the secretary to the president and two state governors. Suffering Even Bornwell Chakaodza, the editor of the government-owned and faithful Herald, accepts that all this is having an effect. "We are talking about a party that has been in power for 20 years. Given the economic hardship people are suffering, there is a mood that is particularly anti-government, especially in the urban areas." This is a mood reflected only very warily in the Herald's columns. An editorial yesterday claimed the ruling party was fighting corruption and was being renewed in the current series of primaries, which have overturned several sitting members: "It has demonstrated its dy namism, its willingness to listen to the people's concerns and to make necessary changes." This view has not had much resonance in the five-hour petrol queues that built up last week, which often turned into impromptu political mini-rallies. The queues have eased a little in the past couple of days, but yesterday drivers needing diesel still had to wait nearly three hours and were then limited to five litres each. The national oil company (itself the subject of corruption allegations) has been forced to pay cash up front for its imports. At present, Zimbabwe is not earning enough overseas to pay the monthly petrol bill. This cannot wholly be blamed on homosexuals in the British cabinet, of ten the subject of tirades from Mr Mugabe. The situation will ease slightly in a few weeks when the year's tobacco sales kick in. This is one good reason to delay the election. However, tourism has, predictably, collapsed like a pit canary at the first whiff of international disfavour. The donor nations are standing aside. Relations with Britain are terrible and South Africa will not step in. Tobacco and gold, the basics of the Zimbabwean economy, are products with their own long term problems. There is no easy way out for Mr Mugabe. The old electoral arithmetic was that his supporters from the Shona tribe would outvote the minority Ndebele. But the new generation is too sophisticated for that. His supporters trust that votes from the countryside (counted fairly or otherwise) will pull the party through come election-time. But rural Zimbabwe depends heavily on money from family members working in towns. If Harare is feeling the chill, the villages of the heartland will catch their death. The whites, of course, are itching for Mr Mugabe's downfall. But it is Zimbabwe future, not Rhodesia past, that is making the position untenable. "There is one thing we can thank Mugabe for," said Trevor Ncube, the editor of the anti-government Independent. "He has united the country. White, black, Indian, coloured, Shona, Ndebele. There is a resolve across this land to bring about change." From freedom fighter to oppressor 1924 Born February 21 1963 Founds dominant movement for independence from Britain, Zimbabwe African National Union (Zanu), becoming secretary general 1964-74 Imprisoned by British as they attempt to check resentment at colonialism 1975 Escapes into Mozambique. The armed liberation struggle under Zimbabwe African National Liberation Army (Zanla), the armed wing of Zanu, begins to wear down Rhodesian regime. Within three years peace talks are held in London 1980 Zanu wins elections and Mugabe becomes first prime minister of independent Zimbabwe 1987 Made president. Opposition suppressed by ruthless security machine but growing economic problems, particularly over vexed question of land ownership by whites, begin to dog him 2000 Opposition wins shock victory in February referendum on draft constitution that would have given Mugabe greater powers. The worst defeat of his rule. Subsequent poll suggests 65% of Zimbabweans think he should step down

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
 Happy birthday to you, Philip Gould, on this your 50th! When Phil's party begins this evening with a spin aboard the millennium wheel, New Labour High Command will all be there, led by none other than Mr Tony himself. Indeed, it's a mark of how close he is to that least charlatan of focus groupies that, unable to attend his Sedgefield Labour party's AGM on Saturday, Mr T asked Philip to stand in for him! Philip found the perfect way to "entertain" his audience, with readings from his magnificent book, The Unfinished Revolution. As members drifted off, Philip tried to liven things up with the tale of a focus group that showed an unnamed MP - Mo, we imagine - as far more popular than expected. When he reported the grim results, Mr Tony replied: "Then refocus your focus group." Delightful. Judging his audience to perfection, Phil then joshed about how the Blairs' constituency house had all the old furniture from their Islington house, and was "such a throwback to the 80s". That went down brilliantly. Well, it would, in a County Durham crowd of ex- miners, wouldn't it? Many happy returns, Phil!

 Bad news on the Jonathan Aitken prayer front. With his friend Melvyn, you will recall, Jonathan has been praying for some Guardian colleagues but not for me. So I am planning to pray for him, that he will find it in his heart to pray for me. Unfortunately, it's been a busy day and I haven't had a moment to address God about this. Let's pray for better luck tomorrow.

 News arrives from Derbyshire of a major gig yesterday at the Palace Hotel in Buxton, at the prison governors' association conference. Headlining was Jack Straw, albeit at a distance. "It's a pleasure to speak to you today, even by videolink," is how the speech began (I have the text in front of me). "I'm told that I am now being projected on to a huge screen rather in the manner of a Rolling Stones stadium concert. I hope it's to your Satisfaction. (Pause.)" Pause? What, to allow the laughter to die down, you mean? Cancel the right to silence, if you must, Jack, and scrap trial by jury by all means. But please, no more jokes.

 Distressing to report, new VW press officer Kate Thomson is even harder than Wayne Bruce, and reclaimed my lime-green Beetle on Monday, despite the fact that I was too ill last week to drive it far. Even so, being strictly objective as always, I agree with my colleague Richard Adams (who drove it over the weekend), that it is an eye-catching and impressive car. With its two-litre engine and leather seats, at £15,000 it seems excellent value to us. (Is this enough for another week, or do we have to run the publicity shot as well?)

 After yesterday's hilarious joke about the German child who does not speak until his fourth birthday, I must clear up a confusion. Unless expressly stated, gags that appear under the Frank's Chuckle title are not Frank's own. They are far too funny for that (to give a flavour of Dobbo's efforts, we gather that when comparing himself to Shagger Norris at a recent party, he replied: "Oooh, I suppose you could say that I'm Whittington and he's Dick!"). They are Diary jokes told in the hope that they will delight Dobbo and keep his serotonin levels high enough to negate any need for psychotropic drugs. Thank you.

 Meanwhile, the first celebrity volunteers to pose in an Oooh You Amaze Me! T-shirt. It's Tom Robinson, who attends a photo shoot today (eerily, Tom's number one record, 2-4-6-8 Motorway, contains the couplet: "1, 5, 7, 3, Oooh you 'maze me!"). Cheques for T-shirts (£7.50 each, made out to Guardian Media Group) should be sent to the Diary, 119 Farringdon Rd, London, E1R 3ER. And stand by for sensational news about an addition to the Guardian website's mayoral section.

fields.headline: History's orchards
fields.standfirst: Witton-le-Wear, Co. Durham
fields.trailText: Field names on old maps often have meanings that are lost in the mists of time. Not so Plum Tree Field at Low Barns nature reserve, where a thicket of plum trees bestows an identity on the pasture. It's not hard to believe that they may have been there for several centuries, refugees from some long-lost orchard.
fields.body:
Field names on old maps often have meanings that are lost in the mists of time. Not so Plum Tree Field at Low Barns nature reserve, where a thicket of plum trees bestows an identity on the pasture. It's not hard to believe that they may have been there for several centuries, refugees from some long-lost orchard.

At the moment the trees provide visitors with the near-certainty of fine views of a pair of bullfinches that seem to treat them as their personal property. They were in residence again today, caught by early morning sunlight against a clear blue sky; a magnificent cock with glossy black head and dusky pink breast, and the more sober-hued hen. I watched as the cock tore off and chewed some of the swollen blossom buds - a sight to make an orchard owner fume, but here the bullfinches' predilection for fruit tree buds doesn't matter. Those flowers that escape their attention produce small, hard fruit, so sour that its taste lingers long after the initial shock of its bitterness. Within a week the tangle of plum branches and suckers will be laden with blossom - despite the bullfinches' attentions - and humming with bumblebees.

The reserve provides other near-certainties at this time of year. A furious cacophony of honking Canada and greylag geese on Marston Lake, contesting territory with the resident swans; carpets of scarlet catkins, whipped from poplar crowns by March winds; forests of Himalayan balsam seedlings germinating amongst the butterbur flowers along the riverbank.

The alder wood, more than two centuries old, is in a fine state of advanced decrepitude, shedding limbs and bark, providing perfect feeding and breeding conditions for woodland birds. A raised bank of soil left by the excavation of Marston Lake offers grandstand views of their activity in the alder canopy, where I watched a tree creeper working its way from tree to tree, beak full of tiny twigs. It's a near-certainty that somewhere down there, behind a peeling sheet of bark, its nest will be coming along nicely.

fields.headline: The word from on high
fields.standfirst:
Labour has its hands on too many levers

The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Like most governments, when this one sees a problem, it wants to solve it. That is a laudable ambition - but in its zeal to cure all ills, it is developing a nasty habit. It is succumbing to the temptation to answer every need with the remedy of central control, extending its micromanaging reach to health, education and almost the entire public sector.
fields.body:
Like most governments, when this one sees a problem, it wants to solve it. That is a laudable ambition - but in its zeal to cure all ills, it is developing a nasty habit. It is succumbing to the temptation to answer every need with the remedy of central control, extending its micromanaging reach to health, education and almost the entire public sector. Yesterday the health secretary, Alan Milburn, promised personally to sack any underperforming manager, sending in his own crack troops, if necessary. Mr Milburn had already angered senior NHS staff by suggesting they could not be trusted to spend wisely the extra £600m allocated to health in the Budget. Instead he would use special powers to "direct" the money himself. Local education authorities are to be similarly bypassed. New cash for education is to go directly to headteachers - missing out the LEAs altogether.

The result is a creeping power-grab. Strict caps remain on local authority spending, while the new breed of elected city mayors can look forward to only feeble powers. The railways complain that they are in a tighter Whitehall grip now than when they were state-owned. And the rest of the public services, from the local library to the ballet company, agree that they are under the strict, line-by-line control of "targets" set by the Treasury - 6,000 of them, according to a Liberal Democrat report. As one local government official sighs: "It's becoming Gosplan."

One can understand why the government wants to grab power to itself. It sees the public discontent at the state of the health service, knows that it will be judged on the issue at the next election, and cannot bear to leave its fate in the hands of what it regards as second-rate managers out in the sticks. Labour's motto seems to be: if you want the job done properly, do it yourself. (Mr Blair has clearly made that his own personal rule.) More deeply, it rightly feels that a national service like the NHS cannot tolerate such wild differences in quality. It is not right that an operation can be done well in one town, yet botched a hundred miles away. Fairness seems to demand a common standard for everyone, rather than privilege for those who happen to live in the right place.

Nevertheless, centralisation is a bad habit which needs to be checked. For one thing, as any corporate chief knows, it leaves those out in the field feeling powerless and passive - instead of innovating, they simply wait for orders from HQ. They are suddenly at the whim of targets set not by those at the front-line, but by politicians - with politicians' priorities. An NHS manager may know that, say, more hip replacement operations are needed in the area, yet still have to comply with an edict from London demanding a fall in heart-op waiting lists. Statistical targets are a blunt instrument: they cannot be sensitive to what is needed in a specific area at a specific time. Besides, it is not as if centralisation has not been tried already. The NHS has always been centrally run, yet disparities of service have existed from the start.

What has not been tried is full-blooded, democratically accountable local control, in health or education. A structure which allowed communities to decide their own level of spending - even raising more local tax if they need it - would represent a genuine departure for Britain's public services. The challenge then would be to keep provision roughly even across the country. Such a balance would be hard to achieve, most certainly. But it should not be impossible - and it would surely take us much closer to the devolved, empowered society Labour says it wants to create.

fields.headline: On message
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Sacrifice
fields.body:
Sacrifice

Concessions offered by Microsoft in its anti-trust case with the US government go beyond what would be likely to be imposed if the court decides in the government's favour, the Washington Post reported yesterday. It quoted an email from Microsoft chief executive Steve Ballmer to the firm's 30,000 employees as saying: "We believe we've put more on the table than the judicial process would ultimately provide, even if we lost the case.

"While we're very sure of our legal position and we're prepared to take it all the way on appeal, we've learned that discretion is the better part of valour, so we are working hard to resolve the case through settlement."

Wap gambit

In its effort to become the biggest pan-European e-tailer in games, Gameplay.com said it had signed a mobile-phone commerce deal with Carphone Warehouse . Gameplay will provide its products on wireless application protocol (Wap) phones sold by Carphone Warehouse. The retailer sells about 50,000 mobile phones weekly across Europe.

Split

Business software firm Baan said it intended to float "at least a percentage" of a new e-commerce customer relationship management subsidiary it is forming. "We don't know what form it will take. It may be with others. It could be on our own," said corporate treasurer Frans Goettsch. The move is intended to unlock perceived value within Baan and also employees with a more effective options-related incentive plan.

Power house

Consultancy PricewaterhouseCoopers will help 15 of the largest US utilities create an internet-based business-to-business market place expected to cut purchasing costs while providing the owners with a profit. The utilities expect PwC's efforts to lead a memorandum of understanding and the operation starting by year-end.

fields.headline: From refugees to political footballs
fields.standfirst:
In the last of a Guardian series on the experience of asylum seekers in Britain, we look at the bungled programmes and ulterior motives that lie behind the question of how they are treated. Today: the politicking

Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: In the last of a Guardian series on the experience of asylum seekers in Britain, we look at the bungled programmes and ulterior motives that lie behind the question of how they are treated.  Today: the politicking
fields.body:
One of the root causes of Britain's political crisis over asylum can be found in the decision in 1996 by Ann Widdecombe, who was then the immigration minister, to sign the contract to computerise the civil service system for sorting out genuine refugees from economic migrants.

The chaos of that bungled modernisation has led to a backlog of 103,000 asylum seekers who have been waiting, on average, more than a year for their cases to be resolved, and left a political legacy which Labour's private polling says stands only just behind the state of the national health service and Britain's schools in damaging the government's standing in the country.

The pollsters' focus groups have quickly confirmed the suspicion that when hostile newspapers and people in pubs talk about asylum it is because it is the new politically acceptable way - as Europe was before it - of talking about race and the suspicion of foreigners that lies beneath the surface of British life.

While few but the most hardened racists would now talk in public about the smell of their neighbour's curry, they are only too willing to talk about bogus asylum seeking beggars who milk our generosity to build palaces on the outskirts of the Romanian capital, Bucharest. Thus the apparent need to crack down on asylum seekers has become an unquestioned given of political life.

Grinding to a halt

Before the last election, Labour claimed the system was "grinding to a halt" when the backlog stood at only 60,000 unresolved cases. The Tories' last attempt to tighten the law on asylum, Labour said, was "a political attempt to play on fears about immigration".

Now Labour itself has struck a kind of historic compromise: acting liberal on race and the rights of established minor ity ethnic communities but talking tough on asylum seekers. The idea of an "anti-racist asylum policy" which Labour ministers once espoused now sounds like an anachronism.

Instead, next Monday will see a new asylum law come into effect which will replicate in Britain the German system of dispersal and vouchers instead of welfare benefits. In Germany, this has helped to cut asylum numbers from 450,000 applicants a year to around 90,000.

Meanwhile the Conservative shadow cabinet, with one political eye on local elections this May and the other on the many seaside marginals in the coming general election, seeks to exploit the new anti-asylum mood by demanding the immediate detention and deportation even of those who are fleeing the authoritarian Taliban regime of Afghanistan.

As Andrew Lansley, a former Conservative Central Office strategist and now a Conservative MP, once put it: "Asylum is an issue which plays particularly well in the tabloids and still has more potential to hurt."

The Tory local authorities of Westminster, Wandsworth and Kent have been instrumental in stirring this volatile political pot and played a leading role in establishing the claim that London and the south east had become so overburdened with asylum seekers that the compulsory national dispersal programme that starts next week is needed.

To this volatile mix is added the claim from the Immigration Service Union and Conservative politicians that over the last 10 years up to 60,000 asylum seekers have simply disappeared from official sight and are living illegally in Britain.

It is a claim which Home Office officials cannot contradict as they do not keep statistics for how many failed asylum seekers voluntarily leave Britain. They do know that the 7,000 each year they compulsorily deport are only a fraction of those who leave.

Meanwhile local government as a whole, which housed and welcomed 4,000 refugees from Kosovo last summer, has been struggling to find up to 40,000 bed spaces around the country so that the dispersal programme can be carried out. The Local Government Association itself, which has been locked in argument with Whitehall over who will foot the bill for supporting asylum seekers while their claims are processed, has not been above a little grandstanding of its own.

But many of the fears and emotions stirred by this political debate are based on a myth. It is now the conventional wisdom at Westminster that nearly all asylum seekers are regarded by Middle England swing voters as "bogus" or rather "abusive" as Jack Straw rightly prefers to call them.

Recognition rate

In actual fact the Home Office last year gave refugee status or exceptional leave to remain in Britain in 54% of the asylum cases they managed to consider in detail. That is to say most asylum seekers in 1999 were genuine. It is not a statistic that you will hear quoted very often by MPs of any political hue. The refugee welfare organisations argue that the official Home Office figures obscure the actual "recognition rate" and it is worth working through the breakdown.

In 1999, the year in which the wheels officially came off the asylum system in Britain, there were initial decisions given in 16,920 cases which were looked at in detail. Some 7,075 or 42% were given full refugee status and a further 2,110 or 12% were given exceptional leave to remain on compassionate grounds. The remaining 7,735 cases which were examined on their merits were refused.

This gives a "recognition rate" of 54% which implies that most asylum seekers are genuine and not abusive. The Home Office however quotes a "recognition rate" of 47% for 1999.

The Refugee Council argues this is because the Home Office includes the number of cases which are turned down either on "safe third country grounds" - that the asylum seeker passed through another country on the way to Britain - or on "non-compliance" grounds, such as not turning up to an asylum interview. Some 1,830 cases fell into the first category and a further 1,120 into the second.

Refugee welfare groups say in neither category does the Home Office decide the case by looking at whether the applicant faces a threat of persecution in their home country and that failing to turn up to interviews is not necessarily an indication that the application is illegal.

These calculations also fail to take account of asylum seekers whose cases are recognised on appeal. Between 10% and 20% of cases have succeeded on appeal. The appeal figures for 1999 are not yet available but they are likely to push the Home Office's "recognition rate" above 50%. Both arguments underline the fact that the official figures understate the proportion of asylum seekers whose individual plight is officially recognised.

Critics point out that the Kosovo crisis made 1999 an exceptional year which saw a record level of 71,160 new asylum applications. "The figures are higher than last year but so are the instances of human rights abuse, political persecution, internal conflict and turmoil raging around the world," said Nick Hardwick of the Refugee Council. "This period also contains a European war described as 'the greatest humanitarian disaster since the end of the second world war,' by Nato spokesman, Jamie Shea.

"The UK is not the only country to be receiving a higher number of asylum seekers and, according to the most recent figures available, 10 other European countries received more asylum seekers per head of population than the UK. In fact, the poorest countries in the world take the highest number of refugees, far exceeding the numbers received in Europe."

But these "exceptional years" are not as rare as might be imagined. The last time the "recognition rate" stood at over 50% was in 1993 when Bosnia blew up and the figure rose to 71% of asylum applications approved. The recognition rate in an average year is about 40%.

Mr Straw argues that life on vouchers worth £35 a week is bearable if the wait is no longer than six months. He justifies the compulsory dispersal and withdrawal of welfare benefits on the grounds that the genuine refugee will put up with the privations involved while the abusive will be deterred.

The asylum system is at last beginning to recover from Ann Widdecombe's bungled computerisation. For the first time last month more decisions were taken - 8,000 - than the number of new applications that were received - 6,100 - but at this rate it is going to be a lot longer than six months before the asylum caseworkers at Home Office offices in Croydon get through the backlog of 103,000 cases.

In the meantime, local government is arguing with Whitehall over who should put them up and look after them and who should pay the bills. When the Local Government Association tried last summer to put together a voluntary scheme to relieve the pressure on Dover, which saw some of the worst racial attacks, and London, the response was disappointing.

A voluntary scheme which has been operating in advance of next week's dispersal programme initially produced offers of only 4,000 of the 40,000 bed spaces that were needed.

Out of pocket

As the LGA put it earlier this month: "Local authorities have already taken on board almost 80,000 asylum seekers, including 1,500 via the LGA's voluntary dispersal scheme, which is fantastic.

"However, councils may not now be so willing to offer help as they continue to fear being out of pocket by millions. This can mean only one thing - either cutting back on frontline services like education and social services or hiking up council taxes which no council wants to do."

It is no idle threat. There is now a list of 27 local authorities doing the rounds in Whitehall who have told the Home Office's new national asylum support service that they should be exempted from taking any further asylum seekers.

Most are the London boroughs and the Kent councils who have loudly and repeatedly complained about being overburdened. But there are others on the list such as the Isle of Wight, Blackpool, and Northampton which are some distance from the overcrowded corner of south-east England.

Isle of Wight council says straightforwardly that it already has problems of homelessness and a shortage of accommodation. It decided to tell the government it could not take any asylum seekers "because we have our own problems".

Blackpool council leaders, angry at the way London boroughs and private firms have been placing asylum seekers in the Lancashire resort without telling them, protested last week to Jack Straw that they were using unfit properties as well as guest houses in Blackpool's main holiday area in breach of planning rules.

Northampton borough council simply says that it has already taken 2,000 asylum seekers - well above the threshold laid down in the formula for deciding how many asylum seekers each area should take under the dispersal programme.

What is common to many of the places outside London on this list is that they include some of the more marginal Labour and Liberal Democrat parliamentary seats and so could be counted as realistic prospects by the Tories in this May's local elections and, more importantly, in next year's general election.

Jack Straw is hopeful that his new asylum law will both massively reduce the flow of asylum seekers to Britain and tackle the backlog. He also hopes that it will remove this issue, with its potential to hurt Labour's election prospects, from the agenda. The word inside the Home Office is that it might work as long as there is not another asylum emergency on the scale of a Bosnia or a Kosovo.

Unfortunately for Mr Straw, all the signs are that one thing can be guaranteed about life in the 21st century - somewhere on the planet a war or an ecological disaster will leave millions homeless or facing persecution. Britain's asylum system is still in no state to cope.

fields.headline: Second sight
fields.standfirst: There are huge amounts of money to be made out of the internet boom - but the real profits may not lie where you first expect to find them
fields.trailText: There are huge amounts of money to be made out of the internet boom - but the real profits may not lie where you first expect to find them
fields.body:
The battle for power over the internet - of which the fortunes of Lastminute.com are but a tiny skirmish - can best be seen as a struggle between the centrifugal forces pushing power down to the individual and the centripetal forces - mainly involving corporations - that are trying to capture control of the centre.

Individual empowerment through the free exchange of information was the Magna Carta of the net in earlier days. Remember when commercial organisations trying to use the internet to sell things were subjected to instant spamming? Then commerce, inevitably, staked its claim.

If one had to put a date on it then it was probably when the successor to the Mosaic browser developed at the University of Illinois (and distributed free over the internet) was launched by Netscape, a company determined to make millions by giving its browser away free.

For all the hype, Britain's (corporate) internet boom has yet to celebrate its first birthday. Yet the flotation of Netscape, the first internet bubble stock, happened almost five years ago. (Yes, we are still that much behind the Americans.)

Netscape's market capitalisation surged in the first few hours of trading to $2.7bn, a milestone that had taken General Electric 43 years to achieve. At the time Netscape was losing $4.3m on six months' trading of $16.6m (rather a good performance compared with today's UK net start-ups).

Where is the money now being made? There have been two main beneficiaries. First, the builders of the infrastructure - the equivalent of the entrepreneurs who made money out of selling shovels during the gold rush. Cisco briefly ousted Microsoft last week as the most valuable company in the world in terms of market capitalisation - although hardly anyone outside the loop has heard of it.

One of the reasons the infrastructure companies have been successful is that they have built up strong near-monopolistic presences in areas where the barriers to new entrants are high. It's much easier to put up a new website selling to the consumer than to break into the markets for routers, servers and fibre optic networks.

The second area where money is being made is on the stock market in anticipation of the profits that may, or may not, to be made from selling goods and services to you and me. But, as of now, hardly any money is being made from selling things to the consumer.

So, either there will be a huge spending bonanza on the web at prices that will justify the absurdly inflated prices at which these companies are being valued - or valuations will tumble to reflect the fact that the centrifugal forces are winning. The consumer, not the producer, is king of the web.

As the world gradually becomes a single market for many consumer goods, it will become increasingly difficult for companies to make high margins from products unless they have a monopoly or a binding patent.

Investors are beginning to get wise to the fact that the huge marketing spend needed to establish a presence is very difficult to recoup from the low-margins offered by products sold on the net where consumers (or electronic agents acting on their behalf) are constantly scouring the web for cheaper options.

The concept behind Lastminute.com was, and is, a good one. It also has an importance disproportionate to its size in being an iconic flagship for UK web start-ups. Its problem is not that it isn't a good company, but that it is impossible for it to live up to the hype with which it readily acquiesced when it agreed to be floated at such a wild premium to its short-term potential. It is not easy for a business based in Mayfair to undercut airline bucket shops in Victoria and make a big profit from it. At least not until it establishes a global base (which Lastminute is working hard on).

But the real significance of all this is not that ecommerce corporations from Amazon to Egg, are finding it difficult to make any money, let alone serious profits, from online trading but that the web is being returned to its original ideals, albeit by a circuitous route. The founding mutuality of the web has metamorphosed into enforced mutuality. Companies are under pressure to give away, or sell at a loss, products they find difficult to sell at a decent profit on the web, however much they would like to.

It is not just email, browsers, calendars and online applications such as word processors and spreadsheets that companies are being forced to release for the comon weal. It is also a wealth of content. News, stock market prices, databases (on films, sport etc) and music that used to cost money are now free.

Only where companies have proprietary rights over products for which there are no immediately available substitutes (eg popular films) can charges be made to stick.

Even where the centripetal forces have been successful - like Amazon's amazing success in creating the world's biggest bookstore - they haven't been able to deliver the cream. Pioneers of e-selling, including Amazon, are facing an e-paradox: they won't make profits until they raise prices - but every time they try to do this, customers will click to a cheaper source.

There has never been a better time to be a consumer.

fields.headline: Immigration and Asylum Act 1999
fields.standfirst: Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Key measures from next Monday
fields.body:
Key measures from next Monday

 Most cases to be decided within six months by April 2001

 Vouchers worth £35 a week for an adult to replace welfare benefits. No change given

 Accommodation provided on no-choice basis around UK

 Fines of £2,000 per illegal passenger on lorry drivers coming into Britain

 Regulation of immigration advisers

 Increase in airline liaison officers abroad to curb numbers travelling to Britain on forged papers

 New legal framework for detention of asylum seekers

 Crackdown on marriage for immigration purposes

webTitle: Cut to the quick by childbirth article

fields.headline: Cut to the quick by childbirth article
fields.trailText: Kate Figes' polarisation of earth mother and hi-tech camps within childbirth is too simplistic (When push comes to shove, March 29). The re-emergence of community-based, midwifery-led care meant that I had excellent NHS ante-natal, labour and post-natal care.
fields.body:
Kate Figes' polarisation of earth mother and hi-tech camps within childbirth is too simplistic (When push comes to shove, March 29). The re-emergence of community-based, midwifery-led care meant that I had excellent NHS ante-natal, labour and post-natal care. I have undergone two positive birth experiences - in hospital - where my wishes have been respected and yes, I managed without any pain relief other than deep breathing. All this, while not being a wholemeal, homeopathic, kind of person and not attending National Childbirth Trust ante-natal classes.

Furthermore, while I agree that longer term post-natal support is desirable, the NCT post-natal group I joined fell very quickly into abeyance. As first time mothers, we started returning to work from around three months. Maybe that is the real problem.

J Evans
London joy.ian@talk21.com

 The NCT helped me to celebrate my pregnancy, birth and new daughter despite a rise in blood pressure, artificial rupture of membranes, constant monitoring, drip, episiotomy and Simpsons forceps.

The NCT (and its volunteers) provided vital support, reassurance and a listening ear when the reality of early parenthood (little sleep, sore bottoms, bulging breasts) kicked in. The NCT were there when the health professionals stated we were "normal" and left us to "get on with it". And every year, all over the country (and with forces based overseas), thousands of us attempt to pass on that support and aid to other new parents, irrespective of whether they had a drug-free waterbirth, an epidural, caesarean section or however those mothers delivered their children.

Helen Armfield (branch volunteer )
Hastings, East Sussex

 NCT's policy of explaining the well-documented and researched effects of drugs in labour is likely to be a better basis for choice than Kate Figes' unresearched statement that she "would have thought a little dope might just ease the shock of being born".

Heather Neil
NCT worker Newcastle upon Tyne

fields.headline: Topsy Turvy dot.con
fields.trailText: The Home Office has decided to call Oakington a reception centre for "protecting the refugees" (Six asylum seekers flee centre, March 29). They could call it a theme park, but it does not alter what the centre is or how it operates. Detainees are kept behind 12ft barbed wire fences and can only move around the centre under guard. It can hardly be a surprise that asylum seekers do their best to escape.

webTitle: Stand-up routines leave them rolling in the aisles

fields.headline: Stand-up routines leave them rolling in the aisles
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Now and again the Commons resembles a theatre on a seaside pier. There ought to be hoardings with merry pictures of favourite stars, such as John "Chubby" Prescott, Tony "Don't Mind Me, Missus!" Blair, and William "Yer Gotta Laugh" Hague.
fields.body:
Now and again the Commons resembles a theatre on a seaside pier. There ought to be hoardings with merry pictures of favourite stars, such as John "Chubby" Prescott, Tony "Don't Mind Me, Missus!" Blair, and William "Yer Gotta Laugh" Hague.

The poster would add "Do not come if easily offended," as if the punters are going to mutter, "Oh dear, I'm very easily offended, I'll go to Bernard Manning instead."

The trouble is that politicians have little sense of timing. Take Gordon Marsden, Labour MP for Blackpool South, who really ought to look the part in a floral jacket and flying helmet. He asked the prime minister about a petition to stop extortionate bank charges. He had taken 1m signatures to the trade secretary, Stephen Byers, whose rare appearances since the Rover disaster have caused much Tory sarcasm.

"Was 'e there?" asked a heckler from the audience (Sorry, from the opposition.)

"Yes," said Mr Marsden, "he was on the job!"

The speaker should have gone "boom boom" like Basil Brush, but so understated is Mr Marsden's manner that a listener might not even have realised it was a joke.

Next, Mr Hague returned to the subject of section 28 for an acrimonious exchange. The Tory leader wanted to know if ministers were saying that the government had decided to pack in the whole campaign against the clause.

Mr Blair said it was untrue that the abolition of section 28 would affect sex education in schools. There would, he implied, be no compulsory reading of politically correct books such as "Cherie Lives With Tony And Gordon" and similar filth.

Instead, there will be lessons about the importance of commitment: "When two rich lawyers become very friendly indeed and really, really like each other, and want to have babies together, there can be useful tax benefits if they get married," and other lessons for living in today's Britain.

The prime minister returned. Section 28 had nothing to do with sex education.

"The truth of the matter is that this campaign is based on people who don't want to come out...!" He paused. The audience, having warmed up now, realised that this was what comics call a "banker", a gag guaranteed a big laugh.

And it got one. Mr Hague chortled especially hard, so the prime minister can't have meant him.

What's so brilliant about Mr Blair's comedy persona is that, like Buster Keaton, he never lets on that he means to be funny. He keeps his poker face and continues as normal, so that the audience is kept in stitches.

"They don't want to come out and say they are prejudiced against gay people," he went on. But he hadn't finished. "Parents will carry on!" he said. "Being able to withdraw ...!" Double entendre followed single entendre. By now I was slumped helpless on the floor. Well, almost.

Paul Tyler tried to keep the bubble of mirth floating. This was an error. Some acts are just too good to follow.

Did the prime minister recall the time they had both contested the Beaconsfield byelection? "You were welcomed in the local paper : 'Barebacking barrister is Labour's choice'."

Sorry, my mistake. "Barebacking" is gay sex without a condom and condemned by section 28. What Mr Tyler said was "Benn-backing" - an even more serious offence.

Mr Tyler went on. And on. The jeers and hubbub got louder. Any comedian knows that's the most dreadful sound of all - it means he has lost the audience.

Betty Boothroyd stood up, ostensibly to support him. "This is a parliament, and members have to be heard in this parliament!

"Boring or not!" she finished. This is the terrible equivalent of what they shout to failed acts in comedy shows: "Taxi for Mr Tyler!"

fields.headline: A whinge
fields.trailText: There's nothing funnier than watching the Scots lose their rag (Sidelines, March 28) and Libby Brooks and others have been giving us all hours of fun as they foamed at the mouth at the prospect of Johnny Depp being cast as Robert Burns, their second greatest poet (McGonagall's pre-eminence is unassailable).
fields.body:
There's nothing funnier than watching the Scots lose their rag (Sidelines, March 28) and Libby Brooks and others have been giving us all hours of fun as they foamed at the mouth at the prospect of Johnny Depp being cast as Robert Burns, their second greatest poet (McGonagall's pre-eminence is unassailable). Many irate Scotchers have been asking why Ewan McGregor wasn't cast. I can answer that McGregor can't do it because he's currently shooting a movie in which he plays that well-known Scotsman, James Joyce, and will then go off to fulfil a contractual commitment to make two more Star Wars movies in which, if his accent in the first is to be believed, he will play an Englishman. Grow up, you whingeing gits. Johnny Depp is a world-class actor who'd get an audience for your second-string bard that he hasn't had before. You'd be lucky to have him.
Neil Pearson
London

fields.headline: Figure it out
fields.trailText: Frank Murphy states (Letters, March 29) that the population of Northern Ireland is 46.5% "Irish". I don't know where he gets this figure from as evidence on national identity is notoriously sketchy.
fields.body:
Frank Murphy states (Letters, March 29) that the population of Northern Ireland is 46.5% "Irish". I don't know where he gets this figure from as evidence on national identity is notoriously sketchy. In the 1989 attitudes survey, 60% of Catholics and 3% of Protestants identified themselves as Irish (the rest divided between British, Ulster and Northern Irish). If he means "Catholic" (not to be equated with Irish), 38.4% of the population identified themselves this way in the 1991 census. Even if we equally divide the 11% who said they had no religion, this would still only give a figure of 43-44% Catholic and 56-57% Protestant. At present there isn't an "equal split" in the community in terms of religion or national identity.
Alan Greer
University of the West of England

fields.headline: Heroin killed my son
fields.trailText: It would have been my son's 34th birthday today (March 29) but he died last month, a victim of heroin abuse. He was the only one of our five children to turn to drugs. None of us really knows why.
fields.body:
It would have been my son's 34th birthday today (March 29) but he died last month, a victim of heroin abuse. He was the only one of our five children to turn to drugs. None of us really knows why.

In the 60s I helped to set up the Cambridge Association for the Prevention of Addiction, one of the first education and support groups in the country for young people. I know we helped many to stop using soft drugs, because I saw the results, but we didn't do so well with those on hard drugs and several died.

It is easy for those who feel they are not affected by drugs simply to leave the problem to the police and the courts (Rebuff for drugs reform, March 29). The reality is that everyone is affected, either by the enormous number of crimes committed by those desperate to get the money for drugs, or through the taxes they pay to support police, customs, courts, probation service, prisons and the health service.

I am no "loony liberal", but I believe the time has come for the government to heed expert groups which advocate decriminalisation of some drugs and then go on to consider decriminalising all drugs. The billions saved in this unwinnable war could be channelled into better education and treatment and a licensing system to control supply, just as there is for alcohol. This may well be seen as an admission of defeat by a grieving parent. I prefer to see it as a recognition of reality. By refusing to debate what is, for many, unthinkable, we may be condemning future generations of young people to misery and death,
FM Gillespie
Cambridge

 We supposedly live in a free society yet we are not allowed to choose how we treat our own bodies. The government should be concentrating on the crime-related effects of drugs, such as theft. I can count the number of people I know that don't take some form of illegal drug on one mitten'd hand; does that mean that I live in a community of criminals? There is something morally wrong with a society that not only condones the use of certain drugs over others but also profits heavily from a tax on these drugs, whilst criminalising those who choose to smoke a simple herb with calming effects and few long-term health risks. Alcohol and nicotine are freely available for any early developed teenager to distribute to their less hormonally endowed friends, yet these drugs are now generally accepted to be among the most harmful. If this government were really worried about the messages they pass to our children, they would stop playing nursemaid to those who have no need of it. Now please excuse me, I'm off to skin-up.
Name and address supplied

 Meanwhile, back in the real world, the average age of a heroin addict in Amsterdam is over 30 and rising, while in British cities it is late teens and falling.
Alan Paterson
London alan.paterson@easynet.co.uk

 Alcohol and tobacco are not only legal, but tax brings in millions every year. Wouldn't the revenue from cannabis be similar? Has the Treasury been asked for its views?
Joseph Nicholas
London
josephn@globalnet.co.uk

 New Labour's polling must be telling them people who do dope are too stoned to vote. But I persuaded quite a few young people to vote Labour at the last election on the grounds they must be a bit more sensible about drugs than the Tories. Jack Straw's blinkered authoritarian attitude has lost Labour those votes for the next election and, finally, mine.
LR Armstrong
Portsmouth

fields.headline: Ian Dury's enduring appeal
fields.trailText: When I was a hack on the NME, the most modest, intelligent, sweetest and funniest person I interviewed was Ian Dury, at his bizarre riverside home in Hammersmith, complete with scraps of his poetry all over the walls.
fields.body:
When I was a hack on the NME, the most modest, intelligent, sweetest and funniest person I interviewed was Ian Dury, at his bizarre riverside home in Hammersmith, complete with scraps of his poetry all over the walls. Part Sid Field, part Gene Vincent, the self-styled "world famous raspberry ripple" was a true humanitarian. I play that interview once a year and I, like thousands, will miss "Old Durex" greatly. But, as he said so eloquently, "the jackpot is in the handle of a normal fruit machine!"
Paul Wellings
Colchester, Essex

 Matthew Engel says (March 29): "there has never been a lyricist quite like Gilbert". Yes there has, though, sadly, he died on Monday. "Cruising down carnality canal in my canoe, can I canoodle" is certainly a match for any modern major-general. Like WS, Ian Dury was the master of the memorable music-hall lyric.
Dr Richard Gough
Torrance, US rgough@earthlink.net

 Ian Dury was never ashamed of his disability or tried to hide it, but neither did he expect favour because of it. He stood up to be counted and never gave up fighting. His life was a shining example.
Dave Thomas
Wallasey, Merseyside

 When I was at the Royal College of Art, Ian Dury painted a work called I Don't Want To Set The World On Fire. He did just that. He was a smart geezer.
Anthony Clark
Barnard Castle, Co Durham
