fields.headline: EU rewards Balkans' loyalty with £1.3bn
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Balkan countries stand to get nearly $2bn (£1.3bn) to build or repair roads, bridges, power connections and other infrastructure as Europe rewards them for supporting last year's war in Kosovo.
fields.body:
Balkan countries stand to get nearly $2bn (£1.3bn) to build or repair roads, bridges, power connections and other infrastructure as Europe rewards them for supporting last year's war in Kosovo.

Pledges at a donor conference in Brussels yesterday are expected to meet initial targets for urgent work - and underline that Serbia will remain in the cold as long as the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, is in power.

The EU is making a determined effort to Europeanise the south-east corner of the continent - and answer US criticism that it is not doing enough. Funding was one of the things agreed under a "stability pact" adopted as the Kosovo conflict ended last June; peace, prosperity and stability were supposed to be fostered in the region, in part by integrating Balkan countries into the European mainstream.

"A year on from the [Natoair] strikes in Kosovo, we're starting to make progress," said Chris Patten, the EU's commissioner for external relations. "A ring of democracy is starting to take shape around Serbia."

But, he added: "While Milosevic is still in power the serious money stays in the vault." He described the Serb leader as "a brooding presence, locking Yugoslavia into a bleak winter".

Last week's EU summit in Lisbon mandated Mr Patten and Javier Solana, the union's foreign policy chief, to "get a grip" on a situation characterised by overlapping authority, underperforming agencies and poor delivery of help.

Mr Solana told representatives of 44 countries, mostly European but including the US, Canada, Japan and Korea, as well as 36 international organisations, that it was crucial to ensure that all refugees displaced by the Kosovo conflict returned home.

"Without that we will have a pact but no stability," Mr Solana said. "We are going to do our best. The people who run the European Union are ready to roll up their sleeves."

Pledges came thick and fast despite a rule that speakers address the conference for no more than seven minutes, with delegates joking that poorer countries needed more time to set out their needs.

The EU offered £325m for "quick start" projects. "What matters is whether the road to the next town is actually rebuilt, whether the bridge is being repaired, whether the electricity grid functions and clean water comes out of the tap," Mr Patten said.

Britain's minister for Europe, Keith Vaz, announced a £100m allocation - the Department of International Development's entire Balkan budget for the next three years - illustrating the familiar point that such pledges are often not new money.

In return for aid and investment under the stability pact, Albania, Bosnia, Bulgaria, Croatia, Macedonia and Romania have all committed themselves to democratic and economic reform and creating a stable environment that will attract private investment.

Representatives of Montenegro - considered likely to be Mr Milosevic's next target if it tries to break out of its federation with Serbia - and of the Serbian opposition, are also at the two-day conference.

"The real question for us [as donors] is how we actually spend the money," said James Wolfensohn, president of the World Bank.

More than 400 projects were proposed by the countries of the region to tackle the infrastructure with road- and bridge-building and to help reform economies, banking systems and tax systems. The projects were studied and whittled down to a manageable number.

Thirty-five quick-start projects are expected to cost about £670m. A further £430m will go to projects to help democracy, security and reform.

According to the World Bank, progress is most urgently needed in trade integration, anti-corruption measures and investment in regional infrastructure, to tie the region to the rest of Europe.

"This is just straight, simple, logical fact," Mr Wolfensohn said. "If you don't do it, there is nothing we can do to help."

fields.headline: A multitude of masts
fields.standfirst: Permission is granted too easily
fields.trailText: We see people using mobile phones on the street, in cars and buses, and we know the number of owners has now topped the 25m mark and is due to hit 40m within a few years. What we do not know is how many of the mobile phone masts which underpin this revolution have been erected in the last few years.
fields.body:
We see people using mobile phones on the street, in cars and buses, and we know the number of owners has now topped the 25m mark and is due to hit 40m within a few years. What we do not know is how many of the mobile phone masts which underpin this revolution have been erected in the last few years. The mobile phone operators are surprisingly coy. But estimates run in the region of 40,000 by the end of this year. And this is only the start. As cellular systems are phased out and replaced by the personal communications network (PCNs), more will be needed, as PCNs have a much reduced range. We face an extraordinary proliferation of masts over the next few years across our cities and countryside.

There are very good reasons why this should worry us. Firstly, there is concern about their impact on public health, in particular on the learning capacities of children. The environment committee of the Scottish Assembly yesterday published a report arguing that there was "reasonable doubt" about the health risks and advocated the adoption of the precautionary principle by siting masts well away from schools, nurseries, hospitals and residential areas. Secondly, campaigners, including the Council for the Protection of Rural England, are concerned at how these masts clutter up the countryside, and are often very intrusive because they have allegedly to be placed in prominent positions such as hilltops to be effective. Are such concerns likely to be taken seriously by this government? There is disturbing evidence that they will not be. Many masts do not require planning permission and where they do, planning guidance has been to give the mobile phone operators a green light; the system has been stacked in their favour. Local authorities have been instructed that their decisions must take account of the growth of the telecommunications industry, and must make allowance for the special technical needs of the apparatus such as height, or positioning. Also, planning authorities have a maximum of 28 days to reach a decision on applications which are supported by a barrage of highly technical information which they are often ill-equipped to assess. New Labour has rushed to facilitate the mobile phone operators' bid for dominance in the global telecommunications market, but that appears to have come at the cost of issues such as local accountability and the precautionary principle.

webTitle: He could not tell a lie

fields.headline: He could not tell a lie
fields.standfirst:
Which is why he is no longer a candidate

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: It is difficult to appear sleazier than Edward Kennedy, the seven-term satyr of the US senate. But Jack E Robinson III, a 39-year-old Massachusetts Republican and Mr Kennedy's would-be opponent in this November's elections, has managed it with ease. In launching his campaign last week, Mr Robinson decided that honesty is the best policy.
fields.body:
It is difficult to appear sleazier than Edward Kennedy, the seven-term satyr of the US senate. But Jack E Robinson III, a 39-year-old Massachusetts Republican and Mr Kennedy's would-be opponent in this November's elections, has managed it with ease. In launching his campaign last week, Mr Robinson decided that honesty is the best policy. "Candidates should be able to look their constituents in the eye and say, 'Yes, I believe that I deserve your trust'," he said. To prove his good intent, he published a lengthy account on his personal website of everything bad he had ever done. That is when the trouble started. Mr Robinson is now one of America's best-known politicians. But he is no longer the Republican senate candidate for Massachusetts.

Mr Robinson's investigative exposé of himself is ruthless, a brutal internet "Je m'accuse". Yes, he admits, he was once nicked for drink driving. And for speeding. Yes, police did find an illegal "martial arts implement" in his pocket. To be frank, there was a plagiarism charge over a book; and indeed, several other lawsuits. And there was "Jane", who twice alleged sexual harassment. The case was dropped but yes, sadly, it happened.

Such candour! And such a miscalculation! For were the Massachusetts citizenry impressed? Not a bit of it. The man must be a nut, or a fool, or both, to come clean like that, said astonished local politicians, fearing precedent. Mr Robinson, it was quickly claimed, had not told the whole story. One woman alleged other sexual misdemeanours by "Jack the Tongue". Muttering about "kamikaze politics", the state's Republican governor disowned him. And as fast as you can say Jack Robinson, Mr Robinson was out. Undaunted, he is running as an independent. But now we know how Bill Clinton got away with it. In politics, as in life, truth hurts. Better to keep mum. Anyway, digging up dirt is the media's job.

For more unvarnished, unpalatable truths, see:
 www.robinson2000.com

fields.headline: Talking dirty
fields.standfirst: Quotes of the week
fields.trailText: Quotes of the week.
fields.body:
"In Hollywood, cross-dressing liberates the subject to kiss or kill. And, while it conceals gender, it can, oddly, especially when women are dressing as men, enhance it... If nothing else, Swank's Oscar is an acknowledgement from a male-dominated, largely sexist industry that there is not now, nor has there ever been, such a thing as gender certainty. Expect Billy Crystal to host the next Oscar ceremony in a Versace ballgown and, possibly, a tiara"

Neil Norman on the significance of Hilary Swank's Oscar for the cross-dressing film Boys Don't Cry, Evening Standard.

"Germaine Greer sneers and purports to pity women who wear high heels, pluck their eyebrows, try to look younger or even consider face-lifts. She, of course, is muscly, greying and scrawny with a skin like leather. I suspect this is because she's fundamentally unhappy and doesn't like herself very much"

Lynda Lee-Potter urges women to make an effort with their appearance, Daily Mail.

"Raising sons, I've become aware of the tragedy of what happens to men. You see these little boys who start off so feeling and empathetic, and by the time they're 10 they're told they have to 'fight' their way through disappointment. It doesn't seem to be socially acceptable for men to whine to their men friends"

Susan Sarandon, Aura.

"Sadie gets more jealous than I do. She says the only kiss she was happy seeing me do was with Stephen Fry, when I played his lover, Bosie, in Wilde"

Jude Law on how he and Sadie Frost, his wife feel about each others' love scenes, Cosmopolitan.

"When you're single and pregnant the first question is always 'So who's the father?' Women whisper it, looking concerned, while men leer it, nudging and winking"

Newsreader Kirsty Lang on being an SMC, Single Mother by Choice, Times.

"We Chest Can't Wait, tomorrow's going to be the bust day of the year. It's the countdown we have all been waiting for - only this one ends at TWO"

Headline writers get far too excited about National Cleavage Day, Sun.

fields.headline: Home truths
fields.standfirst: This week Tony Blair launched his notion of New Patriotism, but why have so few female voices been involved in the debate?  Yvonne Roberts  on how women's participation has been edited out of the saga of nationalism
fields.trailText: This week Tony Blair launched his notion of New Patriotism, but why have so few female voices been involved in the debate?  Yvonne Roberts  on how women's participation has been edited out of the saga of nationalism
fields.body:
'As a woman," said the writer, Virginia Woolf, "I have no country." A view which would appear to exclude the female half of the population from the current preoccupation: what does it mean to be British? English? a nationalist in the 21st century in the UK?

John Major's favourite image of Englishness is Orwell's description of "Old maids biking to holy communion through the mists of an autumn morning". It is safe, undeniably white and nostalgic. Given the sparsity of old maids (or, for that matter, communicants), it is, of course, also hopelessly outdated and doesn't do much to raise the patriotic pulse of the under-25s.

Recently, a stream of male commentators, among them Jeremy Paxman, Darcus Howe, and Simon Heffer, have tackled the question of who precisely we are, often retreating into a list of idiosyncratic habits.

We've had the pundits - now, it's the politicians' turn. On Tuesday, Tony Blair launched his notion of New Patriotism. He defined the British identity as founded on, "Work... strong communities... fair play, rights and responsibilities..."

This could, of course, apply to almost any country in the EC, but no matter. Blair is to be followed on the same subject by Blunkett, Jack Straw and others. Gordon Brown has also been working to wrench back nationalism from its nasty right wing connotations and place it on a Third Way plinth.

Polling has apparently told Brown that we are pluralist, as much committed to Europe as to Empire. We can cope with devolution and we don't need the traditional props of patriotism - war, and the terminal challenge of dying for our country - to feel as one. According to Gordon Brown, we are "a nation in living colour".

Part of the flag waving, of course, is because New Labour is manoeuvring the tugboat UK closer to Europe. Less easy to explain is why there have been so few female voices added to the debate, whether from right, left or centre; black, white or brown.

For decades, women voted to keep the Conservatives in power, not least because of their traditional bulldog patriotism. Where are those voices now? And where is their opposition?

Next month, Yasmin Alibhai-Brown, a Ugandan-Asian who has lived in Britain for over 25 years, publishes Who Do We Think We Are? Imagining the New Britain. The book exposes the casual racism exercised by so-called liberals; argues passionately for inclusiveness; and points out that before the differences between tribes can be bridged, "First... we must know ourselves." When it comes to women, however, that is easier said than done.

One reason why the saga of nationalism has been so dominated by male voices is that women's participation has been heavily edited out. Wendy Webster, senior lecturer at the University of Central Lancashire, is researching a book on how women have attempted to incorporate themselves into stories of nationhood.

"History," she points out, "was written through the lives of the famous." In the 1901 Dictionary of National Biography, for instance, only 3% of those mentioned were female.

Obituaries from the newspaper of record, The Times, reveal a similar pattern. Amy Bradford was considered a true patriot because three of her four sons died in the first world war. In her obituary in the 1950s, only one sentence was allotted to her, the rest was about her boys. "She was excluded from her own life," says Webster.

Women, of course, were also excluded from issues of the flag - war, trade, imperial expansion - because they were deemed men's business. However, females had their symbolic value - for example, as maidens and mothers. Australia was allegorised as "a passive pliant virgin awaiting consummation".

In her book, Imagining Home, a riveting study of gender, race and national identity, Webster describes how, as the empire declined, so maternal symbolism grew more racially poisonous. In 1947, for instance, Eva Hubback urged (white) women to have more children for fear that inferior races might fill the population gap.

The mythology of empire was reworked as its size shrank; it became more about the sanctity of the home, the domesticated life. Colonial women were often portrayed as "plucky little heroines", fighting off the savagery of inferior black men. In Coronation year, two British women fought off a Mau-Mau attack in Kenya. They were hailed in the press as "the two bravest women in Africa".

The potent mix of protecting home, hearth and womanhood, was again employed to redefine British patriotism by Enoch Powell in his infamous 1968 "rivers of blood" speech. Powell referred to "ordinary English people" particularly - symbolised by an elderly white woman whose sons had died patriotically in the war. He claimed her "quiet street" had been turned into a place of "noise and confusion" when "the immigrants moved in".

"The story of imperial national identity had been a story of white masculinity signifying power... and Britain's supremacy in the world. Powell's... speech reversed this imagery," Webster writes. "The story of nations he tells is about... vulnerability in an English street, and it has at its centre the figure of a white woman."

Twenty-first century woman is, perhaps, too diverse, too contradictory to lend herself easily to national symbolism. She is in the home and outside it; autonomous and dependent; as likely to be at the battle front as waiting for the Falkland boys to return. Thatcher resolved some of these contradictions by becoming an imperial drag act; a bellicose man in Britannia's gear, maternally concerned for our boys as she put them in the firing line. But, please God, she was unique.

The historian Linda Colley, the only female advisor to the government's pontifications on the new nationalism, offers perhaps a more internationalist, potentially less racist, option. Aspirations to a decent and inclusive notion of citizenship, she argues, are less dangerous than espousals of mythical superior national characteristics.

Our preoccupation with empire, she points out, has not only fed our racism, it has distracted us from the battle to win basic, written citizen's rights - a battle of particular importance for women still burdened, for instance, by the lack of equal pay. The French Revolution promised liberty, equality, fraternity. We require something similar.

Feminist historians have been criticised for their parochialism and their westernised perspective. It's interesting, therefore, that as the men in the red, white and blue corner go into a huddle to decide who they really are (an issue not unconnected to the alleged crisis in masculine identity), the female historians are stepping out of the ring, to look beyond national borders. In June, for instance, the Women's History Network is organising a conference to examine Women, Nations and Identity.

The historian Catharine Hall has referred to "blind eyes turned to the past". On Tuesday, Blair reverted briefly to the vocabulary of empire. He linked our alleged sense of fair play to our "unique history". But that is a deception. Many of the features of traditional nationalism have been moulded from the most shameful actions - unchanged by New Labour's face-lift or sticking the word, "new" in front of patriotism. Look at the ugly nationalism rampant in the treatment of refugees.

I, for one, am not much bothered about who we say we are as a nation. Rhetoric and symbolism come cheap. Let us be judged by how we behave.

fields.headline: House fire kills three children
fields.trailText: A discarded match or cigarette was the cause of a fire at a maisonette in Essex which yesterday left three children dead and two others from the same family severely burned, the fire service said.
fields.body:
A discarded match or cigarette was the cause of a fire at a maisonette in Essex which yesterday left three children dead and two others from the same family severely burned, the fire service said.

The children's mother escaped by clambering along guttering into a neighbour's window to raise the alarm, but when firefighters arrived minutes later the blaze was too fierce to save the children, according to the fire service.

The three were confirmed dead after they were pulled by firefighters from the family's maisonette in Brentwood, Essex.

Two other children were revived by paramedics. An 11-year-old girl was taken to Guy's hospital, London, and a boy, thought to be aged 13, was taken to Great Ormond Street hospital. Their 32-year-old mother was being treated at Basildon hospital.

It was confirmed later that the maisonette was fitted with a smoke alarm, and an investigation was under way to determine whether it was working at the time.

Station commander Martin Powell said that the fire was "raging" when the crews arrived. "Flames were shooting and punching out of the ground floor. The front of the premises was untouched but we believe that materials flashed over because it was so intense and engulfed the whole room," he said.

"Toxic gases would have put the children to sleep. They would have gone to sleep and not woken up.

"The children were in the upstairs rooms. They may have woken initially in certain rooms and moved into other rooms before they were overcome. The ground floor was heavily involved in fire and the first floor was heavily involved in smoke," he added.

Divisional officer Barry Cable, one of the first firefighters on the scene, described arriving to "absolute chaos" with flames billowing from the maisonette's ground floor window.

fields.headline: Schoolboy dies in bath accident
fields.trailText: A Northamptonshire schoolboy died after a radio fell into the water while he was taking a bath, it emerged yesterday. Stephen Williamson, 12, of Old Stratford, was taken to Milton Keynes general hospital on Friday but died later.
fields.body:
A Northamptonshire schoolboy died after a radio fell into the water while he was taking a bath, it emerged yesterday. Stephen Williamson, 12, of Old Stratford, was taken to Milton Keynes general hospital on Friday but died later.

An inquest was opened and adjourned at the hospital yesterday, a spokesman for Two Shires ambulance service said.

At Sponne school, Towcester, Northamptonshire, where Stephen was a pupil, a minute's silence was observed during assembly on Monday. Ian Brown, the headmaster, said pupils were given bereavement counselling by staff.

Roger Vincent, of the Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents, said: "Although this is an extremely rare accident, probably about one person each year dies in the UK as a result of an accident involving electricity and water in the bathroom.

"It is a reminder to everyone, particularly teenagers, of how serious this can be.

"There is a temptation, particularly for young people, to run extension leads into the bathroom, but we would urge them not to."

A pre-Raphaelite picture given to a young woman by the artist LS Lowry - and said to provide a poignant insight into the disappointments of his life - is expected to make £500,000 when it is auctioned at Christie's.

Lowry - celebrated for his "matchstick men" paintings - gave Pandora (pictured left), a pastel by Dante Gabriel Rossetti, to Carol Ann Lowry, a young art student whom he befriended in the 1960s.

Pandora is a portrait of Jane Morris, the beautiful wife of Rossetti's friend William Morris, with whom Rossetti fell hopelessly in love after the death of his wife Lizzie Siddal.

Lowry formed a pre-Raphaelite society in 1966, with a handful of art lovers, to celebrate the work of the group of Victorian painters. A condition of membership was the ownership of a pre-Raphaelite work.

The painter, a bachelor, obtained the portrait in exchange for one of his own pictures in 1968 and gave it to Carol, who was no relation, so that she could join the society. Carol later became Lowry's heir and hung the picture in her bedroom for many years.

The society has not met since Lowry died in 1976. A museum dedicated to his work opened last year in his native Salford.

fields.headline: Kidney plea by lottery winner
fields.trailText: A patient suffering from kidney disease who won more than £4m on the national lottery said yesterday he would swap his windfall for a new kidney.
fields.body:
A patient suffering from kidney disease who won more than £4m on the national lottery said yesterday he would swap his windfall for a new kidney.

Mick Taylor, 26, from Halifax, West Yorkshire, has suffered from kidney failure since he was 11 and has had two failed kidney transplants. He now has renal dialysis three times a week at St Luke's hospital, Huddersfield.

The first transplant, which he had at the age of 13, lasted only a year. His second, at 21, lasted for three-and-a-half years.

"I would exchange my millions for a new kidney. I was more excited when I got my transplant than when I won this money."

Doctors have told him there is a good chance that a third transplant could last longer.

He shared Saturday's jackpot with two others, and has decided to donate part of his new fortune to the hospitals where he is treated.

"It is important to me to be able to thank the hospitals that have helped me. I will be making donations to St Luke's and to the paediatric renal unit at St James's hospital in Leeds."

Mr Taylor, a former cafe manager, said his illness had not stopped him leading as normal a life as possible. "I play golf and snooker. It does not restrict me."

Neither did it stop him from drinking alcohol. He had already had a party for his friends and family to celebrate.

webTitle: Demands of people threaten 25 bird areas

fields.headline: Demands of people threaten 25 bird areas
fields.trailText:
Twenty-five of Britain's most important bird areas are threatened by intensive farming, new housing and industrial estates, pollution or rises in sea level, the Royal Society for
 the Protection of Birds said yesterday.
fields.body:
Twenty-five of Britain's most important bird areas are threatened by intensive farming, new housing and industrial estates, pollution or rises in sea level, the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds said yesterday.

Overgrazing and heavy pes ticide use endangered vital breeding and wintering habitats throughout Europe with as many as one in three of the continent's 515 bird species suffering serious declines because of heavily subsidised farming methods, it said.

Graham Wynne, its chief executive, said: "The crisis in UK farming is accompanied by a crisis for Europe's wildlife. Both have the same cause - a system of farming subsidies that work for neither farmers nor the environment."

The society has called for further big cuts in production subsidies under the EU's common agricultural policy and their replacement by green grants to encourage conservation of habitats, smaller herds of cattle and deer and flocks of sheep, better animal welfare, and preservation of hedgerows and dry stone walls.

Mr Wynne said: "Across the continent, farming activities take place in nearly two-thirds of all the important bird areas, and many of these sites owe their importance for conservation, and their scenic beauty, to non-intensive agriculture."

He appealed for Tony Blair and farmers' leaders who meet today to discuss the future of farming to "look beyond short term political expediency and see the positive role that agriculture can play in preserving wildlife and the environment, as well as creating a brighter future for farmers".

The RSPB believes 25 out of 287 important sites in Britain are under serious threat. Intensive farming is a prime cause in areas such as the Breckland heaths and Thetford forest in East Anglia, home of stone curlews, nightjars and woodlarks, and Morecambe bay, Lancashire, where the overgrazing of the saltmarsh may affect breeding populations of the lesser black-backed gull, herring gull, and sandwich tern and wintering flocks of pintails, oystercatchers, grey plovers, knot, sanderling, curlews, red shanks and turnstones. The north Pennine moors and Severn estuary are also affected.

Farming methods are also causing problems along Lough Foyle and the River Foyle in Northern Ireland, where wintering whooper swans, light-bellied brent geese and bar-tailed godwits are at risk. In Scotland the Cairngorms, Caithness lochs, the forest of Clunie and the peatlands in Caithness and Sutherland are said to be overgrazed with birds affected including golden eagles, ospreys, capercaillies, several types of geese, hen harriers and short-eared owls.

The RSPB is part of the BirdLife International alliance which yesterday published an inventory of 3,619 important bird areas in 51 European countries. This concluded 93% were threatened to some degree.

fields.headline: Airborne tomato clips duke
fields.trailText: A mysterious tomato thrower who almost managed to knock off the Duke of Edinburgh's straw hat yesterday overshadowed perhaps the warmest welcome of the Queen's two-week tour of Australia.
fields.body:
A mysterious tomato thrower who almost managed to knock off the Duke of Edinburgh's straw hat yesterday overshadowed perhaps the warmest welcome of the Queen's two-week tour of Australia.

The tomato clipped the duke's hat as thousands cheered the royal party at the City Park in Launceston, Tasmania's second city.

The Queen apparently did not notice and carried on chatting to well-wishers and accepting flowers. But the duke motioned security officers to a tree from which he thought the tomato had been thrown, though no culprits were found. Earlier police spotted rowdy teenagers around the tree and one officer described the incident as most likely to have been "tomfoolery".

In Alice Springs, the next destination on the tour, police detonated two home-made bombs believed to have been made by children. Police said the "rudimentary devices" were made from soda siphons and had been planted in the grounds of the police station.

webTitle: Government to investigate claims by 'sheep dip victims'

fields.headline: Government to investigate claims by 'sheep dip victims'
fields.trailText: More than 1,000 seriously ill people who blame their condition on being exposed to sheep dip are to have their claims properly investigated by the government for the first time.
fields.body:
More than 1,000 seriously ill people who blame their condition on being exposed to sheep dip are to have their claims properly investigated by the government for the first time.

Among those who it is believed have been badly affected by the organophosphates in sheep dip are 25 children who have learning difficulties and physical abnormalities.

In some cases, scientists believe their illnesses were caused because their mothers were exposed to sheep dip during pregnancy, damaging the foetus in the first 12 weeks of pregnancy. On small family farms women regularly help husbands to dip the sheep.

A campaign to get injuries caused by sheep dip investigated has long been resisted by the Ministry of Agriculture, but Lady Hayman, the junior agricultural minister, said it was imperative the issue was properly researched.

At a conference on the topic convened by the ministry yesterday, she said: "It is essential that we research more widely, and listen more broadly than to official advisers. We must be transparent in investigating this most difficult of issues."

In the wake of the BSE crisis the ministry was reluctant to investigate organophosphates too closely because officials feared they would be blamed if injuries could be proved. For some years it was compulsory to dip sheep even though the ministry knew that organo-phosphates were dangerous to health.

The government feared it could be liable to damages if injuries could be proved. A number of people who claim to be victims are already planning to sue.

Tony Fletcher, from the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, is expected to take a year to investigate 1,000 cases amassed by voluntary bodies. Most of those involved are far too ill to work.

He said: "We want to see if there are similarities in their stories, and whether sheep dip is really the cause. Much of the evidence is subjective but with so many cases it will be possible to check whether there are patterns. Many of the people involved will also be properly clinically examined for the first time."

Elizabeth Sigmund, who runs an organisation called OP Information Network, has compiled a list of 800 victims.

Among them are 25 children. She said: "This is a tragic situation. Their lives were blighted in the womb. They cannot remember things, they do not have normal speech, yet we have been unable to get proper scientific investigation of the problem"

Farmers were obliged to dip sheep to protect them against scab. They were advised to wear protective clothing, but the conference was told that the dip contained chemicals which attacked the rubber in gloves making them porous. The effect was to render the protective clothing useless.

Although it has been known for years that high level exposure to sheep dip damaged the nervous system, the controversy has been about recurrent low level exposure to chemicals.

Farmers often become ill with "dippers' flu" for weeks after the sheep dip season. New research projects will look at whether this and other exposure has long term effects.

webTitle: ITV news in Scotland hit by strike

fields.headline: ITV news in Scotland hit by strike
fields.trailText: ITV news bulletins were in disarray in Scotland yesterday after journalists staged the first in a series of one-day strikes over pay cuts and compulsory redundancies.
fields.body:
ITV news bulletins were in disarray in Scotland yesterday after journalists staged the first in a series of one-day strikes over pay cuts and compulsory redundancies.

Members of the National Union of Journalists and the broadcasting union Bectu took the action after being told more than 160 staff at the Scottish Media Group face wage cuts or freezes.

Scotland's main ITV news bulletins - Scotland Today and Grampian Tonight - were drastically shortened and presented by stand-ins.

The action comes as SMG has revealed record profits and prepares to bid for the new ITV operating franchises. SMG won the Scottish franchise with a token bid, but it is now preparing a more realistic offer as other companies eye the market.

fields.headline: Stepmother in death plot jailed
fields.standfirst: Woman driven by jealousy gets nine years for trying to hire circus clown to murder her stepson
fields.trailText: A woman who tried to hire a part-time circus clown to murder her stepson was jailed for nine years yesterday for plotting to murder him and his wife.
fields.body:
A woman who tried to hire a part-time circus clown to murder her stepson was jailed for nine years yesterday for plotting to murder him and his wife.

Sylvia Paterson, 54, was consumed by jealousy of her stepson's wealth, Manchester crown court was told. She and her business partner John Holmes, 43 - also jailed for nine years - plotted to murder Paul Paterson and his wife Sarah on their wedding anniversary in April last year.

They hired petty criminal Paul Thorlsog, who also worked as a circus clown called Banjo, to carry out the contract killing, but he contacted police.

Sentencing them after a seven week trial, the judge, Sir Rhys Davies, said Sylvia Paterson was the driving force behind the plot .

"It is clear from what has transpired in this court that of the two of you, Sylvia Paterson, you are the stronger character and probably the driving force," he said. "You John Holmes, wealthy as you are, possessed of a certain charm you may be, but you lack judgment."

Undercover police officers taped Banjo's incriminating conversations with John Holmes. He was offered a total of £40,000 to kill the couple.

The court heard that Sylvia Paterson was "not the sort of person to go around wanting to kill people".

A partner in her own property firm, she drove a Mercedes with the registration plate CLA 55Y - she had planned to pay for the murders by selling the plate.

The defence claimed she had merely asked Thorlsog to carry out surveillance on her husband Kenneth, 77, whom she suspected was having an affair. She had paid Banjo a total of £1,150 for his work.

But she bitterly resented the wealth of her stepson and his wife - whom she dubbed greedy.

She was angry that her husband had transferred his controlling interest in the family metal business to his son without telling her. The relationship between stepson and stepmother became frosty. She blamed Mr Paterson for the deterioration in her marriage.

She believed that if the murder plot had been successful, the controlling share in the family metal business would transfer back to her husband and she would ultimately benefit.

Holmes was a social climber educated at Gordonstoun and owned a dry cleaning business. He boasted that he was worth up to £3m.

He claimed Banjo had entrapped him in to the murder plot and said he began behaving like James Bond. Holmes claimed Banjo began hanging around his business dressed in a cowboy outfit or a clown's red nose.

He said he had been taken in by Banjo, who had been kind to him while they were in jail in Merseyside in 1998, after he was convicted of indecently assaulting a 16-year-old waitress at a New Year's Eve party.

Banjo had boasted of serving with the SAS and appearing as a stunt man in a James Bond film.

In reality he had been thrown out of the army and occasionally joined a travelling circus as Banjo the clown in between prison terms for petty crimes.

Paul and Sarah Paterson said in a joint statement: "We are very relieved that this is now finally over - the last year has been very difficult for us and our family. We knew nothing of the plot to kill us until the police came to inform us. We can now look forward to returning to a normal family life."

fields.headline: Marconi invests £40m in university
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Marconi, the internet and telecoms equipment group, is to invest £40m in a new research centre at Cambridge University to rival the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's multimedia lab in the US.
fields.body:
Marconi, the internet and telecoms equipment group, is to invest £40m in a new research centre at Cambridge University to rival the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's multimedia lab in the US.

The six-year programme, to be announced today, is the largest ever corporate funding programme at Cambridge and is believed to be the biggest business collaboration with any UK university.

The communications research centre, to be based at the university's technology park in west Cambridge, is designed to match MIT's role in spearheading new internet-based technologies and providing the foundations for high growth, cutting-edge companies.

"If the US is in the foothills of the e-commerce revolution, Britain is on the path leading there and the rest of Europe is still to get off the boat," one insider said. "This new centre is designed to provide intensive hothouse research and help Britain to challenge the American leadership of the global e-revolution."

Lord Simpson, Marconi's chief executive, said the project was a response to Tony Blair's call for Britain to lead the e-commerce revolution. "We recognise that an unequivocal commitment to research is essential if Britain is to maintain its strong position in the knowledge economy," he said.

The deal includes £10m from the company to build research facilities at the Cambridge site, which is at the heart of the development of "silicon fen". Construction is due to be completed by 2002.

Marconi will provide £18m to fund the university's research programme, including around 200 scientists, and £12m for a laboratory staffed by a further 200 of its own researchers.

The group, which is funding a Marconi chair at the university, makes internet and telecoms switching equipment and broadband optical networks. It hopes the centre will inspire new products.

Among the goals set for the centre are the development of secure networks, resistant to hackers, and wap mobile phones, which can download film and music as well as high-speed data.

Other corporate investors in Cambridge include BP-Amoco, Unilever, Zeneca, Rolls-Royce, AT&T and Microsoft.

webTitle: Royal Society accused in row over origins of HIV

fields.headline: Royal Society accused in row over origins of HIV
fields.standfirst: Conference put off 'after pressure from vaccine theory opponents'
fields.trailText: The Royal Society, Britain's most prestigious scientific body, was accused yesterday of bowing to pressure from opponents of a controversial theory of the origin of the HIV virus after it said it was postponing a conference called to debate the issue.
fields.body:
The Royal Society, Britain's most prestigious scientific body, was accused yesterday of bowing to pressure from opponents of a controversial theory of the origin of the HIV virus after it said it was postponing a conference called to debate the issue.

One of the leading advocates of the theory, which holds that HIV was spread accidentally from chimps to man by western doctors testing an experimental polio vaccine in the Belgian Congo in the 1950s, said yesterday that the society was trying to give the idea's opponents more time to organise a counter-attack.

Ed Hooper, whose book, The River, ignited a ferocious dispute among the HIV and Aids research community worldwide, said: "I see this as an attempt by certain members of the scientific community to load the dice in their favour with regard to the origins debate, and one has to ask why they feel the need to do that."

One biologist who reviewed the book called it "the theory to beat".

In the US, researchers who have devoted their careers to meticulous research into more conventional theories of the origins of Aids have scorned The River and refused to attend the conference. One US scientist compared the Royal Society event to a discussion among astrophysicists of whether the moon was made of green cheese.

One of the organisers of the conference, Robin Weiss, professor of virology at London's University College, denied that the delay in holding the conference - originally to be held in May, now rescheduled for autumn - had anything to do with pressure from opponents of the theory.

"I think that's risible. It's nothing to do with marshalling a defence."

The postponement comes just three weeks after the sudden death from a malaria-induced haemorrhage of the leading scientific supporter of the polio vaccine theory, Bill Hamilton, one of the world's leading evolutionary biologists.

Professor Hamilton had contracted malaria a few days earlier as he left the Congo, where he had been gathering evidence in support of the polio thesis.

The May conference was his idea. His family is understood to have written to the Royal Society, asking that it go ahead as plannned.

HIV, the virus which causes Aids, is now accepted to have spread to humans from apes, perhaps chimpanzees

Most researchers support a version of the "cut hunter" theory, which supposes that a hunter in Africa - where apes are sometimes eaten - was infected by ape blood while slaughtering an animal.

The polio vaccine theory, backed up in The River by nine years of research, 600 interviews and the study of thousands of articles, suggests that HIV was spread to humans by well-meaning western doctors in a tragic accident when the kidneys of infected chimps were used to manufacture an orally-administered polio vaccine.

webTitle: Search to begin again for bodies of the disappeared

fields.headline: Search to begin again for bodies of the disappeared
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Police in the Irish republic are to resume digging for the remains of six of the so-called disappeared - Roman Catholics who were abducted, murdered and buried up to 30 years ago by the IRA - after the terrorists again attempted to pinpoint their bodies.
fields.body:
Police in the Irish republic are to resume digging for the remains of six of the so-called disappeared - Roman Catholics who were abducted, murdered and buried up to 30 years ago by the IRA - after the terrorists again attempted to pinpoint their bodies.

Last year the IRA tried to turn the page on one of the darkest episodes of the troubles by passing details of nine graves to the Irish authorities.

Police found three bodies, and their families were able to re-inter them, but they failed to find the others, despite an operation lasting three months. The digs were abandoned last July.

IRA terrorists are understood to have returned to the burial sites and passed fresh information through priests to the independent commission for the location of victims' remains.

John Wilson, its chairman, said the searches, to begin in two months, would be the last attempt to find the bodies.

Seamus McKendry, whose mother-in-law Jean McConville, 37, was killed in 1972 after she helped a dying British soldier, said last night: "I believe we will find them this time."

fields.headline: Collins sues tour horn players
fields.trailText: Phil Collins, whose personal wealth is estimated at £300m, yesterday sued two former backing musicians to recover royalty payments of $20,000 (£13,000) he claims were made by accident.
fields.body:
Phil Collins, whose personal wealth is estimated at £300m, yesterday sued two former backing musicians to recover royalty payments of $20,000 (£13,000) he claims were made by accident.

In the high court action Mr Collins, 49, yesterday claimed that excessive payments were made to Louis Satterfield and Rahmlee Davis, former members of Earth Wind and Fire, over a seven-year period.

Mr Satterfield, a trombonist and Mr Davis, a trumpeter, deny that they have been overpaid and will claim that withdrawal of royalties would leave them destitute.

The action, brought by Phil Collins Ltd, centres around a contract signed by the horn players prior to Mr Collins' 1990 world tour. Mr Satterfield and Mr Davis, along with two other members of their band, the Phoenix Horns, were paid a flat rate of $5,000 per week for the duration of the eight-month tour. The contract also contained a clause indicating they would receive a royalty of 0.5% on the resulting album.

Robert Howe, representing Phil Collins Ltd, told Mr Justice Jonathan Parker that because of an accounting error, Mr Satterfield, 62, and Mr Davis, 51, were paid the half-point royalty on all 15 tracks of the album rather than the five tracks to which they contributed. These payments continued for six-and-a-half years before the accounting error was spotted.

Mr Collins claims $780,000 (£500,000) has been paid to the pair since 1990, but he is not seeking to recover the full amount. Instead, said Mr Howe, what was at stake was the remaining sums Mr Collins's company claims the pair owe.

Referring to the relatively small amounts of money involved, Mr Justice Parker said: "It is not much is it ... For more than six years these royalties were paid and after six years a letter arrives to say in effect, 'Oh, it's a mistake'. It's not a very attractive position, is it?"

The hearing continues today.

fields.headline: Sacked cancer teacher wins damages
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A sixth form psychology teacher who was sacked by her school after taking leave for breast cancer treatment has won damages at an industrial tribunal.
fields.body:
A sixth form psychology teacher who was sacked by her school after taking leave for breast cancer treatment has won damages at an industrial tribunal.

Deborah Sander, 48, lost her part-time job at Kings of Wessex school in Cheddar, Somerset, within hours of hearing from her doctors last summer that she was fit to return to work.

Later she was asked back to provide cover during another teacher's sick leave, suggesting that her professionalism was not in doubt.

She has been awarded more than £9,000 for injury to her feelings and unfair dismissal, her union announced yesterday.

Mrs Sander was appointed in June, 1998, to teach A-level psychology students at the Church of England community school. Two days later she was diagnosed as having an advanced case of breast cancer. But the school said it still wanted to employ her from the start of the autumn term.

The National Union of Teachers said: "Her distress about her illness was compounded by the fact that both her mother and grandmother died of breast cancer. As the mother of two young daughters she was devastated at the idea that they might lose their mother when they were so young."

Mrs Sander began teaching at the school in September, 1998, on a one-year contract. She said she was led to believe that renewal was a formality.

She taught during most of the autumn term, fixing appointments to have hormone implants replaced on her days off work.

But in December, 1998, she had to go into hospital for surgery, followed by further scans and radiotherapy.

In May she was told there was a possibility that her contract would not be renewed.

"I felt the school was using a temporary contract as an excuse to dismiss me because I had cancer."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Archer's new book deal
fields.body:
Archer's new book deal

The publisher HarperCollins is standing by the disgraced former Tory peer Lord Archer by signing him up for three more books, it was announced yesterday. Lord Archer signed a deal thought to be worth seven figures on Tuesday, less than two months after being suspended from the Conservative party for asking a friend to lie in his 1987 libel trial.

Driver faces 2 years in jail

A British lorry driver faces two years in a Macedonian jail after losing his appeal against a driving conviction, it emerged yesterday. Richard Hudson, 44, of Derby, was transporting supplies for Nato forces when the accident, which left a Macedonian man dead, happened in July.

New breath for Viagra

The makers of Viagra have come up with a more powerful form of the anti-impotence drug which can be sniffed rather than swallowed. Pfizer has lodged a patent application for a novel version of Viagra called sildenafil mesylate which is highly soluble, making it suitable for an inhaler.

Rugby fans to face court

Nine men appeared before Huddersfield magistrates yesterday charged in connection with a pitch invasion at a rugby league cup tie. The men were charged with public order offences after Sunday's challenge cup semi-final game between Leeds and Hull.

webTitle: Trainees to be paid to avert teacher crisis

fields.headline: Trainees to be paid to avert teacher crisis
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government is to intervene to avert a looming teacher recruitment crisis by paying salaries ranging from £6,000 to £13,000 a year to graduates embarking on training for the profession in September.
fields.body:
The government is to intervene to avert a looming teacher recruitment crisis by paying salaries ranging from £6,000 to £13,000 a year to graduates embarking on training for the profession in September.

David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, will spend £70m from the £1bn windfall for education in the Budget last week to pay more than 25,000 trainees who would otherwise have had to survive on student loans and family support.

For the first time all students on the one-year course for a post-graduate certificate in education will be paid at least £6,000, whether or not they subsequently take a job in teaching.

Those studying to become secondary teachers in maths, science, modern foreign languages and technology will get £10,000, but the £4,000 bonus will depend on them taking up a job in one of those four subjects in which teachers are in short supply.

A few hundred students on school-based courses outside the normal university training system will get the top rate £13,000 - just £3,050 short of the starting salary for a newly-qualified graduate teacher.

The new training salaries for teachers will be considerably more generous than means-tested bursaries worth up to £4,500 for students taking degrees in nursing. Only graduates will qualify and there will be no pay for trainees on the four-year undergraduate degree in education.

Mr Blunkett has decided to introduce training salaries after receiving evidence of a further drop in recruitment to the postgraduate teaching course.

So far 9,200 students have applied for the 14,380 places available for the course in secondary education starting in September. This is 14% down on last year at the same stage.

Ministers are concerned about an apparent failure to attract graduates into the shortage subjects. Last year the offer of a golden hello worth £5,000 increased numbers of specialists going into secondary teaching by 17% in maths and 4% in science. "This year it looks as if the figures are going back to where they were before," an education department source said.

Demand for training to teach in primary schools is stronger, with 10,981 applications lodged so far for 6,178 places. But the figure is down 11% on last year and ministers are concerned about the academic quality of many applicants and a gender imbalance. Only one in seven primary trainees are men.

Mr Blunkett intends training salaries to be a permanent part of the induction of secondary teachers, but he will review payments for primary trainees next year.

The payments are being introduced to coincide with the start of the government's scheme for performance related pay and fast-tracking.

This will allow teachers to reach a salary of about £24,000 within five or six years of starting in the profession. They can then move on to a higher pay scale with a maximum of about £30,000 for classroom teachers and £72,000 for secondary heads.

The government will today back up these salary adjustments with an advertising campaign. Ministers are concerned that recruitment over the last eight years has fallen by 13%, partly due to a more buoyant graduate labour market.

A poll last month for Guardian Education showed that half England's teachers expected to quit the profession over the next 10 years - either because they were due to retire or because they were discontented with the workload, stress and bureaucracy.

If teachers leaving the pro fession cannot be replaced by high-quality graduate recruits, the government's drive to raise educational standards will be put in jeopardy.

Hitherto there have been few financial incentives for graduates to enter teacher training. There were no tuition fees, but the only salaries were for the small numbers on school-based training programmes paid at the head's discretion.

Under the new scheme, the government will for the first time pay a £4,000 bonus to the school and provide £13,000 for the trainee.

webTitle: Illness forces Times editor to take break

fields.headline: Illness forces Times editor to take break
fields.trailText: The editor of the Times, Peter Stothard, disclosed yesterday that he is taking a break from day-to-day control of the newspaper because he is receiving treatment for a tumour.
fields.body:
The editor of the Times, Peter Stothard, disclosed yesterday that he is taking a break from day-to-day control of the newspaper because he is receiving treatment for a tumour.

News International, the owners of the Times, said Mr Stothard briefed employees on the reasons for his absence yesterday. He was keen to quash speculation among his staff and in the media that his departure was linked to reports suggesting Michael Ashcroft, the Tory party treasurer, was in line for a peerage.

Mr Stothard said he was undergoing chemotherapy for a neuroendocrine tumour of the pancreas, and that the treatment meant he could not put in the effort required to edit a national newspaper at the moment.

He said in a statement yesterday that he had wanted to keep the illness private, but had changed his mind.

"I felt this was a private matter between Sally, me and our children, but as a journalist I should have known better. As everyone who has had this treatment knows, it makes you a bit tired, but I'll be back in robust health very shortly. I am looking forward to using the time to consider many projects relating to the future of the paper."

Les Hinton, executive chairman of News International, said: "We wanted to respect Peter's wishes about how this event in his life should be handled. But it has led to such wild speculation from competing media that Peter felt he should make the facts absolutely clear. Peter heads an exceptionally talented team who are producing an award-winning paper: they will carry on his editorial policy and vision during his absence."

Mr Stothard first disclosed to staff on Tuesday that he was to take leave. Yesterday, the paper ran a story suggesting that Mr Ashcroft might receive a peerage, after earlier being blocked by the committee which scrutinises the appointment of working peers.

Mr Ashcroft sued the Times last year over its coverage of his business dealings, but the legal action was later dropped.

Mr Stothard told staff yesterday that he wanted to stress that he had not been "eased out of the editor's chair, even temporarily, at the instigation of Mr Ashcroft, his acolytes and satellites".

He pointed out that News International and Rupert Murdoch, the paper's proprietor, had been "wholly supportive" in the Ashcroft affair.

webTitle: State of the art yacht snaps at sea

fields.headline: State of the art yacht snaps at sea
fields.standfirst: Ruing the waves: British team's embarrassment
fields.trailText: It was named by the Queen and heralded as the world's premier racing yacht. Team Philips, designed by the country's leading boat and aircraft designers, set off two weeks ago amid promises that Britannia would once again rule the waves.
fields.body:
It was named by the Queen and heralded as the world's premier racing yacht. Team Philips, designed by the country's leading boat and aircraft designers, set off two weeks ago amid promises that Britannia would once again rule the waves.

Last night, the £4m state-of-the art catamaran that took four years to construct was staying afloat with the support of air bags after being partially broken up in waves that would not trouble an amateur sailor.

Team Philips was preparing for a round-the-world race when a 25 foot section of its port hull snapped off while a 15 foot crack appeared on its other hull, leading to severe embarrassment amongst its ambitious crew, led by Pete Goss, 39, a veteran racing sailor and former Royal Marine.

The yacht was on the third day of sea trials around 30 miles north west of the Isles of Scilly, in preparation for the attempt on the round-the-world, non-stop sailing record, when the crew heard a loud bang and saw one section of the hull slip away into the water.

The crew immediately called the coast guard and the yacht was towed back to the port of St Mary's on the Isles of Scilly, where the damage is being assessed by navy divers.

According to reports, the conditions Team Philips encountered in the Atlantic yesterday were mild compared to what it would have faced in any round-the-world race, leading to fears that there are problems with the yacht's design.

Some of the best brains in yachting design were drafted into the project and the expertise of aircraft designers was used to make it the most aerodynamic sea vessel ever.

During yesterday's sea trials, the wind was blowing at around 25 knots and there was a 10 foot sea swell, considered mild in sailing terms.

Winds in the Southern ocean can reach up to 60 knots with sea swells of around 40 feet.

Team Philips is today due to be towed back to the yard in Totnes, south Devon, where it was constructed from carbon fibre and epoxy resin, the same material used to build stealth fighter bombers.

Its revolutionary design was set to make it the fastest yacht in the history of sailing, capable of reaching speeds of up to 40 knots per hour.

Once the sea trials were complete the vessel was to compete in the 71-day Jules Verne round-the-world race and later this year in the Race, a round-the-world competition considered the most gruelling in yachting circles.

As his boat bobbed on air bags in the water of St Mary's port and his dreams of shattering world records lay in tatters, Goss said: "Obviously there is a huge sense of disappointment.

"There were times when I saw water wash over the hull names [of sponsors] on the port side and it made me feel like crying. This is a major set back, and I feel most for the team who have put their heart, body and soul into this.

"It is a sad, sad day, but we are going to regroup and come back stronger - it is not over yet."

The entire £4m for the yacht's construction was raised by sponsors and financial backers.

Experts believe that serious miscalculations were made in the design of the 120 foot long yacht and that it was not heavy enough to sustain relatively mild waves and wind.

The boat was constructed using a mould technique and the hulls are hollow.

It weighs four tons but many racing yachts are heavier so that they can withstand rough seas and high winds.

Goss had stated from the outset that his aim was to build the fastest yacht ever and he had assembled the country's leading constructors at the Totnes yard specially set up for Team Philips.

Goss became a hero in the sailing world after he turned back in a Southern ocean hurricane to rescue his fellow competitor Raphael Dinelli in the 1996-97 Vendee Globe round-the-world single-handed race.

Goss was later awarded France's highest honour, the Legion d'honneur by President Jacques Chirac and also an MBE.

Team Philips was preparing for a round-the-world race when a 25 foot section of its port hull snapped off while a 15 foot crack appeared on its other hull, leading to severe embarrassment amongst its ambitious crew, led by Pete Goss, 39, a veteran racing sailor and former Royal Marine. The yacht was on the third day of sea trials around 30 miles north west of the Isles of Scilly, in preparation for the attempt on the round-the-world, non-stop sailing record, when the crew heard a loud bang and saw one section of the hull slip away into the water. The crew immediately called the coast guard and the yacht was towed back to the port of St Mary's on the Isles of Scilly, where the damage is being assessed by navy divers. According to reports, the conditions Team Philips encountered in the Atlantic yesterday were mild compared to what it would have faced in any round-the-world race, leading to fears that there are problems with the yacht's design. Some of the best brains in yachting design were drafted into the project and the expertise of aircraft designers was used to make it the most aerodynamic sea vessel ever. During yesterday's sea trials, the wind was blowing at around 25 knots and there was a 10 foot sea swell, considered mild in sailing terms. Winds in the Southern ocean can reach up to 60 knots with sea swells of around 40 feet. Team Philips is today due to be towed back to the yard in Totnes, south Devon, where it was constructed from carbon fibre and epoxy resin, the same material used to build stealth fighter bombers. Its revolutionary design was set to make it the fastest yacht in the history of sailing, capable of reaching speeds of up to 40 knots per hour. Once the sea trials were complete the vessel was to compete in the 71-day Jules Verne round-the-world race and later this year in the Race, a round-the-world competition considered the most gruelling in yachting circles. As his boat bobbed on air bags in the water of St Mary's port and his dreams of shattering world records lay in tatters, Goss said: "Obviously there is a huge sense of disappointment. "There were times when I saw water wash over the hull names [of sponsors] on the port side and it made me feel like crying. This is a major set back, and I feel most for the team who have put their heart, body and soul into this. "It is a sad, sad day, but we are going to regroup and come back stronger - it is not over yet." The entire £4m for the yacht's construction was raised by sponsors and financial backers. Experts believe that serious miscalculations were made in the design of the 120 foot long yacht and that it was not heavy enough to sustain relatively mild waves and wind. The boat was constructed using a mould technique and the hulls are hollow. It weighs four tons but many racing yachts are heavier so that they can withstand rough seas and high winds. Goss had stated from the outset that his aim was to build the fastest yacht ever and he had assembled the country's leading constructors at the Totnes yard specially set up for Team Philips. Goss became a hero in the sailing world after he turned back in a Southern ocean hurricane to rescue his fellow competitor Raphael Dinelli in the 1996-97 Vendee Globe round-the-world single-handed race. Goss was later awarded France's highest honour, the Legion d'honneur by President Jacques Chirac and also an MBE.

webTitle: Science handed a clue to sexuality

fields.headline: Science handed a clue to sexuality
fields.trailText: Homosexuality could be a matter of fingertip control. In research guaranteed to have everyone staring at the backs of their hands, scientists have linked the ratio of finger lengths, the number of older brothers, and hormones in the womb to sexual orientation.
fields.body:
Homosexuality could be a matter of fingertip control. In research guaranteed to have everyone staring at the backs of their hands, scientists have linked the ratio of finger lengths, the number of older brothers, and hormones in the womb to sexual orientation.

Marc Breedlove of the University of California at Berkeley reports in Nature today that he and his colleagues studied the hands of 720 adults in San Francisco and asked their age, the number of older siblings they had and whether they were gay.

The researchers found a link between their subjects' fourth fingers and their sexual identity. In women, the index finger and the fourth finger are about the same length. In men, the fourth digit is usually longer than the second digit.

The team found that the ratio of difference between the two telltale fingers was significantly more "masculine" in gay women.

There was no clear difference in finger length ratios of homosexual and heterosexual men, but the team found that the more older brothers a male subject had, the more likely he was to be gay and the more "masculine" was his fingertip ratio.

"A mother's body appears to alter the foetal development of subsequent sons, increasing the likelihood of homosexuality," the researchers write.

webTitle: Which millionaire?  Stars line up to face Tarrant

fields.headline: Which millionaire?  Stars line up to face Tarrant
fields.trailText: ITV is to screen a version of its hit programme Who Wants to be a Millionaire, with the twist that many of the contestants will be millionaires.
fields.body:
ITV is to screen a version of its hit programme Who Wants to be a Millionaire, with the twist that many of the contestants will be millionaires.

TV presenter Carol Vorderman and newsreader Kirsty Young are among celebrities lined up to face presenter Chris Tarrant.

They have been judged to possess enough intellectual prowess, and enough cash not to be concerned about giving away a million, since all the prize money will go to charity.

ITV would not reveal yesterday who has been signed up for the show, but spokeswomen for Young and Vorderman said they were involved.

David Liddiment, ITV's director of programmes, said: "The celebrities who are going on are very brave. People in the public eye do not like to look foolish."

The format of the show has not been changed for the celebrity special, except that there will be no elimination round. All will be able to "phone a friend".

The show will be aired during ITV's Day of Promise in May, part of a 12-month campaign in which people around Britain are asked to make a simple pledge.

Celebrity Millionaire is part of ITV's spring and summer season, details of which were announced yesterday.

Barbara Windsor is the subject of a one-off drama Cor, Blimey! which tells the story of her real-life affair with Carry On colleague Sid James.

The show is based on Terry Johnson's award-winning Royal National Theatre play Cleo, Camping, Emmanuelle and Dick.

The TV version recreates some of their best-known film scenes, including the moment when Windsor's bikini top snaps off during a campsite workout. Windsor makes a cameo appearance, and her younger version is played by Samantha Spiro.

ITV's Real Life documentary series returns, and includes a profile of Barrie Drewitt and Tony Barlow, the two gay men from Essex who travelled to the US to adopt surrogate twins.

The newscaster Trevor McDonald gets his own interview series for the ITV terrestrial network. Trevor McDonald Meets the Newsmakers was established on the digital channel ITV2, where guests included John Major, Desmond Tutu and Richard Branson.

While BBC bosses said last week they have temporarily ditched period dramas, ITV is to present a new version of Nicholas Nickleby and an adaptation of Thomas Hardy's The Mayor of Casterbridge.

Sporting highlights include three football finals, the FA Cup, the UEFA Champions League and Euro 2000.

fields.headline: Work in progress
fields.standfirst: Mona Hatoum, sculptor
fields.trailText: Mona Hatoum, sculptor.
fields.body:
Since last Spring I've been working on a number of projects at once. When I was invited to propose new works for the Duveen Galleries at the Tate, I was about to leave London for two months residency at ArtPace in San Antonio, Texas. While I was there, I created a number of new works and used my time to experiment with ideas towards the Tate exhibition and a large touring exhibition - which is in France at the moment and will travel to MUHKA, Antwerp in June.

People often say I'm too busy, but I get inspired by working in different spaces in different parts of the world. Once the exhibition at The Tate opens, I'll start working on my contribution to the London Biennial. It's a do-it-yourself biennial dreamed up by this wonderful guy called David Medalla. I have a vague idea for a performance, but it's still not completely formulated. I have found a great space - a shopfront in Spitalfields.

Over the summer I'm also installing works in three group shows in Europe, and in September I'm participating in an art festival in Beirut which is exciting because it will be the first time I show my work there. For the Tate I created three new installations conceived specifically for those very special central spaces, but the works are at the same time a continuation of some of my current concerns. The Mouli-Julienne (x21) in the South Duveen is based on a French rotary vegetable shredder which I found in my mother's kitchen in Beirut a couple of summers ago. I immediately pictured making it very big, turning this harmless kitchen utensil into a threatening infernal machine. I enlarged it to 21 times its orginal size and now it looks like some extinct mammoth - a dinosaur.

The next exhibition will be taking place in Caracas in October. This will probably allow me to have a rest but, then again, I'm a perpetual workaholic who hasn't stopped going from exhibition to exhibition since 1993. So why stop now?

fields.headline: The not-so great Gatsby
fields.trailText: The Great Gatsby | Sex And The City | Dangerous Company | Animal Hospital Birthday Special
fields.body:
We'll meet you on some corner. I'll be the man smoking two cigarettes." The Great Gatsby (BBC1) faithfully reproduces Fitzgerald's coolest lines, so why does it feel like a romp through the plot for GCSE revision? Maybe they shouldn't mess with the sacred books of adolescence. No fool has made a mini-series out of Catcher In The Rye (I see Jason Priestley, I see Tori Spelling).

Paul Rudd should have been good as Nick, the young narrator who gets drawn into Gatsby's orbit in order to lead him back to Daisy, the love of his youth, because he has a soft white boy's face which is asking to be charmed. "I had lost my capacity for wonder", Nick says at the end. But all of the wonder has been missed out of this production and Rudd mostly just wanders around looking vaguely annoyed.

Because no one is charming. Not Toby Stephens as Gatsby, whose performance shows you only that Gatsby is a fake and a crook and whose smile is not Gatsby's smile of "eternal reassurance" but Joey-from-Friends' cheesy girl-pulling grin.

And not Mira Sorvino as Daisy, whose voice is supposed to be full of money, but is just moany. Why would Gatsby love her? She looks like a drowned goose and her hats like they've been made out of old pants.

And the glittering Gatsby parties are as uninspired as the bunchy school-play frocks and the shampoo-advert flashbacks. So when Gatsby and his world are broken up by careless old moany Daisy and her husband Tom, who cares? There has been nothing for Nick to be enchanted by so there is no reason for disenchantment either, and when Gatsby gets shot in his swimming pool, you just wonder why the bullet didn't go through the lilo he's lying on.

Don't men get lonely? If they do, popular culture's been keeping it a big secret. In Sex And The City (C4) Carrie and her three friends went to a fashion designer's funeral and pondered mortality. Reddy, Browny and Yellowy represent a kind of L'Oreal spectrum of single womanhood.

Yellowy is shallow and tarty so she tried to shag someone else's husband while raising money for the dead fashion designer's charity. Browny is romantic and naive so she slept with a widower she met at the cemetery and then discovered she wasn't the only woman whose sympathy he was playing on to get sex. Reddy, who tries to be independent, was buying an apartment. It turned out an elderly spinster had died alone in the apartment and had her face eaten off by her cat. Reddy has a cat herself and had a rather scary panic attack which was slightly too grim for the programme's gag-driven format so she hastily got over it.

Carrie, the Everywoman character, thought a bit about death and got anxious about being alone and the show ended with her having sex with her vampirish ex, "Big", yellow light falling on limbs like a bundle of chicken bones in the bed.

Sometime soon, I hope, women are going to get tired of all this and start burning effigies of Ally McBeal in the streets or leading holy wars or at least stop watching these shows.

Dangerous Company (BBC2) showed that management consultants are truly spookier than the Moonies. Three companies underwent consultant-led, flipchart-tastic down-sizing revolutions. BP and Amstrad eventually emerged, Figgie International (they existed, they made those Fred Perry sportshirts) went under.

Len Barbee, a speckle-headed Uncle Fester-alike, blames the twenty-three-year- old consultants (total bill $75 million, including lapdancing outings): "I had people on the floor who knew more from their butts than they knew from their heads." But you have to wonder a bit about Figgie pere and fils, Harry (who sometimes wore superhero outfits) and Dr Harry III. They were responsible for calling the down-sizing hit squad the Valdez Team, after an old Burt Lancaster film where Burt shoots people from very long distances.

Rolf Harris is 70. Until I saw the Animal Hospital Birthday Special (BBC1), I hadn't realised quite what a renaissance dude he really is. There's the art (Rolf once topped a "name a famous artist" survey), mastery of a dazzling array of humorous instruments, the dance routine involving Rolf having three legs, the animal noises, a sideline in lizard massage... What's more you never hear Rolf boring on about single women and he cries over starving dogs. Happy Birthday, Sport.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Anastasia | The Bad And The Beautiful | Kiss Me Deadly | Nil By Mouth
fields.body:
Anastasia

(Anatole Litvak, 1956)

7pm, Carlton Cinema

Ingrid Bergman chalked up a second Oscar but she's a shadow of her Gaslight self: the award was more a signal that Hollywood had forgiven her her love-child scandal. She plays a woman coached, Henry Higgins-style, by White Russian Yul Brynner in Paris, 1928, to pose as the surviving daughter of the executed tsar - and must pass muster with fearsome Dowager Empress, Helen Hayes. Lush romance, with an approach to rewriting history that really verges on the Stalinist.

The Bad And The Beautiful

(Vincente Minnelli, 1952)

3pm, TCM

Minnelli lifts the lid on trashy Tinseltown, with Kirk Douglas playing a charming producer forcing his way to the top. Lana Turner's starlet, Barry Sullivan's director and writer Dick Powell recount in flashback what a scoundrel he is (perfectly equipped for Hollywood, in fact). Packed with movieland references it's a grand, over-the-top drama.

Kiss Me Deadly

(Robert Aldrich, 1955)

8pm, FilmFour

Whatever you do, don't open the box! It's Pandora's, of course, in this screen version of Mickey Spillane's brutal thriller for the nuclear age. Ralph Meeker's private eye Mike Hammer picks up panicky blonde Cloris Leachman on the road and unwittingly speeds her to her death - which sets him Terminator-like on the trail of a bunch of uranium thieves.

Nil By Mouth

(Gary Oldman, 1997)

1.15am, Sky MovieMax

Clearly an act of catharsis for Oldman, whose directing and writing debut is a brutally honest picture of a dysfunctional southeast London family. Shot edgy and dark with handheld camera, it makes most verite look like wild flights of fantasy, while the performances are stripped bare and are utterly convincing. Ray Winstone's savage, drunken Raymond is one long snarl of hopelessness as he brutalises wife Kathy Burke and her junkie brother Billy (Charlie Creed-Miles). Awesome.
