fields.headline: The price is right
fields.standfirst: Which British film is most likely to become a television series before the end of 2005?
fields.trailText: Which British film is most likely to become a television series before the end of 2005?
fields.body:
 High Fidelity 6/4
 Kevin And Perry Go Large 3/1
 Four Weddings And A Funeral 8/1
 Love, Honour And Obey 12/1

Welcome back to the joys of film spin-offs, many years after M*A*S*H set the precedent for quality television adaptations of successful films. The Welsh rave film Human Traffic and Lock, Stock And Two Smoking Barrels will soon be appearing on Channel 4. And in America, with a whole host of series from LA Confidential to Bull Durham in the offing, executives are keeping an eye out for future films to be downsized and re-released on the box.

"The reason behind this is the success of Buffy The Vampire Slayer", says Ed Nicholson, Ladbrokes' entertainment odds compiler. "But it's not easy - a recent sitcom, Manchester Prep, based on the film Cruel Intentions was cancelled without an episode being broadcast. Nevertheless, others should follow."

"High Fidelity, the film version of Nick Hornby's novel, is released in the US soon. I think its quirky, slightly neurotic characters would make for a superb series - especially as the new demographic television execs are hankering after is the young male."

Love, Honour And Obey should score a hit at the box office, with Denise Van Outen and the British stars du jour, Jude Law, Ray Winstone and Kathy Burke. "However, the plot is very Lock Stock", Ed points out.

"Kevin And Perry Go Large is the film version of the popular Harry Enfield and Kathy Burke characters. But I think that it won't work as a film - and that is one of the basic rules: If the movie's not a success then try a TV series."

Four Weddings And A Funeral was a world-wide success and with a possible sequel appearing on the big screen the odds are quite good that a TV spin-off could be in the offing.

fields.headline: Anthony Powell
fields.standfirst: Comic writer in the English tradition whose million-word masterpiece introduced us to an army of characters - one hauntingly mysterious
fields.trailText: Anthony Powell, who has died aged 94, is inevitably regarded as the English Proust, on the strength of the massive novel sequence A Dance to the Music of Time - 12 volumes and a million words - that became his central life's work.
fields.body:
Anthony Powell, who has died aged 94, is inevitably regarded as the English Proust, on the strength of the massive novel sequence A Dance to the Music of Time - 12 volumes and a million words - that became his central life's work. The Proust impact was more dominant and more obvious than that of other great European novelists and assorted influences from Petronius to modern Americans. Yet he will stand as essentially a comic writer in the English tradition - comic in the least uproarious way imaginable, reflective and often melancholic, the strong social spine to his work being the one distinctively uncommon feature in a branch of writing remarkable more for eccentricity than togetherness.

In fact, Powell has a measure of both. He goes in for no deep psychological dredging, yet his novels rest on a firmer base of instinct and belief than is usual among the English comedians. He is fascinated by the play of time and chance on character, and it is by no means time and chance that always win. His narrating hero and anchorman, Nicholas Jenkins, is constantly being mildly surprised by the way things and people turn out.

Others are more mysterious. Above all - literally so, if he had his way - there is the preposterous, the ever-haunting Widmerpool. This reaction is particularly strong in the account - laconic and uninhibited like the fiction - of the early days in London when Jenkins is finding his feet in the literary world. The real-life memories develop, as the novels do, a sense of the significance of trivial and seemingly casual events, while large ones may pass invisibly by. We watch him becoming a Territorial recruit in the Royal Artillery ("I felt that if the gunners were good enough for Tolstoy they were good enough for me") and, rather more dangerously, pursuing a friendship with Evelyn Waugh. There are drinks with the Sitwells. The air of clubbishness, a cool, bookish intimacy, persists. Most of the way, that is. Just once in a while togetherness fails: "In the flat below mine lived EM Forster (a writer whose books have never greatly appealed to me), but we never met."

The trivia of the memoirs can be as funny as anything in the novels, and that means very funny indeed. Powell was of the opinion that most important writers, unlike most critics, have been well equipped with resources of humour; he even seems to have regarded it as a touchstone in evaluating them.

Powell began as a writer for addicts - clubmen too, members of the Powell Club - but they increased rapidly. Or was it more like an open prison, in which Powell was governor and his readers were condemned to life sentences? They never wanted to be anywhere else for long, and they always came back at call.

For a single writer to have put such a stamp on his day, and against the prevailing mood and style of the time, is a huge achievement. Powell didn't stand quite alone. Kingsley Amis was with him, dealing bold strokes in defence of the comic spirit; but the Amis comedy, though by no means all belly-laughs, was of a rougher order and failed to carry the approval of the bookish establishment. While Amis sold books, Powell won praise. It was ungrudging and well-earned.

Largely it was a triumph of tone. A fastidious satirist, he never shouts and seldom mocks - or (except in the physical sense) moves very far. Powell's ideal hunting-ground seems a mile square and an inch deep, and there are bound to be some - particularly when so little, for such long spells, manages to happen - who get to find the inflexibly well-bred narrative voice a shade wearing. This is surely part of the fun. Powell's descriptive powers are clinically accurate and searching, and he is constantly putting himself in the way of good material.

He is a conscientious mixer in the interests of his profession. It goes beyond clubland and the haunts of off-duty politicians, bureaucrats and important artists, though even lower life has its standards and good manners survive in unlikely places. Powell's world is well supplied with pubs without being beery, and there are times when the streets are thronged with well-born paupers conscientiously dodging their creditors. In taxis, of course.

Violence, public and domestic, in peace and war, is muted by the modulated tones of civilised life. This relentless gentility would risk serious tedium without that sharpness of eye and wit. The head, you could say, remains as cool as the heart. He lacks what Amis and most of the later English humorists have possessed - sentimentality. That would have destroyed the work.

He has a strong indulgence towards fantasy and eccentric behaviour, always with the assumption that it is observed and not invented. He can be ruthless, not always in expected settings. There are funerals, not necessarily particularly mournful occasions; death seems no more serious than life, which is indeed serious enough in so inflexible an English comedy world. There is an inclination for ritual, with serious sacrificial moments such as the drowning of a key manuscript in the Regent's Park canal (Books Do Furnish A Room), or the death - could it be possible after all? - of Widmerpool in the final volume of the sequence.

The fiction adds up to a marvel of skill, originality, patience and sheer longwindedness. Technically the challenge, brilliantly met, must have been the handling of that enormous flock of free-range characters and the disposing of the maddening, mysterious, apparently indestructible Widmerpool. No wonder the face in Poussin's ritual dance came to look more malign than ever, for the Powell version must have called for a kind of anti-choreography remote from dancing. These hundreds of performers had to be trained to collide with each other as much as possible for fear that they might otherwise stray off and never be seen again.

There must have been many who wished that for Widmerpool. Did Powell ever wish he had never created the man, if man it was? Keeping track of Widmerpool through 12 volumes and a million words, not really knowing whether he was ink or flesh, whether his true existence was inside the book or out, could have been a lifetime's job in itself.

He popped up everywhere: something in the City, something in the army, employed in many an advisory capacity. He was a Labour MP under Attlee, an admirer of Mrs Ernest Simpson. Hugh Gaitskell - though nobody seems quite sure about this - was thought to have been instrumental in getting him a peerage. He influenced people's lives though not in the traditional way; more a kind of one-man quango. He would always be in touch. There was no danger of his getting lost.

After the Music of Time sequence Powell continued to write - he had also been literary editor of Punch after the war and a long-time book reviewer for the Daily Telegraph - until immobilised by a series of strokes in the late 1980s. There was a short novel in 1983 dementedly entitled O, How the Wheel Becomes It! (Ophelia's mad scene, it fittingly turns out, provides the clue). And in 1986 he published The Fisher King, an elegant modern version of an ancient myth. He was made a Companion of Honour in in 1988.

Powell had married Violet Packenham, sister of Lord Longford, in 1934 after a brief acquaintanceship. For many years they lived in a handsome regency house near Frome in Somerset. He is survived by Lady Violet and two sons.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Performance On 3 | Melly's Maidens
fields.body:
Performance On 3 (7.20pm, Radio 3) brings a live relay from the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, of Ian Judge's famous production of Wagner's The Flying Dutchman. Originally staged there eight years ago, it proved a huge critical and commercial success. In this revival Simone Young conducts the resident orchestra. Austrian baritone Bernd Weikel plays the condemned Dutchman and soprano Solveig Kringelborn sings the role of Senta, the romantic young woman who becomes his obsessive lover.

The rich tones of the blues singer Bessie Smith bring Melly's Maidens (9.0pm, Radio 2) to its conclusion. She has been George Melly's idol throughout his own long jazz career. She was only 43 when, after a road accident, she was refused admission to a whites-only hospital in Tennessee. Without treatment she haemorrhaged to death, but her artistry proved immortal.

webTitle: Britain weighs in on neutrino hunt

fields.headline: Britain weighs in on neutrino hunt
fields.standfirst: They are such tiny particles that their discoverer swore they would never be seen. But scientists are hot on their trail, writes  Frank Close
fields.trailText: They are such tiny particles that their discoverer swore they would never be seen. But scientists are hot on their trail, writes Frank Close
fields.body:
A s you read this sentence, billions of neutrinos are hurtling through your eyeballs like light rays, but unseen. The neutrino is one of the most pervasive particles in the universe yet is also one of the most elusive.

Neutrinos from the sun and from the collapse of stars rush through space, through walls, through the whole Earth without slowing down: vast numbers of neutrinos from the sun shine on our heads by day and arrive undimmed up through our beds by night.

These ghostly relics of creation are widely believed to hold the secrets to the origins of matter and possibly to the eventual fate of the entire universe. They might also form vast clumps of the mysterious dark matter that seems to control the motions of the galaxies.

To understand the profound role that neutrinos play in the cosmos, to reveal the true nature of these bizarre particles, and to use them as tools for science, physicists need a "neutrino factory" to make vast numbers of them. Today the UK Particle Physics Committee will be discussing the possibility that the UK could host this relatively small scale fundamental research facility, and bring experimental research in particle physics back to the country where the subject began.

The neutrino was invented in 1930 by Wolfgang Pauli in order to balance the energy accounts in subatomic processes.

Careful accounting showed that the neutrino must be electrically neutral, have practically no mass and almost no interactions with matter. It was as near to being invisible and undetectable as anything could be.

Pauli wagered a crate of champagne that the neutrino would never be seen. By the 1950s technology cost Pauli the bubbly and today neutrinos are an integral part of the standard picture of the fundamental particles and forces of nature. They have even spawned neutrino astronomy enabling us to look inside the Sun and record stellar explosions such as supernovae. We make intense beams for use as probes of the deep structure of matter and of the fundamental forces that control the workings of the universe; yet with all this explosion of uses, we know very little about the neutrinos themselves.

We still do not know whether neutrinos have any mass. If they do, it is trifling relative to that of the ubiquitous electron. However, even a tiny mass for each neutrino could add up such that in total they outweigh everything else in the universe. As a result, neutrinos could eventually cause the universe to collapse under its own weight.

With a mass, neutrinos and their antimatter counterparts, antineutrinos, could reveal differences between matter and antimatter and provide new ways of investigating this most profound asymmetry in the universe today. There is a huge amount of interest in knowing more about this ghost particle of the cosmos but to do so we will first have to overcome their inbred shyness.

Neutrinos are the end products of processes like those in the sun. To make them here we use protons, the solar fuel, concentrate them into high intensity beams and speed them sufficiently that the efficiency for making neutrinos is dramatically increased. Particle physics usually brings to mind images of huge accelerators, such as the large hadron collider in Geneva. But the one being discussed for Britain would be designed to make large numbers of neutrinos at low energies, a thousand times lower than those at the LHC, which means an accelerator that is tens of metres across, rather than kilometres.

The scale is similar to what already exists in the Isis accelerator at the Rutherford Appleton Laboratory, in Oxfordshire, and that site could be a natural one for the development of a European neutrino factory.

The technological challenges are vast and it is only recently that the dream has become realisable. The opportunities for high-tech industries and for science are exciting. The possibility that, once again, the world's high energy physicists would be coming regularly to work on our soil, with obvious added value for the intellectual life in our universities, increases the hopes for what is being discussed today.

Professor John Garvey of Birmingham university, and chair of the UK Particle Physics Committee, said: "This is one of the most exciting possibilities for UK particle physics for many years because it can bring us back to the centre of world activity."

One way of measuring an exceedingly small mass is to produce neutrinos at one laboratory then direct the beams over hundreds of miles towards another laboratory where a few of these flighty particles can be detected. If neutrinos have a mass, what arrives will differ in certain characteristic ways from what set out. However, the changes happen only very slowly, hence the need for a long flight path to give time for this to happen: the optimal distance is estimated at around 1,000 to 2,000 km.

At the Gran Sasso laboratory in the mountains of central Italy there is already a laboratory where sophisticated apparatus, shielded from cosmic rays by the hundreds of metres of overlying rock, promises to be an ideal base for the sensitive detection of the neutrinos.

This is 1,500 km away from Oxfordshire, which makes the UK ideally placed geographically. The neutrinos from the factory will pass through the Earth and be detectable also at other underground laboratories in Japan or the USA enabling them to be sampled at even greater distances and adding to the scientific output.

With a neutrino factory in Oxfordshire producing the necessary intense beams, British scientists would be well placed to answer some of the biggest questions about "everything" by means of a particle that consists of almost nothing.

 Frank Close's latest book, Lucifer's Legacy - The Meaning Of Asymmetry, is published by Oxford University Press.

But the one being discussed for Britain would be designed to make large numbers of neutrinos at low energies, a thousand times lower than those at the LHC, which means an accelerator that is tens of metres across, rather than kilometres. The scale is similar to what already exists in the Isis accelerator at the Rutherford Appleton Laboratory, in Oxfordshire, and that site could be a natural one for the development of a European neutrino factory. The technological challenges are vast and it is only recently that the dream has become realisable. The opportunities for high-tech industries and for science are exciting. The possibility that, once again, the world's high energy physicists would be coming regularly to work on our soil, with obvious added value for the intellectual life in our universities, increases the hopes for what is being discussed today. Professor John Garvey of Birmingham university, and chair of the UK Particle Physics Committee, said: "This is one of the most exciting possibilities for UK particle physics for many years because it can bring us back to the centre of world activity." One way of measuring an exceedingly small mass is to produce neutrinos at one laboratory then direct the beams over hundreds of miles towards another laboratory where a few of these flighty particles can be detected. If neutrinos have a mass, what arrives will differ in certain characteristic ways from what set out. However, the changes happen only very slowly, hence the need for a long flight path to give time for this to happen: the optimal distance is estimated at around 1,000 to 2,000 km. At the Gran Sasso laboratory in the mountains of central Italy there is already a laboratory where sophisticated apparatus, shielded from cosmic rays by the hundreds of metres of overlying rock, promises to be an ideal base for the sensitive detection of the neutrinos. This is 1,500 km away from Oxfordshire, which makes the UK ideally placed geographically. The neutrinos from the factory will pass through the Earth and be detectable also at other underground laboratories in Japan or the USA enabling them to be sampled at even greater distances and adding to the scientific output. With a neutrino factory in Oxfordshire producing the necessary intense beams, British scientists would be well placed to answer some of the biggest questions about "everything" by means of a particle that consists of almost nothing.  Frank Close's latest book, Lucifer's Legacy - The Meaning Of Asymmetry, is published by Oxford University Press.

webTitle: Suits you, sir, said the tailor to the ichthyosaur

fields.headline: Suits you, sir, said the tailor to the ichthyosaur
fields.standfirst: Theagarten Lingham-Soliar  links a Parisian dressmaker and a 200 million year old fossil
fields.trailText: Theagarten Lingham-Soliar links a Parisian dressmaker and a 200 million year old fossil
fields.body:
Ichthyosaurs, extinct, predatory, marine reptiles may have had skin that acted like a tight but flexible swimsuit that helped to give greater swimming speeds according to recent research. This may put them firmly back in the race with some of the fastest swimmers of today's, oceans.

In the early Jurassic seas about 200 million years ago, ichthyosaurs were unrivalled as the fastest swimmers. These were creatures that ranged in size from about a metre to10 metres in length but all had one thing in common: spindle-shaped bodies and large crescent-shaped tails, adaptations for fast swimming. More recent high-velocity swimmers such as sharks, tunas and dolphins had not yet evolved. The inevitable question is, if ichthyosaurs were alive today, how would they compare with these super-swimmers of today's oceans?

We know that in addition to hydrodynamic streamlining, tunas, sharks and dolphins, have extremely stiff bodies. Only in the last couple of decades with microscopic examination of the skin, have scientists worked out how this is achieved. The skin was found to possess layers of fibres wound round the body in opposing directions and forming a kind of meshwork.

This "fishnet" helps to contain the hydrostatic pressure that builds up within the animal during fast swimming and accounts for increased stiffness to the body. The benefits of a stiffer body are that it allows the animal to cleave through the water with less disturbance or drag. This has the potential of greatly increasing swimming speeds.

This kind of information is often more than we can expect to find from fossilised animals. Hence comparisons at this level of swimming performances between ichthyosaurs and the high velocity swimmers of today have been wishful thinking. This may have recently changed.

A study of ichthyosaurs with preserved skin tissue indicates that there may have been striking similarities between the fibrous structure of their skin and that of present day fast swimming fishes and cetaceans. In a paper published in December's issue of Proceedings of the Royal Society I describe the preserved skin of one of the earliest Jurassic ichthyosaurs, which is on display in the university of Glasgow's Hunterian Museum. The specimen is believed to be that of Ichthyosaurus, from southern England, an early relative of the ichthyosaur Ophthalmosaurus seen in the recent BBC series Walking With Dinosaurs.

What is most remarkable is that this specimen is one of a mere handful in the world that shows details in the skin. This is not to be confused with other ichthyosaur material with soft tissues fossilised, notably from the world famous lower Jurassic Posidonia shale of southern Germany. Frequently, the so-called preserved pieces of skin are in fact often decayed and transformed soft tissue that may simply outline the body as a black carbon-like film. The Hunterian specimen shows actual preserved skin structures. Two layers of skin fibres are seen to form a fishnet arrangement astonishingly similar to that of tunas and sharks.

Simply winding fibres around the body would clearly make the animal stiff but the essential bending movements needed in swimming would be hampered. Only recently have scientists been able to answer in biomechanical terms how freedom of movement and stiffness is achieved at the same time.

However, a dressmaker in Paris, a Mlle Vionnet, understood the practical applications a lot longer with her invention of the "bias cut". In 1922 Mlle Vionnet, who had probably never heard of fish skin tensile stresses and strains, intuitively realised that a piece of fabric could be both stiff and flexible and that a clinging effect could be achieved without pulling on strings or straining on hooks.

Cloth consists of fibres that run horizontally and vertically - pulling along either of these, the cloth will extend very little (ie it is stiff in tension). However, if you pull the cloth at 45 degrees to the direction of the thread i.e. in the "bias direction", it is much more extensible. A simple test of pulling on a handkerchief along the bias demonstrates this quite well. Cloth in a dress is subjected to vertical tensile stresses from its own weight and the movement of the wearer, bending, sitting etc. However, if the cloth is disposed at 45 degrees to the vertical, it allows longitudinal extension and, importantly, it also contracts laterally at the same time. Thus, the body-hugging dress was invented and fashion has never looked back.

Fish and ichthyosaur stiffness works in exactly this way - the skin with the mesh work of fibres is oriented like cloth cut on the bias. The longitudinal extension during swimming movements causes the fibres to tighten around the circumference of the animal to produce a stiffer but flexible animal.

It also reduces creases and wrinkles on the body surface, allowing a smoother passage through the water. These conditions, as we've seen in living animals, have dramatic effects on swimming performance.

Similar fibres to the Hunterian specimen are found in only two other ichthyosaurs, in collections in Germany and Sweden. These are described in a paper sub mitted to the palaeobiological journal, Lethaia.

The work of scientists on fossil animals may sometimes be underestimated but the true heroes in our science whose work can never be taken be taken for granted are the fossil preparators. Whether for a child looking up in amazement at Tyrannosaurus rex or a scientist peering down a microscope at some fossilised scrap of material, it is the preparators' meticulous skills that make it all possible.

 T. Lingham-Soliar is visiting professor of palaentology at the Russian Academy of Sciences in Moscow.

fields.headline: At home with the ancients
fields.standfirst: Henry Gee explains why the second discovery of DNA from Neanderthal bones is so much more important the the first
fields.trailText: Henry Gee explains why the second discovery of DNA from Neanderthal bones is so much more important the the first
fields.body:
Michael Crichton has a lot to answer for. This most skilful of thriller writers is also a meticulous researcher with a preternatural gift of timing. His scheme, in Jurassic Park, for recreating dinosaurs from fossilised DNA coincided with reality so precisely that Nature published an account of DNA from a 135-million-year-old beetle in the same week that the film of Jurassic Park opened in the United States.

As far as Nature was concerned this was the merest coincidence - but journalists to this day swear that it was a set-up. In the same way that sequels never quite stand up to the original, virtually all reports of DNA from the chthonic past have failed the all-important test of subsequent verification - and that includes the battered old beetle.

In every case, the extraction of DNA from fossils many millions of years old has not proved to be repeatable in any labs apart from the original. In some cases, the DNA turned out to have had more in common with dandruff than dinosaurs. After a few months of boom and bonanza in the early 1990s, the nascent field of ancient DNA research imploded into recriminations, retractions and a good deal of cautionary finger-waggings about wishful thinking, the evils of contamination, and the sheer unlikelihood that a molecule as fragile as naked DNA would last long enough - or be tough enough - to make it to the fossil record. Ancient DNA research got itself a bad reputation, like cold fusion and the persistent memory of water.

Sober reflection, though, has yielded dividends. Much of it has come from the Munich laboratory of Dr Svante Pääbo, the researcher who first established the fact of ancient DNA by extracting it from museum specimens such as Egyptian mummies. The extraction of DNA a few tens of thousands of years old (rather than millions) is now well-established. DNA sequences from mammoths frozen in Siberian permafrost are, if not a-couple-a-kopeck, then at least hardly worth a raised eyebrow.

In 1997, Pääbo and colleagues announced the next big thing in ancient DNA research: DNA from Neanderthal Man, our closest extinct relative. Their research paper, in the molecular biology journal Cell, set standards in scientific probity against which all other ancient DNA work is now judged. The DNA came from the first ever Neanderthal bones to be discovered, unearthed from the Feldhofer Cave near Düsseldorf in 1856. More than just a feat of laboratory work, this result went some way towards settling the biggest issue in anthropology - the origins of you and me.

Neanderthals are everyone's idea of stone-age humanity. Burly and rugged, they played Rugby Union, ate mammoths for breakfast and laughed in the face of the mile-thick glaciers that covered most of Europe. They appeared sometime before 200,000 years ago and died out 29,000 years ago. Their natural home was Europe and western Asia, from Spain to Uzbekistan. Modern humans, with their sophisticated stone-tool technology and unaccountable liking for Rugby League, appeared in Europe around 40,000 years ago, overlapping with the Neanderthals.

An acrid debate of long standing is whether the Neanderthals were directly ancestral to modern Europeans, or were replaced by them.

The Feldhofer DNA allowed this question to be addressed directly, for the first time. If Europeans were descended from Neanderthals, then the sequence of the Neanderthal DNA might resemble that of modern Europeans more than that of, say, Africans or Australians. It turned out that the Feldhofer Neanderthal DNA sequence fell well outside the entire range of modern human DNA, irrespective of geographic or ethnic origin. It could still be the case that modern Europeans harbour Neanderthal genes, but the evidence from the Feldhofer Neanderthal DNA provided no positive support for this.

Now comes a second Neanderthal DNA sequence, reported in today's Nature by William Goodwin of the university of Glasgow and colleagues. This DNA was extracted from one of the last and most easterly known of its kind. It came from the rib of a Neanderthal child who died 29,000 years ago in the northern Caucasus moun tains of southern Russia. Comparison with the Feldhofer DNA sequence shows a divergence of around 3.5%, comparable with ethnic or geographic differences between the DNA of different groups of modern humans. This is not surprising, given that the Russian and German Neanderthals lived 2,500 kilometres apart in space and perhaps tens of thousands of years apart in time (the geological age of the Feldhofer bones is unknown).

But what is most reassuring is the fact that the Russian Neanderthal DNA, like the Feldhofer DNA, falls entirely outside the modern human range of DNA variation. Instead, the two Neanderthal DNA sequences form a tight and distinct group, set apart from modern human genetic sequences. It looks less and less likely that Neanderthals contributed to the modern human gene pool. The fact that neither Neanderthal fossil was preserved in especially favourable conditions for DNA survival - the bones were carelessly lying around in dirty caves - gives grounds for hope that more Neanderthal DNA sequences will follow soon. It would be nice to have a range of Neanderthal DNA sequences from the full temporal as well as spatial range of the species.

This would allow us, for the first time, to get a snapshot of the DNA evolution of an entire species from start to finish. The promise of ancient DNA would be fulfilled.

 Henry Gee is a senior editor of Nature. His book Deep Time: Cladistics, The Revolution In Evolution (ISBN 1-885702-986-0) is published next week by Fourth Estate, price £20.

fields.headline: Science update
fields.trailText: Going for a geranium | A flan called horse
fields.body:
Going for a geranium
Natural historians at a Linnaean society meeting tomorrow will announce a new classification for pelargoniums. The class is wider than first thought: good news for geraniumbreeders, with more genes at their disposal. "It just goes to show that taxonomy opens up the treasure chest again," said the Natural History Museum in London, which on Tuesday embarks on Nature's Treasurehouses, a four-day conference about science and natural history museums, botanic gardens and art galleries in the world of information technology. Contact: www.nhm.ac.uk/conference

Power from the compost
Biomass could become a driving force. The US produces 100m tons of corn stalks, 11m tons of newsprint waste and 38m tons of dead leaves and discarded Christmas trees each year. Enzymes could be breaking the stuff down to fermentable sugars which in turn could make organic compounds once made from petroleum, Larry Walker, a biological engineer from Cornell university, told the American Chemical Society in San Francisco yesterday. America's 279m tons of plant waste could supply all the organic chemicals consumed in the and US each year - with some left over to be turned into gasoline.

A flan called horse
Daniel Fisher of the university of Michigan has been kitchen-testing stone age meat storage. According to April's Scientific American, he threw chunks of horse meat below the ice on a pond, every week fishing some up, cooking and eating it. The point: to test what ancient hunters did with slain mastodons. The creatures weighed 8,000lb: too much for one sitting. He argued that harmless lactobacilli colonised the submarine meat, rendering it inhospitable to more dangerous microbes. The horse belonged to a friend, and died naturally.

fields.headline: Stop rowdy neighbours call
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, will today attack councils and police for failing to make use of anti-social behaviour orders amid signs that councils are still reluctant to use the tough new powers to tackle the problem of disruptive neighbours.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, will today attack councils and police for failing to make use of anti-social behaviour orders amid signs that councils are still reluctant to use the tough new powers to tackle the problem of disruptive neighbours.

Launching a new report on anti-social behaviour, published by the social exclusion unit, Mr Straw will urge greater use of the orders to tackle "hard cases", and will also press councils to give problem tenants deadlines to improve or face eviction.

Fewer than 40 behaviour orders, which can lead to curfews, eviction and ultimately imprisonment, have been served since councils were granted the powers a year ago.

The report, which Mr Straw will launch today, will publish figures indicating a significant rise in complaints against nuisance neighbours. Complaints to the police climbed by 19% between 1995/96 and 1997/98, while complaints to environmental health offices shot up by 56% between 1993 and 1997.

Mr Straw last night criticised the police and councils in an interview on ITV's Tonight with Trevor McDonald. "What's frustrating is that we put these orders in the Crime and Disorder Act at the request of the police and local authorities.

"Now they are not using them as they should. They are coming out with excuses when, frankly, they should be getting on with gathering the evidence and getting the orders."

The social exclusion report will ask councils to draw on good practice elsewhere. In Manchester, disruptive tenants are given six months to improve or they do not have their tenancy renewed. "We want to see that idea extended around the country," a Home Office source said.

The report will urge written neighbourhood agreements under which residents and service providers would set out clear expectations of behaviour.

It will point out that much anti-social behaviour is racially motivated and will call for better monitoring.

webTitle: Pensioners gain but Smith loses wider museums fight

fields.headline: Pensioners gain but Smith loses wider museums fight
fields.trailText: The government yesterday kept its promise to introduce free admission for pensioners to national galleries and museums.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy,  Arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The government yesterday kept its promise to introduce free admission for pensioners to national galleries and museums.

But the culture secretary, Chris Smith, had to put a brave face on the destruction of his hopes to scrap entry charges for everyone. He failed to persuade the Treasury to back his plans to scrap all charges which have halved visitor numbers at some museums, including the Science Museum in London.

Yesterday, at the National Railway Museum in York, he said the government had announced the biggest ever increase in funding for culture and heritage, and promised further announcements on increasing access soon.

However, the museum sector believes this will amount to an extension of free hours, days or special events but that universal free admission is dead in the water.

Last year children were granted free admission, and when the pensioners join them from this weekend it is estimated that 23m people will no longer have to pay.

The deputy director of the Museums Association, Maurice Davies, said: "This opens up a glittering prospect of grandparents taking their grandchildren to museums and cutting out the middle men - their parents can go shopping."

There are anomalies even within the present limited exemption. The London Transport Museum in Covent Garden, designated a collection of national importance, is left out. The troubled Royal Armouries in Leeds, which came to the brink of closure last year, has also been left out but one of its outposts, the Artillery Museum at Fort Nelson in Hampshire, is included.

Museums admitting pensioners free from Saturday:

National Museum of Science and Industry; National Railway Museum,York; Natural History Museum; Zoological Museum,Tring, Hertfordshire; Victoria & Albert Museum; Theatre Museum, Covent Garden; Wellington Museum, Apsley House; National Maritime Museum; National Museums and Galleries on Merseyside; Imperial War Museum; Royal Armouries at Fort Nelson, Portsmouth; Tate St Ives

The deputy director of the Museums Association, Maurice Davies, said: "This opens up a glittering prospect of grandparents taking their grandchildren to museums and cutting out the middle men - their parents can go shopping." There are anomalies even within the present limited exemption. The London Transport Museum in Covent Garden, designated a collection of national importance, is left out. The troubled Royal Armouries in Leeds, which came to the brink of closure last year, has also been left out but one of its outposts, the Artillery Museum at Fort Nelson in Hampshire, is included. webTitle: Dobson in adverts row as rival hits a purple patch

fields.headline: Dobson in adverts row as rival hits a purple patch
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone yesterday launched a "Livingstone4London" campaign logo in purple colours, as it emerged that his main London mayoral rival, Frank Dobson, has had to ditch a series of anti-Livingstone advertising slogans after focus groups rejected them as too negative.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone yesterday launched a "Livingstone4London" campaign logo in purple colours, as it emerged that his main London mayoral rival, Frank Dobson, has had to ditch a series of anti-Livingstone advertising slogans after focus groups rejected them as too negative.

Hard-hitting billboard and newspaper advertisements, planned to boost the official Labour candidate's support, are also understood to have caused dissension between Mr Dobson's advisers and the agency picked for the campaign.

"There hasn't been a huge fight over the issue," a spokeswoman for the Dobson campaign said last night. "We have to strike a fine balance between positive and negative messages."

"Various people have had various ideas at different times," a senior Labour spokesman added.

"Some come from people who are not terribly sophisticated about political messages. But there's never been any suggestion that we would stoop low or smear him in a billboard campaign."

There was no sign yesterday of any let-up in the Dobson campaign attacks on the independent frontrunner.

Mr Dobson warned Londoners they "should be afraid of the dangerous reality" of the former Greater London council leader, who he claimed would drive more than 100,000 jobs out of the capital.

The Labour candidate also hailed a report by David Currie of the London Business School, arguing that the government's part-privatisation of the London Underground could end up 20% cheaper than the public bond issue favoured by Mr Livingstone.

The Brent East MP continued yesterday to attract practical support from the sphere of the arts and showbusiness, with the announcement of a benefit gig by DJ Fatboy Slim and an auction of works by artists such as Damien Hirst and Tracey Emin to raise funds for his campaign.

Meanwhile, the latest entries in the MPs' register of financial interests show that both Mr Livingstone and Mr Dobson raised around £100,000 for their respective campaigns to win Labour's mayoral nomination.

Mr Dobson's largest donor was electronics tycoon Sir Maurice Hatter, who gave £25,000, while Mr Livingstone's was the actor Neil Pearson, who donated £13,450.

Mr Livingstone was also given £12,000 by three union organisations - the London TGWU, FBU and and London AEEU electricians - while Mr Dobson got £7,500 from the ISTC and London GMB.

webTitle: Section 28 violates human rights act, lawyers claim

fields.headline: Section 28 violates human rights act, lawyers claim
fields.standfirst: More about section 28
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday accused opponents of moves to abolish laws preventing promotion of homosexuality of being motivated by anti-gay prejudice, and pledged to press on with attempts to scrap section 28.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday accused opponents of moves to abolish laws preventing promotion of homosexuality of being motivated by anti-gay prejudice, and pledged to press on with attempts to scrap section 28.

The political row over government attempts to repeal the legislation boiled over as a new legal opinion, released to the Guardian, concluded that section 28 will violate the human rights act, which comes into force in the autumn.

Solicitors Belmont Hodgson found the section, which states that local authorities must not "promote homosexuality" or promote teaching of homosexuality in schools "as a pretended family relationship", breaches the rights to freedom of expression and to privacy and respect for family life. Both are enshrined as articles 10 and eight in the European convention on human rights, which will be incorporated into British law on October 2.

The opinion comes a day after it emerged that another legal firm had also advised that schools would violate the right to privacy if they refused to allow pupils over 16 to have gay relationships. As private schools were left in confusion over the legal advice, the home secretary, Jack Straw, urged schools and other organisations not to panic over the implications of the human rights act.

However, lawyers suggested that his attempts to play down fears over the new legislation by claiming it was all about balancing "one right against another", did not take account of the force of human rights law.

Richard Campbell, of Belmont Hodgson, said: "It is true that the human rights act is fluid because its provisions have not yet been tested in court, but there are certain principles in European and English case law where the courts are willing to apply very rigorous rulings over human rights."

Legal debate over section 28 developed as the political row over the government's attempts to scrap the legislation spilled over at prime minister's questions in the Commons.

William Hague challenged Mr Blair to disclose whether he would abandon attempts to repeal the legislation if it were defeated again.

The prime minister said: "No, we remain committed to the repeal of it and we in particular remain absolutely set against the mischievous propaganda campaign run against this that has suggested that in some way by repealing clause 28 children in our schools are going to have their sex education lessons changed."

Since 1994, section 28 had not applied to schools in England and Wales, which set sex education policy according to governors, staff and parents, he said.

Schools would continue to set policy and parents would still have the right to withdraw children from sex education lessons.

Goaded by Mr Hague to drop "politically correct propaganda", the prime minister hit back. "The truth of the matter is that this campaign [against section 28 repeal] is based on people who don't want to come out and say they are prejudiced against gay people and so they hide behind the issue of child protection."

fields.headline: Good day, bad day
fields.trailText: Good day
fields.body:
Good day

Tom Brake. The Liberal Democrat MP has joined the ranks of major employers such as Boots and BT to become the first MP to win an Investors in People award. Since he only employs five people in his constituency office he now faces the problem that - as his own constituency MP in Carshalton and Wallington - he may have to present himself with his celebratory plaque.

Quote of day

Tory social security spokesman Eric Pickles, advocating new penalties on parents who persistently fail to pay child support. "What we are essentially saying to some body is: 'Well, I'm very sorry but you won't be able to go to Saturday afternoon football and that there will be no possibility of your pouring your earnings down your throat at the weekend and there's no possibility of you going out clubbing'."

Today

Trade and industry questions. Learning and skills bill, second reading. Lords: Financial services and markets bill, committee.

webTitle: Livingstone vows to recognise gay marriages

fields.headline: Livingstone vows to recognise gay marriages
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone, the leftwing candidate for London mayor, yesterday vowed to recognise gay marriages in the capital and said the Greater London authority would boycott homophobic companies.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone, the leftwing candidate for London mayor, yesterday vowed to recognise gay marriages in the capital and said the Greater London authority would boycott homophobic companies.

The planned contract ban could hit Stagecoach, the bus company owned by millionaire Brian Souter who has been funding the campaign in Scotland to keep section 28. Stagecoach has multi-million pound contracts with London buses.

In a pitch to London's large gay community, Mr Livingstone also claimed he would try to repeal section 28 banning the promotion of homosexuality in schools by local councils.

Mr Livinstone's aides said that other candidates for mayor, including Frank Dobson and Steve Norris, had recently backed an important extension of gay rights when they addressed a gay and lesbian election meeting at the National Film School.

They conceded that the GLA would have no legal powers to recognise same sex relationships, or provide gay partners with new legal rights. They also said the authority will have no powers over education and would therefore be unable to repeal section 28 unilaterally.

They nevertheless claimed a civic register for gay couples would have great symbolic importance and at least give gays a chance to celebrate their marriage with the official support of the GLA.

Defending his decision to boycott homophobic companies, Mr Livingstone said: "I will not tolerate companies that are commercially involved with the GLA if they display homophobia. I think Brian Souter's campaign in Scotland is homophobic. I would not countenance London buses becoming associated with that sort of cause."

It is not clear whether local councils are entitled to boycott companies because they are acting in a discriminatory way.

The Greater London Council in the 1980s ran a policy of contract compliance requiring its sub-contractors to recognise trades unions and give minorities full rights in the workforce. The Conservative government subsequently removed many of the powers and said that contracts should be handed out on strictly commercial basis.

The Home Office has formally opposed recognised same sex relationships although the European court of human rights has recently ruled that the partner in a same sex relationship can stay on in a tenancy if the other partner dies.

The Home Office has also recently accepted that a foreign partner who has been living with a British national for two years in a relationship "akin to marriage" can claim residency.

Many countries formally recognise same sex marriages giving partners rights to compensation and pensions.

Mr Livingstone's remarks came as Mr Norris, the Conservative mayoral candidate, said he is to marry Emma Courtney, the mother of his child, on Saturday week.

webTitle: Fury at Welsh minister's GM 'cave- in'

fields.headline: Fury at Welsh minister's GM 'cave- in'
fields.standfirst: GM food: special report
fields.trailText: The Welsh agriculture secretary, Christine Gwyther, came under attack from environmental campaigners and opposition members of the Welsh assembly last night after giving approval for a genetically modified form of forage maize to be placed on the UK national seed list.
fields.body:
The Welsh agriculture secretary, Christine Gwyther, came under attack from environmental campaigners and opposition members of the Welsh assembly last night after giving approval for a genetically modified form of forage maize to be placed on the UK national seed list.

The decision came only hours after the assembly's all- party agriculture and rural affairs committee had recommended that she should block the application and goes against Ms Gwyther's known personal wish to see Wales established as a GM free zone. Campaigners from Friends of the Earth Cymru accused her of collapsing under "massive pressure" from Westminster.

Welsh approval for the her bicide-resistant ChardonLL seed developed by the biotech company Aventis has no immediate practical implications because the industry has agreed a moratorium on commercial growing of GM crops until farm scale trials have been evaluated in 2003.

But opposition parties claim the decision represents a lost opportunity for devolved government in Wales to be seen to be doing something different.

There is also disquiet at the way in which the views of an assembly committee have again been ignored by the executive. The Liberal Democrat assembly leader, Mike German, said Labour had blatantly ignored the will of the assembly on GM crops.

Ms Gwyther, who six months ago was censured over her handling of the farming crisis in Wales, asked the committee to consider the Aventis application because of what she acknowledged to be widespread public interest. But after considering the committee's views and legal and professional advice she announced yesterday that the only "reasonable, legal way forward" was for the application to be approved.

Friends of the Earth condemned the move as setting a terrible precedent. ChardonLL was the first GM seed to approach the market and it was unlikely that others now on their way would be looked into in as much detail.

The Liberal Democrat leader claimed Labour was holding the assembly in contempt: "If Labour had no choice but to agree the licence then they should have come clean and made the decision weeks ago."

webTitle: Deal to end student fees inequality

fields.headline: Deal to end student fees inequality
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Scottish executive took a further step yesterday to damp down unrest over tuition fees by removing one of several anomalies that are disadvantaging students from England, Wales and Northern Ireland at universities in Scotland.
fields.body:
The Scottish executive took a further step yesterday to damp down unrest over tuition fees by removing one of several anomalies that are disadvantaging students from England, Wales and Northern Ireland at universities in Scotland.

For those starting courses from 2001, no fee will be charged for the final year of a four-year course. This will remove a financial obstacle for undergraduates from south of the border where degree courses usually last for three years.

The proposals were agreed by education ministers in Scotland and England on the recommendation of a committee under the banker, Sir George Quigley. When the fees were introduced in 1998, Scottish and EU students were exempted from the fourth year, but undergraduates from other parts of the UK were told they would have to pay.

That anomaly was overtaken by another when the Scottish executive agreed in January to scrap up-front tuition fees for Scottish students at Scottish universities from the start of the next academic year.

Vice-chancellors in Scotland and England last night welcomed the latest concession that would "protect the flow of students across the border to Scotland, and with it a significant income stream (and) diversity in Scottish higher education".

Last year about 20% of the 31,216 students starting courses at Scottish universities were from England, Wales or Northern Ireland.

Henry McLeish, the Scottish enterprise and lifelong learning minister, said there was little evidence that students from south of the border were put off by the fourth-year fee. "Nevertheless, Scottish universities and colleges were very keen to remove any disincentives."

Tuition fee income will be cut by £2m, but the net cost after administrative savings will be about £500,000.

John Swinney, SNP shadow enterprise and lifelong learning minister, said it was a humiliating U-turn for Labour. The Quigley committee was the second independent review to recommend overturning Labour policy.

fields.headline: New-look Lords rediscover old powers
fields.standfirst:
Far from becoming 'Tony's cronies', the upper house has found fresh vigour after reform

Lords reform: special report
fields.trailText: The law of unintended political consequences has been working overtime in the House of Lords since all but 92 of the hereditary peers were expelled from their 700-year tenancy with minimal ceremony on November 11. As the government is due tomorrow to announce a new raft of working peers the Lords are once again in sharp focus - and the Blairites don't particularly like what they see.
fields.body:
The law of unintended political consequences has been working overtime in the House of Lords since all but 92 of the hereditary peers were expelled from their 700-year tenancy with minimal ceremony on November 11. As the government is due tomorrow to announce a new raft of working peers the Lords are once again in sharp focus - and the Blairites don't particularly like what they see.

Since the 1999-2000 session of parliament opened the government has been defeated 10 times. This was not what ministers had in mind when they purged the old aristocracy. Far from becoming the obliging "Tony's cronies" upper chamber which critics predicted, the truncated Lords have been enjoying a distinct revival of morale.

They have even claimed that Labour's stage one reform has re-legitimised their status as a revising chamber with powers they have barely dared to use for 90 years since their powers were decisively clipped after the battle over Lloyd-George's budget in 1910-11. Ministers have routinely been taunted by the likes of Lord Onslow, a Tory 7th earl, who was one of the 75 peers elected - admittedly only by fellow peers - to stay on pending the long-term stage two reform promised by Tony Blair and Lord Wakeham's three-option royal commission. It has not prevented Lord Onslow from protesting that no party has a majority in the Lords and that the 666 peers left after the Blairite cull can exercise independent judgment in a way that the cowed New Labour majority in the Commons rarely does.

His party leader, Lord Strathclyde, says much the same. He constantly quotes the leader of the Lords, Lady Jay, as saying that the half-reformed Lords is "more legitimate" than the old, hereditary Lords.

Doctrine

It follows, says Lord Strathclyde, that they can exercise dormant powers including the right to reject secondary legislation - statutory instruments in the jargon - which peers have passed on the nod since 1945 when Lord Salisbury enunciated the doctrine that bears his name: that peers would not reject at second reading bills specified in the election manifesto of a winning party, in his case Clement Attlee's Labour team (1945-51).

Strathclyde says the Salisbury doctrine is dead, replaced by what he mischievously calls the Jay doctrine - that the Lords are "more legitimate". The numbers tell much of the story. Instead of the 1,100 peers in the old Lords, most of them Tory by conviction or declared allegiance, there are 232 who take the Conservative whip. Labour has 182 peers, the Liberal Democrats have 54, the crossbenches 161.

There are still 26 bishops, plus 11 odds and sods including Lord Tim Beaumont, who left the Lib Dems for the Greens. "That means that the Liberal Democrats and the crossbenchers decide any given issue," says one Lib Dem peer. On the government's plans to curb the right to trial by jury they voted against Jack Straw - and won. But on section 28 they backed the government - and lost.

Why ? A refined version of the new order states that the crossbenchers decide. "The political parties strut their stuff, but the real jury are the crossbench peers," said a worldly Tory peer.

In theory Downing Street is committed to stage two reform and there have been hints that Mr Blair favours the most modest of Lord Wakeham's options, 65 peers indirectly elected from regional top-up lists, or 87 elected directly in the European list model. The rest would be appointed in the manner of life peers, albeit via an independent vetting system that would retain balance and ensure no one has an overall majority. Tories and other sceptics believe Mr Blair will happily settle for the current compromise - though it has not proved a happy one so far.

Backstairs gossip

Meanwhile the government is poised to appoint new "working peers" . All the backstairs gossip has focused on the Tory party treasurer, Michael Ashcroft, and whether or not he has been blackballed, or even nominated. But Labour will nominate 19 more peers, the Tories will get four and (to their fury) the Lib Dems nine, less than they think they deserve if they are to get a roughly proportionate share. All sides will whinge, not least because Mr Blair's efforts to restore Labour's depleted stock of peers, so many old, so many ill, so many unBlairite, has hit a recurring problem.

If you want to appoint smart movers and shakers, active men and women in their 40s and 50s, how can you expect them to turn up and voted at funny hours?

Labour has shot a much-loved Tory fox, the reactionary backwoodsmen who, as Labour legend had it, were dragged from their clubs to vote against progress. Life without them is tougher than expected.

Flexing muscles
The 10 defeats for Blair

Government defeats in the Lords this year:

January 20: Right to trial by jury upheld by 222-126 votes. The normally loyal Labour peer, Lady Kennedy QC, led opposition to government proposals.

February 7: Ban on promoting the teaching of homosexuality upheld by 210-165 votes. Tory Lady Young spearheaded the campaign for retention.

February 22: Motion amended to allow candidates for election to London mayor and GLA to have election addresses sent out free carried by 215-150 votes.

February 22: Government's rules for London elections overturned by 206-143.

March 9: Local authorities right to reject "super committee" model for town hall structures upheld by 144-82 votes.

March 14: After Ripon parents ballot to save local grammar, peers vote to scrap future ballots by 166-161. Conservative Lady Blatch led calls for government to back down.

March 23: New sex education guidelines for teachers defeated by 190 votes to 175.

March 23: Government also defeated as peers vote to allow the new learning and skills council to spend more on expensive courses for the over-16s. Voting was 173 to 127.

March 23: In third defeat on learning and skills bill peers vote by 157 to 142 to ensure that the new youth careers service, would not "adversely affect the quantity or quality" of existing information.

March 28: Peers vote by 162-132 to require the same regulatory standards for private homes and hospitals as for NHS ones.

Doctrine It follows, says Lord Strathclyde, that they can exercise dormant powers including the right to reject secondary legislation - statutory instruments in the jargon - which peers have passed on the nod since 1945 when Lord Salisbury enunciated the doctrine that bears his name: that peers would not reject at second reading bills specified in the election manifesto of a winning party, in his case Clement Attlee's Labour team (1945-51). Strathclyde says the Salisbury doctrine is dead, replaced by what he mischievously calls the Jay doctrine - that the Lords are "more legitimate". The numbers tell much of the story. Instead of the 1,100 peers in the old Lords, most of them Tory by conviction or declared allegiance, there are 232 who take the Conservative whip. Labour has 182 peers, the Liberal Democrats have 54, the crossbenches 161. There are still 26 bishops, plus 11 odds and sods including Lord Tim Beaumont, who left the Lib Dems for the Greens. "That means that the Liberal Democrats and the crossbenchers decide any given issue," says one Lib Dem peer. On the government's plans to curb the right to trial by jury they voted against Jack Straw - and won. But on section 28 they backed the government - and lost. Why ? A refined version of the new order states that the crossbenchers decide. "The political parties strut their stuff, but the real jury are the crossbench peers," said a worldly Tory peer. In theory Downing Street is committed to stage two reform and there have been hints that Mr Blair favours the most modest of Lord Wakeham's options, 65 peers indirectly elected from regional top-up lists, or 87 elected directly in the European list model. The rest would be appointed in the manner of life peers, albeit via an independent vetting system that would retain balance and ensure no one has an overall majority. Tories and other sceptics believe Mr Blair will happily settle for the current compromise - though it has not proved a happy one so far. Backstairs gossip Meanwhile the government is poised to appoint new "working peers" . All the backstairs gossip has focused on the Tory party treasurer, Michael Ashcroft, and whether or not he has been blackballed, or even nominated. But Labour will nominate 19 more peers, the Tories will get four and (to their fury) the Lib Dems nine, less than they think they deserve if they are to get a roughly proportionate share. All sides will whinge, not least because Mr Blair's efforts to restore Labour's depleted stock of peers, so many old, so many ill, so many unBlairite, has hit a recurring problem. If you want to appoint smart movers and shakers, active men and women in their 40s and 50s, how can you expect them to turn up and voted at funny hours? Labour has shot a much-loved Tory fox, the reactionary backwoodsmen who, as Labour legend had it, were dragged from their clubs to vote against progress. Life without them is tougher than expected. Flexing muscles The 10 defeats for Blair Government defeats in the Lords this year: January 20: Right to trial by jury upheld by 222-126 votes. The normally loyal Labour peer, Lady Kennedy QC, led opposition to government proposals. February 7: Ban on promoting the teaching of homosexuality upheld by 210-165 votes. Tory Lady Young spearheaded the campaign for retention. February 22: Motion amended to allow candidates for election to London mayor and GLA to have election addresses sent out free carried by 215-150 votes. February 22: Government's rules for London elections overturned by 206-143. March 9: Local authorities right to reject "super committee" model for town hall structures upheld by 144-82 votes. March 14: After Ripon parents ballot to save local grammar, peers vote to scrap future ballots by 166-161. Conservative Lady Blatch led calls for government to back down. March 23: New sex education guidelines for teachers defeated by 190 votes to 175. March 23: Government also defeated as peers vote to allow the new learning and skills council to spend more on expensive courses for the over-16s. Voting was 173 to 127. March 23: In third defeat on learning and skills bill peers vote by 157 to 142 to ensure that the new youth careers service, would not "adversely affect the quantity or quality" of existing information. March 28: Peers vote by 162-132 to require the same regulatory standards for private homes and hospitals as for NHS ones.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst:
Send letters to online.feedback@guardian.co.uk.
Please include a full postal address and telephone number. Short letters stand a better chance of being published. No attachments, please.
fields.trailText: Your mail
fields.body:
Hardest hit
Your article on Napster (March 16) is a good summary of the debate surrounding the unprecedented access some are now allowing to copyright music.

Surely, though, it is not beyond anyone's imagination to see that free access to music is not a model for ensuring our music creators continue to produce good quality music in the future.

Often forgotten in the frenzied debate about the music business revolution are the people at the core of the creative process - the composers, songwriters and music publishers which British Music Rights represents. Copyright protects their interests and ensures they receive proper payment for their work - it keeps good creators creating more.

Ironically, when individuals trade copyright music for free, they harm the individuals whose work they admire the most. Music isn't free - it does have a value, and there is a long term cost to society of ignoring that value.

Frances Lowe

Director General, British Music Rights

Still snooping

Paul Trueman (March 23) seems to think that one can use one's free ISP's mail server for outgoing mail. I advise him to have a look at the MAPS RSS or ORBS.

Also, any half decent company with internet access will have firewalls, probably preventing outgoing POP3 email connections and making sure outgoing HTTP goes through a proxy, and so it could be blocked or logged.

There is even a problem connecting a modem to a PC in most offices, especially those which use digital PBXs, and so need special handsets.

Matthew Byng-Maddick

mbm@colondot.net

Fighting on
Mylene van Noort's article on queer sites online was interesting - but not all sites are as commercial as you might expect from her piece.

There is a vast amount of campaigning and organisation on the web. Delga's site has been up since 1996, making us one of the oldest gay campaigning sites in the UK.

Mark Ynys-Mon

Delga (Liberal Democrats for Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender Equality)

TV email hope
Warren Newman (Feedback, March 23) wonders what will happen to attachments to email received through interactive TV.

I imagine that companies will provide server-based viewers for all common file formats - you could see Word documents, hear music, maybe even see video, all via attachments to your email!

Maybe we really are moving towards Larry Ellison's net computer revolution...

Moray McConnachie

cerberus@herald.ox.ac.uk

Warren Newman has missed the point.

If he receives an email with an attached document authored in Microsoft Word, he should simply ask the sender to resend the text in a more universal format, such as rich text, which the set top box should be able to translate and display.

Really, on a platform-inspecific medium such as the internet, file formats that are so exclusive to one package and platform, however "standard", should not be used.

Thomas McIntosh

thomas.mcintosh@argonet.co.uk

My Sky email system also has the distinct disadvantage that the user must go on-line before being able to access the email software.

This means that the user is paying BT local rate + 1p per minute while composing and typing correspondence.

A nice little earner in the short-term, one imagines, but hardly likely to do much for Sky's longer term ISP market share.

Chris Jackson

chris@cj-associates.co.uk

fields.headline: Wonder web
fields.standfirst: Danny Brown is a creative technologist at internet consultancy Amaze and is behind the Noodlebox on the website
fields.trailText: Danny Brown is a creative technologist at internet consultancy Amaze and is behind the Noodlebox on the website
fields.body:
What new challenges does the internet give to designers? One of the biggest problems with internet sites today is that they don't help the user. Websites as a whole are geared towards people who are willing to work at a slow pace and wait for pages to load. A few years ago that was a technology issue whereas now it's more of a design issue.

Could you explain the Noodlebox part of the Amaze website? Noodlebox was me setting myself an agenda to look at the technology from an absolutely empty space and then see what I can do with it. The purpose of the project was not the little rooms themselves, rather the way all the rooms are strung together in a truly immersive environment. One other feature is that the loading screens, while something's being done with the network, always have something random moving around them - so you have a much more televisual feel.

How would you say the net has changed since you started using it? Not enough. The technology has changed beyond all doubt and the bandwidth has changed - though not that much. But there are accepted web "standards" with regard to design, such as frames and spinning-buttons etc, where there's no real technical reason to keep doing those things. There was a period in about 94/95 when people were saying that the future would be plug-ins. Now, if you look at the penetration of these things, it's actually going down as the average new user is using an "out of the box" installation.

How do you see the net evolving? I'm very dubious of Wap. Why would I want to use my mobile phone as an information network when I'd much rather just phone someone up and ask them? With regard to the future of internet design, I think there's a real need to look at interface and navigation. A much more interesting role for the interface is for it to look at what I'm actually trying to achieve as one whole process.

Any favourite websites? I believe there are very few websites worth using. I'm sure there are a lot of people like myself who don't want to look at boring screens of information or spend all day looking round for something. At the moment web-pages are aimed at someone who's willing to surf around. What happens if someone doesn't want to learn the interface of a site? What if they just want to get something done? Saying that, for industry stuff I like NinfoMania and Sabre Magazine. Other good sites are Colors Magazine as it's not just an online copy of the magazine. Creation Records has elegant design and branding. For seamless integration of the branding between site and product there's the WipeOut3. For fun/wacky sites there's Kid Koala sound toy and NetBabyworld.

 See Noodlebox at: www.amaze.com/noodlebox

fields.headline: What's new
fields.standfirst: No home is complete without a fridge linked to the internet and a robot vaccum cleaner - or so  Ashley Norris is told at the Electrical Retailing Show
fields.trailText: No home is complete without a fridge linked to the internet and a robot vaccum cleaner - or so Ashley Norris is told at the Electrical Retailing Show
fields.body:
There are many exciting exhibitions in the Online journalist's (electronic) diary. The year kicks off with CES , the Consumer Electronics Show, in Las Vegas - an Aladdin's cave of gadgets so dazzling they even put the City's glorious light-shows in the shade.

In February comes the jaunt to CeBit in Hanover, an exhibition so enormous it almost spans three different countries.

But the most exotic location is saved until last. For in March trainloads of hi-tech hacks descend on Birmingham's NEC for the Electrical Retailing Show.

OK, so it might not be able to compete with Vegas' glamour or Hanover's size, but it rivals the Commercial Vehicle Show for the title of the NEC's biggest attraction for that week. And, to be fair, there are a lot of White Van Men out there.

The show, which has been going for five years, actually pulls in large numbers of the country's consumer electronics dealers. They come not only to compare notes on microwave oven promotions, but also eager to find out what they'll be filling their shelves with later in the year.

So what do the people at the sharp end really make of the product the makers insist will change our lives? We asked a bunch of dealers from all over the UK what they really thought about this year's hottest gizmos.

LG's Internet fridge

When's it due? Sometime in 2001. It's expected to cost around £5,000

The hype: It's a large American style cool-box featuring a mini PC and screen. Not only can you use it to surf the net (see www.coolfridge.com ), shoot video messages and play MP3 music files, it also helps out with your shopping. By touching its screen you can find out what food is in the fridge and how long before it starts going mouldy. In theory, every time you run out of milk, it could also email the supermarket, which would oblige by whizzing over a pint of semi-skimmed.

The reaction: The fridge was the undoubted star of the show. But will anyone buy it? One Leeds based dealer thought he knew of a few footballers who would be well up for it. Others weren't so sure. "This fridge is not likely to be bought by a family man. The geeks who'll be impressed by this sort of thing don't tend to have girlfriends let alone large families," he said with a smirk.

What the dealers really want: A fridge that instantly chills warm beer.

Vivanco's MP3 player

When's it due? In the next couple of months, priced at £130.

The hype: The world's smallest MP3 player. It can even hide behind a postage stamp.

The reaction: Shaun Barrett of the wonderfully named Barrett's Digital World in Canterbury was quick to see the product's potential. "This is toys for the boys stuff. There are blokes out there who'll think nothing of spending £130 just to say that they own the world's smallest player."

Others thought its size might be its downfall. "People are always losing their personal MD and tape players. The only way they'll keep hold of this is to have it surgically inserted into their body," quipped a Liverpool-based dealer.

What the dealers really want: An MP3 player they understand. Preferably one that doesn't have to go anywhere near a PC.

Sharp 28-inch widescreen LCD TV

When's it due? End of the year. Estimates in price range from between £7-9000

The hype: The clearest, brightest TV picture of all time. It makes even those hang-on-the-wall gas plasma models look like they are replaying grainy pictures broadcast 60 years ago from Ally Pally.

The reaction: Almost universal acclaim for its picture quality. One dealer was so engrossed in a Japanese promo film of a flower show you'd think he was watching an Oscar-laden epic. Simon Hughes, a dealer from Lowestoft, Suffolk confidently predicted that "in seven years time all TVs will look like this".

What the dealers really want: This product priced at £200 with built in digital TV decoder and surround sound.

Toshiba SD900E DVD-Audio Player

When's it due? Late summer sporting a price tag of around £1,300.

The hype: It'll soon be time to ditch your CD player. This not only plays standard CDs and DVD movies, but also playback discs mixed for DVD-Audio. This new format has a significantly higher frequency capability and wider dynamic range than standard audio CDs.

The reaction: Not entirely a crowd-pleaser. "It might persuade some of these so-called golden-eared hi-fi types to buy a DVD player," suggested one dealer. Others thought that the impending format war with Super Audio CD - and the way in which the British public seemed perfectly happy with the sound of CDs - would prevent it from ever going mass-market.

What the dealers really want: "If I had a pound for everyone who's asked for a DVD recorder that also plays back American discs, I'd probably own half of South ern England," said a London dealer.

Dyson DC06 Robot vacuum cleaner

When's it due? Late summer for around £2,500

The hype: The world's first commercially available robot vacuum cleaner. The processing power of several PCs enables it to move methodically through your house, disposing of the dust. If it's given any grief by Fido or Tiddles, it plays dead for 30 seconds before continuing its chores.

The reaction: "This is straight out of Absolutely Fabulous," proclaimed one south-coast dealer. "You can just picture some rich London housewife flicking through Harper's & Queens while this robot whizzes under their feet picking up crumbs from last nights dinner party."

What the dealers really want: A robot that also cooks, does the washing-up and looks after the kids. If it's female, blonde, of Scandinavian origin, and taking a year out before university, so much the better.
