fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: Not even the combination of an almost unanimous Opec deal to boost oil output and a bouncy opening of the Dow Jones on Wall Street was enough to drag the London market out of the doldrums. Volumes were better than earlier in the week without being startling, but the market could not shake off its recent lacklustre tone, ending above its worst for the day but still 51.3 points down at 6,598.8.
fields.body:
Not even the combination of an almost unanimous Opec deal to boost oil output and a bouncy opening of the Dow Jones on Wall Street was enough to drag the London market out of the doldrums. Volumes were better than earlier in the week without being startling, but the market could not shake off its recent lacklustre tone, ending above its worst for the day but still 51.3 points down at 6,598.8.

Traders pointed to an absence of company news and the willingness of fund managers to sit on the sidelines as the first quarter draws to a close - both familiar themes of late - for the lack of real excitement. Nor was the news from the US entirely beneficial. Although the Dow was up 90 points by the close in London the "new economy" Nasdaq index was down 44 points.

Among the technology stocks to be affected by Nasdaq's decline were Baltimore , down 601p to £95.97, Psion , 195p lower at £46.00, and Freeserve, 35p off at 510p. Misys , however, stood out from the trend, adding 46p to 963p, helped by a "strong buy" recommendation from Warburg Dillon Read.

The investment bank's repetition of its earlier "buy" advice on Reed International helped the shares climb 16p to 466p.

The outcome of the Opec meeting in Vienna helped the big oil stocks with Shell up 9p at 485p and BP Amoco 8p higher at 522p.

BSkyB was in the spotlight with news of its £340m placing to help fund acquisition of a stake in the Kirch pay-TV channel in Germany. The shares lost 165p to £17.98.

Embattled stores group Somerfield had a rough ride after revealing that talks about a possible takeover had been called off. The shares fell to a low of 51p before rallying slightly to end down 4p at 57p.

Also in the stores sector, Safeway lost 8p to 193p

Among engineers, GKN lost ground, slipping 64p to 761p but Rolls-Royce rallied 8p to 200p.

Scottish & Newcastle put on 22p to 445p, helped by Tuesday's pub sales, and Rio Tinto was back in favour, picking up 27p to close at £10.15

The utilities sector continued to attract interest in the wake of the bid approach for Hyder earlier in the week. Pennon , for example, put on 13p to 503p.

Among the telecom stocks, BT lost 19p to £12.22 and Vodafone AirTouch lost 8p at 355p after Oftel said again that the two companies continued to wield influence in the mobile phone market and must continue to allow network access to other service providers.

fields.headline: BAA
fields.trailText: The stock market does not like profits warnings. Just ask BAA. Last October the company's shares got a clattering when the group disclosed that the impact of the abolition of duty free sales within the European Union had been worse than it expected. In just six sessions BAA's market capitalisation had shrunk by 25%.
fields.body:
The stock market does not like profits warnings. Just ask BAA. Last October the company's shares got a clattering when the group disclosed that the impact of the abolition of duty free sales within the European Union had been worse than it expected. In just six sessions BAA's market capitalisation had shrunk by 25%.

Yesterday the market believed it had got a whiff of another warning, albeit a veiled one. The story doing the rounds was that, at a dinner for analysts on Tuesday night, the company let slip that it was trying to make up for fall-off in duty free revenues by way of higher charges on airlines and that the airlines were disinclined to play ball.

The result was predictable. Before BAA had time to scramble its damage limitation teams, the shares had slumped more than 10%.

Understandably the company was not best pleased at the post-prandial fall-out, not least because it had been at pains when it released third-quarter figures in January to try to reassure the market that it was recovering from the duty free blow.

Profits warning? "Certainly not" was the firm response. BAA was "very confident" that this year's results would be in line with expectations. What appears to have happened is that, far from warning about profits, BAA merely indicated that in its negotiations with the airlines it would probably have to cede a little ground. Hardly the stuff of shock, horror headlines.

As one analyst who was at the dinner put it yesterday, BAA had said nothing new. Therein lies the rub. BAA could do with some good news, rather than reassurances that there is no more bad news. Earlier this month the shares hit a seven-year low of 342p compared with the 615p at which they stood a little over six months ago.

Yesterday's clarification did enough to help the shares receive a little lost ground, leaving them down 35.75p at 392.75p. But it will need rather more if the shares are to break significantly higher.

fields.headline: UK tardy in bribery battle
fields.trailText: Britain is being urged to toughen its laws against companies offering bribes to win foreign contracts amid accusations that it lags other industrialised countries in implementing a global anti-corruption deal.
fields.body:
Britain is being urged to toughen its laws against companies offering bribes to win foreign contracts amid accusations that it lags other industrialised countries in implementing a global anti-corruption deal.

A committee at the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development says the UK is not in compliance with the agreement and wants the government to enact appropriate legislation "as a matter of priority".

The OECD convention to combat bribery, signed by then trade minister Lord Clinton Davies in December 1997, makes it a crime to offer, promise or give a bribe to a foreign public official in order to obtain or retain international business deals.

The convention commits signatories to adopt common rules to punish offenders. Twenty countries have ratified the pact.

But Britain is the only one not to have adopted its legislation, despite UK firms featuring on the World Bank's list of companies banned from receiving contracts for violating its anti-fraud and corruption rules.

Like others that have ratified the convention, Britain has undergone detailed examination by its peers at the OECD to see if UK law is strong enough to enforce it. The review group is understood to have concluded that "it is not in a position to determine that the UK laws are in compliance" with convention and detected a reluctance on the part of the government to address the problem.

"Patience is wearing a little bit thin," said an OECD source.

Countries such as Korea, whose "crony capitalism" was blamed for the Asian financial crisis, are understood to have been judged more favourably than the UK.

Anti-bribery experts say Britain's perceived foot-dragging might be due to a misplaced desire to protect British business interests.

"It could be a reluctance to disadvantage UK plc, a view which in the light of modern concepts of corporate gover nance, which emphasise the importance of good reputation, looks distinctly old fashioned." said Graham Rodmell, coordinator of the UK chapter of Transparency International, a non-governmental organisation that campaigns against corruption.

Mark Pieth, who chairs the OECD working group on bribery, said one reason why some countries had been slow to adopt laws to abide by the convention was they wanted to protect their arms traders, for whom 30% "commission" payments to win contracts were common. "It's a lot of money, billions of pounds."

Britain has argued that existing laws, based on the Prevention of Corruption Act 1906, are sufficient to comply with the convention. But there has yet to be a successful prosecution under that legislation.

Civil sevants have been conducting a review of the law but Transparency International believes any new legislation is unlikely before 2001-02.

A Department of Trade and Industry spokesman said: "The UK is prepared to prosecute anyone who commits and offence within the UK jurisdiction and it is prepared to extradite nationals for offences committed abroad.

"But we are not complacent and we recognise that legislation can be modernised, and the Home Office is expected to publish a consultation document in May."

webTitle: Tate & Lyle sours to a 10-year low

fields.headline: Tate & Lyle sours to a 10-year low
fields.trailText: Life is far from sweet for Tate & Lyle's investors - a profits warning sent the sugar group's shares tumbling to their lowest level for 10 years yesterday morning.
fields.body:
Life is far from sweet for Tate & Lyle's investors - a profits warning sent the sugar group's shares tumbling to their lowest level for 10 years yesterday morning.

They later recovered some ground, closing down 10p at 217p, but there was little comfort in the detail of the trading statement.

Tate & Lyle's biggest headache is in the United States, where the company said the sugar market has "deteriorated significantly" since November.

Prices of beet and cane sugar are at their lowest point since 1979, following an unusually large harvest and an influx of cheap supply from Mexico.

A swift recovery is unlikely - the American market has traditionally been heavily regulated, but there is a growing feeling that the system intended to keep prices steady is not working. Any liberalisation of the regime could depress prices further.

Tate & Lyle's response has been to begin a "strategic review" of the business, holding out the possibility of a withdrawal from US production. The problem is that buyers will be hard to find - the market is unattractive and unlikely to change in the near future. US sugar production is relatively small for Tate & Lyle, comprising about 12% of its assets.

However, it has joined a number of other factors in producing a somewhat sluggish performance.

Low prices have meant a tough time for Tate's Australian operations and higher net corn costs have hit margins at Staley, the group's cereals and starch business.

Tate & Lyle is keen to concentrate on manufacturing operations where it can add value, such as Staley. These are less vulnerable to swings in commodity prices.

In an unusually active period the group has made £90m of disposals in the last six months. More are likely, and there is a chance of a return of cash to shareholders.

But the climate is tricky - one analyst said: "Any bad news from food companies is greeted with hostility, while good news is greeted with indifference." Broker ABN Amro cut its forecast for full-year profits from £216m to £200m, and tough times seem likely to continue.

fields.headline: Irn-Bru invasion
fields.standfirst: Scottish soft drink heads south
fields.trailText: Scottish soft drink Irn-Bru is heading south with a multi-million pound marketing push planned by manufacturer AG Barr to convince the English of its qualities.
fields.body:
Scottish soft drink Irn-Bru is heading south with a multi-million pound marketing push planned by manufacturer AG Barr to convince the English of its qualities.

Known for its potency as a hangover cure, Irn-Bru has a 25% share of the Scottish fizzy drinks mar ket but just 0.8% south of the border.

AG Barr chairman Robin Barr said: "It has a bit of a cult following. Our primary ambition is to turn Irn-Bru from a niche brand into a mainstream one."

The Glasgow-based company, which also makes Tizer and Orangina, intends to launch its first na tional television advertising campaign for Irn-Bru.

Mr Barr said: "We've never had any sort of steady pattern before: it's been one thing one year, something else the next. We're going to really address the thing with some assiduous attention and money."

AG Barr has committed "several million" pounds to the project, with a target of doubling Irn-Bru's share of the English market to 1.6%. This would put it level with Dr Pepper, and just behind orange-flavoured Tango.

Mr Barr was speaking as AG Barr announced a 1% increase in annual profits to £12.1m. Excluding the effect of a property sale and early redemption of a bank loan, underlying profits rose 6.2%. Volume sales of Irn-Bru rose 8%, including a 16% jump in England.

Irn-Bru's last big assault on the English market used the slogan "made in Scotland, from girders". This was dropped 12 years ago because it was unpopular south of the border.

Mr Barr said: "It was an absolute turn-off for people in England. It conjured up a kind of hard, red Clydeside football rowdy. It was a very aggressive image."

Irn-Bru is now promoted using much more "quirky" humour. Mr Barr said the target market would be 13- to 18-year-olds.

webTitle: Minister says EU rules prevent intervention in ferry bid

fields.headline: Minister says EU rules prevent intervention in ferry bid
fields.trailText: Defence secretary Geoffrey Hoon has warned northern MPs that he is unable legally to prevent a £300m MoD contract for roll-on, roll-off ferries going abroad.
fields.body:
Defence secretary Geoffrey Hoon has warned northern MPs that he is unable legally to prevent a £300m MoD contract for roll-on, roll-off ferries going abroad.

Unions fear the contract's loss would sound the death knell for one or two shipyards on the Tyne or at Harland and Wolff in Belfast.

Mr Hoon told the "northern group" last night that under EU competition law he was required to put out the contract to open tender. The ferries were classified as a civilian order since most of the time they would be used for civilian purposes, he said.

Mr Hoon fears he cannot shape the contracts so they remain in Britain; he can only insist the ferries are available for use by the MoD within a specified deadline.

The ship unions are furious about claims made by a MoD spokesman that British yards did not have the skills to build the ferries.

Ken Curren, the GMB northern secretary, described the comments as scandalous. "British workers expect the support of the government. They do not expect their government to be briefing against them and in favour of French and German competitors. If ministers do not get to grips with this issue it will become this government's Westland."

The MoD criticism came as the yards were making bids for huge overseas orders in the Philippines for ro-ro ferries. It is understood defence ministers are deeply unhappy at the public criticisms made by their officials and that they had no prior notice of them.

Unions accused the government of "breathtaking ignorance"and demanded an immediate meeting with Mr Hoon. Alan Robson, general secretary of the Confederation of Shipbuilding and Engineering Unions, called on the government for an immediate re traction of comments which suggested none of Britain's shipyards was able to build the six ferries the MoD wants to order as troop transporters.

Mr Robson said Mr Hoon should initiate an internal MoD inquiry if the official's statement had been issued without his authority.

The MoD told the Guardian that no UK shipyard had built a ro-ro ship for 20 years, but it is only 10 years since such a vessel was built at Govan in Scotland, for example.

Industry executives point out that British yards have been building sophisticated vessels such as cruise ships compared with which ro-ro ferries are simple exercises.

Jamie Webster, GMB convenor at Govan, said that while unions had no problem with smart procurement policies, the decision to build the ships under the private finance initiative was "ludicrous."

"We are the only country which plays to the rules on these things," Mr Webster said.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Merrill recruits Adair Turner
fields.body:
Merrill recruits Adair Turner

Adair Turner, former director general of the Confederation of British Industry, has been appointed a vice-president of Merrill Lynch Europe with responsibility for developing the investment bank's relations with companies and governments. He will also be a member of the firm's wider European leadership team. Since leaving the CBI at the end of last year, Mr Turner has picked up a non-executive directorship of United News and Media and is also involved with a dot.com company. But he has decided not to take up a job offer at Schroders following its merger with Salomon Smith Barney Citibank.

Fall in new car prices slows

The fall in new car prices is beginning to slow, according to the Alliance & Leicester index which yesterday showed a 1% drop in the year to February compared with a fall of 3.3% to January. Family cars bucked the trend, rising 2.9%, but small, "city" cars showed a 14.1% drop in prices. "This sector is least affected by fleet sales and probably the category which reflects the pruchasing patterns of private car buyers the most," said A&L.

But the index reveals that the "rip-off Britain" campaign is also hitting prices of nearly new cars, which fell by 18.5% last year, while three-year-old cars are selling for 18% less than a year ago. Worst hit are second-hand small cars, fetching prices 23% lower than a year ago.

Belfast aerospace company Bombardier is in line for a jobs boost after its Canadian parent moved closer to clinching a deal for the largest regional aircraft order in history. The Toronto-based company announced yesterday it had signed letters of intent for a £1.25bn deal to supply 94 jets to two subsidiaries of Delta Air Lines. The agreement includes options on a further 406 aircraft. Important elements of the aircraft are built in Belfast where a spokesman said the "great news" was likely to increase employment on the production line, which has 600 staff.

Oil company British Borneo yesterday agreed to a 70p per share (£263m), cash bid from Agip Ventures, a division of Italian oil firm Eni.

The company, which struggled last year against a rock-bottom oil price, effectively put itself up for sale earlier this year. The recommended bid offers a 40% premium to yesterday's British Borneo closing price.

fields.headline: Crude measure of Democrat hopes
fields.standfirst: Opec's decision to increase oil production reveals its still critical role in US politics
fields.trailText: Every politician knows that oil matters. Cheap oil helped to create the golden age of social democracy in the 1950s and 1960s; expensive oil in the 1970s killed it off. Careers have been made and broken by the fluctuations in the price of a barrel of crude.
fields.body:
Every politician knows that oil matters. Cheap oil helped to create the golden age of social democracy in the 1950s and 1960s; expensive oil in the 1970s killed it off. Careers have been made and broken by the fluctuations in the price of a barrel of crude.

As such, it is not hard to guess who is breathing the biggest sigh of relief after Opec decided to take the heat out of rising fuel prices by increasing production: Al Gore. Bill Clinton's vice-president knows the race for the White House with Republican George W Bush is going to be a close-run thing and that he can only slip seamlessly into the Oval office if Americans continue to experience the warm glow of the feelgood factor.

Gore's boss did the talking for him yesterday, calling the decision by Opec to lift production by 1.45m barrels a day a "positive development". Clinton added: "These increases will help sustain worldwide economic growth and provide greater balance between oil supply and demand."

What he should perhaps have added is that they also increase the chances of a third successive Democrat presidential election victory in November - the first time this has happened since Franklin Roosevelt and Harry Truman won five in a row between 1932 and 1948. Gore understands from his experience of being Clinton's running mate in 1992 against Bush's father that a sharply higher oil price can tip countries over into recession.

The message for presidential hopefuls is the same now as it was then: It's the economy, stupid.

Given the recent strength of the US economy there is little chance of a recession this side of the November election, even in the event of a sudden and dramatic turn for the worse.

But the US has already drawn down heavily on its reserves during the winter, and prices at the pump have started to rise sharply - just at the time demand is picking up for the summer "driving season" when Americans take to their gas-guzzling vehicles and head off into the wilds. Motorists, already unhappy about higher fuel prices, will be even less well disposed towards Gore if the rising cost of energy pushes up inflation in America's already overheating economy and forces the Federal Reserve into pushing up borrowing costs.

More than anything else the White House needed to buy Gore time, and that is what yesterday's deal has probably done. But it may not have won him that long a breathing space, with Charles Dumas of Lombard Street Research warning yesterday that output would match "global needs this spring, but will increasingly fall short of it from this summer, so that existing serious inventory shortages could worsen soon".

It remains to be seen whether oil prices will come back to haunt Gore just as the presidential campaign gets into full swing. Oil experts do not expect a dramatic drop in prices as a result of the deal struck in Vienna early yesterday, but they do not expect them to carry on rising, either. Crude prices have increased from a low of $10 barrel in early 1999 to more than $30 a few weeks ago, and are now expected to settle at around $20 to $25 a barrel - not so different in inflation adjusted terms from the price in aftermath of the first oil shock in 1973 to 1974.

The price had already been softening in anticipation of an agreement, and most of the agreed increase in output has already taken place in recent months as Opec nations have exceded the quotas set in spring last year.

According to the Centre for Global Energy Studies (CGES), Opec members are already overproducing by at least a million barrels a day, which means that the deal will only lead to extra production of fewer than half a million barrels a day.

In reality the increase will be more than this because the one country that refused to sign up to the deal - Iran - is likely to raise output quietly once the dust has settled. Iran's objection to the Opec deal was not so much the impact on prices of raising quotas but of member states being pushed around by Washington.

Extra output from Iran will push the increase in Opec production up to 1.7m bar rels a day - on paper, at least. But the CGES believes that on past form, countries will exceed their quotas by a further 300 to 400,000 barrels a day. This would result in an increase of production of around 2.1m barrels a day, or around 1.1m barrels more than is at present being produced.

"An output increase of 1.1m barrels per day from the beginning of April will not have a significant downward impact on oil prices, although it should prevent them from returning to the $30 a barrel level that we have witnessed recently."

Even if non-Opec countries such as Mexico increase production - as they almost certainly will - the CGES estimates that demand will still slightly exceed supply this year because the global economy is on the mend. Margaret Thatcher, one of the politicians made by the energy crisis in the 1970s once famously said: "You can't buck the market." Opec has proved that you can. But only up to a point.

webTitle: Waiting game that may not pay off

fields.headline: Waiting game that may not pay off
fields.standfirst: Weak euro hurts manufacturing
fields.trailText: The only way for the Bank of England's monetary policy committee to bring down the value of the pound - up 30% on a trade-weighted basis over the past 3 years - would be for it to abandon its commitment to meeting the government's inflation target, according to the bank's deputy governor Mervyn King.
fields.body:
The only way for the Bank of England's monetary policy committee to bring down the value of the pound - up 30% on a trade-weighted basis over the past 3 years - would be for it to abandon its commitment to meeting the government's inflation target, according to the bank's deputy governor Mervyn King.

Not only would that be a breach of the bank's statutory duty; the cure would be worse than the illness. Inflation would take off and hard-won stability would fly out of the window.

The only comfort that Mr King could offer a Black Country audience yesterday was that the monetary policy committe took account of the exchange rate when setting interest rates and they were thus lower than they would have been had the pound not been so strong. Monetary instability has not been good for manufacturing either.

But is it true that the bank - and the chancellor for that matter -has little choice but to wait for the euro to recover, thus pushing down the value of the pound in markets which are crucial to manufacturing industry?

Certainly that could take some time. As Mr King noted, interest rate differentials, the sustainable level of the exchange rate and the riskiness of sterling against the euro "imply" - Mr King's word - that sterling is more likely than not to fall against the euro in the next two years or so.

But Gerry Holtham at Norwich Union Investment Management suggests an elegant alternative is available. The government should issue substantial quantities of long-dated gilts and then use the cash raised to buy European government bonds. That, he argues, would put pressure on the exchange rate and because the scheme would actually generate revenue financial markets would be frightened the government could repeat the trick indefinitely. So sterling would head helpfully lower.

There are a couple of snags. The political fallout from the sales of gold may make the authorities wary of the gilts scheme. They might have trouble, too, persuading foreign investors at least to buy assets denominated in a currency which is set for a fall. And central banks which undermine their own currencies are never favourites with financial markets capable of taking their revenge.

But the scheme is a creative way of looking at a problem which conventional wisdom dictates can only be solved by waiting for the euro to recover. Conventional wisdom may well be right. On the other hand, waiting for the single currency to strengthen could be like waiting for Godot.

Sated stock?

Internet millionaires may be 10 a penny these day but yesterday Japanese investors threatened to take the enthusiasm for the sector to heights that are truly dizzying. Shares in Yahoo! Japan, part owned by Softbank and part by Yahoo! of the US came within a whisker (OK, $40,000) of becoming the first $1m share.

But can the insatiable appetite for seemingly any internet stock carry on? Analysts at Salomon Smith Barney think not.

In the UK, for example, they reckon the move towards unmetered access is changing the nature of the industry. While lower access charges will mean users will spend more time online, internet service providers will have to subsidise those lower charges, thus turning a source of revenue into a cost. As a result ISPs will need other sources of revenue and that they believe will trigger a consolidation in the industry - sorting out those with the critical mass to exploit new revenue streams from those which haven't. It may also prompt some more sensible valuations.

Oil lubrication

Opec was always going to cobble together some sort of deal. The fact that not everyone is on board for the level of the increase in output is nothing for consumers to worry about. Iran has tra ditionally had a reputation as a hawk and could hardly have been expected to accept publicly US pressure for higher increases. Cynics might point out, too, that Iran has less excess capacity than, say, Saudi Arabia.

Though the extra oil that will now be pumped is less than the Americans wanted and less than the International Energy Agency believes is necessary to rebuild inventories, there is every likelihood that producers will exceed the new official limits. Already the oil price is settling back towards the $20 to $25 a barrel which is regarded as a comfort zone both for most producers and for the industrialised economies.

The trick will be to find the balance between continued strong demand as the US economy roars on and Europe and Japan (hopefully) recover and the ability and willingness of producers to pump more oil. Viennese hotels could be busy again soon.

fields.headline: O'Reilly foresees Independent profits
fields.trailText: Tony O'Reilly's Independent News & Media yesterday said the company's two UK national newspapers remained on course to move into profit in the next 12 months.
fields.body:
Tony O'Reilly's Independent News & Media yesterday said the company's two UK national newspapers remained on course to move into profit in the next 12 months.

Chief executive of the UK division Brendan Hopkins said he was bullish about reaching the target set by the group when it won full control of the Independent and Independent on Sunday in March 1998.

"We set ourselves targets of breakeven by three years and we are quite confident we will achieve that," he said. Revenues in the UK, which also include regional newspapers, magazines and educational publishing, increased by 6% to £99.8m during 1999 but made an undisclosed loss.

Mr O'Reilly pledged to inject £50m over five years to restore the national papers' fortunes when it bought out the then Mirror Group's 46% stake. But while the group claims that loses are being reduced, sales have yet to reach targets.

At the time, the aims were to increase daily circulation to 250,000 and the Sunday to 300,000 within three years. The average circulation for the Independent for the nine months to January was 224,554, up 1.5% while the Sunday was 249,548 - a drop of 1.9%.

Mr Hopkins maintained the company was pleased with the progress of Janet Street-Porter whose appointment as editor of the Sunday paper last summer stunned the industry. "She's doing absolutely fine and has developed quite a following," he said.

The group, with interests spanning Ireland, Australia, New Zealand and South Africa, reported a 68% jump in pre-tax profits to 143m euro on turnover of 1.2bn euro - up 46%.

The controversial acquisition of the Belfast Telegraph group from Trinity Mirror was yesterday referred to the competition commission by trade secretary Stephen Byers.

webTitle: Hopes rise for air slots deal with US

fields.headline: Hopes rise for air slots deal with US
fields.trailText: Senior UK transport officials are meeting their American counterparts today in the first sign that talks about a transatlantic aviation deal could be back on track.
fields.body:
Senior UK transport officials are meeting their American counterparts today in the first sign that talks about a transatlantic aviation deal could be back on track.

Today's meeting, which comes after high-level political intervention, could pave the way for British Airways to relaunch its efforts to form a global alliance with American Airlines. A proposed deal was suspended last year after the US authorities refused to offer protection against future anti-trust complaints.

The British government is understood to have pushed for a resumption of talks after receiving clarification from British Airways about its position following the ousting of Bob Ayling as chief executive earlier this month.

In a separate development, it emerged that the UK embassy in Washington has ended a long-standing travel agreement with BA. The move, understood to be relatively insignificant in revenue terms, is embarrassing for the company at this delicate stage in the talks. The embassy is believed to be considering a travel arrangement with Virgin Airways, BA's arch-rival.

Negotiations over a broader "open skies" agreement between the two countries - aimed at allowing more carriers to fly across the Atlantic - collapsed earlier this year amid a welter of accusations on both sides.

The prime minister subsequently raised the matter informally with President Clinton and then, two weeks ago, John Prescott made an impromptu visit to Washington in an effort to ease tensions with his US counterpart.

Sources close to today's negotiations were wary of predicting a swift resolution, however. One said they were "informal talks about talks" to set the ground rules for a future agreement.

Roy Griffins, the director-general in charge of civil aviation at the department of the environment, transport and the regions, is to lead the talks for the UK. At the heart of any deal would be an increase in the number of airlines flying to and from Heathrow. Only four airlines - British Airways, Virgin, United Airlines and American Airlines - now do so.

webTitle: Eircom plan needs the luck of the Irish

fields.headline: Eircom plan needs the luck of the Irish
fields.trailText: It would take the luck of the Irish for Eircom to be one of the five winners from the British government's auction of third generation mobile phone licences.
fields.body:
It would take the luck of the Irish for Eircom to be one of the five winners from the British government's auction of third generation mobile phone licences.

The bidding stands at more than £1bn per licence. The former state-owned telecoms monopoly has the enviable position of one of the few telecommunications firms to boast a balance sheet free from debt. However, it is no match for the deep pockets of rivals like Vodafone and British Telecom.

In fact, Eircom's £6bn market cap may see it struggle to pay for a licence. It would have to undertake an additional huge spend on network infrastructure to deliver the next generation of mobile technology.

Compounding this apparent weakness is the uncertainty over Eircom's share registry where big shareholders Dutch KPN and Sweden's Telia are planning to dispose of their respective 21% and 14% stakes.

It means Eircom's shares could be in for a roller coaster ride with the prospect of more than a third of the company coming to the market - which raises even bigger questions of its becoming a takeover target.

The company floated last July on the Irish, London and New York stock exchanges at €3.90 (£2.40) and that price has only improved to €4.70 recently.

Yet Eircom is still hanging in there with 12 other bidders. Bidding in the auction is part of Eircom's wider strategy to become a significant player in the Northern Irish and British telecom markets. Eircom has yet to realise this goal, remaining heavily reliant on the Irish fixed line network, which accounts for almost 90% of its sales.

Only 44% of the Irish population has a fixed line phone and this is expected to be overtaken by mobile ownership next year. Now estimated at 43% of the population, it is likely to reach 61% by 2003.

Finland is one of the few other European countries where mobiles are the dominant breed.

Ireland's tiger economy - where gross domestic product has leaped ahead at 9% per annum - has helped underpin the revenues for Eircom's fixed line business.

Yet this growth is at risk, as Eircom acknowledged this week in a statement that said: "The impact of the company's new business development strategies and increased competition are expected to reduce earnings in the short term."

BT has just bought Esat, Ireland's second largest telecom's operator, for £1.6bn, and it is expected to make a grab for Eircom's business customers.

Margins will no doubt fall and so Eircom is now looking at broadband opportunities, like the internet and interactive television, to exploit more revenues from its fixed line network of residential and business customers.

Eircom boasts 200,000 internet surfers using its lines and has plans to spin them off into an internet division. Those internet users account for 27% of Eircom's local calls.

Eircom's plans to offer its 1.6m customers high-speed internet access and interactive television via broadband are also under threat from NTL's Irish cable network, which intends to compete with high-speed data and telephony on its own network.

These factors have kept Eircom's share price in check, restricting the rise since it listed to 20%. This lacklustre performance suggests the company has more battles to win than just a bidding competition for British mobile phone licences.

The company floated last July on the Irish, London and New York stock exchanges at €3.90 (£2.40) and that price has only improved to €4.70 recently. Yet Eircom is still hanging in there with 12 other bidders. Bidding in the auction is part of Eircom's wider strategy to become a significant player in the Northern Irish and British telecom markets. Eircom has yet to realise this goal, remaining heavily reliant on the Irish fixed line network, which accounts for almost 90% of its sales. Only 44% of the Irish population has a fixed line phone and this is expected to be overtaken by mobile ownership next year. Now estimated at 43% of the population, it is likely to reach 61% by 2003. Finland is one of the few other European countries where mobiles are the dominant breed. Ireland's tiger economy - where gross domestic product has leaped ahead at 9% per annum - has helped underpin the revenues for Eircom's fixed line business. Yet this growth is at risk, as Eircom acknowledged this week in a statement that said: "The impact of the company's new business development strategies and increased competition are expected to reduce earnings in the short term." BT has just bought Esat, Ireland's second largest telecom's operator, for £1.6bn, and it is expected to make a grab for Eircom's business customers. Margins will no doubt fall and so Eircom is now looking at broadband opportunities, like the internet and interactive television, to exploit more revenues from its fixed line network of residential and business customers. Eircom boasts 200,000 internet surfers using its lines and has plans to spin them off into an internet division. Those internet users account for 27% of Eircom's local calls. Eircom's plans to offer its 1.6m customers high-speed internet access and interactive television via broadband are also under threat from NTL's Irish cable network, which intends to compete with high-speed data and telephony on its own network. These factors have kept Eircom's share price in check, restricting the rise since it listed to 20%. This lacklustre performance suggests the company has more battles to win than just a bidding competition for British mobile phone licences.

webTitle: BSkyB takes a tumble after Kirch fundraiser

fields.headline: BSkyB takes a tumble after Kirch fundraiser
fields.trailText: Shares in BSkyB tumbled 165p to £17.98 yesterday after the pay-television group raised £340m through a placing of new equity to fund its acquisition of a stake in Germany's Kirch pay TV company.
fields.body:
Shares in BSkyB tumbled 165p to £17.98 yesterday after the pay-television group raised £340m through a placing of new equity to fund its acquisition of a stake in Germany's Kirch pay TV company.

The issue will cover the cash element of BSkyB's deal to take a 24% stake in Kirch which was cleared by the EC last week. The deal is BSkyB's first foray into mainland Europe and unites Rupert Murdoch, whose News Corp owns 40% of the UK firm, with Leo Kirch, whose German media empire spans music, print and TV. Kirch has a pay-TV subscriber base of 2.2m homes.

Under the terms of the deal BSkyB is paying DM1bn in cash (£312m) and issuing 78m shares which will give Kirch a 4.3% stake in BSkyB.

The company also announced that Sky Digital sales had reached the 3m mark, in line with most analysts' expectations. At the announcement of BSkyB's recent financial results, chief executive Tony Ball said the company could reach 5m by the end of this year. BSkyB added 190,000 subscribers during the quarter ending March 31, the highest since the digital service was launched in October 1998.

After completing its book building exercise BSkyB said it would issue 19m new shares at £18.25 each. The referral of the Kirch deal to the EC has been fortuitous for BSkyB. The delay has enabled it to capitalise on a share price which has gained 90% this year.

fields.headline: Bigheads need not apply
fields.standfirst: Matthew Higgs is sick of artists who think they're it: he believes the work is more important. Which is a bit radical when you're putting together a huge survey of new British art. As part of our series on curators, he talks to  Jonathan Jones
fields.trailText: Matthew Higgs is sick of artists who think they're it: he believes the work is more important. Which is a bit radical when you're putting together a huge survey of new British art. As part of our series on curators, he talks to Jonathan Jones.
fields.body:
Matthew Higgs, currently the most influential curator of contemporary British art, recently brought out an odd little book through his publishing venture, Imprint 93. The Tate Celebrity List was compiled by Chris Coombes and Christian Rutherford, two artists with day jobs selling the Tate magazine to visitors to the museum. They and their fellow vendors noted famous visitors and commented on their appearance and behaviour. Nicole Kidman: "Plastic face, 'This is great!' ". Jack Dee: "Grey, went into shop alone". Jack Nicholson: editor's note - "Jack Nicholson will not do. The laxity of this list is becoming something of a concern".

Higgs has been curating his series of artists' publications since 1993, and it has grown remarkably from a marginal alternative to the London art world to a catalogue of today's most highly regarded artists. Contributors have included Chris Ofili - who compiled Black, a series of cuttings from his local newspaper in which crimes were attributed to black suspects - and Jeremy Deller, whose latest Imprint 93 work is a guest list stolen from the ICA and given the title RANK.

Higgs loves lists, and loves mocking pomposity. Which is ironic, because on the coffee table in his studio he keeps a copy of the Evening Standard's Power List of London's 100 movers and shakers, including one Matthew Higgs. Higgs the outsider is now Higgs the insider.

The British art scene now is full of people bidding to define the next thing post-Damien Hirst. Contenders have come and gone, but it's Higgs, curator of exhibitions including Then and Now at the Lisson Gallery and a director of London's Cabinet Gallery, who seems to be the man with a plan. And the reason that Higgs is a genuine influence is that he chose the right artists. Long before they attained their current fame, he worked closely with Ofili, Martin Creed, Fiona Banner, Jeremy Deller and Paul Noble.

These are not just names to play with but are among the best artists at work in Britain now. Creed and Deller, in particular, could never have developed in the way they have without Higgs - and without them British art would be a bleak prospect. So Higgs is a success in the best possible way for an art critic or curator - he was right. His latest project is the British Art Show, a huge survey of current work organised every five years by the Hayward Gallery, which opens in Edinburgh on April 8. It's being spoken of as "Matthew Higgs's British Art Show", although he emphasises he's only one of three selectors, the others being freelance curator Pippa Coles and artist Jacqui Poncelet. But it is hard not to see Higgs's hand shaping the list of selected artists, which includes Creed, Billy Childish, Deller and Lucy MacKenzie.

Lists again. A list is a very controlled literary form: the compiler may have a deeply emotional relationship to what is on it, or they may be joking. They are certainly not giving themselves away. Higgs is in his mid-30s, a dry character, hard to pin down. For him, art is "a conversation". He uses his curating to stress the value of collaboration and dialogue, in contrast to the single-minded art of the Hirst generation. Last year he staged an exhibition at the Anthony Wilkinson Gallery of his own works, which featured collaborations with friends. The effect was of a group show that he had curated rather than of a signature style by a single artist. He juxtaposed cut-up books made with Ofili and Peter Doig and - the most emotional item - a black-and-white photograph of himself with the legendary Manchester band Joy Division. Why did he include this? "Because these four young men were about to change history and I was lucky enough to be there at the time." In the picture he's a mop-haired figure in the background; it's an uncanny thing to have in your photo collection.

Higgs is from Chorley, Lancashire, and when he was 14 he founded a Joy Division fanzine, the beginning of his publishing enterprise. Joy Division led him to research groups like Throbbing Gristle and, through them, to conceptual art. He and his friends met and befriended Joy Division. The band's generosity to an awkward teenager had an openness he still can't get over. "For whatever reason they took us seriously. That always strikes me as odd because at the time they were a significant presence on the British music scene and you'd have thought the last thing they'd want in their rehearsal studio was teenagers."

When he started Imprint 93, Higgs says, he was trying to recapture this generous spirit, the sense he got from the group that what transpired in a light way between friends - a band rehearsal on a grey Manchester morning - could have a weight and significance. "It was about trying to find that level of conversation again."

Recently an art magazine asked 20 curators what they hope for in the art of this millennium. Another list. The only person who said anything interesting was Higgs. He pointed out that no art exhibition he saw in Britain last year was anywhere near as good as the American independent film Rushmore. This is a surprise coming from someone who makes his living promoting British art. But Higgs represents a completely different, far more sceptical, attitude from the one that prevailed in Britain in the 90s. The huge international success of British art has been simultaneous with the decline of British pop, as if art had swallowed up popular culture. The British artists of the Goldsmiths generation - "the dying empire of the YBAs", as Higgs calls them - came on like pop stars, but only to produce a spectacle. The epitome of this was Gavin Turk's statue of himself as Sid Vicious in an Elvis pose. What did this mean? That all icons are the same? To say that is to erase history, to feel nothing about music or what it means to people.

Compare this with the pride Higgs takes in the photograph of himself with Joy Division. He likes the picture precisely because it puts him in history. Its meaning is absolutely connected with who Joy Division were and their place in British culture. Higgs has emerged as the spokesman of post-YBA art, a job that had many applicants, because he put his finger on what was wrong with the art of Gavin Turk and co - its obsession with the artist as a one-off voice. By contrast, the artists associated with Imprint 93 revel in multiple voices. Higgs is the leader and curator of a school of artists who have a positively studious relationship with popular culture. They don't see it as raw material to be ransacked, but a real history, a continuing story. I suppose you could accuse Higgs and his collaborators of being a bit adolescent. Higgs has an impressive collection of vinyl and once curated an exhibition called Desert Island Discs in which he invited artists to select records they love. He commissioned Deller to place an anonymous Valentine's message in the Guardian that quoted Morrissey: "I am human and I need to be loved, just like everybody else does."

Higgs is bringing history, politics and passion into British art. He's serious. His sense of history doesn't just extend to old records but to great artists. Tonight he's "in conversation" with the pop artist Richard Hamilton at the new Milton Keynes art gallery. Hamilton makes art that both respects and criticises pop culture, and has, in turn, influenced pop music.

Higgs restores excitement to art because he makes it feel like something rough and amateurish, like British pop music at its best. Will success spoil him? Even if it does, at least he'll have access to some more amusing art-world guest lists.
 The British Art Show 5 is at Dean Gallery and other venues, Edinburgh, from April 8 to June 4. Details: 0131-529 3795. It then tours to Southampton, Cardiff and Birmingham. Richard Hamilton talks with Matthew Higgs at Milton Keynes Gallery tonight. Details: 01908 676 900.

fields.headline: This man must be stopped
fields.standfirst: Stop up your ears. Unplug the radio. Phil Collins is back, with an Oscar-winning song, a tribute album, even a high-profile lawsuit.  Tom Cox  prays this isn't the start of a full-scale revival
fields.trailText: Stop up your ears. Unplug the radio. Phil Collins is back, with an Oscar-winning song, a tribute album, even a high-profile lawsuit. Tom Cox prays this isn't the start of a full-scale revival.
fields.body:
No other artist epitomises the 80s quite like Phil Collins. In a way, he is the 80s: slick, capitalist, compromised. The 80s began... Phil Collins became Phil Collins. The 80s ended... Phil Collins immediately began to lose significance. In 1990 No Jacket Required, one of the fastest-selling new albums of all time in 1985, started to become the fastest-abandoned old album of all time, as vast chunks of the populace abruptly came to their sense and car-booted it into touch. I don't have the figures to prove this, of course, but my local second-hand record shop claims it was receiving 20 copies a week at one point during 1991, and these days No Jacket Required, alongside Supertramp's Breakfast in America and Rush's Grace under Pressure, doesn't even make it into the three-for-a-quid section.

What turned us against Collins? Was it that he left his second wife and nicked off to Switzerland with a girl half his age? Was it the dreaded slaphead/mullet in-yer-face interface of the Live Aid era? Was it that he gradually drained all the artistic vision from Peter Gabriel's original model of Genesis, then walked out? Was it the gobsmackingly insulting video with the homeless that accompanied 1989's Another Day in Armani in the Lear Jet (Where's the Champagne, Slave?)? Or was it simply that you can only treat your audience like moronic, sentimental peasants for so long before they cotton on, even if they are moronic, sentimental peasants?

Today Collins doesn't even qualify as an international pop antichrist, like Celine Dion, or a chintzy, ironic icon, like Barry Manilow. It's as if he was cryogenically frozen at the Knebworth Festival in 1990, along with his influence on popular music. It's only in the last couple of weeks, with an Academy Award for his Tarzan theme song, You'll Be In My Heart, and news of a forthcoming album of cover versions from rap and modern R&B artists, and a royalties battle with the two surviving members of Earth, Wind and Fire, that we've been forced to acknowledge his continuing existence. Two groups of people, it seems, still care: the first lot are from Hollywood and not really worth worrying about. The second are a bigger concern. Surely an album of Collins covers should feature Gary Barlow, Bryan Adams, Jon Bon Jovi, Robbie Williams and Celine Dion - not Ol' Dirty Bastard, Montell Jordan, Li'l Kim and Dru Hill?

Actually, while bitching, whoring gangsta rappers might not fit in with the suburban grandma's picture of "that nice man Phil", modern rap is more in sync with Collins's I-want-it-all-I-want-it-now-and-I-don't-care-what-I-have-to-sell-to-get-it aesthetic than any other musical genre. The Day Today's Chris Morris foresaw all this in 1993 with his homicidal wordsmith Fur-Q, who covered the Collins/Phil Everly duet Easy Lover as Uzi Lover, proving in the process how eminently sampleable Collins was.

It's possible to see how an album of Collins covers might work. But this probably won't be it. Taken to a dank, abandoned warehouse, strip-searched, and well and truly worked over, it's possible to see how Turn It On Again, Sussudio or I Missed Again might be revealed as killer tunes dressed in travelling sales rep's clothing. But don't expect a rerun of Run DMC's Aerosmith makeover here. With rap ever more overproduced and sterile, we can only expect No Jacket Required remade as No Reebok Hi-Tops Required, with a bit more jewellery and misogyny.

Will it sell? And if so, who to? As the last five years have proved, words like "compromise" and "integrity" aren't in mainstream rap audiences' lexicons, so don't expect them to be too worried about putting a few more royalties into the pocket of the man who once said he would leave the country if Old Labour got into power. But Phil's hordes? That's a tricky one.

After the great spiritual cleansing of the early 90s, residual Collins fans seem to come in three guises: reformed, hiding or crackpot. A few hours on the net, and you learn that the average Collins fan is called Mad Norman, works part-time designing bombs, thinks Peter Gabriel is a "bit weird" and was drawn to Genesis in the mid-80s by the prominence of their drum sound and their lighting arrangements. Meet Jeremy West, "19 years old and unfortunately single, attending college and selling nuclear weapons on the side"; Arnold, who runs a religious cult based on the belief that Collins is the manifestation of someone called Buddha Collins III, and finds deep meaning in his backwards lyrics; Janet, "a paranormal instructor who feels MUSIC is essential to the soul and specific vibrations effect [sic] the physical and metaphysical bodies equally" and preaches "the Phil Collins vibration"; and Crazy Dave, who likes to follow Barbra Streisand around in his spare time.

Then, of course, there's Patrick Bateman, the serial killer from Bret Easton Ellis's 1991 novel American Psycho, who breaks off from his daily torture to write a five-page muso essay on the significance of 80s Genesis. "I've been a big Genesis fan ever since the release of their 1980 album Duke," he explains. "Before that I didn't really understand any of their work... all the albums before Duke seem too artsy, too intellectual." If the old adage that your fans are a reflection of your true self is correct, Collins shouldn't look in the mirror too hard.

Collins is fascinating in that he's an icon to a whole generation of troubled souls who not only don't care how uncool they are, but don't even know it - a special bracket of part-time music fans for whom pop is simply a race to be the biggest, the slickest, and the flashiest, regardless of how little emotional reach the songs possess.

So has Collins reached the point where he's so uncool he's about to become cool? No - because unlike, say Rod Stewart, Neil Diamond, Abba or Elton John, Collins never had a good early phase of songwriting. He was born, fully formed, as Mr 80s: when the 70s ended, he went straight from inconsequential to dangerous, missing out the interesting bit in between. With the exception of Easy Lover, his songs don't even have that good-time, fluffy aspect that kitsch, ironic revival music has - this is serious stuff, "proper", "grown-up". Unlike Tom Jones ducking a barrage of girls' knickers or Eddie Van Halen on his back in the middle of a guitar solo, you could never attach any excitement, tongue in cheek or otherwise, to Collins perched on his drum stool, grimacing like a sombre mechanic dressed up for a night on the town.

He is, without doubt, clever - he conned everyone into thinking it was all right for pop stars to look like plumbers, got away with making comments about Genesis's music being "too demanding for women", and slimed up to punk, calling Yes and Pink Floyd "dinosaurs" when he saw the prog-rock backlash might mean Genesis selling a few less thousand records. But even he isn't cunning enough to make himself credible - not even with the help of a bunch of million-selling rappers who seem to be doing almost as good a job of conning the public as he did in the 80s. Marketable, perhaps, but cool? Never.

Then, of course, there's Patrick Bateman, the serial killer from Bret Easton Ellis's 1991 novel American Psycho, who breaks off from his daily torture to write a five-page muso essay on the significance of 80s Genesis. "I've been a big Genesis fan ever since the release of their 1980 album Duke," he explains. "Before that I didn't really understand any of their work... all the albums before Duke seem too artsy, too intellectual." If the old adage that your fans are a reflection of your true self is correct, Collins shouldn't look in the mirror too hard. Collins is fascinating in that he's an icon to a whole generation of troubled souls who not only don't care how uncool they are, but don't even know it - a special bracket of part-time music fans for whom pop is simply a race to be the biggest, the slickest, and the flashiest, regardless of how little emotional reach the songs possess. So has Collins reached the point where he's so uncool he's about to become cool? No - because unlike, say Rod Stewart, Neil Diamond, Abba or Elton John, Collins never had a good early phase of songwriting. He was born, fully formed, as Mr 80s: when the 70s ended, he went straight from inconsequential to dangerous, missing out the interesting bit in between. With the exception of Easy Lover, his songs don't even have that good-time, fluffy aspect that kitsch, ironic revival music has - this is serious stuff, "proper", "grown-up". Unlike Tom Jones ducking a barrage of girls' knickers or Eddie Van Halen on his back in the middle of a guitar solo, you could never attach any excitement, tongue in cheek or otherwise, to Collins perched on his drum stool, grimacing like a sombre mechanic dressed up for a night on the town. He is, without doubt, clever - he conned everyone into thinking it was all right for pop stars to look like plumbers, got away with making comments about Genesis's music being "too demanding for women", and slimed up to punk, calling Yes and Pink Floyd "dinosaurs" when he saw the prog-rock backlash might mean Genesis selling a few less thousand records. But even he isn't cunning enough to make himself credible - not even with the help of a bunch of million-selling rappers who seem to be doing almost as good a job of conning the public as he did in the 80s. Marketable, perhaps, but cool? Never.

fields.headline: How I tamed Ali G
fields.standfirst: When he was asked to appear on a TV show introducing politics to young people,  Tony Benn  jumped at the chance. The interviewer's name? Ali G. Now, as Staines' most famous son begins his own series, the legendary MP relives the experience
fields.trailText: When Channel 4 rang me last year to ask me to take part in a new television programme designed to introduce young people to politics, I agreed at once and greatly looked forward to it.
fields.body:
When Channel 4 rang me last year to ask me to take part in a new television programme designed to introduce young people to politics, I agreed at once and greatly looked forward to it.

Since "New Labour" was elected, there has been a notable de-politicisation of young people, many of whom tend to think of the prime minister as if he were the well-liked manager of a successful United Kingdom football team, whom they admire as spectators without much sense of personal involvement.

Like many MPs, I visit a lot of schools and speak at student conferences; these sessions are always followed by questions which reveal the pernicious influence the tabloids have upon their political thinking.

When he arrived, Ali G was courteous and friendly as I welcomed him into my office and, in his first question, he asked me to explain socialism, which he seemed to believe was the same as the welfare state but went on to argue that all strikes were motivated by laziness, almost as if he was a leader-writer in the Sun. It was at this early point that I decided that the only respectful thing to do was to argue with him and to do so as vigorously as I could.

There was nothing else I could do since all the crudest prejudices poured out of him, not least his argument that all "bitches" just got pregnant to get on to benefit, and so on.

Although I found his questions deeply offensive, he was very polite to me personally, and I concluded that his views were based upon a deep ignorance - as when he claimed that Mrs Thatcher was a Communist. At the end, he turned to the camera and said "Tony Benn is my main man", and put out his hand in my direction in some greeting of good will, and left after I had told him how much I had enjoyed our talk.

At no stage during our talk did I suspect for a second that it was other than a genuine programme, and when the interview was broadcast and someone rang to tell me about it, I was very angry and wrote to the production company demanding a video, which I watched.

That should be the end of a simple story of an old man being completely fooled by a comedian in a hoax interview - but there was a sequel which showed it all in a very different light.

Lots of young people came up to me in the street, or wrote in to say how much they had enjoyed the programme and how glad they were that I had stood up to him.

I didn't know what they were talking about until one of my teenage grandsons bought the Ali G video at Christmas and we all sat down, as a family, to watch it.

It was, indeed, a hilarious series of interviews with a range of people who had no idea how to deal with Ali G's questions and were puzzled, confused and silent when pressed to explain some absurdity in their own opinions.

These responses were made possible by his feigned naivety, warm expressions of regard for whoever he was talking to, and an absurd emphasis addressed to the television audience of the importance of the person with whom he was talking.

For me the high points were when he asked the general whether he had ever thought of changing sides in the war, and respectfully inquired whether the head of the Orange Order would be ready to marry a Catholic girl "if she had a stereo".

All the interviews on the video were of the same general kind, and although they were extremely funny to watch, they all were genuinely educational in that anyone watching them would be bound to question their own prejudices and think about the real issues raised.

In fact, the programmes were exactly what Channel 4 had said they would be - a chance to present politics to young people.

Ali G is a very clever man, and I am beginning to wonder if that was what he actually intended to do. If so, perhaps he can help explain New Labour by interviewing the prime minister about the Third Way

 Da Ali G Show, tomorrow, 10.30pm, Channel 4

webTitle: To bi or not to bi

fields.headline: To bi or not to bi
fields.standfirst: Last year actor Joy Brook came out as bisexual on these pages. Now she says she'll never fall in love with a woman again.  Stephanie Theobold on the pressures that make women play safe with their sexuality
fields.trailText: Last year actor Joy Brook came out as bisexual on these pages. Now she says she'll never fall in love with a woman again. Stephanie Theobold on the pressures that make women play safe with their sexuality.
fields.body:
So, Joy Brook succumbed to the gender police in the end. But it was not so much a fair cop as proof of society's reluctance to abolish the sexuality caste system.

Only a year ago the actor who plays WDC Kerry Holmes in The Bill put a spring in the step of female sexual renegades everywhere by declaring that she was a bisexual in an interview for the Guardian women's page. Last weekend she recanted by announcing that she's not a bisexual at all. No, siree. She is totally, utterly, 100%, not-even-if-Uma-Thurman-was-winched-down-naked-on-top-of-her certain that she is a heterosexual.

"I'll never fall in love with a woman again," she pledged to the Mail On Sunday. Miss Brook has become engaged to a man called Russell Boulter who plays DS John Boulton in The Bill. Not only is Mr Boulter not a lesbian but he is also a "committed Christian".

The most intriguing part of the news came when Brook insisted that, although she shared a house with her female lover for two years, "I fell in love with her and her personality, not what she was physically." Has a touch of the Kenny Everetts about it, doesn't it? "There I was, lying in bed with another woman - and suddenly all my clothes fell off!"

What does she mean she fell in love with her girlfriend's personality? When she was under the covers pressing against a hot, silky, aroused woman's body was she thinking about her girlfriend's insightful views on Rosa Luxemburg? And what about 10 years down the line when Mr Boulton is more interested in the football scores than he is in coming to bed early? What will she do if an image of a comely nude female in a red sports car suddenly pops into her mind? Is she going to stroke her wedding dress for reassurance?

Apart from the fatuous implication that women - still - don't have a sex drive of their own, one of the more shocking assumptions of Joy Brook's new philosophy on life is that despite our modern lives being haunted by training shoe slogans of the "dare to be different" variety, we apparently all become reactionary and frightened after the age of 21.

Both Brook's before and after revelations are infused with the idea that she was young and therefore foolish when she had her first relationship with a woman. "It was scary at first," she says, "but when you're 21, you think, why not?" As if two women sleeping together is on a par with devil worship, glue sniffing or wearing boob tubes. Naturally, many of Brook's words speak of internalised homophobia. And that is not illogical.

Brook puts the problem succinctly in her original coming-out interview. "I know a lot of actresses who, if not 100% gay, are bisexual," she says. "But it's a difficult situation because it's still a business run by men. They want to be able to fancy you and they can only do that if they feel you could fancy them."

For "business run by men" read planet earth. There is no big secret as to why women are less allowed to experiment with their sexuality than men do. The old chestnut that second wave feminism dug up in the 1970s remains the same ugly old chestnut in the 21st century: men feel threatened by women who - sexually and emotionally - are solely interested in women. Today, such a sentiment is as unfashionable as the concept of the "wage slave" or the "all property is theft" notion. But there, it is said now.

And how do men punish women who dare upset the hetero applecart? Why, they extract the woman on woman concept, they water it down, eroticise it, fashionise it and turn it into a lot of old nonsense. They have the money to do it. Have you seen that new Dior handbag ad, for goodness sake? Two posh, sweaty girls getting it on with some sort of satchel flying around in the background. Whatever next? Lucy Clayton introducing pussy-bumping chic into her deportment classes?

The last time there was such a rush for straight girls to become fly-by-night lesbians was in the 1970s when the discontent with heterosexuality was all part of a political battle. Today's men have a vested interest in creating fake lesbians because they can make money from them. Of course, such sexuality appropriation doesn't happen to gay men - because they are men. They get queer-bashed instead. Besides, why should gay men even bother saying they are bisexual when they have had the money to turn "gay" (meaning male homosexual) into a brand name as established and cool as Gucci, Absolut or Sony?

The trouble with the concept I termed "bi-try" is that it is now being used to sell the kind of magazines which are, in fact, only interested in propping up the old regime of heterosexuality. (If being straight is so "natural", by the way, why are we so constantly coerced into believing in it?)

Take this month's Elle cover story on "Bi-try babes". One writer claims she was "uncomfortable with the idea of being a lesbian. It made me think of smelly old women living with 10 cats." See? Nobody at a deep level really fell for any of that fashion/"lesbian chic" stuff; the propaganda campaign that worked the best of all was the dungarees/fat/cat one. No wonder she never made any more forays into her sexuality. Both Evans' and Joy Brook's sense of what it is to be a woman seems to be so feeble that they can't take any other vision on board apart from some man-made image. And Girl Power was supposed to have sorted all that out, remember? So, what is this basic threat that men feel about women who balk at exclusive heterosexuality? What other chestnuts can we come up with? Could it be primal rage at maternal absence? Anger at mothers turning them on as children? Feelings of invalidation? Fury that not every woman is at their behest? If we knew the answer to that, one friend recently told me, we could bottle it and sell it. Except that the only people who would want to buy it are feminists and they don't have any money.

webTitle: Spurs turn to supporters in hunt for cup-final culprit

fields.headline: Spurs turn to supporters in hunt for cup-final culprit
fields.trailText: Tottenham are to enlist the help of their supporters in identifying the man photographed punching a woman Leicester supporter at last year's Worthington Cup final by publishing pictures of the incident in their programme for Monday's match against Middlesbrough.
fields.body:
Tottenham are to enlist the help of their supporters in identifying the man photographed punching a woman Leicester supporter at last year's Worthington Cup final by publishing pictures of the incident in their programme for Monday's match against Middlesbrough.

More than a year after the attack on Ruth Lelacheur, and despite the Football Association offering a £1,000 reward, the culprit, whose ticket originated from Leicester's Andy Impey, has not been caught. Tottenham hope the photo will encourage people to come forward with information.

"We are particularly disgusted that the yob in question is assumed by connection to be a Spurs fan," the club said. "He may have been at the game with a twisted view as to how to support a football team but he is not a person that we would want to associate with.

"To that end, we have been in continual dialogue with the police since the game in an attempt to find the attacker's identity. Unfortunately that joint approach has been unsuccessful up until now."

Leicester have requested a meeting with the FA to respond to claims that they failed to fully cooperate with the inquiry into the distribution of tickets for last year's final. Seven players and officials have been fined and banned from receiving tickets for varying periods of time.

Everton are set to become the latest Premiership club to sign a lucrative deal with the telecommunications giants NTL. The Merseyside club is believed to be close to announcing a package which will see NTL pay around £20m for a 9.9% shareholding.

For their investment, NTL, which also holds stakes in Newcastle United, Aston Villa and Middlesbrough, would probably win exclusive rights to merchandising and a variety of multi-media spin-offs including possible live broadcast of games on the internet.

Arsenal's striker Thierry Henry has been banned for the first leg of the Uefa Cup semi-final against Lens at Highbury next Thursday after being sent off against Werder Bremen in the previous round. The one-game ban is the minimum punishment the Frenchman could have received.

Real Madrid are to lift their 45-day suspension on Nicolas Anelka on Wednesday, the day after the first leg of their Champions League quarter-final against Manchester United.

fields.headline: Henry the second sinks Scots
fields.standfirst:
Wiltord 54, Henry 89
Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: France scored their first goals and won their first ever match in Scotland to illustrate the difference between world champions and mere mortals. They chose not to outclass or overwhelm their opponents but a 48,000 crowd was left under no illusion that they could have done far more considerable damage had they so wished, Thierry Henry's late second goal from 20 yards notwithstanding.
fields.body:
France scored their first goals and won their first ever match in Scotland to illustrate the difference between world champions and mere mortals. They chose not to outclass or overwhelm their opponents but a 48,000 crowd was left under no illusion that they could have done far more considerable damage had they so wished, Thierry Henry's late second goal from 20 yards notwithstanding.

The reason for this match was the need to celebrate the official opening of Hampden Park but even the programme had to admit that the final stages of its completion were still to be carried out. It could also be added that Craig Brown fielded a side which was an awfully long way short of being the finished article either.

France, in contrast, looked ominously strong. They started with seven of the players who won the World Cup and could afford to leave Frank Leboeuf and Patrick Vieira on the bench.

Scotland's manager had insisted that his side would not be swamped by the French, and as usual the players showed little regard for the reputations of those facing them. They even had two genuine chances to take the lead in the first 11 minutes.

After less than two minutes Callum Davidson's long throw was headed on by Don Hutchison for Billy Dodds to try and flick the ball over Ulrich Rame. It seemed to have succeeded but with Laurent Blanc chasing back Kevin Gallacher nudged the ball into the net with his arm and the goal was ruled out.

In the 11th minute Paul Telfer's long ball down the middle caused Blanc and Marcel Desailly an untypical moment of confusion and Colin Cameron snatched his shot wide of the post. The match was interesting enough but was more a test of technical ability and that, in the long run, was only ever going to favour the French. Their ball control, so assured, kept the crowd quiet, even admiring but throughout the first half they scarcely troubled Neil Sullivan in the Scotland goal.

But two French half-time substitutions - the arrival of Sylvain Wiltord and Yohan Micoud - altered the complexion.

Within seconds the two of them combined to force Sullivan into his first save as he dropped to his left to palm away a Micoud cross. And in the 54th minute the pair were responsible for giving France the lead after a move that went the length of the field.

Once again from Micoud's pass the prolific Wiltord seized the ball on the right side of the penalty area and then drove his cross shot strongly away from the goalkeeper into the corner of the net.

With France ending up making four substitutions in the second half and Scotland replying with a clutch of their own, the game lost its validity. But France should have scored again in the 67th minute when Emmanuel Petit's corner was headed down by Vieira only for Davidson to kick the ball off the line.

The arrival of Mark Burchill for Kevin Gallacher briefly raised the temperature and Scotland, to their credit, did not give up the match.

Scotland (3-5-2)

Sullivan (Wimbledon); Hendry (Coventry), Dailly (Blackburn), Ritchie (Bolton; Pressley, Hearts, h-t); Telfer (Coventry; Johnston, Bolton, 69), Hutchison (Everton), B Ferguson (Rangers), Cameron (Hearts; McCann, Ranger, h-t), Davidson (Blackburn); Dodds (Rangers), Gallacher (Newcastle; Burchill, Celtic).

France (4-5-1)

Rame; Thuram, Desailly, Blanc, Lizarazu; Giuly (Wiltord, h-t), Djorkaeff (Micoud, h-t), Deschamps (Vieira, 60), Petit, Dugarry (Pires, 73); Henry.

Referee: R Pedersen (Norway).

Once again from Micoud's pass the prolific Wiltord seized the ball on the right side of the penalty area and then drove his cross shot strongly away from the goalkeeper into the corner of the net. With France ending up making four substitutions in the second half and Scotland replying with a clutch of their own, the game lost its validity. But France should have scored again in the 67th minute when Emmanuel Petit's corner was headed down by Vieira only for Davidson to kick the ball off the line. The arrival of Mark Burchill for Kevin Gallacher briefly raised the temperature and Scotland, to their credit, did not give up the match. webTitle: Giggs strikes but Finns sink Wales

fields.headline: Giggs strikes but Finns sink Wales
fields.standfirst: Giggs 60 | Litmanen 21, Blake 42og
fields.trailText: In the splendour of their new home and before a record crowd, Wales revealed familiar defensive neuroses last night and despite Ryan Giggs's reply after an hour, the party proved to be a substantial disappointment.
fields.byline: Trevor Haylett at the Millennium stadium
fields.body:
In the splendour of their new home and before a record crowd, Wales revealed familiar defensive neuroses last night and despite Ryan Giggs's reply after an hour, the party proved to be a substantial disappointment.

Finland, who are in England's World Cup qualifying group, scored twice before the break and up until that time were significantly the stronger. Yet they were hanging on at the end after Giggs had squeezed in a low shot and then went close from an acute angle. The 66,500 crowd prepared to celebrate an equaliser on 70 minutes when Nathan Blake fired in his second attempt from close range only for Juha Reini to clear off the line.

Reduced ticket prices had encouraged families to turn out and youthful voices filled the air as the teams emerged. Amid the cheers for Giggs were a few boos, though, a minority protesting at the fact that this was his first friendly since his debut nine years ago.

He and Gary Speed both took up advanced positions behind Blake but from Giggs's first surge it was clear that this was not always a helpful surface, some alarming bobbles hindering the flow.

The national coach Mark Hughes's fear had been that the occasion would inspire a gung-ho approach from his team but if anything Wales began with insufficient urgency and the Finns were able to take control. Only a smart block by Mark Crossley, starting an international for only the second time as Paul Jones was down with flu, prevented Mikael Forssell, who later in the half was to hit a post, from scoring a third-minute goal.

However the goalkeeper was at fault when Wales went behind midway through the first half. Joonas Kolkka's clever diagonal chip enticed Crossley off his line and when he failed to collect Jari Litmanen rolled the ball into an empty net.

Wales reverted to 4-4-2 and Giggs's role alongside Blake nearly brought immediate reward when John Robinson found him in space only for the header to drift wide.

Mark Pembridge was narrowly off target with a low drive and Blake was unlucky when, from near the penalty spot, he nodded the ball goalward but could not beat the onrushing Peter Enckelman.

Wales' improvement was then undone when from Kolkka's corner Blake, standing at the near post, completely mistimed his header, the ball coming off his hand and defeating Crossley's desperate attempt to keep it out.

Wales (3-4-2-1)
