Finland (4-4-1)

Enckelman (Aston Villa; Moilanen, Preston, h-t); Reini (KRC Genk), Hyypia (Liverpool), Saastamoinen (HJK), Tihinen (Viking Stavanger); Nurmela (Herenveen), Valakari (Motherwell), Riihilahti (Valerenga), Kolkka (PSV); Litmanen (Barcelona); Forssell (Chelsea).

Referee : M Ross (N Ireland).

webTitle: LM magazine closes after failed libel action

fields.headline: LM magazine closes after failed libel action
fields.standfirst: The former Living Marxism has learnt the hard way that it cannot throw stones through windows and be able to run giggling down the street without being chased, writes Matt Wells
fields.trailText: The former Living Marxism has learnt the hard way that it cannot throw stones through windows and be able to run giggling down the street without being chased, writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
LM, the magazine formerly known as Living Marxism, is no more. Its publishers have announced that the crushing libel defeat inflicted upon them at the high court in London earlier this month has finished them off.

The next issue will be the last monthly edition, and the company which publishes the monthly leftwing journal will go into liquidation.

Mick Hume and Helene Guldberg, editor and co-publisher respectively, also claim they face personal bankruptcy. The libel defeat at the hands of ITN, the London-based television news service, was a defeat for free speech too, they said.

While Hume and Guldberg remain unrepentant, the case was an instructive lesson in what actually constitutes freedom of expression.

The original LM article, headlined "the picture that fooled the world", accused ITN of deliberately misrepresenting an image that came to symbolise the horror of the Bosnian war. The television report had shown an emaciated Bosnian Muslim, Fikret Alic, apparently caged behind barbed wire at Trnopolje camp. In fact, LM said, the Muslims were not caged at all.

The jury accepted that the camp was - contrary to what LM had suggested - a prison, and the ITN pictures had not misrepresented the truth of what went on there. They awarded £375,000 damages against LM.

LM, and its curious band of supporters drawn from both extremes of the political spectrum, had attempted to attract the sympathy vote by presenting their predicament as a "David and Goliath" fight, branding ITN as the oppressor of truth determined to crush a low-circulation magazine which had said something it didn't like.

But the magazine's opponents - and indeed many with no view about LM at all - claimed this was disingenuous. LM, they said, was attempting to exploit its own position to get away with saying things that other, more established publications could not. It simply could not expect to throw stones through windows and be able to run giggling down the street without being chased, they argued.

LM's trick was a familiar one. Small-circulation magazines often use controversial subjects to punch above their weight. The Spectator's recent campaign exposing what it believes to be a "republican cell" at the heart of the Guardian is another example.

These publications rely on the assumption that the subject of their wild accusations will not hit back, fearing the consequences of being branded a bully - or worse, losing out in the libel lottery.

But ITN decided that LM's denial of the Bosnian terror could not lie on the record unchallenged. LM was free to question whether atrocities such as those perpetrated in Bosnia should be compared to the unique horror of the Holocaust - but, the broadcaster claimed, it could not use a lie as its weapon.

fields.headline: A sublime partnership
fields.standfirst:
Joanne Brackeen/Tommy Smith
Pizza Express, Dean Street, London
****
fields.trailText:
Joanne Brackeen/ Tommy Smith
Pizza Express, Dean Street, London
****
fields.body:
On Monday night Joanne Brackeen, the California-born jazz piano virtuoso, was wearing a hat that made her look as if a mole on a red parachute had bailed out on to her head. But that was the only distraction in an astonishing display of musicality in her performance with the Scottish saxophonist Tommy Smith. Brackeen, who has been as much involved in education as performance, is one of the great underrated jazz pianists of the past 30 years. She has an almost uncanny ability to pick up on the ideas of her partners, and a comprehensive grasp of contemporary jazz styles. Her performance with Smith was a quintessential display of the art of collective jazz improvisation.

Smith sometimes seemed overwhelmed by his partner's fluency and speed of anticipation, and this led to an occasional tendency to rush his phrasing. But for the most part this increasingly mature musician's lyricism and tonal command, particularly in a delicate high register, was an ideal complement to Brackeen's sweeping, orchestral style. Give-and-take went on continuously, but never descended into the kind of smug jazz banter that just sounds like musical ping-pong. The saxophonist would resolve a solo in a caressing series of spaced single notes and Brackeen would come in right after him with the same notes enveloped into sonorous chords. Each message took the music somewhere else.

When Smith played Someday My Prince Will Come as if he were blowing through a clarinet rather than a tenor sax, Brackeen buoyed him up with runs and billowing chords. Then she appropriated the long, feathery sounds at the end of his solo and batted them back at him as clipped, staccato phrases.

John Coltrane's Giant Steps began as a tumbling, unaccompanied sax overture before the pianist began a churning rhythm underneath it. It was a tribute to both Smith's secure control and Brackeen's fizzing swing and density of sound that the piece could sustain the breakneck tempo of the original without a rhythm section.

Piano/sax improvising duets are a hard way to make a living, but this one made it all sound easy.

fields.headline: Intimate but unbalanced
fields.standfirst:
Macbeth
 BAC, London
***
fields.trailText:
Macbeth
BAC, London
***
fields.body:
Macbeth director Tom Morris says that he goes to the theatre seeking something he didn't expect. What I least expected from a BAC Macbeth was a solid, relatively straightforward, deliberately spoken affair suitable for school par ties that, at the final preview, kept a 75-strong Croydon group obediently attentive.

The production's oddities are few but distracting. Accompanying the action with musical maunderings from an on-stage cellist not only undercuts the verse but is extremely old-fashioned: it was the Victorians who treated Shakespeare as if he were a melodramatic librettist. Rearranging the text, in the supposed interests of clarity, only produces obscurity. To begin the play with Ross's battlefield lament for Young Seyward ("Your son, my lord, has paid a soldier's debt") is to kick off in a minor key and pointlessly sacrifice one of the great openings in world drama. Playing Macbeth's return visit to the Witches' cavern in total darkness is also a cop-out and asking for trouble with potentially explosive young audiences.

The strengths of Morris's production lie in its intimacy - Ti Green's design is basically a bloodstained, double-doored back wall lit by a flickering grate - and in the central casting. Corin Redgrave's Macbeth is a seasoned soldier who has to be wooed into assassination against his better judgement and who, once engaged, finds he has has entered a nightmare realm. Applying military solutions to political problems he learns that you cannot achieve security simply by eliminating the opposition. Reduced to a gibbering wreck by Banquo's ghost and lassitudinous despair by Malcolm's advance, Redgrave gives a highly intelligent performance that uses darting vocal emphasis - I liked the stress on his "violent love" for Duncan - to illumine Macbeth's inner torment.

Amanda Harris, doubling as a Weird Sister, is also an impressive Lady Macbeth who could walk straight into any RSC production: with swept-back hair, black jacket and scarlet skirt she exudes both firmness of purpose and seductive androgyny. I even liked the idea of her eavesdropping on her enthroned husband as if refusing to be exiled from the corridors of power.

On the credit side, Shaun Prendergast is a fiercely pensive Macduff who has clearly rumbled Macbeth from the start. Very much in the debit account, Jonathan Coyne is a ludicrously indulged Porter who falls down more often than Norman Wisdom and who, in every sense, makes endless bum jokes. It is typical of this variable production that makes a positive virtue of the space's hermetic intimacy but that, at two-and-three-quarter hours, urgently needs more narrative propulsion.

 Until April 16. Box office: 020-7223 2223

webTitle: Peter Ho Davies's top 10 short story collections

fields.headline: Peter Ho Davies's top 10 short story collections
fields.trailText: Peter Ho Davies's latest book, Equal Love, is published by Granta
fields.body:
Peter Ho Davies's latest book, Equal Love, is published by Granta
Buy Equal Love at Amazon.co.uk

1. Essential Tales of Chekhov by Anton Chekhov (ed. Richard Ford)
A wonderful introduction to the father of the modern short story, selectedby a contemporary master.

2. Dubliners by James Joyce
Joyce wrote (arguably) the greatest novel of the last century, but only after he had written (unarguably) the greatest short story ever: The Dead.

3. The Complete Stories of Flannery O'Connor by Flannery O'Connor
You can hear God laughing (nastily) at the chilling black comedy of A Good Man is Hard to Find. And Good Country People must be the oddest retelling of Cinderella yet - with a prince called Manley Pointer and an artificial leg in place of a glass slipper it is even better than AngelaCarter's reworked fairytales.

4. Collected Fictions by Borges
Borges looks like the genius of laziness - a writer who'd rather review an imaginary novel than write it - but these brief stories, like the tardis (a simple device by Borgesian standards), are always mind-bendingly bigger on the inside than the outside. The South, one of Borges own favourites, is an overlooked masterpiece.

5. The Collected Stories by Ernest Hemingway
The most imitated American writer of the 20th century hasn't always been well-served by followers or fans, but his stories, perhaps his best work,continue to surprise, from the bleak poetry of A Clean Well Lighted Place to the super-human restraint of Hills Like White Elephants.

6. Where I'm Calling From by Raymond Carver
We think of Carver as a kind of broken-down Hemingway: without the bullfights or safaris and left only with the failing relationships, and booze. But the last story here, Errand, about the death of Chekhov,written while Carver himself was dying, offers a glimpse of his range.

7. The Collected Stories of Grace Paley by Grace Paley
Only one collection every ten years or so since the 1950's, but then short stories are all about quality over quantity. In Time Which Made a Monkey of Us All, manages to be funny, profound and moving about both the Holocaust and the Bomb, all in less than 20 pages.

8. The History of the World in 10 1/2 Chapters by Julian Barnes
A "closet" collection (Jim Crace's Continent is another) passing as anovel. Even if the title proclaims them chapters, these linked stories demonstrate one big advantage a collection has over a conventional novel:its ability to vault over time and space, from character to character; to be all encompassing without telling all.

9. Selected Stories by Alice Munro
The Goddess of Small Things. The short story writer who does the impossible and makes stories flow and feel like nineteenth century novels.

10. Jesus' Son by Denis Johnson
The exception to the rule that stories linked by one character are reallyunfinished novels. The fragmented, but overlapping form of a collection is perfect for the detached, numbed-out recurring character (known only as Fuckhead) and his disjointed druggy experience. An American Trainspotting? Better.

webTitle: My job's out of my control

fields.headline: My job's out of my control
fields.trailText: After a major reorganisation, our chief executive is retiring and most of the staff are looking for other jobs. My job's undermined and I am no longer performing many of the functions which I was employed for. How can I stop it?
fields.body:
The problem

After a major reorganisation, our chief executive is retiring and this has created a lot of uncertainty and dramatically lowered morale. Two people (out of a staff of 20) have already handed in their notices and more are attending interviews. Since the reorganisation, my role has been undermined and I am no longer performing many of the functions which I was employed for.

I report directly to the chief executive and I am nervous that my role may change permanently if I do not act to stop it.

The solution

This is a classic case of an organisation's poor management of change. However, there is not an awful lot you can do to safeguard your position, which is why so many of your colleagues are looking to leave. Although an employer cannot legally change the terms of your contract (which is effectively what they are doing if you are no longer doing the job you were employed to do) without negotiation with you, they could argue that it is reasonable for your job role to change. For instance, the reorganisation may mean that some of your former tasks are no longer necessary and thus you are having to perform different ones.

You don't have much choice but to put up with it. Had you been there more than one year, you could, in theory, have left and tried to claim constructive dismissal, but even then this would have been hard to prove. All you can do is to try and negotiate with the new chief exec as and when he or she is appointed. You will need to use all your impression management, communication and negotiating skills to try and convince the new boss that what you were doing before will work just as well now. Whilst I rarely recommend my own books, Psychology Goes to Work could help you with this.

If, at the end of the day, it all goes pear-shaped, I advise you to hang on in there for another year and then start looking to leave like your colleagues. But, you never know, your new boss might sing from the same hymn book as you.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

Had you been there more than one year, you could, in theory, have left and tried to claim constructive dismissal, but even then this would have been hard to prove. All you can do is to try and negotiate with the new chief exec as and when he or she is appointed. You will need to use all your impression management, communication and negotiating skills to try and convince the new boss that what you were doing before will work just as well now. Whilst I rarely recommend my own books, Psychology Goes to Work could help you with this. If, at the end of the day, it all goes pear-shaped, I advise you to hang on in there for another year and then start looking to leave like your colleagues. But, you never know, your new boss might sing from the same hymn book as you. Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

fields.headline: Somerfield sacks chief executive
fields.trailText: The chief executive of struggling grocery group Somerfield was fired yesterday as the group announced it had no prospect of attracting a takeover bid at an acceptable price.
fields.body:
The chief executive of struggling grocery group Somerfield was fired yesterday as the group announced it had no prospect of attracting a takeover bid at an acceptable price.

David Simons, who had been at the helm of Somerfield since 1993, was paid £767,000 last year and is likely to receive compensation for loss of office of some £500,000.

He is to be replaced by Alan Smith, chief executive of pubs group Punch. The company said it would also name a new executive chairman shortly. One analyst described the task facing them as "herculean".

Mr Simons was asked to go when it became clear that shareholders in the group, which has suffered falling sales and market share after a disastrous merger with Kwik Save, were not about to be put out of their misery with a takeover offer.

The shares, which were changing hands at 465p only 18 months ago, closed down 4p at 58p, just above their record low.

The group announced on March 6 that it had received approaches, thought to be from City buyers, which could lead to a bid. But yesterday acting chairman Lady Patten said: "There was no certainty that we would get a firm offer." She abandoned the bid talks, which she described as "a distraction". The group would concentrate on improving trading.

"We need to focus on the basics. This business has good people, it has now got good management and it has a future."

Mr Simons had made "a great contribution" to Somerfield, but non-executive directors decided to ask him to go because "we have become concerned about the business in the last month".

The company denied Mr Simons' removal was linked to boardroom arguments or speculation that he wanted to arrange finance to take the company private.

webTitle: Unions claim BMW blocking rival Rover bid

fields.headline: Unions claim BMW blocking rival Rover bid
fields.standfirst:
Alchemy deal 'the worst possible solution'

Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Union leaders yesterday accused BMW of seeking to block an alternative bid for its Rover cars subsidiary.
fields.body:
Union leaders yesterday accused BMW of seeking to block an alternative bid for its Rover cars subsidiary.

Tony Woodley, chief motor industry negotiator for the T&G, told MPs that BMW was refusing to provide essential information about its planned sale of Rover to Alchemy Partners, a London-based venture capital business.

Giving evidence to the Commons trade and industry select committee, Mr Woodley said: "We are finding it difficult to acquire information which a third party needs to create a bid."

Werner Saemann, Rover's chairman and chief executive, later told the committee that BMW would not provide the details since it was a private deal between two private companies. BMW would consider a "concrete" alternative bid, but not just ideas. "The Alchemy deal is still the best one in town," he said.

He said that BMW had tried to sell Rover to General Motors and Ford, but neither had been interested.

Jon Moulton, Alchemy's managing partner, said he could not yet say how many jobs would be saved at Rover's Longbridge plant in Birmingham and he did not want to raise expectations by guessing.

However he expected it would be several thousand rather than hundreds of jobs. He said the plant would make up to 25,000 two seater sports cars and more than 50,000 sports saloons under the MG badge. He said the thousands of unsold Rover 75 cars would not be sold as a bargain lot. "That would ruin the brand," he said. However he expected to sell "more exciting" versions of the 75.

He did not rule out building short runs of vehicles for other manufacturers. "We are going to have monumental amounts of spare capacity, and if we can fill it on economically sensible grounds, we will," he said.

Reacting to the crisis, Tony Blair and Stephen Byers are to hold a Downing Street meeting today with T&G boss Bill Morris and Sir Ken Jackson, head of engineering and electrical union, the AEEU.

The prime minister, his industry secretary and leaders of the two biggest unions will discuss the future of motor manufacturing. On top of the threats to Rover's Longbridge plant and Ford's Dagenham complex, Nissan and Toyota have complained the high pound is wiping out profits.

John Mantle, chairman of the Rover Franchise Board, told the committee that the scaling down of Longbridge also threatened the jobs of the 15,000 people employed by Rover's 300 dealers.

He told MPs that the new Mini might be sold through BMW dealerships, and it was not clear who would sell the existing Rover models. But it was almost certain that many dealerships would not be viable at lower volumes.

Mr Woodley told the MPs that the Alchemy solution was the worst possible for Rover. He accused the BMW board of panicking and making a spur- of-the-moment decision to pull out of Rover.

The company had behaved "dishonourably and dishonestly" in not consulting its British workers, he said. He expected 10,000 immediate job losses at Longbridge. There was an urgent need for an alternative bid that would keep the fabric of Rover, albeit on a smaller scale, but leave it with scope for growth, he said

Mr Moulton dismissed union fears that BMW and Alchemy would seek to avoid paying Rover's above average redundancy rates.

Mr Saemann reiterated BMW's view that the government had been made aware of Rover's perilous position, created largely by the strength of sterling which had cost the company £237m last year.

He said BMW chairman, Joachim Milberg, had phoned Mr Byers on March 15 and told him the three options being put to the group's supervisory board - the sale of the whole of BMW, the sale of Rover cars and Land Rover, or the closure of Rover cars.

webTitle: Amstrad offers email access for the computerphobic

fields.headline: Amstrad offers email access for the computerphobic
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Sir Alan Sugar, Amstrad's chairman, yesterday launched his latest assault on the consumer electronics market in the form of a fixed-line telephone with email capabilities.
fields.body:
Sir Alan Sugar, Amstrad's chairman, yesterday launched his latest assault on the consumer electronics market in the form of a fixed-line telephone with email capabilities.

Sir Alan described the e-m@iler, which is priced at £79.99, as a "no-brainer", targeted at people who are unable to cope with computers.

He expected Amstrad to sell more than 1m e-m@ilers within two years: "I expect it to be as popular as BSkyB."

However, the stock market was unconvinced: Amstrad's shares dived 104p to 504p.

Analysts said the product would face stiff competition from developments in mobile phones and televisions which are likely to offer broader access to the net. One trader said: "I just can't get excited about this."

Sir Alan said Amstrad had been pondering how to exploit the internet: "We sort of sat back a little bit wondering how we could configure a product to take advantage of it." Email was the "killer application" used by people who lacked the money or inclination to buy a personal computer.

He dismissed the threat from mobile phones: "This [the e-m@iler] has a much bigger screen - it's more useful." He was also sceptical about "smart" television sets: "They will always remain dumb boxes."

Amstrad will make a loss when selling its e-m@ailers, which will be made in its factory in China. The group plans to recoup the money by charging companies to advertise on the phones' screens.

Sir Alan said: "Every one of these is an advertising hoarding. They will download commercials in the middle of the night when phone lines are not very busy."

Customers will pay 12p each time they send or receive emails. Otherwise, calls will cost the usual rates charged by British Telecom - which is collaborating with Amstrad on the project - and there is no subscription fee. The phones also have voice mail and fax facilities.

Howard Brooks of Amstrad's broker, Beeson Gregory, said the shares had fallen because of wild speculation about the launch. He said the product was "evolutionary, rather than revolutionary".

Amstrad is setting up a subsidiary, Amserve, to sell the machines and the venture is forecast to break even in two years.

fields.headline: Ben Zander with the Philharmonia
fields.standfirst:
Royal Festival Hall, London
*****
fields.trailText:
Royal Festival Hall, London
*****
fields.body:
There was a sense of history repeating itself in Ben Zander's concert with the Philharmonia. Mendelssohn's Violin Concerto was played by 14-year-old Stefan Jackiw on his London debut. Mendelssohn himself last heard this concerto in a performance with the 15-year-old Joseph Joachim, who went on to become one of the 19th century's towering musicians.

Maybe at this stage comparisons with Joachim are invidious, but Jackiw's performance suggested that his future could be glittering. Many child virtuosi are notable only for their freakish mastery of their instrument. But Jackiw's performance was more than a polished run-through; it was a performance of real musical integrity.

His technical prowess was never in doubt, with his sure intonation and seamless negotiation of Mendelssohn's transparent violin writing. And the chamber music-like intimacy of his sound, and Zander's accompaniment, were particularly well-suited to the ebb and flow of the slow movement. The way Jackiw paced the bravura showpiece of the first movement's cadenza illustrated his rare combination of virtuoso technique and natural musicality.

Mahler's Fourth Symphony is a sort of reverse image of innocence - the work progressively rids itself of worldly sophistication and complexity. Right from the start, Zander's account was breathtakingly poised on a knife-edge between happiness and sorrow, and life and death. Every disconcerting melodic transformation and jarring shift of orchestral perspective was captured by Zander and an inspired Philharmonia.

Leader James Clark's garish, diabolical solo in the second movement, on an instrument tuned a tone too high, was the most emphatic revelation of Mahler's Janus-like personality. He brought abrasiveness to the surrounding pastoral texture and conjured up a nightmarish vision of the evil resident in every fairy tale. By Lynne Dawson's rapt solo in the fourth movement, Zander had completed an epic emotional journey. Motifs from the first movement, which had been tokens of ambivalence and tainted experience, reappeared as objects of sensuous, unfettered joy.

webTitle: My colleague is fed up with being ignored

fields.headline: My colleague is fed up with being ignored
fields.trailText: The problem
fields.body:
The problem

One colleague at work is making another's life miserable by completely ignoring him. She even crosses the street if she sees him. He does not understand why and is angry about it. It has gone on for several months and the ignored colleague is about to leave. Should he confront her before he goes and how do we stop it happening again?

The solution

Yes, he should confront her. Why not? he has nothing to lose now. Her behaviour sounds rather extreme and goes beyond the sort of general moodiness that some people unfortunately exhibit. It sounds like she has a reason or some perceived injustice that she feels she has experienced at your colleague's hands.

Has this woman been like this with anyone else? If not, you can assume that she feels aggrieved by this man and that now he is leaving, the problem should not recur. From what you say, it does sound like this is a one-off and it may be that this woman has a very good reason for being upset with your colleague. Only by confronting her, will you know.

Of course, another option would be for you to confront her, rather than your exiting colleague. Or, perhaps you could get both people together and act as a kind of arbitrator so that they can try and sort out their differences. Obviously, it is too late for your leaving colleague, but such action may help prevent this happening again.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

fields.headline: Rebels target ScotProv
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Scottish Provident yesterday became the latest mutual life office to face attack by internet-based carpetbaggers after 30 members filed a resolution demanding that its be balloted 750,000 policyholders about demutualisation.
fields.body:
Scottish Provident yesterday became the latest mutual life office to face attack by internet-based carpetbaggers after 30 members filed a resolution demanding that its be balloted 750,000 policyholders about demutualisation.

If the resolution is successful members could be in line for minimum windfalls of £1,000. Analysts yesterday put a price tag of at least £1bn on Scottish Provident, which is the market leader in the UK for "protection" policies such as term insurance and critical illness plans, and has a 40% stake in Aberdeen Asset Management, a beneficiary of the sales boom in technology-related equities.

The demutualisation move is led by 50-year Gordon Hart, leader of the self-styled Scottish Provident Members Alliance Group. Yesterday it launched a website, www.spmag.co.uk, containing a copy of the resolution and a bulletin board for "cyber-baggers".

A Scottish Provident spokeswoman said: "We can confirm that we have received the letter. The board will give proper consideration to the content of the resolution, but until then we cannot say anything else."

Fellow Edinburgh insurer Standard Life recently rebuffed an attempt by Monaco-based carpetbagger Fred Wollard to force the £79bn life office into a demutualisation vote. But Scottish Provident, with £9.5bn under management, is less wedded to mutuality.

Independent life insurance analyst Ned Cazalet said Scottish Provident was more likely to arrange a takeover of the company rather than attempt to float on the stock market. however. "You're unlikely to see a Standard Life-style 'over our dead body' defence of mutuality," he said. "If someone puts a large wodge of cash on the table they will say 'we are open to offers'."

The spmag.co.uk website yesterday carried denials that the campaign to convert Scottish Provident was led by "professional" carpetbaggers. "This is not a funded or professionally backed campaign. Fred Woollard is not involved. Many of us have under-performing endowment policies and hope that a windfall will improve this situation," it said.

Scottish Provident has no with-profits fund policies open to new investment. Only such policyholders would be eligible for potential windfalls.

fields.headline: Manon
fields.standfirst:
Royal Opera House, London
****
fields.trailText:
Royal Opera House, London
****
fields.body:
The first time Viviana Durante danced Manon she was drafted into the show at two weeks' notice, replacing Darcey Bussell. At the time this generated a mini news storm because Bussell had been due to partner Irek Mukhamedov, and the media were trying to set them up as the new Fonteyn and Nureyev. But for ballet fans the real news was that Durante turned out to be so gifted a dance actress.

Hitherto Durante had been known as an elegant technician. But when she danced Manon her steeliness suddenly turned molten. In MacMillan's bold, sensuous choreography her body threw off its habitual controls and her face became hungry with emotion.

Performing the role this week, Durante reveals she's got even deeper into it. When Manon first steps out of her carriage Durante barely has to make a move to register all the emotions that assail her. Intriguingly, Durante does not seem to care whether we like her Manon or not. When she falls in love with Des Grieux her heart may be giddily engaged, but when Monsieur GM tempts her with jewels she responds with a greed that shows exactly where her soul lies. We feel that it's on little more than a whim that Manon finally relinquishes her wealth and returns to her lover.

The self-centredness of Durante's Manon may also stem from the fact that Mukhamedov, her scheduled Des Grieux, was injured and replaced by Jonathan Cope. Cope gives an ardent reading of this role, but his regular Manon is Sylvie Guillem. Technically little was amiss, but the love duets lacked a sense of erotic delirium.

But overall it was a good show. David Drew made a queasily seedy GM while Ashley Page brought a calculating cruelty to the lecherous gaoler. Nigel Burley's agile laddishness injected a fine comic momentum into Lescaut but there was a brutishness in his gesture that also revealed depths of corruption.

webTitle: Bank of England sees mortgage surge

fields.headline: Bank of England sees mortgage surge
fields.trailText: Mortgage lending has surged to its highest level for almost two years, according to new Bank of England figures which put paid to suggestions that the housing market is beginning to slow down.
fields.body:
Mortgage lending has surged to its highest level for almost two years, according to new Bank of England figures which put paid to suggestions that the housing market is beginning to slow down.

The number of mortgage approvals rose to 105,000 in February, up 11,000 on January and the highest figure since the Bank changed the way it records data in October 1997.

The take-off in loan approvals - defined as the "firm offer" made to a homebuyer, usually after a survey has been carried out - comes after recent signs that they may have been slowing, said economists. The new figures may strengthen the argument for an increase in interest rates when the Bank of England monetary policy committee meets next week.

Some observers said the surge in mortgage activity may be linked to a rush to complete house purchases ahead of an anticipated rise in stamp duty in the Budget last week. These fears were borne out when the chancellor announced a 0.5% increase in stamp duty on properties costing more than £250,000.

Figures issued by the Halifax earlier this month added weight to suggestions that the housing market was coming off the boil. It said house prices fell by the largest amount in a single month for almost six years in February. However, this finding was contradicted by Nationwide building society, which said prices jumped by 2.2% in February - the largest monthly increase since 1991.

In the February inflation report, the monetary policy committee drew comfort from the dip in mortgage approvals seen in December, noted Michael Saunders, UK economist at Salomon Smith Barney Citibank. "That sign of slowing housing now looks less certain," he said.

fields.headline: Neither shaken nor stirred
fields.standfirst:
Evgeny Kissin
Symphony Hall, Birmingham
****
fields.trailText:
Evgeny Kissin
Symphony Hall, Birmingham
****
fields.body:
Birmingham's Symphony Hall was packed to the rafters for Evgeny Kissin's solo piano recital on Tuesday. The ecstatic applause at the end of the evening was just as predictable. Although he is only 29 this year, Kissin is already a cult figure - all without any pop-style promotion by record company or management.

Judging from the audience reaction, many felt that they had heard something sensational. People were on their feet, clapping and cheering wildly, within seconds of the thunderous ending of Brahms's Piano Sonata, the final work on the official programme.

Granted, Kissin was impressive. There's plenty of energy in his playing, and the technical control is phenomenal. He can focus complex textures with lucid clarity, and every now and then there's a touch of magic - as in the startling foretaste of the impressionist Debussy in the fourth movement of the Brahms Sonata. But for me there was something strangely remote about a lot of it. Beethoven's D minor Sonata, Op 31 No 2, began compellingly - a riveting pianissimo in the opening slowly spread chord, with strong contrast in the nervously scurrying figures that follow. But expressively the performance didn't seem to grow much from this. The poise and the brilliance were striking enough, but I've heard quite a few performances - some by names a lot less starry than Kissin's - that have had more to say about the emotional drama and the intellectual subtleties of Beethoven's argument than he has.

Schumann's Carnival was more coherent and more consistent in its power and drive. What can sound like a loosely connected string of tiny pieces emerged as a single work with a single purpose - as though Kissin had the riotous final dance in his sights right from the start. But in terms of colour this was like a glossy black and white photograph of a rainbow - striking enough, as long as you're content with shades of grey.

The Brahms came off best, forceful or delicate when required and strongly shaped. But at some deep level the music remained dormant. Kissin can impress, but can he stir?

fields.headline: Ronny Jordan
fields.standfirst:
Jazz Cafe, London
***
fields.trailText:
Jazz Cafe, London
***
fields.body:
In the early 90s Ronny Jordan became a member of an exclusive club: he had a UK chart hit with a jazz instrumental. That track, a dance-floor version of Miles Davis's So What?, cemented the guitarist's reputation as the king of acid jazz. But soon afterwards he packed his bags and left for New York, where he has been for the past six years. This week he was back in Britain to promote a new CD, A Brighter Day.

And a promotion gig was exactly what it was, albeit one redeemed by the elan with which the twin-keyboard quintet sustained an irresistible funk pulse. Jordan first ran through his early successes (1992's The Antidote onward), then rattled down the track list for the new release. But his band was admirably equipped to impart freshness to an idiom of predictable punctuation. The Hammond organ breaks in particular exhibited all the harmonic intricacy and firebreathing climaxes of the Grant Green/Larry Young collaborations that have clearly meant so much to Jordan.

The contrast between the seething, many-layered intensity of the rhythm section and Jordan's reserved and lightly struck guitar sound gives this music much of its subtlety - and if there isn't much in it for improv fans, that's not the point. Jordan himself sounds more at ease with longer lines, and the group sound is mellow, elegantly executed radio-play music with a jazzy gloss. That should be quite enough for the sizeable fan club who are at last able to hear Ronny Jordan on his home turf again.

fields.headline: Grade to head Hemscott online
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Hemscott.Net, the online financial information group, yesterday named former Channel 4 chief Michael Grade as chairman ahead of a potential flotation of the business.
fields.body:
Hemscott.net, the online financial information group, yesterday named former Channel 4 chief Michael Grade as chairman ahead of a potential flotation of the business.

The company was set up as an internet portal in July 1999 and split off from publishing group Hemmington Scott at the beginning of this year. It provides investment and business information and analysis on stock market-quoted firms as well as running a popular bulletin board for investors.

"What separates the real businesses from the fluff in the internet is having real, creative content and ownership over that content," Mr Grade said. "Hemscott has that in abundance and is a great brand."

The company has also launched a portal for the law community which includes a recruitment service.

Hemscott is run by chief executive Ros Wilton - the first woman member of the executive committee at news and in formation group Reuters, where she was managing director of Reuters Information. Ms Wilton joined the Hemscott group six months ago.

The company has retained City bank Rothschilds to help raise finance and review future options for the company, including flotation. A round of financing several months ago raised £5m from existing institutional shareholders.

Hemscott owns the data on which the business is founded and has a contract with its former publishing parent allowing it access to information for books including the widely used Corporate Register.

The non-executive post for Mr Grade - who orchestrated the break-up of First Leisure - will provide another stipend on top of a number of directorships. He is also non-executive chairman of Pinewood Studios and Octopus Publishing and a director of National Lottery operator Camelot.

"I made the decision some time ago that if I could avoid doing a full-time job I would," Mr Grade said.

fields.headline: $1m share looms in Tokyo
fields.standfirst:
Yahoo! Japan soars as internet fever hits exchange

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The world's first $1m share moved closer yesterday after internet fever gripped Tokyo's stock exchange. Shares in Yahoo! Japan, the country's most popular internet portal, shot up by the daily limit to hit 101.4m yen ($960,000) yesterday - more than 50 times the 1997 float price.
fields.body:
The world's first $1m share moved closer yesterday after internet fever gripped Tokyo's stock exchange. Shares in Yahoo! Japan, the country's most popular internet portal, shot up by the daily limit to hit 101.4m yen ($960,000) yesterday - more than 50 times the 1997 float price.

One unnamed director received a $20.5m boost to his pay after Yahoo! Japan said it would issue 38 new shares to him under a employee stock option scheme.

A Yahoo! Japan spokesman added that warrants for about 400 more shares were still outstanding and could be exercised under the stock option plan. Yahoo! Japan's shares closed at 62.3m yen yesterday, trading at a price to earnings ratio of more than 3,355. The astonishing rise is a result of the rarity of stock - there are only 4,200 on offer on the exchange.

The rush for the shares was sparked by plans for a two for one split - with investors apparently willing to pay $300,000 for each new share in the company.

The rise will bring another bonanza for Masayoshi Son, the world's second richest man, whose company owns 51% of Yahoo! Japan.

The other major shareholder, with 34%, is the original search engine Yahoo!, which serves up more than 300m web pages a day.

Japan has been slow to catch on to the internet - less than a fifth of the population surfs the web, in comparison with half of adults in the United States.

However analysts point out that this means there is huge potential for growth for internet firms in the world's second largest economy.

 Shares in Lycos Europe on Frankfurt's hi-tech stock market failed to spark investors' interest on the first day of trading. Issued at €24 a share, Lycos Europe closed the day at €22.75 - a loss of some 5.5% for investors.

Lycos hopes that the cash raised will allow it to build its brand and overtake Yahoo! as Europe's top web portal.

fields.headline: Leicester pay for ticket scandal
fields.trailText: The Football Association has accused Leicester City of trying to hinder its investigation into the 1999 Worthington Cup final ticket scandal, which yesterday resulted in record fines for seven current or former City players and staff.
fields.body:
The Football Association has accused Leicester City of trying to hinder its investigation into the 1999 Worthington Cup final ticket scandal, which yesterday resulted in record fines for seven current or former City players and staff.

The FA spokesman Steve Double said the club had tried to hide behind a "smokescreen" even though the Tottenham fan who punched a young mother during crowd disturbances at the game had gained entry to the Leicester section with a ticket originally owned by the City wing-back Andy Impey.

After the "most serious and thorough investigation into the misuse of match tickets" ever undertaken by the FA, a disciplinary commission found all seven guilty of misconduct over the handling of tickets for the final between City and Tottenham.

Crowd trouble broke out after Spurs fans obtained tickets for the Leicester end at Wembley. Double said yesterday that Leicester players had either deliberately given their tickets to Spurs fans or acted carelessly about where they might end up.

Impey received the biggest fine, £20,000. Yesterday the woman victim, Ruth Lelacheur, said: "We're pleased with the outcome and just wonder why it took so long." Despite an appeal on BBC's Crimewatch her attacker has never been identified.

"The lady needed treatment to head, back and neck injuries," said Double, "and her little girl with her was traumatised by what took place. Those scenes were a direct result of the Leicester players' tickets being sold to Spurs fans. They were allocated to Andy Impey."

The player had bought 75 tickets for the Wembley showpiece and admitted to the commission that 10 had gone to Spurs fans. He was given a five-year ban from receiving tickets for home internationals, cup finals and semi-finals. City have also fined him two weeks' wages.

Tony Cottee had 79 tickets, of which 35 ended up with Spurs fans. He was fined £12,500 and handed a three-year ticket ban. Leicester's academy director David Nish had 129 tickets, of which at least 13 fell into the possession of Spurs fans; he was fined £10,000 with a three-year ban. The chief scout Jim Melrose allowed 26 of his 75 tickets to go to Spurs fans; he was fined £5,000 with a two-year ban. Scott Taylor, now with Wolves, gave tickets to up to 10 Spurs fans; he was fined £7,500 and received a two-year ban. Graham Fenton, currently on loan at Walsall, admitted supplying four Spurs fans with tickets; he was fined £5,000 with a two-year ban. Arnar Gunnlaugsson, on loan at Stoke, gave 31 tickets to Spurs fans and was fined £15,000 with a five-year ban. All seven, who were ordered to pay £2,500 costs each, plan to appeal.

Double was scathing about Leicester's attitude to the inquiry. "There was a lot of questioning about why we were doing it when it was patently an important issue to get to the bottom of," he said. "Our initial requests for information were ignored, which made it hard to discover how the tickets were passed on. Even now, quite how they ended up in certain Spurs supporters' hands remains a mystery."

John Straw, a lawyer speaking on behalf of the seven, said: "The penalties are draconian, wholly disproportionate to each other and in relation to any previous punishment imposed by the commission."

He also said there were no FA guidelines in place at the time about ticket distribution. However, Double countered by saying: "It's blatantly common sense that you don't give opposition fans the chance to obtain your tickets. Segregating rival football supporters is the single most important issue in crowd safety."

Steve Guppy and the City physio Ian Andrews were cleared of any guilt on Monday. Two other City players, Neil Lennon and Stuart Campbell, will receive personal hearings on April 11.

webTitle: Glasgow chill wind is better than home

fields.headline: Glasgow chill wind is better than home
fields.standfirst:
Guardian reporters continue a special series on the experience of asylum seekers in Britain and the bitter politics that lie behind a question that stirs deep emotions. Today: the dispersal, moving to Scotland to relieve the south raises tensions locally

The issue explained: How to claim asylum
Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Guardian reporters continue a special series on the experience of asylum seekers in Britain and the bitter politics that lie behind a question that stirs deep emotions.  Today: the dispersal, moving to Scotland to relieve the south raises tensions locally
fields.body:
There are three photographs. Each show a bloody corpse. One man has gunshot injuries, the other has had his throat cut. Another is a gruesome picture of a dead baby. Abdul Majeed fingers the photographs slowly, explaining what happened to these members of his family at home in Sri Lanka.

There is a pile of manila folders on the 36-year-old's lap containing documents that detail the life he escaped from. There are x-rays of his dislocated right arm which he says was as a result of torture. There is his brother's death certificate and Majeed's complaint to the Sri Lankan human rights commission. There is even a police report detailing the grenade attack on his family home last December.

Majeed (not his real name) is a Tamil Muslim from Sri Lanka's eastern province. Now, he is sitting in a chilly flat in a 20-storey tower block in the north of Glasgow. He and his wife and two children have lived in the Sighthill housing scheme for two weeks after being dispersed to Scotland from a hotel in Hastings where they shared one room. They were moved to Glasgow when a doctor said the hotel food did not agree with Majeed, who has diabetes and hypertension.

The family - wife Fathima, son Husain, four, and daughter Munsifa, 15 months - have a freshly painted, two bedroom flat. There is a check print sofa, armchairs, dining table, lampshades, washing machine, beds with fat duvets, an iron and board: all new.

Relieve the strain

The Majeeds are part of a first wave of refugees sent to Glasgow as part of an interim arrangement made by the government ahead of next week's planned dispersal of asylum seekers. It is hoped that this and further dispersals will relieve the strain refugees are putting on the London boroughs and Kent.

The plan was going smoothly until a group of Romanian women were caught begging in the douce suburb of Bishopbriggs. After discovering that some Romanian families were in breach of restrictions ordering them to report to a police station in London, Glasgow city council bussed them back to Wandsworth and postponed any further dispersals. Last Friday, after negotiation with the London Asylum Seekers Consortium, Glasgow said it would resume the programme and would accept a total of 600 refugees in the city.

That number will increase by another 2,500 after the city's ruling Labour group yesterday agreed to increase its intake. The first 50 families will travel to Glasgow today. There are 60 refugee families in Sighthill at the moment. Many of the new arrivals expressed unease when they saw the strict security system at the bottom of each of the tower blocks. All closed circuit cameras and entry codes, they thought they were being committed to some high-rise prison. Now, they lock their doors from the inside.

As Majeed looks out of his fifth floor window, he can see why people are scared. The north of Glasgow is its poorest part, it holds areas of multiple deprivation such as Sighthill and has problems with alcoholism, drug addiction, crime, unemployment and boredom: trouble that many residents would love to seek asylum from themselves.

The scheme has 10 high rise blocks, each as wide as two traditional multi storeys. Built during 1964-1969 on the soda wastes of the old St Rollox chemical works, Sighthill sits just below the cemetery of the same name. In The Buildings of Scotland: Glasgow, Sighthill, is described as a "singularly unpropitious site".

It says: "From a distance the scheme, with its slab blocks ranged in parallel, resembles the utopian illustration that was no doubt in the architect's mind. Close to, the brutalism of the concrete construction is revealed: hammered concrete panels, huge pebble aggregate and slatted screens to the drying areas." Like other high rise schemes, Sighthill suffers from poor planning and a lack of amenities. It is a miserable, grey, windlashed place. "Just you wait till you catch the wind whipping round the corners," warns one of the scheme's concierges. "You'll never feel a wind like it."

It is to here that the majority of refugees will come. Majeed does not mind. He says he has been warned that some of the children here might be a little rough. He will just have to be careful and quietly go about the business of finding some kind of life here. After all, he paid an agent around £9,000 to get here, or at least anywhere that was not Sri Lanka.

"This is not so bad. The flat is very small but we are happy here," he explains. Asked what the family do all day, the former medical student says: "Nothing, we stay in the flat, we cannot do anything. We have lost our life and I am losing my time." Just as it is with Sighthill's original population, boredom is in abundance for the new one. For most asylum seekers, getting a television is a big concern: it can help with the language and is something to do.

But it is the sight of TVs being carried into the tower blocks that winds up other Sighthill tenants. "They walk in and out with new televisions. Where do they get the money for tellies? And how are they going to pay their licence fee?" asked a man outside the Sighthill post office.

The asylum seekers are given cash every week which means they can buy whatever they want. Majeed would rather buy a television with this week's money and scrimp on food. "My boy asks me for a television all the time. What am I supposed to do?"

£300 a week

Every week asylum seekers traipse over to Sighthill youth centre where they wait in line to pick up their payment. They do not get vouchers because Glasgow refused to become involved in something that was "so demeaning". Instead, the council gets £300 per family per week which will change to £220 a week for families dispersed under the government's new scheme (they will get vouchers).

David Comley, the city's housing director and chairman of the Scottish Asylum Seekers Consortium, says Glasgow has always had a tradition of accommodating refugees. But it is not just a spirit of generosity that has persuaded the council to participate. It could make some money.

"We are able to help because we have more houses than there is demand for. That's obviously a different situation than in the majority of London boroughs," says Comley. "It benefits the council in financial terms. What it gives us is council tax and rent with no collection charges and no arrears and a lot of that is for property we probably wouldn't be able to let. We are not going to make money on this because we obviously have to provide services for asylum seekers."

But it is the provision of services and furniture that provokes the anger of neighbours. Paula Hinton is 28 and lives in a block in the scheme's Pinkston Drive with her four-year-old son Darren. She is unhappy about the presence of asylum seekers. "I think it is ridiculous, they are everywhere," she says. "They are getting all the money spent on them and I get £85 a week for me and Darren. They are getting furnished flats and we have to buy everything and that's what people are angry about, the fact that they get everything brand new. Would we get that if we went to their community?"

Her friend, Ann Marie MacDonald, is more calm: "It's not the fact that they are here. The government is doing an awful lot for other folk but there's a lot of deprivation in our own country. What about all the homeless people we have got?"

Her friend adds: "Take a look around here and nobody is doing anything for us. I have no objection to them personally, they haven't asked to be brought here. But they should be putting us first before them. They have all been through an awful lot and it's not that that people are getting at. It's the principle. It's the fact that there's people here with needs. Did they put them here because it's a poor, poverty-stricken area?"

That mixture of welcome and resentment is similar to the one experienced by Oscar Mendoza, a Chilean refugee who arrived in Glasgow in 1975 when he fled Pinochet's regime after being tortured.

In a recent letter to the Herald newspaper, he said: "All of us experienced a mixture of warm and friendly welcome from some people, mainly those who knew the background to the end of democracy in Chile and supported our struggle against the regime, and hostility, mostly with racist and xenophobic overtones. Not much has changed, apparently."

Such obvious anxieties in the local community made Sighthill a target last week for the smart-suited members of the British National party, who leafleted the estate. They were soon chased out by the concierges. There are four concierge stations across the scheme, each with half a dozen television screens which hold lots of smaller images from the CCTV cameras outside. Allan Syme, the senior concierge, says he tries to help the asylum seekers but communication difficulties mean they often end up playing a game of charades.

It is often easy to pick out the asylum seekers. You can spot them at Huntingdon Square, the cluster of graffiti ridden, shuttered-up boxes that is the area's main shopping centre. Here, some of the shelves of the U-Save supermarket are bare. Like many poor areas, the selection of fresh fruit and vegetables available is dreadful and many refugees walk to the cut-price LIDL store for a marginally better range. The manager there, Dave Carey, says there has been an increase in the sale of fresh goods, health foods and yoghurts. Carey does not mind the asylum seekers but the boy on the till turns up his nose. "I hate them," he says. "They shouldnae be here in my opinion."

School problem

This attitude is a worry for parents sending their children out from behind locked doors and into the classrooms in Glasgow. The newest will go to local schools after the Easter holidays. The city's previous batches of refugee children attended a bilingual education unit but as a result of the massive increase in numbers this will not be possible. Extra staff will be employed and children will be integrated. They will not be taught English as a separate subject but will learn it through the general curriculum.

Maggie Innes is headteacher at the bilingual support unit for primary children in Glasgow's west end. "Because of the numbers that will be coming in we are hoping to set up classes within the local schools in the areas where they will be living," she explains. "How they cope depends very much on the child's educational and emotional background and what they have been through. With some children, their learning process has been slowed up. But when they come to school they become more relaxed and happy."

Some of the same children can be found playing on the landings of Sighthill and the neighbouring Red Road flats. They seem to be happy. A number of Kosovan refugees have been in Glasgow for almost a year now and have settled in well.

The Avdyli family arrived last September and live on the 29th floor of Red Road. Their flat is more homely than those of the new refugees; they have a calendar on the wall, a TV, a PC and tiny little cups for coffee. "When I first came to Glasgow from London I had to accept it, whatever it was," said Ramiz Avdyli, 52, who had been a finance director in Kosovo. "Now I have been here quite a long time I am impressed, especially by the people ."

fields.headline: Six asylum seekers flee centre
fields.standfirst:
The issue explained: How to claim asylum
Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Six Romanian asylum seekers who absconded from a new refugee centre were still at large last night but were not being actively pursued.
fields.body:
Six Romanian asylum seekers who absconded from a new refugee centre were still at large last night but were not being actively pursued.

The Home Office gave details of the men to police after they fled from the former Oakington army barracks in Cambridgeshire on Monday night, a week after the first refugees arrived at the £4.5m centre.

But Cambridgeshire police said they would only recapture them if they stumbled across them, if they believed any of them were at risk, or if they had committed a criminal act.

"People have to remember that these are not convicted criminals, they are people who have come to this country seeking refuge," a spokesman said. "We have to get the balance right, but this is not intended to be a prison. I would stress they are not a danger to the public."

The immigration enforcement directory has responsibility for finding the men. Addresses in Britain mentioned by the men are being checked. "We are not actively searching with police dogs," said a Home Office spokesman. "They could have gone anywhere."

One of those who escaped had been told on Monday that he was being refused asylum, but had been granted temporary admission awaiting appeal.

Villagers claimed they had been told security would be tight at the base. "We have always said that the fencing isn't sufficient to keep the immigrant people in," said Marion Reeves, clerk to Longstanton parish council.

"It is a military establishment built to keep people out, not in. People are now very worried about their safety."

The men came in separately to Britain via Dover last week.

The centre, with a capacity of 400, has been used by 32 people since it opened. The government wants it to process each asylum application within seven days.

"The people who go there are screened from the point of view that we believe they are going to cooperate with the process, said a Home Office spokesman.

Group 4, which supervises the security of the base, would not comment. But the Home Office said that though they were expected to mount patrols, their main role was protecting the refugees rather than preventing them from getting out.

fields.headline: News round-up
fields.trailText: David Beckham was told yesterday that Manchester United will have no hesitation in transfer-listing him if he makes exorbitant demands when both parties discuss renegotiating his personal terms at the end of the season.
fields.body:
David Beckham was told yesterday that Manchester United will have no hesitation in transfer-listing him if he makes exorbitant demands when both parties discuss renegotiating his personal terms at the end of the season.

Having broken their pay structure to keep Roy Keane at Old Trafford, United were at pains to emphasise that Beckham should not view the Irishman's £52,000-a-week deal as a precedent.

"He is free to negotiate what he believes is fair and we will try to stretch to that," said the chief executive Martin Edwards. "But if we can't reach an agreement, then so be it, he will be put on the transfer market." Beckham still has three years remaining on his deal, believed to be worth about £24,000 a week.

Arsenal's Nwankwo Kanu and Chelsea's defender Celestine Babayaro have been named in the Nigeria squad for a World Cup qualifying match against Eritrea on April 9. South Africa, however, have omitted Leeds's Lucas Radebe and Manchester United's Quinton Fortune for their qualifier in Lesotho on the same day.

Middlesbrough have become the third Premiership club to fall under the umbrella of the American cable company NTL after selling a 5.58% stake for around £15m in return for the rights to any Boro television channel and internet operation. The bulk of the money will be freed to help reshape the club's ageing squad in time for next season.

NTL entered into an agreement with Newcastle, where it has a 9.9% stake, during December and also has a deal with Aston Villa.

Cyrille Regis, a former West Brom striker and the interim manager before Gary Megson's recent appointment, has left the Hawthorns coaching staff. "I feel that the ambitions I have will be better served by moving to another club," he said.

fields.headline: Telfer to face French
fields.trailText: Two huge security men walked into Scotland's hotel at Troon yesterday and planted the World Cup down on the table where Craig Brown was sitting. He recoiled in horror, football's superstitions stating that it is unlucky to touch a trophy you have not won.
fields.body:
Two huge security men walked into Scotland's hotel at Troon yesterday and planted the World Cup down on the table where Craig Brown was sitting.

He recoiled in horror, football's superstitions stating that it is unlucky to touch a trophy you have not won.

But the manager still eyed it with some reverence and it prompted him into some remarks about the nature of tonight's friendly against France at Hampden Park.

"If you look at it pound for pound in terms of transfer fees and salaries, we probably don't deserve to be on the same pitch. Their players perform in rarefied atmospheres throughout Europe and we should be swamped. But we won't be swamped because it doesn't work that way on the field," he said.

It is Brown's job to talk up his team but he can claim few high cards as his troubles continued yesterday. Jackie McNamara was sent home having injured himself in training and immediate call-ups were issued to Steven Pressley of Hearts and Paul Telfer of Coventry City. Telfer will start the match.

Brown was less than pleased at the tabloid front-page treatment accorded to Matt Elliott, who had earlier cried off because his three-week-old son is seriously ill.

He faced a similar "sensitive" problem yesterday after calling up the wing-back Telfer, who was told of the request at Coventry's training ground at 11.30 and was airborne by 3pm en route to Scotland.

As a young player at Luton, Telfer was driving a car which was involved in an accident which left his best friend Darren Salton so badly hurt that he has never played again.

"Paul went into his shell after that," Brown said. "He's a religious boy and didn't ever want to play football again. Then he realised that it was his living and that he had to get on with it. But he wanted to do so as quietly as possible and we respected that decision. But we've wanted him for quite a while."

Telfer will be opposed by Bixente Lizarazu of Bayern Munich, some task. But France have quality all over the pitch, such as that shown in Marcel Desailly and Didier Deschamps of Chelsea, Lilian Thuram of Parma and Arsenal's Patrick Vieira, Emmanuel Petit and Thierry Henry. Their coach Roger Lemerre describes his side as playing 4-5-1 but ominously talked at length about his admiration of Johan Cruyff's Ajax, who almost 30 years ago invented what came to be known as "total football".

Lemerre did observe, however, that France have not won a match nor scored a goal in three previous visits to Hampden Park. That crease should be ironed out this evening, for the world champions carry far too much ammunition for a patched-up Scotland side.

webTitle: Giggs happy to sidestep the snipers

fields.headline: Giggs happy to sidestep the snipers
fields.trailText: United winger hits back at critics who say he should not play for Wales
fields.body:
Some had wanted to raise the Severn Bridge and keep him out but, far from turning their backs on Ryan Giggs, the Welsh public will come out in their thousands tonight to welcome him home. The Millennium Stadium, embracing the round ball for the first time, will produce a record crowd figure for a Wales international and the fact that Giggs is involved is itself a piece of history.

He has never before reported fit for a friendly game. Prior to the clash with Finland there had been 18 which went ahead without him, and when he pulled out of last month's trip to Qatar the outcry from supporters who have been starved of success and starved of the sight of the Manchester United express performing in Welsh red was more vociferous than usual.

Newspapers ran polls inviting readers to countersign to the view that Giggs - the finest natural talent this small nation has ever produced, a candidate for the best of Europe XI let alone a British Isles team - should not have a part to play for his country again.

Giggs, as ever, has been protesting his innocence this week of the charge that he is only interested in the big occasion. Yet the regularity with which injury strikes just before Wales do battle has had the cynics falling over themselves to argue that Sir Alex Ferguson is making sure he comes fit and fresh to United's fixture the following weekend.

The recent criticism stung the 26-year-old and he showed little of his usual affability when he talked to reporters at the Welsh training camp yesterday. "I'm very aware of the criticism there has been of me," he said. "I've still got plenty of family who live in Cardiff and they tell me about what is being said and who is criticising me and how much I'm being criticised.

"It hurts because I'm Welsh and proud of it. I've always maintained that two of the greatest moments in my career were when I made my Wales debut and when I captained the team three years ago. Then you find people having polls asking fans whether I should be picked in the future and that's just stupid because I always give 100%. I hope that by playing on Wednesday it will finally kill that off."

It is not the novelty of seeing him flying down the wing for his country which has prompted a stampede at the box office. Most tickets had been sold in advance and the assumption was that another "Ferguson hamstring" would force his withdrawal yet again.

To the delight of officials the decision to switch to the Millennium Stadium from Ninian Park - the manager Mark Hughes, with an eye on the World Cup qualifiers that start in the autumn, insisted on it - and to peg prices at £5 a ticket has struck a chord with fans. The 66,500 attendance is 6,000 short of capacity because of safety fears and includes only 30 Finnish visitors.

If the top of the bill dazzles as brightly as he has in recent weeks in the Premiership and Champions League, then the Giggs grudges will all be forgotten. Certainly Hughes is grateful that he can call on him for his first home fixture since being confirmed as manager last December.

"Ryan is a fantastic player who is in a marvellous run of form at the moment," said Hughes. "Everyone in the squad is lifted when he is around."

Hughes doesn't think Giggs has ever performed more impressively and in training the players have noticed that he appears even more super-powered than before. "He's one of the senior pros at United now and that responsibility, allied to the experience he now has, makes him a better player," Hughes added.

"He's one of a group at the club who came through together, whose work ethic is second to none and who have the desire to win things and be the best they can be. Ryan has always had that determination."

Both sides are looking on the game mainly for its value as World Cup preparation. Finland, who are in England's qualifying group, include six players with English and Scottish clubs, including Liverpool's Sami Hyypia and the exciting Chelsea striker Mikael Forssell.

Newspapers ran polls inviting readers to countersign to the view that Giggs - the finest natural talent this small nation has ever produced, a candidate for the best of Europe XI let alone a British Isles team - should not have a part to play for his country again. Giggs, as ever, has been protesting his innocence this week of the charge that he is only interested in the big occasion. Yet the regularity with which injury strikes just before Wales do battle has had the cynics falling over themselves to argue that Sir Alex Ferguson is making sure he comes fit and fresh to United's fixture the following weekend. The recent criticism stung the 26-year-old and he showed little of his usual affability when he talked to reporters at the Welsh training camp yesterday. "I'm very aware of the criticism there has been of me," he said. "I've still got plenty of family who live in Cardiff and they tell me about what is being said and who is criticising me and how much I'm being criticised. "It hurts because I'm Welsh and proud of it. I've always maintained that two of the greatest moments in my career were when I made my Wales debut and when I captained the team three years ago. Then you find people having polls asking fans whether I should be picked in the future and that's just stupid because I always give 100%. I hope that by playing on Wednesday it will finally kill that off." It is not the novelty of seeing him flying down the wing for his country which has prompted a stampede at the box office. Most tickets had been sold in advance and the assumption was that another "Ferguson hamstring" would force his withdrawal yet again. To the delight of officials the decision to switch to the Millennium Stadium from Ninian Park - the manager Mark Hughes, with an eye on the World Cup qualifiers that start in the autumn, insisted on it - and to peg prices at £5 a ticket has struck a chord with fans. The 66,500 attendance is 6,000 short of capacity because of safety fears and includes only 30 Finnish visitors. If the top of the bill dazzles as brightly as he has in recent weeks in the Premiership and Champions League, then the Giggs grudges will all be forgotten. Certainly Hughes is grateful that he can call on him for his first home fixture since being confirmed as manager last December. "Ryan is a fantastic player who is in a marvellous run of form at the moment," said Hughes. "Everyone in the squad is lifted when he is around." Hughes doesn't think Giggs has ever performed more impressively and in training the players have noticed that he appears even more super-powered than before. "He's one of the senior pros at United now and that responsibility, allied to the experience he now has, makes him a better player," Hughes added. "He's one of a group at the club who came through together, whose work ethic is second to none and who have the desire to win things and be the best they can be. Ryan has always had that determination." Both sides are looking on the game mainly for its value as World Cup preparation. Finland, who are in England's qualifying group, include six players with English and Scottish clubs, including Liverpool's Sami Hyypia and the exciting Chelsea striker Mikael Forssell.

fields.trailText: A convincing performance for England Under-21 tonight can enable Steven Gerrard to complete a rapid rise from captaining the Under-18s to making Kevin Keegan's Euro 2000 squad.

webTitle: Anelka apology sets up Real return

fields.headline: Anelka apology sets up Real return
fields.trailText: Nicolas Anelka has publicly apologised for his recent conduct in a move which smacks of expediency by Real Madrid, who face Manchester United in the Champions League quarter-final next Tuesday.
fields.body:
Nicolas Anelka has publicly apologised for his recent conduct in a move which smacks of expediency by Real Madrid, who face Manchester United in the Champions League quarter-final next Tuesday.

"The reason for my appearance is to publicly ask for forgiveness for the attitude that I have maintained during the last days which has not benefited either the club or myself," the Frenchman said.

The £23.5m signing from Arsenal was suspended by Real Madrid for 45 days when he refused to appear at training for three days; he had taken exception to an order to practise alone after criticising tactics.

"I ask for forgiveness. I'm aware that a sanction from the club is suitable. Given the matches facing the club at the present time I am making myself available if required, and I accept the sanction."

Anelka, who read from a prepared statement while sitting alongside a club director, was not allowed to field questions but nodded sheepishly when asked if he hoped to play against United. Real will have to do so without their top scorer Fernando Morientes and their key defender Fernando Hierro, both injured.

webTitle: First No 10 e-forum shows opposition to parenting advice

fields.headline: First No 10 e-forum shows opposition to parenting advice
fields.standfirst: Policy forum on Downing Street site
fields.trailText: Parents have given a clear thumbs down to government proposals to use the child benefit database to send families guidance on parenting, in responses to the first Downing Street electronic consultation.
fields.body:
Parents have given a clear thumbs down to government proposals to use the child benefit database to send families guidance on parenting, in responses to the first Downing Street electronic consultation.

Responding to the "virtual forum" on parenting policy tomorrow, the first e-consultation between a government and its citizens in Europe, home secretary Jack Straw will acknowledge that parents rejected any government moves to tell them how to bring up their children.

Partifcipants on the newly revamped Downing Street website expressed concern that information should not be forced on "the vast majority of caring, competent parents in this country".

Some suspected that the option of a parenting website, also floated in the consultation, would merely allow the distribution of government "propaganda". Others felt that the government should not be giving lessons on parenting at all, warning that there was "a fine line between genuine concern for the people and setting up a nanny state".

The government asked for answers on if and how parents would like to receive parenting advice, and suggested using the child benefit database to send parents information direct to their home address.

However, ministers will still consider the option - welcomed by some of those responding - of using the database merely to let families know what information is available and where.

Mr Straw, who chairs the ministerial group on the family, will say: "Government should provide to parents, and how that information should be delivered. The people who took part in the discussion made it clear that the government should do more to make parents aware of what support and advice was available to them, but without seeking to tell parents in too much detail about how they should bring up their kids."

He added: "There are certainly ideas here which will help us to come up with the right policies for the future."

E-consultation would soon become a routine part of policy-making, he predicted, saving on time as well as paper and postage. Future Downing Street debates will cover homelessness, the fight against crime and sports funding.

However, conventional consultation will continue so as to avoid charges that ministers are neglecting those unable to afford or use internet technology.

Other issues raised by parents included the need for speedier reform of the child support agency and for a better balance between work and home life.

Mr Straw said a change in attitude was required in business and industry, but acknowledged that the government, as an employer, "could do more to help our staff strike the right balance".
