fields.headline: Search engines
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about the net navigators
fields.trailText: 1. The end of the search engine is nigh, according to a British software company.
fields.body:
1. The end of the search engine is nigh, according to a British software company.

2. Kenjin, the latest product from Autonomy Corp, launches tomorrow with a promise to look for concepts, not keywords, and dig out relevant documents from the web and the user's own PC.

3. It sounds more modern than it is. Autonomy's software is based on the work of 17th century mathematician and cleric Thomas Bayes, whose work on probability allows Kenjin an intelligent take on the net.

4. Current search engines are one of two types. The first, such as AltaVista and Google, employs software to crawl spider-like across the web and "read" a large number of pages. When you type, for example, "chocolate" you get 190,000 pages it has found containing the word.

5. The second, such as Yahoo! - founded by chief Yahoos Jerry Yang and David Filo while at college - uses human editors to build a directory of the best sites on the net. You search using categories such as travel, sport and entertainment.

6. Another type is the meta-engine - for example Ask Jeeves, the internet butler who looks at lots of different search engines and was recently interviewed by the business satirists at FN Wire

7. He does not have the last word on search engines. Technology that looked advanced two months ago has been superseded by the new kids on the block Simpli.com, GuruNet and Kachianet.

8. There was a time (in 1993-4) when you didn't need a search engine because all the sites in the world fitted on a single HTML page. The NCSA What's New Page would update you with new websites as they were built.

9. Now the net is bigger and there are a multitude of regional (which in web-speak means continental), speciality and kid-safe engines, all helpfully listed and explained on Danny O'Sullivan's Search engine watch.

10. But to get what you need to know on the net you sometimes have to go a little further, to the invisible web - and do a direct search to the ever growing number of online databases the search engines' software spiders never find.

webTitle: Councillors may have record allowances capped

fields.headline: Councillors may have record allowances capped
fields.trailText: Members of the Welsh assembly will today unite in condemning the record breaking allowances that have been given to leading councillors on Cardiff county council.
fields.body:
Members of the Welsh assembly will today unite in condemning the record breaking allowances that have been given to leading councillors on Cardiff county council.

The Tory-sponsored debate, which is expected to draw cross party support, comes as the Welsh local government minister, Peter Law, is preparing to take action to cap payments that have caused embarrassment and division among Labour party members in the Welsh capital.

Eight Cardiff Labour councillors were recently suspended from the party for opposing the controversial £58,000 allowances of council leader Russell Goodway, before being reinstated on appeal to the Welsh Labour executive. The increased allowances, making Mr Goodway the highest paid council leader in Britain, were recommended in a report that measured the jobs of Cardiff councillors against similar jobs in the private sector.

The huge increases flew in the face of recommendations contained in separate reports by the Welsh office and the Welsh local government association which suggested linking allowances to the average Welsh wage.

Of the 22 councils in Wales only Cardiff failed to take up those recommendations.

Mr Law, who has the power to cap the Cardiff allowances under the 1989 local government and housing act, has been urging Mr Goodway and other senior Cardiff councillors to rethink.

webTitle: Blair to plough on with section 28 repeal

fields.headline: Blair to plough on with section 28 repeal
fields.standfirst: More about section 28
fields.trailText: The prime minister today insisted the government would press ahead with its plans to repeal section 28, which bans the promotion of homosexuality in schools.
fields.body:
The prime minister today insisted the government would press ahead with its plans to repeal section 28, which bans the promotion of homosexuality in schools.

Attempts to repeal the clause - which is bitterly opposed by the Tory party - and find a compromise have twice been defeated in the House of Lords.

During question time in the Commons, the leader of the opposition, William Hague, asked Mr Blair if he would abandon attempts to repeal the legislation if it were defeated again.

The prime minister replied that he would not and attacked the "mischievous propaganda" put about by those who support section 28. He said that children would not be forced to take part in gay sex lessons.

"This has nothing at all to do with sex education in schools. It never has had, since 1994 section 28 has not even applied to schools. Sex lessons in schools will carry on being the prerogative of teachers, parents and governors. Parents will carry on having the right to withdraw their children from those sex education lessons."

But Mr Hague suggested that the prime minister was sick of the issue and had his ministers running around telling newspapers he was ready to give up on the whole thing.

"Just so we know what we have to do to get you to back off from this politically correct nonsense, will you tell us if the Lords defeat it one more time, will you abandon it?" he asked.

But the prime minister again insisted that the government was committed to its repeal and reiterated that children would not be forced to take part in sex education lessons outside the prerogative of parents, teachers and governors.

"If you do not want to be accused of hiding behind prejudice, you should say whether you accept that what I have just said is true," he challenged.

To loud Tory cheers, Mr Hague replied: "I am very happy to move round there and answer the questions at any time.

"Section 28 applies to councils administering schools and it applied to the advice and materials that councils give to schools. So now I have answered your question, let's have an answer to mine. When are you going to realise that the majority in this country are tolerant and are understanding, but they do not want their children subject to politically correct propaganda?

"Why don't you listen to the common sense of the great majority of the country and abandon this now before it gets to the Lords?" he added.

Northern Ireland: The prime minister urged Northern Ireland parties not to lose "this chance for peace" as talks continue to get the devolved institutions running again in the province.

He told the Commons every major question and point of principle at issue in Ulster either had been or could be resolved by the Good Friday agreement, but acknowledged that the current state of the peace process was still "frustrating".

Rover: Mr Blair denied that trade secretary Stephen Byers knew before Christmas that BMW might close the Longbridge Rover plant. Challenged repeatedly by Mr Hague, he said conversations with the company in December centred on the need to speed up European aid.

Mr Hague condemned Mr Byers' handling of the Rover selloff and accused him of failing to understand the seriousness of the situation, but Mr Blair replied: "I'm sorry you should seek to make political capital out of this ... you have no alternative policy to offer at all."

webTitle: FA hit Leeds and Spurs with big fine

fields.headline: FA hit Leeds and Spurs with big fine
fields.standfirst: Read the full FA statement
fields.trailText: Leeds and Tottenham have both been fined £150,000 by an FA disciplinary hearing in Birmingham.
fields.body:
Leeds and Tottenham have both been fined £150,000 by an FA disciplinary hearing in Birmingham.

The fines follow a mass brawl during their Premiership match at Elland Road on February 12. Both clubs were found guilty of failing to control their players, censured and warned that any future misdemeanours would result in the loss of league points.

FA spokesman Steve Double said: "The commission gave serious consideration today to deducting league points. On this occasion they have decided not to but both clubs have been made clear that any future findings of guilt for similar instances will result in points being deducted." Both clubs have 14 days in which to appeal.

Meanwhile, the FA decided that Leeds' Republic of Ireland international Ian Harte, who faced a separate charge of stamping on opponent Chris Perry during the same game, was not guilty. Double added: "It was accepted that it was accidental and that his momentum wasn't able to take [the challenge] away."

After the hearing Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale said his club accepted the FA's decision. But Tottenham look more likely to take up their option to appeal. A statement from the London club said they were "very disappointed" at being found guilty of failing to control their players. It added: "The club stated quite clearly at the hearing today that the incident in question was instigated by a Leeds player."

fields.headline: Beckham honours
fields.trailText: So now it is official. David Beckham has become such an icon of our times that he will soon be a subject of study for those enrolling at Staffordshire University.
fields.body:
So now it is official. David Beckham has become such an icon of our times that he will soon be a subject of study for those enrolling at Staffordshire University.

According to newspaper reports, a 12-week course entitled Football Culture will examine the cultural impact of the United midfielder, including the relationship with his wife, the fallout from his haircut and that "moment of madness" which resulted in his being sent off during the match against Argentina in the last World Cup.

The truth however, a bit like Beckham's importance to the life of the nation, has perhaps been a little over-exaggerated. Staffordshire University's course is not just about Beckham, a fact that some of the papers chose to overlook; it also aims to look at the overall cultural impact of the beautiful game and its changing nature in a climate of increasing popularity.

Given that Beckham (and his alluring wife Victoria) is currently the darling of the national newspapers, it was obvious the wider implications of the course would soon be overlooked.

We live in an age of sport, as some sociologists have observed. Sport and football in particular have become the new rock music, with Beckham and Posh Spice its royal couple.

Footballers are the cultural icons of the modern era, and the attempts by academics to study their impact, not just at Staffordshire, but at universities around the country, are symbolic of the importance we give them.

Football itself has become a convenient metaphor for the state of the nation. If the national team does well, it is seen as a reflection of the rest of the country; and if our players misbehave, it mirrors the malaise within society at large.

It has become convenient to hold footballers up to this kind of scrutiny because it is easy - ultimately, we all know that they are not really that important: nobody will go hungry if Beckham is not selected for Manchester United; Britain's relations with a foreign country won't deteriorate if he is sent off during an England international game.

Like watching a soap opera, following the life of David Beckham requires little thinking and provides for comfort reading and viewing.

The media and the tabloid press in particular need personalities to focus on, and the celebrities get the publicity they need in return. This all makes for a convenient relationship. A decade ago, musicians or even Princess Diana might have played that role, but today, it is the turn of football.

In the words of Professor Ellis Cashmore, who will be teaching the football culture course at Stafford: "Beckham himself is a vacuous personality. His importance is down to his celebrity status."

fields.headline: Whipping, Shagging and Grinding
fields.trailText: LASH MINUTE.COM
fields.body:
LASH MINUTE.COM

Hi! It's Madame Whiplash Fiver here, and there's nothing I like more than standing around in restrictive leather underwear while whipping a whip and reporting on the latest disciplinary developments in football. So boys - and gerbils - here goes!

Tasty Tim Sherwood of Tottenham has been spared a pair of raw buttocks after the FA decided not to discipline him over allegations that he made obscene gestures to Newcastle fans after a Premiership encounter at St James' Park last year. No more will players - at Leicester, say - be able to take the odd free ticket from the FA and off-load them, like latter-day Robin Hoods, in pubs and clubs throughout the land. Instead the club gets FA spokesman Steve Double accusing them of "breathtaking carelessness," setting up a "smokescreen" and failing to make any sort of a public apology as they leave an FA disciplinary hearing in their silver Porsches.

So it was good to see some element of normalcy return today. The seven 'guilty' parties plan to appeal, while Leicester denied most of the FA's accusations in a carefully worded statement. fields.headline: The Human Rights Act
fields.trailText:
Is it a new law?
The Act is a new name for a long-standing piece of European legislation. It takes the European Convention on Human Rights, which was ratified by Britain in 1951, and introduces it into domestic law. Individual citizens have been able to appeal to the European court at Strasbourg since 1966.
fields.body:
Is it a new law?
The Act is a new name for a long-standing piece of European legislation. It takes the European Convention on Human Rights, which was ratified by Britain in 1951, and introduces it into domestic law. Individual citizens have been able to appeal to the European court at Strasbourg since 1966.

What's changed?
From October 2 this year, it will be much easier for individuals to bring cases against public authorities. Bringing a case to the European court tended to be a lengthy and expensive business. Now it can be done in Britain, and the Home Office anticipates that many more complainants will decide to pursue their cases as a result.

What's in the Act?
Articles setting out a person's rights in law, including:

 the right to life
 the banning of torture
 the banning of slavery and forced labour
 the right to liberty and security
 no punishment without law
 the right to respect for private and family life and correspondence
 the right to freedom of thought, conscience and religion
 the right to freedom of expression
 the right to marry and found a family
 the right to freedom of assembly and association
 the right to an education

So why is the Institute for Public Policy Research concerned about it?
The Act makes public services - including the police, schools, local government and hospitals - potentially liable for breaches of the Act. The Home Office has already charged a Human Rights Task Force with the job of telling them about it. The IPPR, however, has just published a report which emphasises how many organisations that consider themselves outside the public sector could also be liable. Those include private schools, hospitals, prisons and nursing homes, because they carry out public sector duties.

Do many organisations fall into that category?
Yes. The growth in private healthcare and public-private partnerships during the 1990s created many such companies. A number of them, according to the IPPR, claim to have no knowledge of the report. Guardian Unlimited tried to contact the Task Force to determine just how widely the advice document had been circulated, but they were unavailable for comment.

So how will these basic rights affect public services?
The right to liberty and security directly affects the prison service. Freedoms of conscience and expression, as Clause 28 campaigners have already pointed out, could affect the way homosexuality is treated in schools; suspension and expulsion could become impossible. Stop-and-search powers are under threat, and healthcare rationing and fertility treatment on the NHS could be affected. Doctors and health-service administrators could be sued for failures in their care.

Does the right to private correspondence also affect employers?
Absolutely. Intercepting office email and phone calls is one of the practices that could become illegal under UK law.

What has the home secretary, Jack Straw, said on the subject?
At a conference on the Act today (March 29), Mr Straw tried to play down the implications of the Act. "Most of the rights in the Human Rights Act are not absolute. In almost every case it is open for the public authority to limit the right or balance one right against another," he said. "It's about looking at how you treat the public and putting yourselves in their shoes. Do as you would be done by. Do that and then we will be more than halfway there." The home secretary pointed out that human rights were the responsibility of all citizens and urged every organisation that might be affected by the Act to make sure they knew about it. "People shouldn't panic about it, but they should get to know what's the convention," he told BBC Breakfast News. "If people are operating in a fair and reasonable and legal way, they've got nothing really to fear, but they want to look at their procedures."

How can I do that?
Visit the Human Rights Task Force site and download the guidance.

fields.headline: Obituary: Anthony Powell
fields.trailText: Anthony Powell is inevitably regarded as the English Proust, on the strength of the massive novel sequence - A Dance to the Music of Time, 12 volumes, a million words - that became his central life's work
fields.body:
Anthony Dymoke Powell, CH, author, born December 21, 1905; died March 28 2000

Anthony Powell is inevitably regarded as the English Proust, on the strength of the massive novel sequence - A Dance to the Music of Time, 12 volumes, a million words - that became his central life's work. The Proust impact was more dominant and more obvious than that of other great European novelists (such as the Austrian novelist Robert Musil) and assorted influences from Petronius to modern Americans he has himself mentioned.

Yet he will stand as essentially a comic writer in the English tradition - comic in the least uproarious way imaginable, reflective and often melancholy, the strong social spine to his work being the one distinctively uncommon feature in a branch of writing remarkable more for eccentricity than togetherness.

In fact Powell has a measure of both. He goes in for no deep psychological dredging, yet his novels rest on a firmer base of instinct and belief than is usual among the English comedians. He is fascinated by the play of time and chance on character, and it is by no means time and chance that always win. His narrating hero and anchor-man, Nicholas Jenkins, is constantly being mildly surprised by the way things and people turn out.

The unpredictability of life, as Powell has himself described, is built into his structure as an essential part of it. Coincidences, so irritating to some readers, often happen in life so why should they be forbidden to fiction? They are not excluded from Powell's novels, nor are all manner of trivia other writers might scorn or mishandle. It was his belief that with the right cook in charge anything could go into the cauldron. A novelist never lacks material - only the capacity and energy to handle it.

Silver spoons, in the Powell kitchen, were never short. The world he deals with, upper middle-class life from the 1920s onward, is his own world. The son and grandson of distinguished soldiers, at Eton he was a contemporary of Orwell. He went on to Balliol, married Lady Violet Pakenham in 1934, served in the Intelligence Corps during the second world war, lived in a handsome regency house near Frome, belonged to good clubs. He worked for a time as a publisher's reader and as literary editor of Punch.

His first novel, Afternoon Men, appeared in 1931 and there were several others by way of prelude, followed by a long silence through and for some years after the war. Then, in 1951, came the start of the Music of Time sequence, the title deriving from Nicolas Poussin's allegorical painting. The books emerged at roughly two-yearly intervals.

The twelve-volume sequence, stretching across a quarter of a century from A Question of Upbringing (1951) to Hearing Secret Harmonies (1975) is more than a successful fictional marathon. It achieves a coherence, a central vitality which runs sluggishly at times but is never extinguished. His vast army of characters, clubmen all, pursue their power-games through peace and war, marriage or divorce, in sickness and in health. War - as memorably described in the ninth volume, The Military Philosophers - is for Powell-people an extension of ordinary life; the flow is diverted but not stemmed, and rank is merely a crude token of what always existed in this elegantly competitive world. Some characters may only be glimpsed before disappearing from view, perhaps springing up like blades of grass in another volume years later. But nothing is lost or without its effect on the total pattern, while the allegorical master of the dance - as in the Poussin picture - smiles a shade malignly. Other characters are as perennial as the unreliable Dicky Umfraville, often in hot or at least very warm water, first noted leaving school under a cloud (not actually expelled, it was insisted) and last seen masquerading as an octogenarian drug-addict. Or the ever-indulgent Lady Molly, whose house in South Kensington, more than the Ritz, is really open to all.

With Powell's known writing method and this roving cast of hundreds there was naturally much speculation about who were the originals, in whole or more usually in part, of the characters appearing in the Dance. Sometimes the guess-who game was easy, as with the well-known Fitzrovian writer and reviewer Julian Maclaren-Ross who became the character X. Trapnel. He appears as a novelist who holds forth at length about the art of the novel to the narrator Jenkins, also a novelist. He insists, and Jenkins doesn't contradict, that naturalism is only natural in the right hands and that reading novels takes almost as much talent as writing them. It can hardly be carrying presumption too far to assume that some of these ideas, as from novelist to novelist, are shared by the club's founding member, Powell himself. Others are more mysterious. Above all - literally so, if he had his way - there is the preposterous, the ever-haunting Widmerpool. Writhing with self-contradiction - a shade pathetic, a little absurd, more than a little sinister - he pervades the book, occupying a full half-century even of Powell's ocean of time. Where can this strange creature have sprung from?

"I am perpetually badgered about Widmerpool," Powell said when he was being interviewed for his 80th birthday. All sorts of orginals have been suggested, from a recent Lord Chancellor down. Actually, so far as the character was drawn from life, "he was drawn from somebody I served under during the war."If any character was going to beat time you felt it would have to be the apparently indestructible Widmerpool, but he goes in the end - suitably weirdly, collapsing (as it seems) on a ritual jog at dawn.

The inextricable mingling, in such a world as Powell's, of life and literature is made doubly apparent in the memoirs, To Keep the Ball Rolling, which Powell brought out in four volumes between 1976 and 1982. So happily do fact and fiction marry that it is easy to forget at times that you are reading about a real character in an actual place, and imagine you have slipped back into one of the novels.

This reaction is particularly strong in the account - laconic and uninhibited like the fiction - of the early days in London when Jenkins is finding his feet in the literary world. The real-life memories develop, as the novels do, a sense of the significance of trivial and seemingly casual events, while large ones may pass invisibly by. Real people surge on to the scene like figures from a fantasy world: Augustus John, J. C. Squire, Rosa Lewis of the Cavendish, Maclean and Burgess ("a notorious scallywag"), the seedy diabolist Aleister Crowley at Simpson's, Tallulah Bankhead in a nightclub.

We watch him becoming a Territorial recruit in the Royal Artillery ("I felt that if the gunners were good enough for Tolstoy they were good enough for me") and, rather more dangerously, pursuing a friendship with Evelyn Waugh. There are drinks with Sitwells. The air of clubbishness, a cool, bookish intimacy, persists. Most of the way, that is. Just once in a while togetherness fails: "In the flat below mine lived E. M. Forster (a writer whose books have never greatly appealed to me), but we never met."

The trivia of the memoirs can be as funny as anything in the novels and that means very funny indeed. Powell was of the opinion that most important writers, unlike most critics, have been well equipped with resources of humour; he even seems to have regarded it as a touchstone in evaluating them.

There are funerals, not necessarily particularly mournful occasions; death seems no more serious than life, which is indeed serious enough in so inflexible an English comedy world. There is an inclination for ritual, with serious sacrificial moments like the drowning of a key manuscript in the Regent's Park Canal (Books Do Furnish A Room), or the death - could it be possible after all? - of Widmerpool in the final volume of the sequence. Technically the challenge, brilliantly met, must have been the handling of that enormous flock of free-range characters and the disposing of the maddening, mysterious, apparently indestructible Widmerpool. No wonder the face in Poussin's ritual dance came to look more malign than ever, for the Powell version must have called for a kind of anti-choreography remote from dancing. These hundreds of performers had to be trained to collide with each other as much as possible for fear that they might otherwise stray off and never be seen again.

There must have been many who wished that for Widmerpool. Did Anthony Powell ever wish he had never created the man, if man it was? Keeping track of Widmerpool through twelve volumes and a million words, not really knowing whether he was ink or flesh, whether his true existence was inside the book or out, could have been a lifetime's job in itself. He popped up everywhere: something in the City, something in the army, employed in many an advisory capacity. He was a Labour MP under Attlee, an admirer of Mrs Ernest Simpson. Hugh Gaitskell - though nobody seems quite sure about this - was thought to have been instrumental in getting him a peerage. He influenced people's lives though not in the traditional way; more a kind of one-man quango. He would always be in touch. There was no danger of his getting lost. Powell tells us, in his Journals for 1982-1986 published in 1995, that he first came across Widmerpool as a Cromwellian Captain of Horse in Hutchinson's Memoirs of the Civil War. Where, and when, will the man turn up next?

After the Music of Time sequence Powell published The Fisher King, an elegant modern version of an ancient myth. There was also a short novel dementedly entitled O, How the Wheel Becomes It! (Ophelia's mad scene, it fittingly turns out, provides the clue).

The Proust impact was more dominant and more obvious than that of other great European novelists (such as the Austrian novelist Robert Musil) and assorted influences from Petronius to modern Americans he has himself mentioned. Yet he will stand as essentially a comic writer in the English tradition - comic in the least uproarious way imaginable, reflective and often melancholy, the strong social spine to his work being the one distinctively uncommon feature in a branch of writing remarkable more for eccentricity than togetherness. He is fascinated by the play of time and chance on character, and it is by no means time and chance that always win. His narrating hero and anchor-man, Nicholas Jenkins, is constantly being mildly surprised by the way things and people turn out. His first novel, Afternoon Men, appeared in 1931 and there were several others by way of prelude, followed by a long silence through and for some years after the war. Then, in 1951, came the start of the Music of Time sequence, the title deriving from Nicolas Poussin's allegorical painting. The books emerged at roughly two-yearly intervals. It achieves a coherence, a central vitality which runs sluggishly at times but is never extinguished. His vast army of characters, clubmen all, pursue their power-games through peace and war, marriage or divorce, in sickness and in health. Or the ever-indulgent Lady Molly, whose house in South Kensington, more than the Ritz, is really open to all. fields.headline: Off the shelf
fields.standfirst: Building a library for your child
fields.trailText: Building a library for your child
fields.body:
The Guardian has always championed the idea that books are as important to babies and children as they are to adults. In the 1960s we introduced the Guardian Award for Children's Books and it is still going strong. Last week, this year's award was given to Jacqueline Wilson for The Illustrated Mum.

Children's book publishing is booming. Shelves in shops and libraries are stuffed with new titles and classics. There was a time when generation after generation of children read the same books, classics that were handed down from parent to child. Now there is a huge amount of choice. But how do you choose?

We hope to help you. Today sees the start of a new monthly column that will select from the best new titles and reissues. These columns can be used in conjunction with the Guardian website (BooksUnlimited) where you will find short reviews of classic, well-loved and crucial books that will make a useful backbone of any children's library.

All books can be bought at a discount direct from the website, which will be regularly updated. The titles reviewed below can also be bought at The Guardian CultureShop, at the discount prices indicated. Freephone 0800 3166 102, or send your order with a UK cheque payable to the Guardian CultureShop to 250 Western Avenue, London W3 6EE .

The age groupings fit roughly into the way booksellers arrange their shelves; they are not set in stone. Children develop at different rates. The books selected have not been chosen by any criteria other than that we have enjoyed them and think you and your children might too.

They have not been selected because they have educational value, tie in with the National Curriculum or may help your child learn to read, although some will do all these things. These books are not about fact-gathering, but about journeys of the imagination that help children find out about the world around them in the widest sense and take them to places they may not otherwise go.

Ages 0-4

Little Pig Figwort

by Henrietta Branford, illustrated by Claudio Munoz (Collins, £10.99; CultureShop price £8.99 plus 99p p&p. See above for details)

The final book from ace kid's writer Branford, who died last year, is a high-spirited tale about a little pig who likes to have fun - so much so that he can't get to sleep. But when he goes to the bottom of the sea the mermaids are sleepy and at the north pole the polar bears growl at him to go home. It is only on the moon that he finds his soulmates, the moon pigs, who play all night.

The I-can't-get-to-sleep picture book is genre in children's fiction, and frankly some of them are a yawn. But Branford's humorous text and Munoz's expressive pictures ensure that this one won't send you to sleep while you are reading it.

My First Elmer Joke Book

by David McKee (Red Fox, £4.99; CultureShop price £3.99 plus 99p UK p&p)

What do elephants talk in their sleep? Mumbo jumbo.

What do you give an elephant with big feet? Plenty of room.

I never used to see the point of the cute patchwork elephant: his only purpose seemed to be cute. Maybe that's why babies seem to love him so much. But this little book is incredibly daft and full of joy. The vivid pictures have real wit, which is more than you can say about the jokes, which are all as old as an elephant.

You and your one-year-old will love the colourful pictures, while your four-year-old will wet herself at the sublime silliness of the jokes and wear you out repeating them.

Ages 5-7

The Famous Adventures of Jack

by Berlie Doherty (Hodder Children's Books, £10.99 hb, £3.99 pb; CultureShop price £3.99 freepost)

A girl walks into a cottage and asks for Jack. "Which Jack did you want?" asks the old woman inside. "They're 10 a penny, Jacks are." Ten a penny - but all extraordinary.

Clever Jacks, daft Jacks, Jacks who kill giants. . . Familiar and not so familiar Jacks all turn up in this clever weaving together of a series of short stories. Then there are the talking cats, disappearing castles - and don't forget the magic beans.

Ingeniously splicing the old and the new, this is a book that plays on children's familiarity with fairy tales and which celebrates our need to hear old stories in a new ways.

Grandma Chickenlegs

by Geraldine McCaughrean, illustrated by Moira Kemp (Doubleday, £9.99; CultureShop price £7.99 plus 99p p&p)

Parents are often so hung up at this stage on getting their children to decipher text that they forget the importance of pictures. But there is nothing babyish about this re-telling of the Baba Yaga story. The poetry of the text is perfectly in tune with colourful pictures that evoke the inner turmoil of little Tatia: when her mother dies, her father marries a woman "with eyes as sharp as needles and a soul as thin as thread".

There is something pleasingly theatrical in the way the pictures show Tatia as a tiny figure and her persecutors as huge presences until the final pages, when the newly confident Tatia soars in the air on a swing over her sleeping father.

Ages 8-11

Amber's Secret

by Ann Pilling (Collins, £9.99; CultureShop price £6.99 plus 99p p&p)

"Did you know," said Amber one day to her friend Sally, "that if you pick up the phone and ring Appleford 616 you can talk to God?" It is the 1950s; Sally's dad is abroad and her mum has been taken into hospital. When Sally accidentally shatters her mother's beloved grandfather clock and the mending of the clock becomes mixed up in her mind with the mending of her mother. Desperate, she rings God.

This is a beautiful, quiet book about faith, miracles and the kindness of strangers, which evokes the lumpy-mince misery of childhood and the sense of being utterly alone. Not action-packed enough to appeal across the board, but plenty will fall for its reflective charm.

The Dare Game

by Jacqueline Wilson (Doubleday, £10.99; CultureShop price, £8.99 plus 99p UK p&p)

This sequel to The Story of Tracey Beaker is not in the same league as Wilson's The Illustrated Mum, which scooped this year's Guardian children's award. But, as always with Wilson, the prose is as feisty as her heroine, the armour-plated Tracey, a girl with a hard attitude and the softest of hearts.

Now out of the children's home and living with her foster mum, Cam, Tracey hasn't given up hope of being reunited with her mother. But only as the dares that she sets herself and her friends get wilder, does Tracey finally face up to reality. Wilson tackles subjects that other writers shy away from and this meaty read will win her more fans.

Ages 12 +

Heaven Eyes

by David Almond (Hodder, £10; CultureShop price £8.99 plus 99p UK p&p)

Erin, January and Mouse run away from the children's home where they live and set sail on a raft down the river. They are rescued by Heaven Eyes, a girl with webbed hands and feet who believes they are her lost siblings.

Set largely in a dilapidated warehouse, Almond's story is a beautiful, eerie tale in which the living and the dead find comfort in each other. What's it about? Who knows? But perhaps about daring to go as far as death and having the bravery to come back again, or about discovering that you don't have to go as far as you think to find yourself. Like Almond's brilliant Skellig, this is a a book about love and faith - particularly faith in yourself and others.

A Long Way From Chicago

by Richard Peck (Hodder Children's Books, £3.99; CultureShop price £3.99 freepost)

It is 1929 and Joey and his sister travel from the Chicago of Al Capone to the hicksville town of their gran on what is to be the first of a yearly summer visit. Here in her parlour they see their first dead body.

A series of interlinked short stories that telescope in time to 1942, Peck's brilliant book has the polecat reek of authentic American fiction, filled with characters such as Shotgun Cheetham, a gran who behaves with the recklessness of a frontier-town outlaw.

Seen entirely through the eyes of the child, this is a great book about the way you grow up slower than you want and much faster than you ever realise.

fields.headline: 'My son was a fascist'
fields.standfirst: A new report says we should respect our children's rights - but what if you are shocked by their choices?
fields.trailText: A new report says we should respect our children's rights - but what if you are shocked by their choices?
fields.body:
Fiona Smith thought she was a good parent to her three children. The house was filled with books and paintings and friends. It was a happy childhood, a left-wing, middle-class upbringing in a cosmopolitan, multicultural area of London.

When the children were still young, their father left, so Fiona brought them up alone. She held down a full-time job and studied for a degree in the evenings. Rightly or wrongly, that's the bit she regrets. If she had her time again, she'd have been at home more for her children.

Her two sons and daughter mixed well at school; their best friends were black, Indian, Greek Cypriot. They would play together, go to each other's houses for tea. Then Mark, her eldest, began at the local secondary school and things began to change.

He said his dinner money was taken off him at knifepoint by black pupils, who would pick fights and cause trouble. He said the teachers were frightened of dealing with the troublemakers for fear of being called racist.

His solution to his growing sense of injustice was radical. At the age of 13 he threw in his lot with the British National Party. His younger brother Philip followed soon after.

They put up racist posters in their bedroom, played racist songs on their hi-fis and became increasingly entangled in the scary world of the far right.

They produced magazines, took part in demonstrations, performed in skinhead bands and were repeatedly arrested for their activities.

Adolescence is a frightening time for most parents. Drugs, sex, teenage pregnancy, bunking off, car crashes, running away - but joining the BNP?

It was Fiona Smith's reality; it's also one of the scenarios raised in a document published today promoting children's rights - their rights to be listened to, to help make decisions about things which affect them and to express their own views.

The concept of children's rights is not popular in Britain, according to Gerison Lansdown, director of the Children's Rights Office and editor of the new document, All Right at Home? "They are seen as undermining to us as parents.

"But tackling children's human rights enhances relationships within families. We wanted to provide practical ways to show how important it is that children are respected and listened to."

Fiona Smith tried to reason with her sons. She listened to them, gave them room to express their views, then put the opposite argument. "I remember my father used to be quite authoritarian. You had to be what he wanted you to be. You had to wear the clothes he said. You had to go to church on Sunday. There was no argument.

"I used to think, I'm never going to lay down the law with my children - I'm going to listen to their argument and go from there. There was no other way. After all, I had no control over what they did when they were out."

To start with, she thought they would outgrow it. She would take down the fascist posters, her sons would just put them back up. Then they began to be picked up by the police for distributing leaflets or being involved in demonstrations.

"They couldn't understand why I couldn't support them. They thought I was naive, that I didn't understand how the world worked. One of the main things they began to believe in was that the Holocaust hadn't happened. It was like talking to the Flat Earth Society. You could not get past some issues with them.

"The first time they got picked up by the police, they gave me a present to say sorry. It was quite sad, really. They knew books were important to me, but they wouldn't have known what to get me. They gave me a Wilbur Smith. They wanted to show me that what they were doing was right and that they would create a better world.

"Among our friends (many of them black or Jewish), people used to agonise about which university to send their child to. I was just concerned with which police station I was going to have to pick mine up from next."

Then her sons began to come home beaten up. They went into hiding, disappearing for weeks on end, living at different addresses. She would see them on television taking part in marches; they'd be featured in newspapers. It began to have a detrimental effect on their younger sister, Eve, who began playing truant from school.

Fiona couldn't bear the shame of it any more. She suffered a nervous breakdown. "I sank into such a depression I couldn't stop crying. Everything was disintegrating around me. My children were growing up and they were growing away from me." She told her sons to move in with their father. She simply couldn't cope any more.

One day, her sons' activities took an even more serious turn. She received a call telling her that Mark had been arrested in East Germany. He had been performing with his band, a fracas had broken out, someone had been stabbed and Mark was one of those accused. "I remember thinking, he's done it now; that's the the limit."

It was eight weeks later that she finally contacted him. "We went across to see him. He was so horrified at finding himself in prison, it was a turning point for him. For years I had hoped and prayed for a turning point to come and this was it."

Mark admitted he was there when the stabbing happened but denied being responsible. His colleagues who had carried out the attack let him carry the can, and as a result he lost all respect for them. He stood trial but the case was adjourned because his co-defendants failed to turn up and it has never been resolved.

"It wasn't until a couple of years after that I was convinced it was over. Mark wrote me letters saying he would make me proud of him again. And he has," says Fiona.

Philip took a little longer to extricate himself. He was still involved in writing lyrics and producing magazines and became a key figure in the far right. Fiona's not sure how he escaped, but she's convinced he has.

Her sons are now in their mid-20s, and Fiona sees them every day. They never talk about it - not yet. "It's enough for me that it's come right. I just apologise to all our friends, and to everybody we know and don't know who suffered from what they were involved in."

According to Gerison Lansdown, Fiona reacted in exactly the right way to her sons' involvement. Had she been more heavy-handed and tried to ban them from their activities, she might have lost them for good.

"As we say in the document, the tendency is to want to protect your children by preventing them from doing the thing that you think is wrong or would place them at risk. But if you try to simply stop them doing something, it leaves them less protected than if you were to respect their capacity to make choices.

"Fiona respected her sons' autonomy. In the end, she still has a relationship with them. Had she taken a more authoritarian line, she might have driven them away and would have been unable to exert any influence on them at all."

So how does Fiona feel about her sons? "Somebody once said to me you love your children in spite of the mistakes they made. Sometimes you love them more because of the mistakes they made. That's the way I feel. They've come through it."

fields.headline: Can he play football?Jane Muir
fields.standfirst: Alex is eight and has cerebral palsy. For eight years his mother has been asked questions. Does he know his name? Does he keep still when he sleeps? And always lurking in the background is the Big One: what's it like to have a disabled child? In her fortnightly column, she reveals all.
fields.trailText: Alex is eight and has cerebral palsy. For eight years his mother has been asked questions. Does he know his name? Does he keep still when he sleeps? And always lurking in the background is the Big One: what's it like to have a disabled child? In her fortnightly column, she reveals all.
fields.body:
We arrived intact. Monteverde, Costa Rica. Twelve hours on the plane from Gatwick, then five hours from the capital, San Jose, along an impossible road. We found our "cabana" near the tiny isolated village of Saint Elena. Access? Only really for horses - or quad bikes.

Perhaps I really was mad to attempt it, but one more year older and we wouldn't have been able to cope at all; it was now or never. This is A's chance to get to know his dad, Edgardo, his "other family", and the cloud forests high up on the mountains.

On the first day we leave the wheelchair in the bungalow and take the three-wheel all-terrain buggy. We abandon the buggy in a bush at the side of the track in the cloudforest, to be picked up later, and A rides on his father's shoulders.

His father works in the forest as a biologist and is used to the paths. He strides on, surefooted among the tree roots and the undergrowth.

Today we don't spy any animals, but we hear strange rustles in the trees and the endless drip, drip, drip of water on leaves. A has the best view with the least effort, but on our return he cries because he wants to be able to walk.

He buries his face in my lap and won't look at the hummingbirds sipping nectar from red plastic dishes. I look at Edgardo, tears in my eyes. He takes A's hand and sits silently. We don't talk on the way home.

After a while, A is laughing his head off as the truck bumps outrageously over the potholes, loose stones and mud of the Monteverde road.

At night, A is restless. We are woken by the roar of the wind in the tree tops, and bits of twig and dry leaves being thrown across the corrugated-iron roof. It feels like a storm at sea: the relentless roar punctuated by bird calls - the car alarm bird and the squeaky gate bird, as we have named them.

In the early hours, A wakes up. "Mum," he says sleepily, "I liked the walk in the forest. And I like my dad." I put my arm around him, and we go back to sleep.

fields.headline: Whose life is it anyway?
fields.trailText: Liz Garrett didn't want her daughter to start smoking. Two years earlier her mother had died of lung cancer after being a life-long 40-a-day woman.
fields.body:
Liz Garrett didn't want her daughter to start smoking. Two years earlier her mother had died of lung cancer after being a life-long 40-a-day woman.

When Susie was 13, Liz began to notice how her daughter's bedroom window was always open whenever she went in. A non-smoker herself, she realised her daughter had taken up the one habit she strongly disapproved of.

"It was the point at which I realised she's a separate person. I can't stop her; I just have to tell her that this distresses me. There was this realisation that she was nearly a grown-up."

They talked about the health implications and the cost, but Susie continued to smoke.

"I had to make decisions about what I was to do about smoking in the house, about smoking in front of relatives," says Liz. "It was an uncomfortable period. I felt there were bigger dangers in getting it wrong. There were huge dangers in saying, 'You do not smoke in my house'.

"She would then smoke elsewhere and would be exposed to further dangers by being driven out of the house. It was a real turning point about how much of my child's life I could control.

"I made rules about not smoking in communal spaces. But I knew that saying 'You will not smoke' was not an option. I would have been setting myself up to reject her completely. I would rather have her here and smoking than not here at all."

This sort of scenario is addressed in All Right at Home? "The issue here is once your child reaches a certain age, they know that smoking is harmful, addictive and expensive," says Gerison Lansdown.

"You telling them these things is not going to make the slightest bit of difference. If you ban it in the house, she will do it elsewhere anyway. Liz is not in a position of power to stop Susie from doing it.

"You can make it clear you disapprove, but you have to accept your child will make a choice; to try to prohibit that will drive it underground and get them into situations that will put them at greater risk."

Sarah Spencer's 10-year-old son had been invited to the park by a popular group of boys who were known to get into trouble sometimes. It would have been the first time he had been to the park without an adult. He was pleased he had been invited, but his mother was concerned.

"I didn't want to stop him going, but I was anxious. So I talked through with him what might happen if he went so he could anticipate what he might have to deal with and be prepared for it.

"I asked him what he would do if they pulled up flowers in the park - how would he handle it. I asked him what he'd do if they ran off and left him there - how would he get home?

"There are some situations where you know they're not safe and you have to say no. Other situations are perfectly safe. This was in between.

"My instinct is to be protective, but in these situations where it's borderline, it's a matter of preparing your child for situations with that extra bit of information and forethought so they can deal with it.

"I could have said no, but it would have had certain consequences. He was at the stage where he wanted to start becoming independent. It would have been postponing that. It would have meant loss of face.

"They quickly get to the age where they are teenagers and you can no longer make decisions for them. It's good to prepare them for when that time comes."

Gerison Lansdown approves of Sarah's approach. "Sarah was recognising her son's right to take some responsibility for what happened to him, and helping him have the confidence to make choices for himself," says Lansdown, who again features this scenario in her document.

"He also had the right to be protected from situations he might not have been able to anticipate or control. So he was given all the information and helped to see all the issues or implications of whichever choice he made."

fields.headline: When push comes to shove
fields.standfirst: Sunday is Mother's Day, so treat yourself - ditch the National Childbirth Trust, says  Kate Figes
fields.trailText: Childbirth may be natural but it has always been difficult - large head, small hole. So how on earth did we get lumbered with the National Childbirth Trust as our only alternative source of support to the mighty, macho, medical establishment?
fields.body:
Childbirth may be natural but it has always been difficult - large head, small hole. So how on earth did we get lumbered with the National Childbirth Trust as our only alternative source of support to the mighty, macho, medical establishment? Pregnant women are faced with two stark and equally unpalatable extremes: either submit legs akimbo to the stirrups, forceps and baby monitor, or subscribe to the NCT's quasi-spiritual natural birth dogma, which maintains that it is possible to have a serene, enjoyable, even sexual experience of giving birth. The purpose of childbirth is to have a baby rather than to experience labour, but the NCT ignores that - preparation for parenthood in its classes is almost non-existent.

Some 600,000 women give birth every year in the UK and the NCT reaches roughly half of them through their 400 local support groups. Their classes are so heavily oversubscribed that they daren't advertise them and that's not because women suddenly turn into committed naturopaths when they discover they're pregnant (although some do). It's because there is nothing else on offer for the woman who feels that she needs a little more than the quick "Let's listen to baby's heart" approach currently available at NHS antenatal.

Once at the NCT group, women become easily seduced by the notion that there is a right and a wrong way to give birth. The "right" way is to keep control over the course of your labour, to resist medical intervention and to deliver, tear free, in water or at home with the lights dimmed. Pain relief is to be resisted, too, because it can cross the placenta wall to the baby or prevent the mother from pushing properly. Yoga and deep breathing will get you through. Caesareans tend to happen to those poor, weak women who lose control and cannot do it by deep breathing alone.

Then when you hobble to the labour ward clutching your bean bag - for most first-time mothers fail in their attempts to persuade their doctor to let them give birth at home - you're almost destined to give birth the "wrong" way. The midwives hook you up to a baby monitor and start laying bets as to when you'll be screaming for an epidural. They leave you alone for hours on end with the baby's father, who is even more terrified than you are. Most labour wards resemble the set of ER rather than the dimly-lit, serene intimacy of our imaginings. There's a feeling of emergency in the air. As anxiety mounts, and the contractions swell with painful intensity, women feel control slipping away. Forceps, episiotomies and even the dreaded caesarean are now only moments away.

Crucial information tends to get left out of NCT briefings. Next to nothing is said about the immense upheaval that childbirth brings, physically, psychologically and emotionally, and countless women are left stranded after they've had a baby because they feel they have failed. After interviewing new mothers for my book, my guess is that for every woman who has had a "life-enhancing experience of becoming a parent" thanks to the NCT (and that is the Trust's aim, according to its director, Belinda Phipps) there are at least two who have been left severely disillusioned by a philosophy that failed to provide them with the truth about giving birth or new motherhood.

NCT dogma fits in neatly with the popular notion of perfect motherhood, where women are self-sacrificial to the point of masochism for the welfare of their child. Just when modern science gave women a glimmer of hope with pain relief and life-saving equipment after centuries of agony and terror, the natural birth movement snatched it away from them. Once women would have killed for anaesthetic; now women have to do without it to prevent baby from feeling groggy after birth, when I would have thought a little dope might just ease the shock of being born. Once women were able to trust midwives when the time came. Now childbirth has to be studied and practised for like some gruesome exam, and aspirational women are set such high targets that they then feel like terrible failures because they have had an episiotomy or were unable to ride those extraordinary waves of pain. Inevitably, those feelings of failure contribute to postnatal unhappiness, which is extensive.

In the main, NCT antenatal classes are staffed by volunteers who are fascinated by the whole process of childbirth and have probably had a good experience of labour. How many women who have had caesareans or six-inch episiotomies willingly volunteer to become NCT counsellors? Then there is the rather questionable link between the two wings of the organisation: the local support groups and classes, and the campaign side, which has many admirable aims, such as bringing down the national caesarean rate to the World Health Organisation recommended level of 8% (the official UK rate is 18% but it has gone as high as 37% in some areas).

If the NCT were either a campaign group or a resource for pregnant women, it would be far less contentious. But the attempt to be both means that individual women are unwittingly used as tiny arrows in the natural birth movement's war against the mighty maternity machine. If enough women fight or stand their ground for a "natural" birth, the NHS will have to capitulate and accept each woman as an individual with a right to choose how to give birth. But the reality is that few first-time mothers have the medical expertise or the confidence to be able to determine the course of their labour. They are destined to fail.

The sole point of living through childbirth is the prize at the end of it. Childbirth may be difficult but it is nothing compared to the efforts exerted over the subsequent 20 years. It is here that the NCT really fails new mothers because we have absolutely nothing else to support us through the profound psychological and emotional adjustments of those early months. The NHS and social services abandon women unless there is evidence of shaken baby syndrome or extreme psychosis, in which case she is locked up and given psychotropic drugs.

But the NCT, with its extensive reach and network of local support groups, could provide women with a genuine and ongoing source of support if it embraced the full truth of new motherhood: that childbirth is a unique experience for every single woman and that most get through it somehow and, most importantly, that the nine months after labour are just as important as those that preceded it.

Life After Birth by Kate Figes is published in paperback by Penguin at £7.99

The "right" way is to keep control over the course of your labour, to resist medical intervention and to deliver, tear free, in water or at home with the lights dimmed. Pain relief is to be resisted, too, because it can cross the placenta wall to the baby or prevent the mother from pushing properly. Yoga and deep breathing will get you through. Caesareans tend to happen to those poor, weak women who lose control and cannot do it by deep breathing alone. Then when you hobble to the labour ward clutching your bean bag - for most first-time mothers fail in their attempts to persuade their doctor to let them give birth at home - you're almost destined to give birth the "wrong" way. The midwives hook you up to a baby monitor and start laying bets as to when you'll be screaming for an epidural. They leave you alone for hours on end with the baby's father, who is even more terrified than you are. Most labour wards resemble the set of ER rather than the dimly-lit, serene intimacy of our imaginings. There's a feeling of emergency in the air. As anxiety mounts, and the contractions swell with painful intensity, women feel control slipping away. Forceps, episiotomies and even the dreaded caesarean are now only moments away. Crucial information tends to get left out of NCT briefings. Next to nothing is said about the immense upheaval that childbirth brings, physically, psychologically and emotionally, and countless women are left stranded after they've had a baby because they feel they have failed. After interviewing new mothers for my book, my guess is that for every woman who has had a "life-enhancing experience of becoming a parent" thanks to the NCT (and that is the Trust's aim, according to its director, Belinda Phipps) there are at least two who have been left severely disillusioned by a philosophy that failed to provide them with the truth about giving birth or new motherhood. NCT dogma fits in neatly with the popular notion of perfect motherhood, where women are self-sacrificial to the point of masochism for the welfare of their child. Just when modern science gave women a glimmer of hope with pain relief and life-saving equipment after centuries of agony and terror, the natural birth movement snatched it away from them. Once women would have killed for anaesthetic; now women have to do without it to prevent baby from feeling groggy after birth, when I would have thought a little dope might just ease the shock of being born. Once women were able to trust midwives when the time came. Now childbirth has to be studied and practised for like some gruesome exam, and aspirational women are set such high targets that they then feel like terrible failures because they have had an episiotomy or were unable to ride those extraordinary waves of pain. Inevitably, those feelings of failure contribute to postnatal unhappiness, which is extensive. In the main, NCT antenatal classes are staffed by volunteers who are fascinated by the whole process of childbirth and have probably had a good experience of labour. How many women who have had caesareans or six-inch episiotomies willingly volunteer to become NCT counsellors? Then there is the rather questionable link between the two wings of the organisation: the local support groups and classes, and the campaign side, which has many admirable aims, such as bringing down the national caesarean rate to the World Health Organisation recommended level of 8% (the official UK rate is 18% but it has gone as high as 37% in some areas). If the NCT were either a campaign group or a resource for pregnant women, it would be far less contentious. But the attempt to be both means that individual women are unwittingly used as tiny arrows in the natural birth movement's war against the mighty maternity machine. If enough women fight or stand their ground for a "natural" birth, the NHS will have to capitulate and accept each woman as an individual with a right to choose how to give birth. But the reality is that few first-time mothers have the medical expertise or the confidence to be able to determine the course of their labour. They are destined to fail. The sole point of living through childbirth is the prize at the end of it. Childbirth may be difficult but it is nothing compared to the efforts exerted over the subsequent 20 years. It is here that the NCT really fails new mothers because we have absolutely nothing else to support us through the profound psychological and emotional adjustments of those early months. The NHS and social services abandon women unless there is evidence of shaken baby syndrome or extreme psychosis, in which case she is locked up and given psychotropic drugs. But the NCT, with its extensive reach and network of local support groups, could provide women with a genuine and ongoing source of support if it embraced the full truth of new motherhood: that childbirth is a unique experience for every single woman and that most get through it somehow and, most importantly, that the nine months after labour are just as important as those that preceded it. Life After Birth by Kate Figes is published in paperback by Penguin at £7.99

fields.headline: Soul purpose
fields.standfirst: Jeanette Winterson on a project determined to show that inner city trees are not luxuries but essentials
fields.trailText: Jeanette Winterson on a project determined to show that inner city trees are not luxuries but essentials
fields.body:
When I die I hope my life will have been useful to myself, for the sake of my soul - and useful to others, for the sake of theirs. This includes planting trees.

In Gloucestershire, where I live, I have planted hundreds of trees. In Spitalfields, London, where I keep a house, I've planted only one, and that was two weeks ago, with a charity called Trees for London.

Spitalfields used to be a slum, and when it stopped being a slum it was just the East End of London, where you were lucky to get street lamps, never mind trees. In this respect, it had a lot in common with the Manchester scrap heap where I was born - a place where they still hadn't put back the pavements 15 years after the end of the war.

Growing up in the 1960s in Accrington, Lancashire, my street had no trees and we had no garden, but it was near enough on foot to get into woodland. I learned then that, if you are poor and life has little beauty, nature can return what is lost. Woods are a kind of inner space. They ease the body and quiet the mind. There is no waste. There is no hurry. Time falls slowly. The time that we don't have any more is still there in the tree.

Cynics say that city trees are just dog loos and litter points. Spital fields has its share of those who think that money spent on nature is money wasted. Cityside Regeneration, which helped sponsor the Spitalfields trees, was urged to put the money into art works or community projects. Well, I can't think of a better symbol of regeneration and growth than a tree. I can't think of a better way of bringing people together than encouraging them to actively care for their own patch.

The sight of a dozen Bengali kids with spades planting a tree outside a traditional East End pub really is a community project. When people who live in a place get together to improve it, the place changes, but so do the people. The nail bomb that went off in Brick Lane last year was about hate. Planting these trees is about hope.

Most people live in cities. This will not change, whatever John Prescott does to the countryside. City parks and planted squares are small pauses in the breathless narrative of traffic and work. We need those pauses. Our bodies benefit from the filtered air the trees provide and from the natural sound barrier any planting creates.

Those environmental and physical benefits can be measured. What can't be measured is the human value. How do we ever cost the pleasure of birdsong or the sudden relief of a tree-lined street?

City life is stressful, but we don't have to tough it out. We can tell the councils and the government who spend our money for us that we want more street planting, more pauses. We can insist that new development makes provision not just for parking but for trees.

Too often the trees artistically drawn on the architect's plans do not appear when the plans have been passed. This has happened in the expensive St George's development in Spitalfields, where the trees which were promised to enhance the surrounding area were never planted. It has happened in Oxford, where the council chopped down some beautiful old plane trees to make way for a road widening scheme to serve the new business school. So what happened to the squiggly artist's impressions on the paved islands in between the lanes? The trees mysteriously dwarfed into concrete planters squatted with primula.

Trees for London is a dynamic new group, low on overheads, high on results, which works with the public and private sectors to green up the city. If you want trees in your street, they will handle the paperwork and the spadework. On average, it costs £160 to plant and maintain, say, a Chanticleer pear tree around eight feet tall. And if you are already worrying about rotting fruit on your soft-top, forget it; these pears won't fruit.

That's the great thing about getting in the experts. They know what should be planted and where it can go. So you won't discover that your Gingko Biloba is quietly wrapping its roots round your cable TV.

Trees aren't a luxury. The poorer the area, the more it needs trees. Trees are bountiful, exuberant, sapped with life. For those whom life has sapped, at the end of a working day or because there is no working day, trees offer relief. You can lean on them, look at them, chase your children round them, pin a love note on them, watch them change. Trees are for the soul. Tend it.

 Trees for London can be contacted at HMS Belfast, Morgan's Lane, Tooley Street, London SE1 2JH (tel: 020-7407 0888).

fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText: British Nuclear Fuels, unlike the Third Reich, is likely to last 1,000 years. Talk of its main site Sellafield in Cumbria "shutting down" is premature. Even if the nuclear fuel reprocessing works are closed, the legacy of wastes generated in the last 50 years will keep most of the workforce and their children busy well beyond the foreseeable future. For high level waste just to get cool enough to store safely takes 50 years. For the radioactivity to decay takes another 250,000 years. The government is about to come up with yet another plan for waste - this time involving all sides in agreeing a solution. The first step is said to be building mutual trust, which, after the last six months of falsified documents and savage official safety assessments, is a tall order in itself.
fields.body:
British Nuclear Fuels, unlike the Third Reich, is likely to last 1,000 years. Talk of its main site Sellafield in Cumbria "shutting down" is premature. Even if the nuclear fuel reprocessing works are closed, the legacy of wastes generated in the last 50 years will keep most of the workforce and their children busy well beyond the foreseeable future. For high level waste just to get cool enough to store safely takes 50 years. For the radioactivity to decay takes another 250,000 years. The government is about to come up with yet another plan for waste - this time involving all sides in agreeing a solution. The first step is said to be building mutual trust, which, after the last six months of falsified documents and savage official safety assessments, is a tall order in itself.

One of the fascinating facets of the nuclear industry is its inbuilt secrecy. We have heard much from dissatisfied customers recently, such as the Japanese, Germans, Swiss and Swedes, but nothing from the Canadians. This is because they have their own little secret - a quantity of weapons grade plutonium, from reprocessing contracts at Sellafield. Since they are not supposed to be a weapons state, and make no disclosures under the Non-Proliferation Treaty about its whereabouts, it is impossible to tell quite what their intentions are.

While nuclear power seems to be a technology past its sell-by date in most of Europe and North America, the industry refuses to give up. The Canadians, Germans and BNFL -through its American arm Westinghouse, of Three Mile Island fame - are vying to get the contracts to build a new plant in Turkey. The anti-nuke brigade have complained because the site of one proposal, at Akkuyu, is in an earthquake area. But the influential Prof Ibrahim Kavrakoglu, the former dean of the department of engineering at the Bosphorus University, the director of the National Energy Committee and a director of Nato, has hit where it hurt. His main point was that the electricity would cost twice as much, the plant would take 10 years to build and natural gas was readily available and cheap. The Turkish government has three times ducked making a decision on who should get the contract, the latest deadline being April 7.

On a happier note, Hanson Quarry Products Europe seems to have won the battle for hearts and minds with its plan to extract 4.4 million tonnes of sand and gravel in Cambridgeshire. The council granted the application, with Hanson batting with the improbable support of English Nature, the Countryside Agency and the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds. The bait was a linked Hanson plan to transform 1,700 acres of adjoining quarry into one of Europe's biggest manmade wetlands. Hanson is to give the new wetland to the RSPB to manage, and one species expected to benefit is the bittern, which survives only in reedbeds and has been reduced to fewer than 20 pairs.

fields.headline: Cover stories
fields.trailText: Planning permission has been granted for a goat shed at a farm in Apsley Guise, Bedfordshire, to be converted into a granny flat for the owner's mother-in-law
fields.body:
Nanny to granny: Planning permission has been granted for a goat shed at a farm in Apsley Guise, Bedfordshire, to be converted into a granny flat for the owner's mother-in-law.

Pay-off line: A man who was awarded £2,000 compensation from Cleveland police for wrongful arrest used the money to set himself up as a drugs dealer.

Balti Towers: The owner of a chain of curry houses in Leeds has hired actors to pose as Basil Fawlty and his incompetent waiter Manuel to entertain customers.

Bee alert: The owner of a honey farm at South Molton, Devon, has warned the county council not to go ahead with plans for a new infants school because it will be in the flight path of thousands of bees.

Can do: A farmer from Newark, Nottinghamshire, claims his cow has doubled its milk yield since he started giving it cans of Tango to drink.

Head for business: A Sikh businessman from Esher, Surrey, has raised £200,000 for charity by selling advertising space on his turban.

Double indemnity: Luminous plastic jackets have been designed by a livestock specialist from Kirkby Malzeard, North Yorkshire, to keep new-born lambs warm and also scare off foxes.

Queue of admirers: Checkout girls are five times more likely to be chatted up at their tills than on a night out, according to a nationwide survey by a supermarket chain.

Tank filler: An intruder who broke into an aquarium in Todmorden, West Yorkshire, left an adult pacu - a vegetarian cousin of the piranha - in one of the tanks.

Strong reprimand: Trading standards officers from Milton Keynes prosecuted the landlady of a pub for selling unknown brands of vodka and gin that were stronger than indicated on the Smirnoff and Gordon's bottles on the optics.

Wet excuse: The Royal Mail's explanation for a two-week delay in post being delivered to 150 homes in Nuneaton, Warwickshire, is that they have been drying out letters after the postman fell off his bike into a river.

Gnawing doubt: Hungry squirrels may be responsible for gnawing through ropes and silencing the bells at a 15th century church in Ilkeston, Nottinghamshire.

Wee discrepancy: Ealing council, west London, has been accused of sexism because women must pay 10p to use its new public toilets while men can use the urinals for free.

Wrong entry: Immigration and visa applications from around the world have been pouring out of the fax machine at a general store in Bodmin, Cornwall, as a result of a government department's printing error.
