fields.headline: Sickly youth
fields.standfirst: To improve the health of the poorest children in society, David Piachaud argues, the government must do more than reduce poverty
fields.trailText: To improve the health of the poorest children in society, David Piachaud argues, the government must do more than reduce poverty
fields.body:
Every morning, 50,000 children in Britain between the ages of eight to 10 have nothing to eat or drink before going to school. Out of all 13 year olds, 7% are regular smokers. Alcohol consumption among 11-15 year olds more than doubled in the 1990s; one-quarter drink every week, averaging the equivalent of over four pints of beer.

While child health is generally improving, inequalities in health have been increasing. These inequalities are closely related to child poverty with rates of disease and death far higher in poorer households. Inequalities in child health, which cast a long shadow into adulthood, are one key reason for tackling child poverty.

A recent Unicef study found "the UK emerging as a serious contender for the title of worst place in Europe to be a child". Child poverty is the worst in the EU with three million children below half average income level, three times the level in 1979.

Now the government has made the bold commitment to end child poverty in 20 years. With the latest measures in last week's Budget it has made a good start towards achieving this goal. The Treasury estimates that the combined effects of the last three budgets is to reduce the number of children in poverty by 1.2m by 2002. But poverty will still remain far above the EU average - even if health expenditure is closer to it - and far above its 1979 level.

Will this reduction in child poverty improve child health? The cynic may say it will all go on confectionery, crisps and canned drinks - or, worse, more tobacco, alcohol and other drugs - which may worsen child health. But more money gives the opportunity to spend more on nutritious, often more expensive, food; better heating, more holidays, less stress and higher self-esteem should all improve child health.

Yet if the government wants to be sure of improving the health of poor children it cannot rely on only modest increases in family income of some £30 per week in the poorest fifth of families. Improving nutrition does require higher benefits for children and also access to healthy and affordable food supplies, as the 1998 Acheson report on health inequalities stressed. Yet for the children going off to school without any breakfast, these are not enough. The more direct option is to feed the children through school dinner and breakfast programmes.

On school dinners an opportunity was missed in the budget. Giving free school dinners to families receiving working families tax credit would have been a sure way of improving child nutrition.

On breakfasts, there is clear evidence from the US that children's learning suffers if they do not get a nutritious breakfast. Remarkably, the US government has responded by developing nutritious programmes for school dinners and breakfasts on which more is now spent than on welfare benefits. Over 7m children in 70,000 schools get free or subsidised breakfasts in a federal programme administered by the department of agriculture.

In Britain, tentative trials of breakfast clubs have been started that include about 10,000 children. But in areas in which many children do not get a proper breakfast and their education is, as a result, jeopardised, there is a clear need for public health and education authorities - and perhaps even Maff - to combine to tackle one of the worst symptoms of child poverty.

Smoking damages the health of children, and kills them later on. The Budget raised cigarette tax by 25p a packet. Perversely, this will leave many addicted poor parents worse off and children will suffer. If the chancellor extended half the resources with which he is tackling cigarette smuggling, which threatens £7bn revenue from tobacco, to preventing sales to children, and disallowed all marketing and promotional expenditure for tax purposes then children's health would be better served.

Part of the reason for the increase in children's drinking is the mushrooming of alcopops - fizzy, sweetened alcohol. These are a cynical, exploitative and successful attempt to make alcohol more attractive to young people and children. Yet in this area, as so many, the government will not say "boo" to big business. Are politicians so beholden to the brewers, or so blind that they cannot see the inconsistency between allowing the sale of alcopops and improving child health?

Improving children's opportunities requires the ending of child poverty; it must also involve improving the health of the poorest children. While the two are related, it would be complacent and foolish to hope that the reduction of child poverty would automatically improve children's nutrition and reduce their smoking and drinking. Extending nutritional provision, determined regulation and much more effective prevention - Blair's fifth challenge to the NHS - are needed to improve child health.

 David Piachaud is professor of social policy at LSE. This article is based on his address yesterday to the UK Public Health Association annual forum in Harrogate on partnership, participation and power.

Part of the reason for the increase in children's drinking is the mushrooming of alcopops - fizzy, sweetened alcohol. These are a cynical, exploitative and successful attempt to make alcohol more attractive to young people and children. Yet in this area, as so many, the government will not say "boo" to big business. Are politicians so beholden to the brewers, or so blind that they cannot see the inconsistency between allowing the sale of alcopops and improving child health? Improving children's opportunities requires the ending of child poverty; it must also involve improving the health of the poorest children. While the two are related, it would be complacent and foolish to hope that the reduction of child poverty would automatically improve children's nutrition and reduce their smoking and drinking. Extending nutritional provision, determined regulation and much more effective prevention - Blair's fifth challenge to the NHS - are needed to improve child health.  David Piachaud is professor of social policy at LSE. This article is based on his address yesterday to the UK Public Health Association annual forum in Harrogate on partnership, participation and power.

fields.headline: Off cuts
fields.trailText: I still remember my relief when I read page 13 of Richard Sennett's classic study of the erosion of public life, The Fall of Public Man (1977). Friends had warned me the text was positively Foucaultian in the density of its argument and I found, after the author's rather forbidding declaration that his dialectical inquiry would only be complete when the book came to an end, a paragraph on dead public space which cited the London shopping block at the end of my road.
fields.body:
I still remember my relief when I read page 13 of Richard Sennett's classic study of the erosion of public life, The Fall of Public Man (1977). Friends had warned me the text was positively Foucaultian in the density of its argument and I found, after the author's rather forbidding declaration that his dialectical inquiry would only be complete when the book came to an end, a paragraph on dead public space which cited the London shopping block at the end of my road.

The Brunswick Centre, Sennett argued, was an urban space with "no sense of being anywhere in particular, much less in an extraordinary urban milieu". The vast areas of empty space in its interior and the decision to raise the entire concourse several feet above street level meant that everything had been done to isolate its public area "from accidental street incursion, or from simple strolling".

Since that time, Sennett has turned "simple strolling" into a mode of sociological inquiry. When he sets out in The Conscience of the Eye (1991) to answer his own question, "Why are we afraid of unfamiliar people and scenes", he does so by taking walks round New York in order to discover those aspects of urban design which help or hinder people's capacity to lose their burdensome sense of self and find relief in the experience of otherness.

In a lecture to be given next week, Sennett, now centennial professor of sociology at the LSE, brings these traditional urban preoccupations into alignment with the insights into contemporary personality which informed his highly praised The Corrosion of Character (1998).

Modern capitalism with its emphasis upon risk, flexibility and short-term work, not only "corrodes" the sense of purpose, self-integrity and trust in others that were traditionally essential to notions of personal character, but also disrupts long-term local businesses and ways of life. Cities become neutral places with people "jetting in and out". Instead of compensating for our contemporary economic dislocation, they compound it with their neutrality and sense of sameness.

Sennett believes that this "insensate, flat environment" can be challenged by design. That challenge may be nearer than he knows. Last Tuesday, I received a leaflet announcing that the Brunswick Centre was to be revitalised. Did anyone have views on how this might be achieved? I've already posted on the invitation to the LSE.

 Laurie Taylor talks to Richard Sennett about the art of making cities in Radio 4's Thinking Allowed at 4pm today.

fields.headline: Roughing it
fields.standfirst: Can heads of charities stay in touch with the people they are meant to be helping? Omega Douglas reports on one director who decided to get back to his grassroots by joining the homeless for a night on the streets
fields.trailText: Can heads of charities stay in touch with the people they are meant to be helping? Omega Douglas reports on one director who decided to get back to his grassroots by joining the homeless for a night on the streets
fields.body:
It's Monday lunchtime and Brixton tube is bustling. A man sits on the floor, his back against a photo booth and a plastic bag slumped beside him. He's not alone, there are a handful of others who have nowhere to go but loiter at the station.

Most fit under one of several headings - homeless, disaffected, addicts. But not the man with the plastic bag. Though to passers-by he is another down and out to skirt around, he is in fact the director of a charity, Newham Drugs Advice Project. Last night he joined reams of the capital's homeless by sleeping on the street.

In a bid to reconnect with the realities faced by those his charity strives to help, Viv Ahmun decided to sleep rough for 48 hours. It's not an original concept. MPs and celebrities have embarked on similar ventures to raise their profiles, be seen to be "in touch" and raise money for charity. But unlike them, we expect charity executives to not only be steering fundraising initiatives but, crucially, to be in touch with whatever grassroots issues are at the core of their organisations.

Therefore, what is unusual in Ahmun's undertaking is, firstly, that he felt the need to reconnect and, secondly, that he is prepared to admit that he is perhaps more removed from the problems his charity exists to alleviate than he would like to be.

"As a director it's easy to cut yourself off and just deal with bureau cracy. You're constantly at meetings, going to conferences and it's very comfortable, but it's not the reality we're paid to address and be actively involved in," explains Ahmun. "I spend 80% of my time in that kind of environment because one of my key responsibilities is to secure funds and that's where I gain access to people who enable me to do that.

"If I had my way, I'd spend two days a week at grassroots level but that doesn't happen because the bigger the organisation gets the more pressure there is to find funds to keep it running. It creates an imbalance which is why I'm doing this in an effort to redress that."

His actions raise questions about the role of charity directors: how in touch are they and how in touch do they need to be in order to do their jobs effectively?

Indeed, as more major charities are run like private sector companies and, in turn, senior appointments are often made on the basis of an applicant's ability to manage finance, corporate identity and strategic development rather than their hands-on experience of charity work, these have become increasingly important questions.

Though it would be naive to think that charities could operate as effectively without incorporating a business ethic, Ahmun worries that such focus can mean that a discernible connection between chief executive and operation worker is lost.

It was this concern which was a contributing factor in Christian Aids appointment of their director, Daleep Mukarji. His 25 years as a Christian Aid partner, and background running a health and development programme in rural India, meant that he was in touch with what was going on on the ground.

"I've worked at a local, national and international level so I know how the organisation functions from grassroots to senior management. That, and tapping into my experience as a southern person from a developing country, is an important way of me keeping in touch," says Mukarji.

Back in Brixton, Ahmun, who also spent his early years working as an outreach worker, says part of his motive for sleeping rough is also to "re-energise". Ahmun is under no illusion that a mere 48 hours will enable him to know what it's like to be homeless. "Tomorrow I'll be back at my desk. That's my reality but it hasn't stop me feeling unhappy sleeping in a space someone had urinated in and feeling the cold in my bones. It's that experience I'll draw on when I'm advocating on behalf of people who use services I'm trying to secure money for."

Mukarji agrees: "We've got to get across that we're not just helping people to help themselves but, these are human beings and we can identify with them rather than just discussing how we can help them. A sense of solidarity and partnership is essential."

fields.headline: Road to repair
fields.standfirst: New legislation to reduce crime takes effect next week. David Utting looks at work to prevent criminal behaviour
fields.trailText: New legislation to reduce crime takes effect next week. David Utting looks at work to prevent criminal behaviour
fields.body:
A clutch of US and British academics in the mid-1970s took the view that there was no systematic evidence that rehabilitation programmes were effective. Politicians, their populist instincts thus fortified, hastened to embrace the "nothing works" message: the rhetoric of short, sharp shocks, punishment in the community and boot camps was born.

Nowadays, things are rather different. Community-based programmes to prevent youth crime and re-offending will assume unprecedented prominence in the youth justice system next week, when the Labour government's crime and disorder legislation takes full effect. Multi-agency youth offending teams (Yots), throughout England and Wales, are charged with tackling the causes of young people's criminal activities and delivering suitable community intervention programmes.

The range of non-custodial responses to juvenile offenders has been widened to include a police final warning, court-ordered reparation, parenting orders and action plan orders, where intensive rehabilitation programmes can be tailored to the needs of offenders. Over and above them flies a new statutory aim for all relevant professionals of preventing offending by children and young people.

Although a change of government is the immediate reason for this turnround in the fortunes of prevention programmes, it has been underpinned by more positive intimations from research. A resurgent "what works" movement on both sides of the Atlantic has drawn attention to convincing evidence that certain types of rehabilitation can significantly reduce reoffending.

By analysing more than 400 controlled evaluations of work with young offenders, the American researcher Mark Lipsey found that even on average they achieved reductions in recidivism compared with "treatment as usual". More persuasively, there were certain categories that pointed to average reduction rates of 20% or more.

The most promising programmes in community settings were those designed to improve personal and social skills and those that focused on changing behaviour. Services that combined a number of approaches were also noticeably effective.

When Lipsey narrowed the analysis to programmes for juveniles convicted of serious and violent crimes, he discovered that behaviour modification and inter-personal skills work scored average reductions in re-offending of as high as 40%.

Ironically, for the tough talkers in politics, what plainly didn't work were deterrent programmes - such as "scared straight" schemes using shock incarceration to frighten youngsters out of crime. In fact, such programmes made re-offending more likely.

Practitioners and researchers in Britain, such as the forensic clinical psychologist James McGuire, have promulgated a set of principles for effective work with offenders. For example, the choice of programme for each individual should be based on an assessment of the seriousness of their offending and the risk of further offences. Intervention must tackle risk factors, such as lack of basic skills that contribute to their criminal lifestyle. It must be geared to their learning pace and ability, and long enough and intense enough to achieve its aims. They also conclude that, generally speaking, community-based programmes will yield better results than those delivered in custody.

"What works" principles can be seen in action in programmes like Sherborne House, a probation centre run by the Inner London Probation Service. The young men who attend are persistent or serious offenders who would otherwise risk custody. Ten intensive weeks of cognitive-behavioural therapy, reinforcing alternatives to anti-social behaviour, is combined with personal and social skills training, racism awareness sessions and help with education, training and employment. A comparison between 120 participants and similar young offenders (mostly sentenced to custody) showed a significantly lower level of reconviction after two years. The centre appeared especially successful in reducing reconviction among the highest-risk offenders.

Some evaluations of mentoring in the US, where young people receive friendship and support from an adult or older peer, are also encouraging. Others are not - a salutary reminder that the line between failure and success can often be found in the design and implementation of individual schemes.

A comparably mixed message emerges from research into motor projects. By teaching teenagers motor mechanics, as well as confronting their offending behaviour, these aim to provide a constructive outlet for their fascination with cars in place of theft and "joy riding". A 1998 Home Office overview of more than 1,000 young offenders attending projects produced an unimpressive reconviction rate of nearly 80% within two years. However, an evaluation of the long-established Ilderton motor project in south London - comparing 30 participants with similar probation clients who did not take part - did find a significantly lower rate of re-offending in the following three years.

The new parenting order in England and Wales is controversial precisely because of evidence that "parent-blaming" is the wrong starting point for improving the way that young people are supervised and disciplined at home. Yet research in the US suggests court-ordered participation in parenting and family support schemes can reduce young people's anti-social behaviour, including crime.

The most intriguing of these is a parenting-by-computer programme using interactive CD-roms. Professionals may not thrill to the idea, but there are signs that parents find a computer screen less judgmental than working face-to-face with a therapist.

Public policy - even when attractively labelled as "evidence-based" - seldom moves at a steady, reflective pace. Famine is currently giving way to feast. And although some approaches being vigorously pursued by the new Yots have been convincingly evaluated, the evidence often comes from the US, Canada and other countries. These are places where the evaluation culture may be stronger, but the social context of crime can be very different. Restorative justice packages, including opportunities for young offenders to make reparation to their victims, are an example of a currently fashionable intervention where there is much still to be learned.

Routine use of risk-assessment questionnaires, meanwhile, raises the enticing possibility that it may be possible to identify, with greater accuracy, the small minority of juvenile offenders who go on to become persistent, serious and violent criminals in adult life. Early intervention could be highly cost-effective. Success would be crowned by fewer victims, lower costs of crime and fewer troubled young people whose law-breaking drives them deeper into social exclusion.

 What Works With Young Offenders in the Community?, by David Utting and Julie Vennard, (£8) is published by Barnardo's Child Care Publications (tel: 01268 520224).

fields.headline: Adding to the pain
fields.standfirst: Many people are waiting too long for disability equipment, reports David Brindle
fields.trailText: Many people are waiting too long for disability equipment, reports David Brindle
fields.body:
Like so many carers, Eleanor Jones saves the state a small fortune. At the age of 75, she is still looking after her husband, Arthur, left paralysed by a stroke almost two decades ago. Yet it has taken her more than 12 years to get the electric hoist she needs to move him about their one-bedroom flat.

"It may be a monstrosity, but it's a godsend," she says. "I told them and told them that I couldn't manage, what with him being 14 stone, but nobody took any notice. In the end, I only got anywhere because the physiotherapist at the hospital went potty about it."

Why the physio went potty was that constantly lifting Arthur, now 91, was doing irreparable damage to his wife's neck and back. After words were exchanged in a no doubt friendly multi-disciplinary way, social services installed the long-desired equipment at the Joneses' flat in Lewisham, south London. "You shouldn't have to fight like that," says Eleanor, "but it's just the same with supplies. You have to fight for everything."

Keeping up with the Joneses is something that disability equipment services have not been doing, not by a long chalk. According to a report published today by the Audit Commission, service standards are "unacceptably low" in many parts of the country and service patterns lead to inequality and inefficiency. Andrew Foster, the commission's controller, says: "Long waiting times, unclear eligibility criteria and poor quality products threaten to undermine plans to promote independence in the community."

The kind of service needed by the Joneses, defined in the report as a "community equipment service", is part of a much bigger picture. The commission calculates that more than 4m people depend on some kind of disability equipment, ranging from artificial limbs to hearing aids to bath rails, and that too few of them are getting a good deal.

The report, in parts, is shocking. Special mattresses are known to prevent development of pressure sores among people confined to bed for long periods. When sores do develop, they can not only be life threatening but can cost up to £35,000 to treat if plastic surgery is required. Yet at one NHS trust visited by the commission, almost 500 people were found to have been waiting up to 16 months for a mattress - and the longest wait was for a type costing as little as £71. Almost unbelievably, the commission came across one trust - not named and shamed- that had an explicit policy of not issuing pressure relieving mattresses until sores had developed.

The report, Fully Equipped, finds that people are often not asked basic questions about the sort of help they need. Before a wheelchair is supplied, barely a third of users are consulted about what they would like to do with it in order that the most appropriate model might be chosen. Even more users - and there are 750,000 of them - are not shown how to manage their wheelchair. A quarter say they were given no contact for help or advice.

A second problem identified is the long periods people have to wait for equipment to arrive. The average wait for a hearing aid, from GP referral to fitting, is 19 weeks. In one in five health authority areas, it is more than six months.

This problem is often compounded by confusion over people's eligibility for help. In a ruling today by the local government ombudsman, Harlow council in Essex is found to have taken eight months to install a stairlift at the home of an 85-year-old council tenant, as recommended by the authority's own occupational therapist, because it was misinterpreting the law. The council has apologised to the man and paid him £150 compensation.

Other issues identified in the report include unsuitability of much equipment, as evinced by the one in four people with artificial limbs who do not use them as often as they would like because of their poor fitting, and the often poor quality of products. Hearing aids, for instance, are still largely based on 1970s analogue technology since overtaken by digital techniques.

Overall, disability equipment services are said to be organised in ways that are a recipe for poor practice: many services are small, fragmented and characterised by lack of clinical leadership and senior management involvement. Although such services are "pivotal" to the success of many current initiatives to promote independent living, the commission says, they have been sorely neglected by top managers.

The report gives a sobering account of how lack of co-ordination blighted the early life of a baby born with disabilities in both legs. One leg was amputated and a full-length splint prescribed for the other, but the consultant responsible for fitting an artificial limb decided that the splint - the responsibility of a different clinician - needed to be modified. As the report puts it, a "debate" ensued.

Even when this issue was resolved, the modified splint "sat on a shelf for several weeks" as the supplier and hospital argued over outstanding invoices. Meanwhile, a separate argument was taking place among the wheelchair service, social services and the regional centre for disabilities over assessment of the baby for a special buggy and chair. In the end, all three units did their own assessments.

The story concludes: "The package of care eventually provided was considered inadequate by the specialists at the regional centre. This process took over a year to complete."

The commission is calling for the restructuring of mobility services, under clinical leadership, and the integration of health and social services provision for community equipment and hearing aids. It wants the Department of Health to raise the profile of these services and, where necessary, give high priority to plans to improve poor quality provision. Above all, though, the commission wants to see the close involvement of service users at all levels of the process to ensure equipment is tailored to their needs and lifestyles.

"Several million people depend on equipment such as hearing aids, wheelchairs or artificial limbs, which have the potential to make or break the quality of their lives - as well as the lives of the 1.7m family or friends who care for them," says Foster. "A higher priority needs to be given to these services at all levels of the NHS."

 Fully Equipped costs £20 and is available from Audit Commission Publications (tel: 0800-502030).

The commission calculates that more than 4m people depend on some kind of disability equipment, ranging from artificial limbs to hearing aids to bath rails, and that too few of them are getting a good deal. The report, in parts, is shocking. Special mattresses are known to prevent development of pressure sores among people confined to bed for long periods. When sores do develop, they can not only be life threatening but can cost up to £35,000 to treat if plastic surgery is required. Yet at one NHS trust visited by the commission, almost 500 people were found to have been waiting up to 16 months for a mattress - and the longest wait was for a type costing as little as £71. Almost unbelievably, the commission came across one trust - not named and shamed- that had an explicit policy of not issuing pressure relieving mattresses until sores had developed. The report, Fully Equipped, finds that people are often not asked basic questions about the sort of help they need. Before a wheelchair is supplied, barely a third of users are consulted about what they would like to do with it in order that the most appropriate model might be chosen. Even more users - and there are 750,000 of them - are not shown how to manage their wheelchair. A quarter say they were given no contact for help or advice. A second problem identified is the long periods people have to wait for equipment to arrive. The average wait for a hearing aid, from GP referral to fitting, is 19 weeks. In one in five health authority areas, it is more than six months. This problem is often compounded by confusion over people's eligibility for help. In a ruling today by the local government ombudsman, Harlow council in Essex is found to have taken eight months to install a stairlift at the home of an 85-year-old council tenant, as recommended by the authority's own occupational therapist, because it was misinterpreting the law. The council has apologised to the man and paid him £150 compensation. Other issues identified in the report include unsuitability of much equipment, as evinced by the one in four people with artificial limbs who do not use them as often as they would like because of their poor fitting, and the often poor quality of products. Hearing aids, for instance, are still largely based on 1970s analogue technology since overtaken by digital techniques. Overall, disability equipment services are said to be organised in ways that are a recipe for poor practice: many services are small, fragmented and characterised by lack of clinical leadership and senior management involvement. Although such services are "pivotal" to the success of many current initiatives to promote independent living, the commission says, they have been sorely neglected by top managers. The report gives a sobering account of how lack of co-ordination blighted the early life of a baby born with disabilities in both legs. One leg was amputated and a full-length splint prescribed for the other, but the consultant responsible for fitting an artificial limb decided that the splint - the responsibility of a different clinician - needed to be modified. As the report puts it, a "debate" ensued. Even when this issue was resolved, the modified splint "sat on a shelf for several weeks" as the supplier and hospital argued over outstanding invoices. Meanwhile, a separate argument was taking place among the wheelchair service, social services and the regional centre for disabilities over assessment of the baby for a special buggy and chair. In the end, all three units did their own assessments. The story concludes: "The package of care eventually provided was considered inadequate by the specialists at the regional centre. This process took over a year to complete." The commission is calling for the restructuring of mobility services, under clinical leadership, and the integration of health and social services provision for community equipment and hearing aids. It wants the Department of Health to raise the profile of these services and, where necessary, give high priority to plans to improve poor quality provision. Above all, though, the commission wants to see the close involvement of service users at all levels of the process to ensure equipment is tailored to their needs and lifestyles. "Several million people depend on equipment such as hearing aids, wheelchairs or artificial limbs, which have the potential to make or break the quality of their lives - as well as the lives of the 1.7m family or friends who care for them," says Foster. "A higher priority needs to be given to these services at all levels of the NHS."  Fully Equipped costs £20 and is available from Audit Commission Publications (tel: 0800-502030).

fields.headline: Closed worlds
fields.standfirst: Phillipa May visits the deaf and blind people struggling to cope with minimal state help
fields.trailText: Phillipa May visits the deaf and blind people struggling to cope with minimal state help
fields.body:
It's 8am and I believe it is Tuesday. I leave to make a hastily arranged visit to a new referral in Somerset. My new client is in his early fifties, totally blind and now suffering from Ménières disease. His hearing levels have dropped dramatically over the last few months and he has severe tinnitus. He has standard issue hearing aids from his local audiologist which are inadequate and he is very depressed by his deterioration. His wife is also blind and both have guide dogs.

There is minimal statutory service support for this couple. The social worker is not able to help because of resource limitations and the audiologist is unwilling to finance a better, more effective and, naturally more expensive, hearing aid. We discuss the options I can pursue and I arrange a further visit after I contact a specialist hearing service in Birmingham to which I hope to take them.

Next I meet with a deafblind young woman. She has Usher syndrome, which means she has a profound hearing loss and now has very little real sight left. I use the Deafblind Manual alphabet to communicate with her and she responds in British Sign Language. She is desperate to leave her current accommodation, where she feels totally isolated, unsafe and vulnerable.

She has been battling with her local social services for an adequate communicator guide - a linkworker to assist with basic daily living. She has been forced to leave her college course because she could not be properly supported and now has only four hours a week of contact time to deal with everything she needs to do. Her great love, horse riding, has also been lost to her.

We have been engaged on her behalf to improve her woefully inadequate services, with practically no success and much resentment and hostility from the local team manager. This young woman has attempted to live an independent life, despite her disability, and she has met with hostility and arrogance and with little or no understanding. As a result she is now actively involved in emigration discussions with the rest of her family, in the knowledge that she will only get a better service by living in Australia.

On another case, I have been asked by a concerned lady to visit her 94-year-old friend, a widow who lives alone and who is very reluctant to allow anyone into her house or her life. She lost most of her hearing during bombing in the war and was forced to leave her much cherished teaching post. She has now lost most of her usable vision, with the very sudden onset of macular degeneration.

Her most treasured pastime - that of reading - has now been lost to her and she lives in a silent and dark world. She has an elderly, bad tempered dog who bites her and anyone it can get at, and she has a very nasty leg infection to prove it. Her home is unlit and largely unheated, as she has no other source of income but her state pension.

She fears the prospect of being forced into residential care, where we know staff will be generally unaware of the needs of deafblind people and she will have lost all hope of an independent life. She fears statutory services interference and their power and has only ever had one visit from a social worker, who never came back again.

I have contacts in the local volunteer bureau, and I am hoping to find one or two volunteer helpers for shopping, taking her out and reading to her - but I will have to be very careful to keep within her boundaries.

Some days are very long, but I know that I can make a difference in people's lives and that is why I keep going. Eight years in the job: services are not improving and the needs are not diminishing. I hope I am not saying this in another eight years, but I don't hold my breath.

 Philippa May is an outreach worker for Sense, the UK's leading deafblind charity. She is based in Devon and visits people throughout the south-west of England who are deaf and blind.

fields.headline: Countryside alert
fields.standfirst: With British farming in crisis, the wild bird population plummeting and global warming a reality, there are many decisions to make. Here Graham Wynne calls for widespread change and long term planning
fields.trailText: With British farming in crisis, the wild bird population plummeting and global warming a reality, there are many decisions to make. Here Graham Wynne calls for widespread change and long term planning
fields.body:
Tomorrow Tony Blair turns his attention to another creaking area of public policy when he hosts a farm summit at Downing Street with ministers and leaders from the farming and food industries. The issue? How to take British agriculture out of its current doldrums.

It's an odds-on bet that short- term problems will dominate the agenda: an unusual alliance of organisations, including the RSPB, the small farmers' alliance and the young farmers, feels sufficiently confident of this that they have organised an "alternative" summit. Why do these bodies feel that their interests are in danger of being left out in the cold?

There is an extensive history of governments talking a long-term game on farming and the environment but adopting short-term tactics. If this government falls into the trap of concentrating on the immediate economic crisis, it risks losing the opportunity to reflect the developing consensus about the long-term future of farming.

There is no doubt that, across most sectors, the farming industry is in crisis. The role of agriculture in the rural economy has been declining for decades. Stuck with a "dig for victory" emphasis on food production, farming policies are badly out of kilter with modern needs. This has had a knock-on effect on rural communities. The total number of UK farmers and farm workers has declined from over 1m in the 1960s to 605,000 in 1996, and many farming families survive on annual incomes of less than £5,000.

But it would be a mistake to think that, apart from agriculture, the countryside is in good health. The rural environment is in crisis too. Only recently, the government published quality of life indicators showing that countryside bird populations continue their massive declines: millions of wild birds have vanished from the skies in a quarter of a century. In just one three-year period in the early 90s, 54,000 km of hedgerows were lost across England and Wales. This week, BirdLife International published figures showing that 42% of the most important bird areas in Europe are threatened by intensive agriculture. These statistics are indicative of what is happening to the farmed landscape and wildlife country-wide.

No one can blame the farmers; they have simply responded to market demand and the outdated priorities of the CAP. However, opinion polls show the public increasingly wants agriculture that is about more than just mass food production at lowest cost.

Food safety scares, BSE, genetically modified crops and the impact of modern farming on the landscape have intensified consumer anxiety about the way we produce our food. There is a growing recognition that farmers should be rewarded for their wider roles in the countryside - contributing to a diverse rural economy and providing an environmentally rich landscape. In convening his summit, Blair has a prime opportunity to find solutions for redirecting public money to provide what the average taxpayer really wants from British agriculture. But the omens for this are not good.

The RSPB has long been an advocate of the need to reduce the environmental impact of pesticides and the £100m annual costs to the taxpayer of removing them from drinking water.

Introducing fiscal incentives through a pesticides tax is one option. But this has been shelved by the government in favour of an as yet unseen package of voluntary measures from the agrochemicals industry. Until it is demonstrated that the latter has real substance, this can only be construed as gesture politics taking precedence over long-term policy solutions.

The switch from paying sheep farmers on a headage to an area basis made environmental and economic sense, as it would have reduced sheep numbers on the hills and produced fewer, higher quality - and therefore higher value - lambs. With sheep prices at an all-time low and over-grazing continuing to blight the uplands, both hill farmers and the environment will lose out as a result of Maff's decision to keep payments closely linked to sheep numbers. An opportunity has therefore been wasted to move towards a more environmentally sustainable and economically viable agriculture in a struggling sector.

Ministers have repeatedly stated that they want to see an agriculture industry that is competitive on the world market and rewarded for its increasingly important roles in providing rural development and environmental stewardship.

The government has made positive first steps towards this vision. But if ministers fall back on short-term expediency rather than grapple with the long-term solutions then everyone will be a loser: farmers, taxpayers and the environment.

The primary justification for continued state intervention in agriculture should be to safeguard the future of the countryside as a resource for the whole of society. If the government accepts this vision, it has to face up to the challenge of modernising agriculture policy so that it delivers value for money to the taxpayer.

As Blair himself said last month: "There is a healthy future for farming, but it means change."

 Graham Wynne is chief executive of the RSPB.

fields.headline: Addicted to failure
fields.standfirst: In the wake of yesterday's report on UK drug laws, Ethan Nadelmann explains why successive British governments have been wrong to look to the US for a solution to drug misuse - and why we should now turn our attention to Europe instead
fields.trailText: In the wake of yesterday's report on UK drug laws, Ethan Nadelmann explains why successive British governments have been wrong to look to the US for a solution to drug misuse - and why we should now turn our attention to Europe instead
fields.body:
A piece of advice for British leaders in search of better drug policies: look east, look south, but don't look west. Where once the Dutch represented a lone voice for reform, now growing parts of Europe are embracing pragmatic harm reduction strategies based upon common sense, science, public health and human rights.

I'm not sure why British officials keep turning to the US for lessons in how to deal with drugs. My country, after all, is the one that incarcerates almost as many people for breaking the drug laws as Europe incarcerates for everything else. My country is the one that has allowed 200,000 of its citizens to become infected with the HIV virus rather than make sterile syringes more readily available. My country is the one so committed to "just say no" rhetoric and policies, that it provides no realistic drug education or any real fallback strategy for the majority of teenagers who say yes to drugs.

It's not easy trying to end the drug war in the US. Punitive drug prohibition and a temperance ideology almost as old as the nation itself are deeply embedded in American laws, institutions and culture. It's our chronic national hysteria, rejuvenated each time a "new" drug emerges, ripe for political posturing and media mania.

From abroad, the drug war in the US must appear monolithic, broken only by the occasional personality calling for legalisation and the odd prominence of the medical marijuana issue. Viewed from close up, a more nuanced analysis emerges.

Our drug tsar, retired general Barry McCaffrey, is a case in point. He's almost certainly the best drug tsar to date, even if that's not saying much, given his competition. Unlike the first drug tsar, William Bennett, McCaffrey prefers to leave the rhetoric of war and zero tolerance behind, speaking instead of the drug problem as a cancer in need of treatment. He has attacked the relentless incarceration of petty drug offenders, spoken out against New York's draconian Rockefeller drug laws, and even called our prison system "America's internal gulag". McCaffrey has defended methadone maintenance treatment, and he once tried to reduce the billions of dollars wasted on futile air and sea efforts to prevent drugs from entering the country.

Of course, this is the same drug tsar who has mangled and mocked the truth on issues like needle exchange, marijuana and harm reduction policies inside and outside the US. McCaffrey has played a pivotal role in ensuring that the US government remains alone among advanced, industrialised nations in the west in providing not a penny for needle-exchange programmes to reduce the spread of HIV/Aids. His efforts to challenge the scientific consensus bring to mind the cigarette companies' last, desperate claims to have found a new study demonstrating that smoking does not cause cancer.

His position on medical marijuana has been shameful - first mocking patients and doctors, then threatening them with prosecution and loss of licence, and now blocking the efforts of state and local authorities to establish responsible, regulated systems of distribution.

This is the drug tsar who has presided over a ballooning federal drug budget, now just under $20bn, that favours ineffective and punitive prohibition and enforcement efforts, as did Reagan and Bush.

McCaffrey is also notorious for his thin skin, which may explain why he has studiously avoided any public debate with reformers. His insults and claims are always lobbed from a distance. He is careful to withdraw from televised and other public forums when he learns that patients, doctors, scientists and others with a critical view have been invited to participate.

As a reformer, I find McCaffrey's dissembling indefensible. But as a political analyst, I cannot help but be aware of the political forces that bear upon him and his office.

Political power in the US increasingly lies in the hands of those who smoked marijuana when they were younger, but that generational shift has yet to influence policy. Far more important, and perhaps distinctly American, is the lingering influence of our rigid anti-drug ideology.

Most Americans have strong doubts about the drug war. They support treatment instead of incarceration for drug addicts. They think marijuana should be legally available for medical purposes. They are beginning to have doubts about the cost and meaning of incarcerating almost half a million of their fellow citizens for drug law violations. So why does the drug war not just persist but keep growing?

Part of the answer lies in what might best be described as a "drug prohibition complex" - to take off on President Eisenhower's farewell warning of the military-industrial complex - composed of the hundreds of thousands of law enforcement officials, private prison corporations, anti-drug organisations, drug testing companies and many others who benefit economically, politically, emotionally and other wise from this ever growing edifice. Drug prohibition is now big business in the US.

But the part of the answer that is harder for many people, especially non-Americans, to grasp is the powerful influence of what might be called the "John Birchers of the drug war". In the 1960s, when anti-communism still represented the national ideology, the John Birch Society was the most anti-communist of all, ever vigilant for any sign of moderation or detente.

The "John Birchers of the drug war" represent no more than 20% of public opinion today, but their political influence far exceeds that of the nation's leading scientists, scholars and other drug policy experts. Powerful senators and congressmen take their calls, invite them to testify before official hearings, ensure that their organisations are well funded, and act on their advice. Directors of drug treatment and research agencies, fearful of the zealots' wrath, are quick to compromise their own scientific and intellectual integrity. So, too, is drug tsar McCaffrey.

Tony Blair and others looking west for drug policy solutions need to be mindful of the US's temperance traditions and drug war politics. McCaffrey has tried hard to put a benign face on US drug policy, but Britons should not be deceived. US drug warriors mock the Dutch, with their coffee shops, but ignore the fact that fewer Dutch of all ages use cannabis than do their American counterparts, and far fewer go on to use cocaine. US officials avert their eyes from Europe's heroin maintenance trials, saying it can't be done here, even as heroin overdose fatalities rise in the US and decline in Switzerland. Now ecstasy use is rising rapidly in the US, and all the government offers are the "just say no" bromides of yesteryear.

Meanwhile, signs of reform abound in the US. The John Birchers may still be powerful, but they're gradually losing credibility. Marijuana is to them what alcohol was to temperance warriors of old. And just as the temperance advocates became increasingly shrill and silly as prohibition stumbled along, so today's anti-drug extremists sound increasingly foolish to the parent who knows something about marijuana.

The presidential election campaign this year boasted two Democratic candidates, Al Gore and Bill Bradley, who admit to having smoked - and inhaled - marijuana a number of times when they were younger. Note too that when Republican candidate George W. Bush refused, last August, to deny that he had used cocaine as a young man, over 80% of the American public told pollsters they didn't care one way or another, and his popularity ratings actually increased.

Twelve years ago, a brave new mayor of Baltimore, Kurt Schmoke, provoked a firestorm of controversy at the height of the drug war when he demanded that all options, including decriminalisation, be put on the table. Schmoke weathered the onslaught, and was re-elected twice thereafter. Last summer, two free-speaking governors, Minnesota's Jesse Ventura and New Mexico's Gary Johnson, started calling for major reform of the drug laws. Johnson even used the forbidden "L" word, legalisation. And now, for the first time, a politician, congressman Tom Campbell, of California, is running for higher office on a platform that includes prescribing heroin to drug addicts.

The fact that these reform advocates include both Republicans and Independents bodes well for the non-partisan future of this struggle. Meanwhile, medical marijuana and other drug policy reform initiatives have triumphed at the ballot 11 out of 12 times since 1996.

Don't get me wrong. I don't see any Berlin wall of drug prohibition about to come tumbling down in the US. Each year more people are incarcerated for breaking a drug law. Politicians still fear being blasted as "soft on crime" or "soft on drugs". But beneath the surface, reformist sentiments are bubbling ever more vigorously. The consensus behind punitive prohibition is crumbling as Americans tire of drug war strategies and rhetoric and seek more sensible alternatives.

This is not the time for Britain to embrace what has failed so miserably in my country. Look away, Mr Blair, look away.

 Ethan Nadelmann is founder and director of the Lindesmith Center (www.lindesmith.org) a drug policy institute with offices in New York and San Francisco. He is the author of Cops Across Borders: The Internationalisation of US Criminal Law Enforcement.

Part of the answer lies in what might best be described as a "drug prohibition complex" - to take off on President Eisenhower's farewell warning of the military-industrial complex - composed of the hundreds of thousands of law enforcement officials, private prison corporations, anti-drug organisations, drug testing companies and many others who benefit economically, politically, emotionally and other wise from this ever growing edifice. Drug prohibition is now big business in the US. But the part of the answer that is harder for many people, especially non-Americans, to grasp is the powerful influence of what might be called the "John Birchers of the drug war". In the 1960s, when anti-communism still represented the national ideology, the John Birch Society was the most anti-communist of all, ever vigilant for any sign of moderation or detente. The "John Birchers of the drug war" represent no more than 20% of public opinion today, but their political influence far exceeds that of the nation's leading scientists, scholars and other drug policy experts. Powerful senators and congressmen take their calls, invite them to testify before official hearings, ensure that their organisations are well funded, and act on their advice. Directors of drug treatment and research agencies, fearful of the zealots' wrath, are quick to compromise their own scientific and intellectual integrity. So, too, is drug tsar McCaffrey. Tony Blair and others looking west for drug policy solutions need to be mindful of the US's temperance traditions and drug war politics. McCaffrey has tried hard to put a benign face on US drug policy, but Britons should not be deceived. US drug warriors mock the Dutch, with their coffee shops, but ignore the fact that fewer Dutch of all ages use cannabis than do their American counterparts, and far fewer go on to use cocaine. US officials avert their eyes from Europe's heroin maintenance trials, saying it can't be done here, even as heroin overdose fatalities rise in the US and decline in Switzerland. Now ecstasy use is rising rapidly in the US, and all the government offers are the "just say no" bromides of yesteryear. Meanwhile, signs of reform abound in the US. The John Birchers may still be powerful, but they're gradually losing credibility. Marijuana is to them what alcohol was to temperance warriors of old. And just as the temperance advocates became increasingly shrill and silly as prohibition stumbled along, so today's anti-drug extremists sound increasingly foolish to the parent who knows something about marijuana. The presidential election campaign this year boasted two Democratic candidates, Al Gore and Bill Bradley, who admit to having smoked - and inhaled - marijuana a number of times when they were younger. Note too that when Republican candidate George W. Bush refused, last August, to deny that he had used cocaine as a young man, over 80% of the American public told pollsters they didn't care one way or another, and his popularity ratings actually increased. Twelve years ago, a brave new mayor of Baltimore, Kurt Schmoke, provoked a firestorm of controversy at the height of the drug war when he demanded that all options, including decriminalisation, be put on the table. Schmoke weathered the onslaught, and was re-elected twice thereafter. Last summer, two free-speaking governors, Minnesota's Jesse Ventura and New Mexico's Gary Johnson, started calling for major reform of the drug laws. Johnson even used the forbidden "L" word, legalisation. And now, for the first time, a politician, congressman Tom Campbell, of California, is running for higher office on a platform that includes prescribing heroin to drug addicts. The fact that these reform advocates include both Republicans and Independents bodes well for the non-partisan future of this struggle. Meanwhile, medical marijuana and other drug policy reform initiatives have triumphed at the ballot 11 out of 12 times since 1996. Don't get me wrong. I don't see any Berlin wall of drug prohibition about to come tumbling down in the US. Each year more people are incarcerated for breaking a drug law. Politicians still fear being blasted as "soft on crime" or "soft on drugs". But beneath the surface, reformist sentiments are bubbling ever more vigorously. The consensus behind punitive prohibition is crumbling as Americans tire of drug war strategies and rhetoric and seek more sensible alternatives. This is not the time for Britain to embrace what has failed so miserably in my country. Look away, Mr Blair, look away.  Ethan Nadelmann is founder and director of the Lindesmith Center (www.lindesmith.org) a drug policy institute with offices in New York and San Francisco. He is the author of Cops Across Borders: The Internationalisation of US Criminal Law Enforcement.

fields.headline: All change on the farm
fields.standfirst: Paul Brown forecasts an agricultural revolution in crops and practices as the temperature rises
fields.trailText: Paul Brown forecasts an agricultural revolution in crops and practices as the temperature rises
fields.body:
The British countryside faces sweeping changes as farmers switch to growing navy beans - which with tomato sauce are better known as baked beans - sweetcorn, onions and nine-foot-high grasses in order to cope with climate change.

The days of regarding global warming as something which will only affect the next generation are already over, according to scientists gathered at Rothamsted experimental station in Hertfordshire. They were launching a Ministry of Agriculture book of advice to farmers on how to design new buildings so stock do not die of heat stress, which fruit trees to plant to withstand changed weather patterns, and what new crops to try.

Navy beans will become a major crop in southern England as the temperature rises and the rainfall drops. Supermarkets are keen to stock more sweetcorn - until recently a marginal crop with a short ripening season because of the weather - and its commercial growing area already extends anywhere south of a line between the Wash and Bristol. It used to be only warm enough for sweetcorn to have a two to three week cropping season, but growers can already expect six weeks or more in favoured locations. Other research shows that onions, carrots and courgettes will also benefit from greater carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, which accelaaaerates growth.

It is not all good news. Fewer frosts mean a longer growing season, but severe weather like droughts and windstorms could wipe out this advantage. Also, cold winters used to knock out the majority of aphids and other pests, but with the milder climate they are already able to attack crops much earlier. Arable weeds also grow faster early in the season.

Rainfall patterns have changed, with much of the rain arriving in smaller, heavier bursts. This is bad news for water companies, which rely on slow drizzle to seep into the earth to top up drinking water aquifers in winter to draw on in summer. Dr Merylyn MacKenzie-Hedger, of the UK climate impacts programme, says: "Heavy rainfall events can cause rapid run off and place extreme pressure on drainage systems. Blockages can rapidly cause local flooding. Not all the rain can be captured in storage systems and kept for summer droughts."

The scientists also expect some farmers to switch from food to energy producing crops. Two power stations are opening this year in the countryside, one to produce electricity from straw in Ely, Cambridgeshire, and one from fast-growing willow coppicing in Yorkshire.

The straw station in Ely is also experimenting with nine-foot-high Miscanthus grass from China, grown currently as a garden ornament but a promising fuel. It requires no fertiliser and little work once planted and produces 14 tonnes of fuel a year per hectare.

Dr Dudley Christian, who has been growing it for six years in Hertfordshire, says that in its native China the plant thrived for hundreds of years, so farmers here can expect crops for at least 20 years. It makes electricity without adding to carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, and also produces a complex system of rhizomes from which each year's new growth sprouts - and these store six tonnes of carbon a year.

His favourite future crop is prairie grass, smaller than Miscanthus but cheaper to get going and harvestable with normal machines. "It makes it attractive for set-aside land. It can be cut in the winter when its dry and power stations have burnt the available straw. It would be a winter cash crop for farmers when normal activities on the land have ceased."

Currently farmers can expect to make £300 a hectare from planting wheat and only £160 from planting grass for power stations, but if the grass for fuel is planted on set aside or currently unproductive land then it could form a useful extra income, Dr Christian says. His experiments show that the grasses are popular with wildlife: partridges are nesting in a plot in Hertfordshire, with deer and rabbits moving in.

But while the emphasis is on potential new crops and adaptation, there are some farmers who will lose everything. Rising sea levels are already taking away agricultural land, with more than 1m acres in the fenlands alone under threat. Cliffs on Humberside and in Scarborough are disappearing at an alarming rate - as much as 50 feet a year. Scientists warn that storm surges could occur on high grade agricultural land on the Wash, Norfolk and Suffolk coasts and Morecombe Bay.

Even where the sea defences are not breached in storm surges the increasing height of the tides will push salt into the top soil through seepage under the defences. Some embankments are already being abandoned in Suffolk because the environment agency says maintaining them is too costly.

Deeper below ground, salt is creeping into the water supply, much of it in the fen country of eastern England, where it is extracted to irrigate salad crops. Salt accumulates in the soil, badly affecting productivity.

webTitle: Is it bye-bye time for Bibi?

fields.headline: Is it bye-bye time for Bibi?
fields.standfirst: Israel's former PM faces jail term on corruption charges
fields.trailText: Binyamin 'Bibi' Netanyahu rose from mediocrity to become the best known and  least understood man in Israel. Dogged by controversy throughout his career,  the former prime minister is again in the spotlight of scandal, facing  prosecution and a possible seven-year jail sentence for corruption.
fields.body:
Binyamin 'Bibi' Netanyahu rose from mediocrity to become the best known and least understood man in Israel. Dogged by controversy throughout his career, the former prime minister is again in the spotlight of scandal, facing prosecution and a possible seven-year jail sentence for corruption.

The police have recommended that he be charged with bribery, fraud, obstruction of justice, and breach of trust. They are also urging the state's attorney general to press similar charges against Netanyahu's wife, Sara, and two former officials in the prime minister's office.

The charges centre on an allegedly fraudulent bill submitted to the government by a building contractor for work done to the Netanyahu's private home. The couple are also accused of hanging on to 700 official gifts that were supposed to become state property.

Last night, Bibi went on live television to declare his innocence and angrily accuse the police of trumping up the charges. The interview occupied 50 minutes of prime time. It was, as ever, a bravura performance - and it resolved nothing.

Netanyahu is a master of the soundbite, a gifted phrase-maker who ducks and weaves while rarely saying anything of lasting importance. On his latest television marathon, he used props - brandishing a tiny pin worth less than 65 pence that is said to be one of the gifts he withheld from the state - and long, emotion-laden pauses to illustrate how wounded he is by the seven-month police investigation.

Asked about his most difficult moment since the investigation began, he studied the studio floor in silence for several agonised seconds, before revealing that his eight-year-old son had been taunted at school over the affair.

This is what Netanyahu does best. For more than 20 years, he has dazzled, charmed and browbeaten TV audiences in the US and in Israel, first as a diplomat in Washington, and then as a ruthlessly ambitious politician. He acquired a global audience in 1982 as the voice and face of Israel during Desert Storm, and has used television ever since as the main tool of his trade.

Only once did he misjudge his viewers. In the early 1990s he went on air, live and dripping with emotion, to confess that he had had an extra-marital affair. Israelis were dumbfounded, for never before had one of their leaders thought such a thing worthy of remark, let alone confession. The thrice-married Bibi had an Achilles heel: his upbringing in America, where politicians are expected to confess all and ask forgiveness. In earthy Israel, politicians are simply assumed to be schmucks.

Later, as leader of the rightwing Likud bloc, Netanyahu used the airwaves to mount a virulent campaign against the Labour government's rapprochement with Yasser Arafat and the PLO. That campaign seemed to have backfired when Yitzhak Rabin was assassinated by an ultra-right fanatic, and the nation recoiled in distaste from Likud's shrill rhetoric. But a wave of Palestinian terror attacks restored the initiative to Netanyahu, and he seized his chance ruthlessly.

In the 1996 election he narrowly beat Rabin's successor, Shimon Peres, and the Middle East peace process was consigned to the deep-freeze. Then, last May, the pendulum swung again and Netanyahu was decisively beaten by former army chief Ehud Barak.

It was widely assumed that Bibi would drop out of politics. But more recently he was manoeuvring towards a comeback. It may still happen, for Israelis do not take kindly to anything smacking of a witch-hunt, and there are many who believe that Netanyahu is being unfairly pursued.

For all that, the latest scandal will undoubtedly damage Netanyahu's credibility, in a land reeling with corruption allegations. President Ezer Weizman, no less, is under investigation. Police are inquiring into claims of improper fundraising by Prime Minister Barak's One Israel party. A range of charges against other political leaders include bribery, sexual harassment, and even incitement to murder. Israelis may be willing to overlook, or even giggle at, a politician's peccadilloes, but there is a queasy stench about the body politic that hints not just of damage, but of decay.

webTitle: In brief, and the latest casting news

fields.headline: In brief, and the latest casting news
fields.trailText: The search for Harry Potter director is over, Oliver Reed's last film, jail sentence for Jason Priestley, Gwyneth upsets her Miramax friends, and, on the casting couch, Haley Joel Osment, Mel Gibson, Brad Pitt and Britney Spears, who might be doing some more dirty dancing
fields.body:
Harry Potter's director has been found. Warner Bros has recruited Chris Columbus, the man behind Home Alone and Mrs Doubtfire, to film the hit children's books. "Harry Potter is the kind of timeless literary achievement that comes around once in a lifetime", said Warner Bros' Lorenzo di Bonaventura. "It was important to us to find a director who has an affinity for both children and magic. I can't think of anyone more ideally suited than Chris." Columbus gets the gig after rumour touted directors as varied as Spielberg - who passed on the project after a reported disagreement with author JK Rowling - Brad Silberling, Alan Parker, Ivan Reitman, Terry Gilliam and Jonathan Demme (the latter not noted for his 'affinity with children and magic').

Reports on the BBC have confirmed that Oliver Reed will be appearing in Ridley Scott's Gladiator, the film he was shooting when he died. As earlier reports suggested, CGI technology will 'finish up' scenes in which Reed's character was due to appear. The script has been tailored to accommodate Reed's death: his character will now perish saving someone else. The Beeb reports that additional footage was shot with another actor, whose face was digitally replaced with Reed's courtesy of other footage from earlier scenes.

Jason Priestley has been sentenced to five days in a Los Angeles jail, after pleading no contest to drunken-driving charges stemming from a December car crash. Priestley lodged the plea to avoid felony charges for the accident, which he originally explained with the claim that he'd swerved to avoid a deer. "I think we got a pretty good deal," said Priestley's lawyer Peter Knecht. "He's not a Hollywood bad boy, and he's got no prior record." Priestley is currently performing in London's West End, and is unlikely to return and serve his sentence until the summer.

Celebrity gossip alert! Gwyneth Paltrow and Jude Law ruffled feathers by snubbing the Miramax Oscar party. "Everyone was waiting for her and Jude to arrive all night and they just didn't show", says one piqued partygoer. "Gwyneth especially was supposed to be the belle of the ball but she must have been having too much of a good time at the other parties. Everyone looked really disappointed and it certainly upset a lot of her Miramax friends."

Casting couch

 Sixth Sense child star Haley Joel Osment is to star in Spielberg's sci-fi spectacular A.I. Jude Law will co-star in the adaptation of the Brian Aldiss story, long fingered by Stanley Kubrick and picked up by Spielberg after Kubrick's death. Set in the future, A.I. is about artificially-intelligent robots that live in a time when polar icecaps have melted, putting New York's skyscrapers under water.

 Mel Gibson may join Julianne Moore in the biopic I Was Amelia Earhart. The Braveheart star will take on the role of Earhart's navigator, Fred Noonan.

 Tom Cruise, another Oscar non-winner, may star in A Beautiful Mind, a tale of a handsome, schizophrenic, Nobel Prize-winning mathematician, to be directed by Robert Redford. Jim Carrey has also expressed interest in the role.

 Doug Liman, director of Swingers and Go, is to shoot The Bourne Identity, based on the novel by Robert Ludlum, for Universal Pictures. Brad Pitt is in the lead role of what's described as a "cool, hip, spy movie, in the vein of La Femme Nikita with the visual style of Run Lola Run."

 An Ain't It Cool News correspondent reports that teen queen Britney Spears is to produce and star in a 90's update of Dirty Dancing. This only a few months after rumours (that also appeared on AICN) that Natalie Portman was to star in Dirty Dancing II were shot down.

 Gene Hackman will join Sigourney Weaver, Jennifer Love Hewitt and Jason Lee in Breakers, a comedy about mother-daughter con artists who use their feminine wiles to hook and then blackmail the men in their lives.

fields.headline: Leicester hit back over ticket 'smokescreen'
fields.standfirst: Martin Thorpe on the FA's verdict
fields.trailText: The controversy surrounding Leicester City over the 'irresponsible' distribution of Worthington Cup final tickets did not show any signs of disappearing this morning after the club hit back at claims that the club had hindered the FA's investigation into the matter.
fields.body:
The controversy surrounding Leicester City over the 'irresponsible' distribution of Worthington Cup final tickets did not show any signs of disappearing this morning after the club hit back at claims that the club had hindered the FA's investigation into the matter.

Seven current or former Leicester players and coaching staff were fined and banned from holding Worthington Cup tickets yesterday after an inquiry found that their complimentary tickets had ended up in the hands of Tottenham fans, leading to disturbances on the terraces which led to one young mother needing hospital treatment.

In a statement released this morning, the club accepted the seriousness of the matter but rejected the accusation, levelled by FA spokesman Steve Double, that they had tried to hide behind a 'smokescreen'.

"Leicester City wishes to make it clear that they have always viewed the charges arising from the 1999 Worthington Cup final with the utmost seriousness," the statement read.

"Upon the evidence presented to us, a member of our playing staff was fined the maximum permissible - two weeks' wages - in the very early stages of the investigation. Certainly, we have never wished to sweep this episode under the carpet."

webTitle: Don't panic over rights act, says Straw

fields.headline: Don't panic over rights act, says Straw
fields.trailText: Home secretary Jack Straw today played down fears over the government's new Human Rights Act, following warnings that it could lead to private schools and hospitals facing legal action.
fields.body:
Home secretary Jack Straw today played down fears over the government's new Human Rights Act, following warnings that it could lead to private schools and hospitals facing legal action.

Mr Straw said the new Human Rights Act did not create any new criminal offences, but merely incorporated into domestic legislation what Britain had already been subject to for 50 years through the European Convention on Human Rights.

"People shouldn't panic about it but they should get to know what's the convention," he said, "If people are operating in a fair and reasonable and legal way, they've got nothing really to fear, but they want to look at their procedures."

But the Institute for Public Policy Research (IPPR), a centre-left think tank, raised the prospect of private schools and hospitals being sued under the law being introduced in October. An IPPR report released today suggested that under the act, schools could face claims over their response to bullying or decisions to suspend pupils. IPPR also said that some private sector companies have failed to make preparations for the act on the false assumption they will not be covered by it.

The act, which brings the European Convention on Human Rights into UK law, means that organisations performing "public" duties will have to abide by the act's provisions or lay themselves open to legal challenge. Once the act is in force, people who believe their human rights have been violated by public authorities will be able to have their case judged in UK courts rather than face the cost and delay of taking their case to the European Court of Human Rights at Strasbourg.

The roots of recent political controversies such as section 28 (which bans the promotion of homosexuality in schools), new police surveillance powers and even the deportation of the Afghan asylum-seekers can all be traced back to rulings from the European Convention. Now the convention's fundamental principles will have even more impact.

Already an internal Whitehall audit is throwing up a series of issues on which the government believes it may be vulnerable. A paper presented by the Home Office Human Rights Task Force - set up to educate public bodies on the act - has illustrated the convention's potential impact by looking at the health department. It points out Article 2 of the convention protecting the right to life could see issues of health care rationing tested, including the standard of treatment for the chronically sick. NHS trusts could be sued if someone died because of the lack of a doctor.

The IPPR said among the organisations it had contacted which claimed to know nothing about the act were a public school for 700 children, a residential home for 100 elderly people and a nursing care organisation with 7,000 inpatients.

The Human Rights Act meets the government's manifesto commitment to incorporate rights and freedoms guaranteed by the European Convention into UK law, including the right to liberty and security, the right to a fair trial, the right to freedom of thought, conscience and religion and the right to freedom of expression. It also prohibits discrimination.

What makes up a "public authority" has not been defined in the act, but the term will include government departments, local authorities, police, prison, immigration officers, public prosecutors, courts and tribunals, non-departmental public bodies and any person exercising a public function.

The UK has been bound in international law by the terms of the European Convention since ratification in 1951, and in 1966 it agreed that individual citizens should have a right of access to the Strasbourg Court.

fields.standfirst:
Watch the video
Loop the catchphrase
Buy the t-shirt
fields.trailText: It's great to see Frank Dobson among the Guardian comment writers, but                                                                    this is only one of his countless media                                                                    engagements. On Friday Dobbo granted                                                                    an interview to a woman from the Asian                                                                    channel Zee TV.
fields.body:
It's great to see Frank Dobson among the Guardian comment writers, but this is only one of his countless media engagements. On Friday Dobbo granted an interview to a woman from the Asian channel Zee TV.

Everything went fine, until just after ending the interview, the reporter seemed to remember something. Oh, she said, before we go would you mind looking into the camera and saying "Oooh, you amaze me!"

Dobbo affected bafflement at this. You know, said the reporter, your catchphrase. Still feigning confusion, Dobbo nonetheless pointed his beard at the camera and delivered it with gusto, just as Bruce Forsyth would have done in the same boat. What a pro he is.

Amid mounting fears that dear old Dobbo may be on the verge of relapsing into moroseness, we have sent two Oooh You Amaze Me! T-shirts to his campaign HQ, with our compliments.

Fingers crossed these will keep him and Mrs Dobbo smiling until May.

 The shirts are also available to readers in two sizes, Ken (L) and Frank (XL), for £7.50.

Make cheques payable to Guardian Media Group, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER.
