Vague laws on "sabotage" and "terrorism" are used to prosecute perceived government opponents and political parties, elections, independent legislature, and trade unions are all banned, said Amnesty at the start of a six-month campaign to highlight abuses in the kingdom. The report says migrant workers, particularly those from poorer countries in the Middle East, African and Asia, are vulnerable to abuse from their employers as well as from the authorities. If arrested, foreign nationals may be tricked or coerced into sign ing a confession in Arabic, which they may not understand. Migrant workers are frequently tortured and ill-treated, Amnesty says, and are more likely than Saudis to be executed or punished by flogging or amputation. Many expatriate workers exchange horror stories about acquaintances who ended up in jail or were deported for offences ranging from traffic violations to arguments with employers. The report describes how women who go about unaccompanied or are in the company of a man who is neither their husband nor a close relative risk being arrested on suspicion of prostitution. They are terrorised by the Mutaween or religious police who patrol public places on the lookout for "moral offenders". The Mutaween shout at women to cover their hair and sometimes their faces. "The Saudi Arabian government spares no effort to keep its appalling human rights record a secret, and other governments have shown themselves more than willing to help maintain the secrecy," says the report, entitled Saudi Arabia: A Secret State of Suffering. With oil prices at their highest in years, the US and other western nations, busy lobbying oil producers to increase output to put a cap on further price rises, are unlikely to rock the boat by condemning Saudi Arabia's human rights record. Home to thousands of US and British troops since the Gulf war, the kingdom has earned itself the mantle of trusted ally of the west, often to the detriment of those seeking to flee its oppression. Hani al-Sayegh, a 30-year-old Saudi who was seeking asylum in the US, was forcibly returned to Saudi Arabia in October 1999. He was detained on arrival as a suspect in connection with the bombing of a US military complex at al-Khobar in 1996 - an offence punishable by death. He continues to be held without access to lawyers and is at risk of being tortured, Amnesty says. Saudi Arabia has one of the highest rates of executions in the world in both absolute numbers and per capita, it says. In February 2000 alone, 11 people were executed. The state executes murderers, drug smugglers, rapists and those convicted of other violent crimes. Amnesty recorded 90 judicial amputations between 1981 and December 1999, but says the true number is probably higher. Amputation is prescribed for causing injury and for theft, punished by amputation of the right hand, and for highway robbery, punished by amputation of the right hand and left foot. Saudi officials rarely respond to the charges of human rights groups. If they do, they deny abuses and say the punishments meted out are based on Islamic law, and that strict judicial criteria and safeguards are applied. But Amnesty says the Saudi Arabian justice system "from the outset treats suspects as guilty and the lack of independent mechanisms for reporting torture and investigations into allegations have all fostered a climate of fear, secrecy and impunity". Case studies: Victims condemned without defence Nieves's story A Filipino married mother of two, Nieves worked as a secretary at King Fahd National Guard Hospital in the Saudi capital, Riyadh. She was arrested by Mutaween religious police on 9 November, 1992, while celebrating a friend's birthday at a restaurant in Riyadh. Her group included a married couple and a single man and woman. The Mutaween suspected the group of prostitution after they found money in in the bag of one of Nieves's friends and accused her of accepting the money for introducing Nieves to the single man. They tricked the group into signing "confessions", which were used against them at a court trial. Nieves was sentenced to 25 days in prison and 60 lashes. "I could not describe the pain," she said. Nieves was deported to the Philippines immediately after serving her sentence. Abdul's story Abdul-Karim al-Naqshabandi, a Syrian, was arrested, tortured into signing a confession and then convicted of "witchcraft" after a secret, summary trial. He had no access to a lawyer and had no opportunity to defend himself, even though he was charged with an offence punishable by death. In a letter to the court, he protested his innocence: "They did not give me a chance to defend myself. The investigation was carried out by just one person, but they all ratified what he had to say even though they had not heard what I said to him. "He threatened me with a beating and they tied me up like an animal. I had to sign to protect myself. I signed in the hope that I would find someone in the police who would want to listen to the truth, but I was surprised to be treated even more severely. The officer put his shoe in my mouth, beat me up, put me in a cell, and did not allow visits. He threatened me with worse treatment if I refused to agree to the confession in court. I ratified my confession in the hope that someone would listen to me in court." Naqshabandi argued that he had been framed by his employer after refusing to help with false testimony in a business deal. He gave information that threw considerable doubt on the case against him, but it is not known how the court dealt with his defence. He was executed on 13 December, 1996.

fields.headline: Mayor abandons Britart feud
fields.trailText: New York's mayor, Rudolph Giuliani, yesterday dropped his bitter feud with a museum over the staging of a controversial British exhibition of modern art selected by the collector Charles Saatchi.
fields.body:
New York's mayor, Rudolph Giuliani, yesterday dropped his bitter feud with a museum over the staging of a controversial British exhibition of modern art selected by the collector Charles Saatchi.

The mayor abandoned his attempt to evict the Brooklyn Museum of Art from a city-owned site and to remove its board of directors over what he called the "sick" Sensation exhibition.

He had tried to cut public funding for the museum after taking particular exception to the work of Chris Ofili, the Turner prize-winning artist whose painting the Virgin Mary was created using elephant dung.

Under the agreement revealed this week, the city has agreed to pay the museum an additional $5.8m (£3.7m) over the next two years for repairs and has pledged not to treat it unfairly in future funding rounds. The city has already repaid $3.5m, which it had withheld since the mayor took offence at the exhibition last October.

Officials at the museum yesterday welcomed the settlement with the city, which provides about a third of its annual operating budget. Robert Rubin, chairman of the board of trustees, said: "The events of the past six months have only made our institution stronger."

The exhibition, which closed earlier this year, attracted record attendances and star-studded endorsements following Mr Giuliani's attack. In return, the museum dropped its lawsuit accusing the mayor of violating the First Amendment, which protects the right to free speech. Mr Giuliani was due to give evidence in the case within the next 10 days.

Such an appearance would have come at a difficult time for the Republican mayor, as he has been losing ground to Hillary Clinton, his Democratic rival for a US senate seat, in recent days.

Weekend opinion polls showed that Mr Giuliani had lost support because of his handling of the police shooting of an unarmed black man, Patrick Dorismond.

Following the killing almost two weeks ago, Mr Giuliani took the unprecedented step of unsealing police and court records about Dorismond in an attempt to show a "pattern of behaviour" that may have led to his own death.

In a further aggravation to local sensitivities already sharpened by last month's acquittal of the policemen who shot another unarmed black man, Amadou Diallo, the mayor commended the police officer involved while failing to offer condolences to the Dorismond's family.

At the same time as releasing evidence about Dorismond's previous arrests, the city also withheld the disciplinary record of the police officer who shot him. This subsequently showed that he had once had pulled out a weapon in a bar and had shot a neighbour's dog.

webTitle: Reeve plea for end to biotech secrecy

fields.headline: Reeve plea for end to biotech secrecy
fields.standfirst:
Bio 2000 International Conference
The DNA Patent Database
fields.trailText: The disabled former star of the movie Superman, Christopher Reeve, yesterday appealed to a gathering of the world's top biotechnology entrepreneurs not to let commercial competition get in the way of finding cures for diseases that at present are incurable.
fields.body:
The disabled former star of the movie Superman, Christopher Reeve, yesterday appealed to a gathering of the world's top biotechnology entrepreneurs not to let commercial competition get in the way of finding cures for diseases that at present are incurable.

His warnings against secrecy and competitiveness clashed with the high-pressure atmosphere of the biotech industry, where every researcher has one eye on the company's share price and where disputed patent claims threaten to stifle cooperation and resource sharing.

Reeve, paralysed from the neck down after a riding accident five years ago, won a standing ovation from delegates at the Bio2000 conference in Boston with his feel-good message that science and business would find a way to make him and others walk.

He accepted that profit should be one reason to search out medical breakthroughs, but he said the overall mission should be to heal. He also implored scientists and businesses to make more of an effort to tell sufferers of diseases such as Parkinson's or Alzheimer's what progress they have made.

"Many, many people still can't get past the psychological barrier that their life has been ruined," he said. "It's important to give them hope. Not to give them false hope, but to go back to what really is the American mantra - and it is a realistic mantra - that nothing is impossible," he said.

"Let everybody make a profit. Conduct your business, but also heal. That should be our mission," he added.

Recent discoveries in the fields of genetics and molecular biology have increased the prospect of cures for ancient illnesses and injuries. But the line between academic and commercial research has become increasingly blurred; it is common for hospital and university scientists to fund or have shares in biotech firms.

There have been recent encouraging developments in repairing damaged spinal cords; Canadian scientists have grown fresh spinal cord tissue in mice and Swiss researchers have found a gene that stops nerve cells from growing back in the spinal cord and brain.

But for the time being, as Patrick Kluger of Britain's National Spinal Injuries Centre at Stoke Mandeville hospital said, there is no surgical or biotechnical therapy available to repair a damaged spinal cord.

Reeve has been criticised in the US for raising paraplegic peoples' hopes that they will walk again, rather than encouraging them to learn to live with their disability. But Dr Kluger said his work was vital.

"It's not so much about raising hopes as about raising funds," he said. "When President [John F] Kennedy said he would put a man on the moon, he said it out loud so he could be sure it would be funded."

fields.headline: The best dental scene: Magnolia
fields.trailText: On an old TV set, we see a clip from the 60s quiz show What Do Kids Know? Host Jimmy Gator (Phillip Baker Hall) turns to a boy of about 10: his name is Donnie Smith
fields.body:
On an old TV set, we see a clip from the 60s quiz show What Do Kids Know? Host Jimmy Gator (Phillip Baker Hall) turns to a boy of about 10: his name is Donnie Smith

"Donnie, you have an answer?"

"Prometheus."

"It is!"

Cut to Donnie accepting a cheque for $100,000 from Gator. Donnie smiles, shaking Jimmy's hand.

A title card: QUIZ KID DONNIE SMITH- 1968.

Cut to a San Fernando dentist's office. Now 40, Donnie (William H Macy) leans back in the chair. He has a small stud earing, a bad haircut, and a cheap grey suit.

Another title card: QUIZ KID DONNIE SMITH -TODAY

"This is really exciting," he exclaims. "I bet you don't get many people my age getting braces."

A dental nurse opens his mouth, holding the imprint for Donnie's brace. She levers it in.

"You were really cute when you were on that show."

A second nurse stands behind the chair, giggling.

"You can't answer any questions right now though, huh?"

Cut to a close-up of Donnie's teeth.

See also: Little Shop of Horrors, Marathon Man, Track 29

Don't see also: The Dentist

Pointless trivia: Right at the start of his acting career, William H Macy provided a commercial voiceover for Secret aftershave ("Strong enough for a man - but made for a woman.")

fields.headline: Ministers 'forgot' Budget cash for nurseries
fields.trailText: Thousands of nurseries and play groups are threatened with closure because they are being denied the £3,000 bonus earmarked in last week's Budget for even the smallest primary schools, the Liberal Democrats claimed last night.
fields.body:
Thousands of nurseries and play groups are threatened with closure because they are being denied the £3,000 bonus earmarked in last week's Budget for even the smallest primary schools, the Liberal Democrats claimed last night.

They said nearly 350,000 children in pre-school education will miss out on the £1bn extra spending because ministers "forgot" to improve provision for most three-year-olds during late haggling with the Treasury. The Lib Dem warning came as the government faced renewed accusations that it is failing to live up to its pre-election commitments on education spending.

Phil Willis, the Lib Dem education spokesman, said that the education department "forgot" to improve provision for three-year-olds - except for a minority in local authority nurseries.

A senior Department for Education source said the allegation was "utter rubbish". Although playgroups would not enjoy the bonuses available to schools, spending on educating three-year-olds is set to rise from £38m to £110m over the coming year and the childcare budget would increase from £52m to £66m, he said.

The Lib Dems also yesterday released figures compiled by the House of Commons library which show that Labour will spend an average of 4.67% of GDP on education throughout the lifetime of this parliament, compared with 4.98% in the last parliament.

fields.headline: Tackling root causes
fields.standfirst: Prevention teams have been training like footballers for the next season. Nicholas Warner explains the government's new proposals on reducing crime
fields.trailText: Prevention teams have been training like footballers for the next season. Norman Warner explains the government's new proposals on reducing crime
fields.body:
Back in 1996, the Audit Commission produced a well argued report, Misspent Youth, that exposed the inadequacies of the youth justice system. Now a line is being drawn under that wasteful past with far-reaching changes to youth justice.

Across England and Wales, there are 155 youth offending teams (Yots) composed of about 2,500 police and probation officers, social workers and health and education staff. Each team has a manager - usually from a probation or social services background - and a management committee chaired by a chief executive. The new teams will work together from the same location on a genuine partnership basis. Their aim is to prevent offending by young people.

Since October 1998, the youth justice board has been acting like a football coach helping the teams to establish themselves and prepare for their first season. Across the country, these teams have been training together, dev eloping shared information systems, pooling budgets and starting new programmes for preventing offending.

The board has now funded some 450 local programmes covering parenting, reparation, restorative justice, mentoring, bail supervision, education and training, substance misuse and some innovative preventive initiatives.

Over three years, some £55m of board money and equivalent local money will go into the programmes, which will be funded by local agencies at the end of the period.

The most encouraging feature of these reforms has been the huge local commitment to the changes. This is demonstrated by the youth justice plans that Yots were asked to prepare and that the board has now analysed. The board has commended about a quarter of the plans; identified two-thirds as satisfactory; and is working with the remainder to improve them.

The plans reveal a local willingness to tackle youth offending with new strategies and new money. Across England and Wales Yots are planning to spend £140m in the year from April: 60% of this money will come from social services; 13% from the police; 12% from probation; 8% from education and 7% from health. On top of this about £30m of board money is going into their programmes, and nearly another £5m or so has been provided for one-off start-up money.

Local agencies have put their money where their month is by providing a step like increase in the money devoted to tackling youth crime. Spending on tackling youth crime next year could be as much as a half more than before the reforms.

However, new money is only part of the story. The plans show the Yots integrating their youth justice activities with other local initiatives like the local crime partnerships, the anti-drugs strategy, education plans and quality protects plans.

For the first time in most places people tackling youth crime are reaching across organisational boundaries to produce more systematic responses to the problem. There is a refreshing willingness to replace muddling through with analysis and targeted responses. The plans show how the Yots have geared themselves up to service the new final warnings and community orders - action plan, reparation and parenting orders that start in June.

In the majority of areas, parenting initiatives are assessed by Yot staff but provided by others. The reform's emphasis on restorative justice, reparation to victims and parental responsibility has taken root strongly across England and Wales. Some plans have profiled groups of offenders for particular attention: persistent young offenders, arsonists and those engaged in racially aggravated offending. Final warning programmes are being put in place in virtually all areas.

O ne of the past failings of youth justice has been the absence of systematic assessment of young offenders against known offending risk factors. Over the past year, the board has worked with Oxford University and a number of Yots to produce a standard assessment profile for use with young offenders. It will identify the degree of risk they pose to themselves and others; help plan intervention programmes; and produce a risk score on entry to the system as a benchmark to measure progress.

The local plans show Yots gearing up to changes affecting young people in custody from next month, when the new detention and training order will come into operation. This will be the order under which the vast majority of juveniles are detained in custody. It will require Yots to establish and supervise sentence plans for both the custodial and community parts of the sentence.

Youth crime will not stop next week. But the new youth offending teams are ready to tackle it in a more coherent way. The new plans show strong local commitment to making communities safer places and preventing wasted young lives through criminal progression.

 Lord Warner is chair of the Youth Justice Board.

fields.headline: How editor lost his thunder
fields.standfirst: Times chief 's target journalism missed its mark
fields.trailText: When Peter Stothard stepped up to the podium at the What The Papers Say awards a month ago, he must have thought the newspaper of the year accolade secured his shaky position.
fields.body:
When Peter Stothard stepped up to the podium at the What The Papers Say awards a month ago, he must have thought the newspaper of the year accolade secured his shaky position.

But just a few weeks later, after he had taken a curiously hands-off role in the title's relaunch, it was announced that he would be taking a "few months" away from the newsroom to work on "special projects" for the paper. For an authority on Greek tragedy, it must have been a humbling moment.

Until last year, his 10-year stewardship of the Thunderer had been regarded as solid. He was a safe pair of hands, who restored the paper's intellectual core on the highbrow comment pages while allowing the marketing people to turn the front-end into a populist middle market broadsheet. Backed by an aggressive price-cutting strategy, the combination saw off the threat from a young and vibrant Independent.

Latterly, however, it may be that Mr Stothard was stung by criticisms that he was too ephemeral. The paper's mix of stories was regarded as confused, the news pages lacking in focus.

Last year, he embarked on a risky but potentially lucrative strategy of "target journalism". This involves picking a recognisable victim, taking aim, and launching an all-out assault until the subject is bombed out. It can work to spectacular effect. The Sun memorably saw off Neil Kinnock with a series of attacks on his leadership of Labour in the 1990s.

The tabloid's stablemate, however, had no such luck. It picked two high profile targets, and failed to knock either off his perch. Quite the contrary, the strategy backfired spectacularly.

First on the Times's hit list was Greg Dyke. When the then chairman of Pearson television was mooted as a successor to John Birt as director general of the BBC, it branded him unacceptable because of his links with Labour. Dyke was appointed anyway to popular acclaim, and the Times was left looking silly.

Worse, it chose to wage war on Michael Ashcroft, the Tory party treasurer, whom it deemed unfit for the office because of his business dealings in Belize. Too bad that the stories went too far, claiming to expose links to money laundering and drug trafficking which the paper could not prove. Mr Ashcroft sued. Mr Stothard put up a fight, but was forced into a humiliating climbdown after his boss, Rupert Murdoch, met the Sunday Business editor, Jeff Randall, who proposed to broker a deal.

The libel action was dropped. Add to that the mixed reaction to the relaunch, and Mr Stothard's future was under serious threat.

Now the Times editor and the Tory treasurer may never enjoy the kiss-and-make-up lunch the pair agreed when the libel action was settled in December. An aide to Mr Ashcroft said last night: "I suspect if Mr Stothard had not found the need to take an extended sabbatical, I'm sure they would have done."

Mr Stothard, currently on leave, is a Times man through and through, having joined from the Sunday Times in 1980. He was a leader writer and features editor for six years and deputy editor until 1992. fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Man convicted of killing four
fields.body:
Man convicted of killing four

A man was convicted yesterday at Newcastle crown court of killing a pregnant woman, her two young children and their babysitter in an arson attack on their home.

Alan Ray, 26, from Scotswood, Newcastle upon Tyne, was jailed for life for murdering Lisa Dodgson, 25, her daughters Amy, two, and nine-month-old Rose, and babysitter Emma Cater, 16, in the fire at Scotswood in May 1998.

Judge defers legacy decision

A high court judge yesterday reserved judgment in the case of a retired nurse who left most of her money to Great Ormond Street children's hospital, but then signed over her main asset - her house - to her cleaner and companion.

The hospital is challenging an agreement under which Lily Morris, who died aged 74 in 1997, transferred her Derbyshire country home to Pauline Rushin.

Hockney goes for £3,600

A David Hockney drawing was auctioned for £3,600 in Lincolnshire yesterday, fetching nine times more than expected. He drew the pen and ink self-portrait for Kathleen Terry, 59, of Stowmarket, Suffolk, who kept the drawing for more than 40 years.

Farmers in mass rally

More than 1,500 farmers held a rally on the Chatsworth Park estate, in Derbyshire, yesterday in protest at falling prices in the industry, increased regulations and unfair competition from overseas.

Suspect fights extradition

An Amsterdam court yesterday held a private hearing into whether William Beggs, 36, from Kilmarnock, should be extradited to Scotland to face charges of the abduction and murder of teenager Barry Wallace. It will give its decision in two weeks' time. Mr Wallace's severed arms and legs were found at Loch Lomond last December and a week later his head was found on a beach in Ayrshire.

Fall dog lived on rubbish

A border collie who fell 60ft down cliffs on to an isolated beach survived for more than a month by eating rubbish washed up on the shore and drinking out of rock pools. A surfer eventually took her to a nearby RSPCA sanctuary in St Columb, Cornwall.

fields.headline: Charles turns down British beef
fields.trailText: A royal lunch which aimed to show the world that British beef should be back on the menu backfired yesterday when the guest of honour, the Prince of Wales, refused to eat any of the meat.
fields.body:
A royal lunch which aimed to show the world that British beef should be back on the menu backfired yesterday when the guest of honour, the Prince of Wales, refused to eat any of the meat.

In front of 22 of Europe's top chefs, Charles turned his nose up at assorted beef delicacies including beef Wellington, beef ragout, mini tartlets and miniature beef kebabs because he has given up lunch for Lent.

The prince's spokeswoman said: "That is what he chose to give up. He does not enjoy eating in the middle of the day very much, but still has breakfast and dinner."

Despite Charles's abstinence, a number of the chefs invited to the lunch at Grove Farm in Moreton-in-Marsh, Gloucestershire, promised to start using British beef again.

Prince Charles told the assembled chefs: "I happen to believe that you are probably the group who most influence your country's eating and buying habits."

Belgian restaurateur Luigi Ciciriello agreed, "We are the last stop on the chain of beef.

"To have an opinion is very important, particularly if we discover good quality beef. That is why we're here."

Italian chef Luigi Sforzellini said: "I don't think there's anything wrong with Prince Charles not eating lunch. He's just following his beliefs. If he comes to Italy he will find we have things we follow as well."

The party was taken on a tour of the 145 hectare farm, which has about 100 cattle.

The farm's owner, Douglas Scott, said: "It is very rare to show off stock to an audience as distinguished as this. We are just longing to get our beef back on to the marketplace where they belong."

Don Curry, chairman of the meat and livestock commission, which organised the tour, said sales of British beef were back to the same levels as before the BSE crisis.

"Consumer confidence in British beef crashed to an all time low," he said. "It is very exciting to see we are now back to 1995 levels."

webTitle: School whistleblower wins £10,000 but loses her job

fields.headline: School whistleblower wins £10,000 but loses her job
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: One of the first people to use the new whistleblowers' charter has won £10,000 compensation but lost her job, after exposing financial irregularities at an opted-out school.
fields.body:
One of the first people to use the new whistleblowers' charter has won £10,000 compensation but lost her job, after exposing financial irregularities at an opted-out school.

Extra safeguards for staff who disclose malpractice at work failed to protect Elizabeth Mitchell, 52, whose complaint led to a police inquiry and government intervention to reclaim money misspent by governors at Oakbank school in Keighley, West Yorkshire.

Mrs Mitchell's job as finance manager at the grant maintained school, which has since returned to Bradford local education authority, was made "impossible" after her action, according to her union and Keighley's Labour MP Anne Cryer.

"The governors made their financial decisions in what they genuinely felt were the best interests of the school but they were wrong and Mrs Mitchell was absolutely right," said Mrs Cryer. "But her life was made very difficult until she had no real option but to resign."

Mrs Mitchell contacted the funding agency for schools, which oversaw direct grant school budgets until the Labour government ended the "opting-out" system in 1998, after £68,000 saved on a building tender at Oakbank was used without authorisation.

The school also wrongly budgeted money from its publicly-funded Oakbank recreation centre as "business sponsorship" to trigger almost £1m in government grants as a specialist sports college.

The police inquiry found no evidence of criminal behaviour but sports status was withdrawn by the schools minister, Estelle Morris, and the misappropriated building money, which had paid for a fire escape, was returned by the school. Oakbank's headteacher John Roberts said yesterday: "We made a mistake but there was never anything underhand about it. The decisions were made openly by the governors and were minuted and clear." Sports status was later restored.

Mrs Mitchell said yesterday that she had suffered "appalling bullying and harassment" after taking her concerns to the FAS when she failed to make headway through the school's internal system.

Mr Roberts said that the claims of bullying and harassment were false and that Mrs Mitchell was damaging a school she purported to value. He said: "The governors were legally advised to settle out of court because of the uncertainty of industrial tribunals and the levels of compensation allowed under the Public Interest Disclosure Act."

fields.headline: Playgroup perils
fields.standfirst: Most women go out to work today. So closing down these outmoded volunteer nurseries is a good idea
fields.trailText: The Pre-School Learning Alliance (formerly the Pre-school Playgroups Association) is expected to announce today the closure of some 20% of its play groups. Margaret Lochrie, the chief executive, is to give evidence to the education select committee this morning, and will almost certainly ask for help to prop up her ailing empire.
fields.body:
The Pre-School Learning Alliance (formerly the Pre-school Playgroups Association) is expected to announce today the closure of some 20% of its play groups. Margaret Lochrie, the chief executive, is to give evidence to the education select committee this morning, and will almost certainly ask for help to prop up her ailing empire.

The PLA maintains that playgroups are closing because parents are being forced to take up school places early - or lose them. They want education authorities to change admissions policies so that children spend longer in playgroups before entering school. However, forthcoming research by the National Centre for Social Research shows that, given the option, parents prefer to take up school reception places rather than keep their children in often under-resourced PLA groups with untrained staff.

For 40 years, governments have conducted a love affair with the PLA because it promised the impossible: pre-school provision on the cheap, everywhere from the inner city to the smallest village. The organisation, with its army of unpaid, parent volunteers, set itself up as the arbiter of all that is good for our youngest children, insisting that parental involvement and unstructured learning was not just a stop-gap but positively the best option for three and four-year-old children.

Professor Kathy Sylva, of Oxford University's department of educational studies heads a government-funded research project (the EPPE project) comparing playgroups to other forms of pre-school provision. She says: "On a shoestring they have created a satisfactory service. With more resources the maintained sector provides higher quality." It is a polite way of saying what should be obvious: a shoestring service provides shoestring care.

Sylva's research found that, on every single indicator of quality, voluntary play-groups lag behind every other kind of service provided by either the private or statutory sectors. On a number of educational indicators the results for playgroups are below the "minimal" level considered "adequate" for the age group. Even on the indicator for "social interaction", which is where the informal playgroups are supposed to do so well, they bump along the bottom of the league, above the minimum level, but well behind other providers.

When the research came out in the autumn it was accompanied by a document to ministers suggesting that "high profile use of the findings would be unhelpful at this stage". Given the importance attached to giving parents information on which to make choices, such caution may seem surprising. But where it may be easy to scapegoat the odd failing secondary school, when the failing organisation is in the voluntary sector and provides more than a third of total provision, at way below the cost of other services, different rules apply.

Nevertheless there are signs that ministerial patience is wearing thin. Last year when the PLA announced closures, via a carefully orchestrated media campaign aimed at eliciting maximum public support, the government stumped up a big grant to help struggling groups. It seems unlikely that big handouts will be on offer this year.

The fact that more parents are now able to move their children into the maintained sector ought to be a matter for celebration, not for hand wringing. It is the first sign that free, school-based provision for three to five-year-olds, is finally starting to expand - a change long campaigned for by almost every organisation (other than the PLA) concerned with the care of under-fives.

But the PLA has always stood aloof from the organisations which campaigned for statutory nursery provision. Indeed in the mid 80s it was described by American child care expert, Professor Sheila Kammerman, as "a uniquely British disadvantage" because, by substituting cheap, part-time, voluntary play groups, for the statutory childcare provision springing up in every other European country, the organisation effectively held back the development of childcare in this country by at least 20 years. We are still way behind the rest of Europe. Until now, we showed no sign of catching up.

Of course all is not perfect in the schools. There is still disquiet about the government's early learning goals. Many people are unhappy about what is thought to be a premature concentration on literacy. The PLA could have joined forces with other or ganisations and campaigned for better provision inside schools and an expansion of community provision for under-threes. It could have taken as its model the Family Planning Association, which also provided a voluntary service but campaigned for free services on the NHS, and reshaped itself when the day came to hand over its clinics to the public sector.

It didn't and perhaps the time has come for this out-moded organisation to be guided gently towards its end. A country in which the majority of mothers now expect to work for a living can no longer look to those same mothers to provide a voluntary service, on a shoestring, for upwards of one third of its children. The PPA was built by women who believed that their place was in the home. Perhaps it has missed the moment to move on.

webTitle: Blair admits case for regional governments

fields.headline: Blair admits case for regional governments
fields.standfirst: What is Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday rejected English nationalism as the lynchpin of the "new patriotism" but finally admitted that elected regional governments for England may have to become part of Labour's final constitutional settlement.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday rejected English nationalism as the lynchpin of the "new patriotism" but finally admitted that elected regional governments for England may have to become part of Labour's final constitutional settlement.

The prime minister used his much-touted speech on British identity in the post-devolution era to repudiate both the "sentimental nostalgia" of Tories who had resisted all change - as well as nationalist demands for the break-up of Britain.

But his address to regional newspaper editors saw him depart from his text to acknowledge the rising discontent about Labour's slow progress towards English regional devolution among MPs and ministers - especially in his own backyard, the north east.

Downing Street later stressed that the remarks reflected no "change, advance or retreat". Mr Blair's known preference is for elected mayors in major cities, once the dust has settled on London's pioneering exercise. Yesterday, however, he conceded: "The logical conclusion of the growing pressure for regional change in England is to create more accountable regional government."

The gesture will be noted with relief on the backbenches. The north east group of Labour MPs is due to meet Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, today to protest at what they see is typical indifference by the Ministry of Defence, most of whose staff and bases are located in southern England.

The MPs are furious over yesterday's Guardian report that the MoD looks set to buy six roll-on roll-off ferries worth £300m from EU shipyards at a time when yards in England, Scotland and the stricken Harland & Wolff yard in Northern Ireland are trying to win a £600m ro-ro contract from the Phillipines.

Earlier this week the former minsiter, Peter Kilfoyle, used his Commons resignation speech to condemn the "colonial raj" mentality of Whitehall officials governing the regions.

Yesterday the prime minister cited the presence of so many Scots - 745,000 or 15% of them including himself - who live in England, as well as similar flows the other way, to underline the strength of the British national identity.

"Few would disagree with the qualities that go towards that British identity: qualities of creativity built on tolerance, openness and adaptability, work and self-improvement, strong communities and families and fair play, rights and responsibilities and an outward looking approach to the world that all flow from our unique island geography and history," he told the editors.

But none of these qualities was under threat as institutions changed - as they always had - to adapt to new times. Quite the reverse, Mr Blair suggested.

"If these values are what makes us British ... then devolution is a necessary part of keeping Britain together. More regional decentralisation in England makes sense, city mayors with real power have their place, hereditary peers in the House of Lords don't, and a constructive engaged attitude to Europe reflects the best of British values of openness and leadership in the world," he said.

The prime minister argued that Labour's "progressive programme of constitutional reform is now moving us from a centralised Britain, where power flowed top-down, to a devolved and plural state."

William Hague was unpersuaded. "If Hollywood awarded an Oscar for the least convincing performance by a politician, Tony Blair would win it for this speech," the Tory leader said.

fields.headline: Mugabe says critics are 'Blair's gays'
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: President Robert Mugabe has accused the British government of leading an international hate campaign against Zimbabwe because he has criticised the "gay philosophy" of the prime minister, Tony Blair.
fields.body:
President Robert Mugabe has accused the British government of leading an international hate campaign against Zimbabwe because he has criticised the "gay philosophy" of the prime minister, Tony Blair.

His provocative remarks, which were made in the eastern city of Mutare on Monday, can only increase friction with the Labour government, with which Zimbabwe has had increasingly strained relations.

When asked about last week's British parliamentary debate over whether Zimbabwe should be suspended from the Commonwealth, Mr Mugabe replied:"These are the gays of Blair's government talking. They are angry with us because we are critical of his gay philosophy and gay way of life and they would reach for anything against Zimbabwe."

He added: "They have become the spokesmen, you see, of the international community against Zimbabwe but fortunately many countries do not take heed of what they are saying. So I am sure they will not succeed."

In fact the call for Zimbabwe's suspension came from the Conservative front bench spokesperson for foreign affairs, Cheryl Gillan, who cited several examples of Zimbabwe's bad governance, including involvement in the Congo war and the raid on Britain's diplomatic bag to Zimbabwe last month.

Mr Mugabe reiterated that he would not take action against squatters who have invaded 750 white-owned farms. The president claims that he sent thousands of poor black people to occupy the farms to try to right the historical injustice of colonial Rhodesia where land was seized from Africans. He says Britain must pay for that land so that it can be redistributed.

And, in a further toughening of his stance, he yesterday issued a blunt warning to the farm owners. "If the farmers start to be angry and start to be violent then, of course, they will get that medicine delivered to them. And it can be very, very, very severe," he said.

fields.headline: General advocated shooting riot leaders
fields.standfirst:
Bloody Sunday inquiry told of memo to army commander in Northern Ireland detailing tactics to deal with 'Derry's young hooligans'

The Bloody Sunday inquiry: special report
fields.trailText: The deputy commander of troops in Northern Ireland suggested adopting, three weeks before Bloody Sunday, a new policy of shooting the ringleaders of rioting youths in Londonderry amid deepening army frustration over the IRA's control of nationalist no-go areas.
fields.body:
The deputy commander of troops in Northern Ireland suggested adopting, three weeks before Bloody Sunday, a new policy of shooting the ringleaders of rioting youths in Londonderry amid deepening army frustration over the IRA's control of nationalist no-go areas.

General Robert Ford, commander land forces, in a private and confidential memo to Sir Harry Tuzo, general officer commanding in Northern Ireland, also outlined a plan to deal with the illegal anti-internment march, ordering that it be halted at the point of maximum advantage to the army. He believed there would be "some form of battle" and put the Parachute Regiment on standby for its first action in Londonderry.

Lord Saville of Newdigate's inquiry into Bloody Sunday, when paratroopers shot dead 13 unarmed Catholics on January 30, 1972, also heard yesterday the RUC had advised that the march, expected to attract up to 12,000 people, be allowed to continue to its intended destination, the Guildhall. This is the venue for the fresh investigation.

General Ford was told six days before the demonstration that Chief Superintendent Frank Lagan, in charge of policing in Londonderry, believed "massive confrontation with the security forces will shatter such peace as is left in the city, create intense violence and remove the last vestiges of moderate goodwill". Brigadier Pat MacLellan, the army officer in charge in Londonderry, endorsed the RUC's assessment.

General Ford in his memo of January 7 to Sir Harry said "Derry's young hooligans" were gradually increasing their "radius of anarchy" around the Bogside and Creggan areas, where the army had been forced to abandon routine patrols. They rioted daily under the cover of snipers.

He had just met members of the city's business community. They had urged him to consider introducing a curfew and a shoot-on-sight policy.

General Ford wrote: "Against the DYH - described in the People's Democracy as 'brave fighters in the republican cause' - the army in Londonderry is for the moment virtually incapable. This incapacity undermines our ability to deal with the bombers and gunmen and threatens what is left of law and order on the west bank of the River Foyle."

CS gas and plastic rounds were proving ineffective. Some rioters had respirators, while others wore handkerchiefs soaked in vinegar around their faces to reduce the effect of the gas. They also rioted in open spaces beyond the accurate range of plastic batons.

General Ford, whose memo was read on the second day of oral hearings at the Bloody Sunday inquiry wrote: "Attempts to close with the DYH bring the troops into the killing zone of the snipers. As I understand it, the commander of a body of troops called out to restore law and order has a duty to use minimum force but he also has a duty to restore law and order. We have fulfilled the first duty but are failing in the second.

"I am coming to the conclusion that the minimum force necessary to achieve a restoration of law and order is to shoot selected ringleaders amongst the DYH, after clear warnings have been issued. I believe we would be justified in using 7.62mm but in view of the devastating effects of this weapon and the dangers of rounds killing more than one person, I believe we must consider issuing rifles adapted to fire .22 inch ammunition to sufficient members of the unit dealing with this problem to enable ringleaders to be engaged with this less lethal ammunition."

Thirty of the modified rifles were being sent to Londonderry that weekend for training purposes. He said they would not be used without authorisation.

"If this course is implemented, as I believe it may have to be, we would have to accept the possibility that .22 rounds may be lethal. In other words, we would be reverting to the methods of internal security found successful on many occasions overseas, but would merely be trying to minimise the lethal effects by using the .22 round. I am convinced that our duty to restore law and order requires us to consider this step."

General Ford, in his recent statement to Lord Saville's inquiry, denied his proposals amounted to a shoot-to-kill policy. He said: "The suggestion to shoot a few leaders was not an instruction to kill. Shoot and kill are obviously different words."

But Lord Carver, who as General Sir Michael Carver, was then chief of the general staff, said in his statement to the inquiry it was the army's policy if it had to open fire in an anti-riot situation that it would "shoot to kill, not to wound".

He said he had never seen General Ford's memo.

Neither had Sir Graham Shillington, RUC chief constable. He told Lord Saville's inquiry: "I do not remember hearing or reading anything along these lines and I would have been horrified if this had been suggested at any meeting I attended."

General Michael Jackson, who led the British forces in Kosovo, was then a captain in the Parachute Regiment. He said in his statement to Lord Saville: "People should be care ful not to make a ridiculous jump from a memo like that to an allegation that there was a deliberate policy to shoot people."

fields.headline: On message
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: • Expansion Computer company IBM yesterday said it would expand its sales force as part of a $400m (£252m) push to sell networked storage systems and services for online businesses to manage data. IBM will offer new products, services, global and regional testing facilities, and will add 1,000 additional sales people to cater to the so-called storage area network market - in which large businesses need to store, access and manage huge amounts of information. • Time delay The judge in the Microsoft competition case has delayed for a week or more his decision on whether the company broke the nation's competition laws in order to permit more time for settlement talks, according to sources familiar with the case.

webTitle: Marbles talks MPs' visit cheers Greeks

fields.headline: Marbles talks MPs' visit cheers Greeks
fields.standfirst: Elgin marbles: special report
fields.trailText: The first face-to-face talks between British parliamentary officials and Greek politicians over the fate of filched antiquities - not least the Elgin marbles - were yesterday heralded by the Athens government as the best omen yet in its battle to retrieve the treasures.
fields.body:
The first face-to-face talks between British parliamentary officials and Greek politicians over the fate of filched antiquities - not least the Elgin marbles - were yesterday heralded by the Athens government as the best omen yet in its battle to retrieve the treasures.

As Commons culture committe chairman, Gerald Kaufaman, left, and other members of his committee picked their way through the marble slabs that dot the Acropolis, the Greek culture minister said the visit amounted to the start of an official "dialogue" over whether the priceless Parthenon statuary, "stolen" by the seventh Earl of Elgin in 1801, should at long last be returned to its rightful home. "For the first time we have had the chance to start a dialogue with a British institution," enthused the minister, Elisavet Papazoe, emerging from two-hour talks with the committee.

Greek enthusiam over the talks contrasted sharply with the committee's desire to downplay them. Mr Kaufman insisted that the committee was not conducting an inquiry into the marbles, but a wider-ranging inquiry into the illicit trade of cultural goods.

But Mr Kaufman did not deny that the committee had shown special interest in the progress being made on the construction of a new Acropolis museum where Athens hopes to house the artworks by the time it hosts the Olympic Games in 2004.

webTitle: Minister's pledge to aid poorest pensioners

fields.headline: Minister's pledge to aid poorest pensioners
fields.standfirst: More about welfare reform
fields.trailText: The social security secretary, Alistair Darling, yesterday rejected leftwing calls for across the board pension increases, saying it would do nothing to end the growing inequality gap amongst pensioners.
fields.body:
The social security secretary, Alistair Darling, yesterday rejected leftwing calls for across the board pension increases, saying it would do nothing to end the growing inequality gap amongst pensioners.

Mr Darling, under attack for extending means testing, and for failing to restore the link between earnings and pensions, will retaliate today by publishing new evidence showing pensioners' income overall has risen faster than earnings since 1979. "Many of them are quite affluent," he said.

The real pensioners' crisis lay amongst the poorer pensioners who have seen their incomes rise much more slowly, he said.

Mr Darling will publish research showing that 30% of pensioners in 1996-7 had incomes less than half of the national average. By contrast, the incomes of the most affluent pensioners had risen by 80% over the past 18 years.

Mr Darling blamed the growing inequality amongst pensioners on the fact that many of them had not been able to take out occupational pensions, or did not have access to funded pensions.

Defending his decision to target his help at the poorest, he said: "It must make sense to focus particular help on those who have lost out. If there was an across the board increase - for instance, by linking pensions to earnings - you would end up with people at the top end of the scale, with good investment income and good occupational pensions, hardly noticing the extra cash, but those at the bottom end losing any penny we gave them because of the way the benefits system works."

Many of today's poor - de scribed by Mr Darling as the Thirties generation - had missed out either due to unemployment or women not seeking work.

He said he was addressing their problems through the "minimum pension guarantee", an income threshold below which pensioners with savings of less than £6,000 next year should not fall. The guarantee is set at £78.45 a week this year.

Mr Darling will try to increase take-up by launching a £15m advertising campaign featuring the actress Thora Hird and a mailshot to 2m pensioners.

He is also trying to remove the stigma from claiming the pensions by setting up a free phone claims system, rather than requiring them to fill in lengthy forms. The DSS estimates that between 300,000 and 700,000 pensioners do not claim and are entitled to do so.

webTitle: Autonomy PR prematurely kills off the search engine

fields.headline: Autonomy PR prematurely kills off the search engine
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Autonomy, the fast-growing British intelligent software company, yesterday launched a new product which it claimed would sound the death knell for the traditional internet search engine.
fields.body:
Autonomy, the fast-growing British intelligent software company, yesterday launched a new product which it claimed would sound the death knell for the traditional internet search engine.

As part of a profile-raising exercise before its planned Nasdaq flotation, the Easdaq-listed company announced plans for Kenjin, a free software product expected to drive its core corporate business.

From Friday internet users will be able to download the software free from www.kenjin.com It promises to deliver background information, both from the web and their own PC, for users preparing documents on a given theme.

Chief executive Mike Lynch's assessment of the product was more circumspect than his public relations company's claim that "Kenjin will transform the way we use PCs and in particular the internet. It said: "Search engines like Yahoo! are consigned to the dustbin."

Mr Lynch said: "Kenjin does not push loads of irrelevant rubbish. We think its going to have a significant effect in driving our business forward."

Kenjin is based on technology that can understand and "contextualise" information. It is a scaled down version of a range of intelligent software that increased Autonomy's share price thirtyfold last year. The technology analyses text for meaning, rather than just looking for keywords, and then links it to other relevant documents. The information is then pushed to the user's screen .

Mr Lynch said several international partners are being lined up to help roll out the software. Because it is free and does not carry an installation charge, Autonomy will generate revenues through advertising.

However, Beeson Gregory analyst David Johnson said: "As a way of raising profile prior to the IPO on Nasdaq this is very clever. It's too early to say what revenues Kenjin will generate on its own but it will certainly put the package in front of more potential corporate partners."

Blue-chips like the BBC, Merrill Lynch and British Telecommunications use Autonomy products but the company is looking to broaden its customer base to a mass market.

Mr Johnson played down the threat to search engines like Yahoo!, Lycos and Ask Jeeves. "People visit sites like Yahoo! because they know their way round it and know what they are looking for," he said. "I don't think Kenjin will destroy their business model. It will be of more use to people who want information to help them to complete a particular task and need information brought to them."

Easdaq dealers were impressed though. Autonomy closed up $15 at $196, valuing the company at about $7.5bn.

webTitle: Managers angry at insult over NHS cash

fields.headline: Managers angry at insult over NHS cash
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: The shine came off the government's cash boost for the NHS yesterday when health managers reacted furiously to acccusations that they could not be trusted to spend the first £600m in the way ministers wanted.
fields.body:
The shine came off the government's cash boost for the NHS yesterday when health managers reacted furiously to acccusations that they could not be trusted to spend the first £600m in the way ministers wanted.

The leader of the NHS Confederation, the body representing health authorities and trusts, warned that damaging spin doctoring was undermining the goodwill created by the spending commitment and posing a threat to a partnership that is vital to delivery of Tony Blair's NHS modernisation agenda.

Meanwhile the audit commission is today insisting that some of the increased health funding must go into unfashionable areas such as disability equipment.

In a damning report on the state of equipment services, the commission says their neglect is landing the NHS and social services with huge and unnecessary bills.

The row over allocation of the first share of the £2bn extra promised to the NHS in the next financial year, starting next week, was triggered by Whitehall press briefings that ministers were for the first time to use powers to "direct" the £600m straight to front line services.

Echoing an earlier announcement of extra money for schools, cirumventing local authorities, this was presented as bypassing bureaucrats and putting money straight in the hands of doctors and community nurses on local primary care groups and trusts.

The justification offered was that £90m distributed among English health authorities just before Christmas, earmarked to help with high drug costs, had not been used entirely to that end.

Some had been "retained" for other purposes.

The Department of Health yesterday said that while the £600m - plus £60m in performance bonuses - would go to health authorities in the usual way, they would be given a statutory instruction to pass it on directly for specified purposes.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, said: "These new resources for the NHS have to make a real difference to patient care right across the country. They have to be spent on real services. That is why I am using my powers of direction."

However, Stephen Thornton, chief executive of the confederation, said the powers were always implicit in spending allocations. To make a public issue of them was merely to take a swipe at managers and put in jeopardy their clear support for the modernisation agenda.

"Where is the evidence for any of the £90m being 'retained' without consent? I demand to see it," Mr Thornton said.

"What do they think happened - that someone stuck the money in their back pocket and spent it on foreign holidays?"

Suzanne Tyler, deputy director of the Institute of Healthcare Management, described the government's tactics as "potentially worrying".

She said health authorities had a crucial strategic role in channelling resources in line with community needs in the battle against health inequalities.

The audit commission is calling for urgent action to improve what it says are mostly "unacceptably low" standards of the £400m-a-year equipment services for 4m disabled and elderly people, ranging from provision of hearing aids to the fitting of artificial limbs.

Nick Mapstone, one of the authors of the commission's report, said some of the new NHS money must go into such services as a priority. "It really is a case of a stitch in time. If you invest in good equipment services, you are going to reduce costs elsewhere."

Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's official spokesman, took the unusual step of commenting on the report, saying that Mr Blair considered its findings unacceptable.

"We cannot have a situation where older and disabled people are let down in the way this report suggests," Mr Campbell said. The prime minister would be having talks with officials to see how the problems could be addressed.

Nick Mapstone, one of the authors of the commission's report, said some of the new NHS money must go into such services as a priority. "It really is a case of a stitch in time. If you invest in good equipment services, you are going to reduce costs elsewhere." Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's official spokesman, took the unusual step of commenting on the report, saying that Mr Blair considered its findings unacceptable. "We cannot have a situation where older and disabled people are let down in the way this report suggests," Mr Campbell said. The prime minister would be having talks with officials to see how the problems could be addressed.

webTitle: Beethoven Blair pounds kettle drums for Britain

fields.headline: Beethoven Blair pounds kettle drums for Britain
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair gave an important talk to the newspaper conference yesterday. Not for the first time, I was struck by the way a Blair speech is closer to a musical composition than to mere rhetoric.
fields.body:
Tony Blair gave an important talk to the newspaper conference yesterday. Not for the first time, I was struck by the way a Blair speech is closer to a musical composition than to mere rhetoric.

Like a piece of music, its aim isn't to inform but to create good feelings.

It's no more about facts and policies than the Pastoral Symphony is an examination of the common agricultural policy.

And like a piece of music, it has a definite structure, based on internal rhythm and repetition. A theme is announced and then echoed. Fresh themes are introduced and melded in with the earlier ones. The repetition brings a satisfying familiarity, so that by the end the listener's brain vibrates with the interwoven passages.

Nobody ever finished listening to a Blair speech and said, "well, I learned something there". Instead they praise the bravura performance and enjoy the afterglow created by the mood.

He began: "My argument today is this." That was the equivalent of the conductor tapping his baton.

Next he announced: "Britain is stronger together, than separated apart." (How you might be separated together he didn't explain, but that's not the point.)

"True Britishness lies in our values, not unchanging institutions," he continued. This was Beethoven's technique: state the main themes crisply and boldly at the start and then refer back to them at different tempos and in different settings. So "Britain" or "British" in the second sentence appeared a further 47 times in the speech, a rate of nearly five times a minute.

"Values", usually integrated into a longer phrase, such as "a clear sense of shared values", or "our core values as a country," appeared 17 times. And variations on "change" (sometimes in the invariably pejorative "unchanging") cropped up 16 times.

In his third sentence he introduced another powerful theme: "the constitutional changes we have made ... are the means of strengthening Britain for today's world."

"Strong" and "strengthening" appeared 17 times, often associated with "standing up", in the sense of resisting the enemies of change.

The fourth paragraph bound this theme to the earlier ones: "Standing up for our country means standing up for what we believe in. It means standing up for our values, and having the strength ... to stand up for the core British values."

As the themes circled round and disappeared up their own treble clefs, the orchestra was in full flight. The violins were soaring, the harps created a loud glissando, and the brass was about to crash in.

"To fail to modernise would be to fail Britain. But we must modernise according to our core values ..." (The various forms of "modernise" appeared 11 times, and were coupled with the nine mentions of "reform".)

After just two minutes, all the main motifs had appeared.

Three minutes later we heard of a "Britain that is stronger, fairer, modernised ... modernisation based on values."

Then, "standing up for Britain means fighting for British values" (the kettledrums were pounding now).

So we seemed to be moving towards a crescendo. But this is not the composer's style.

Instead we were reaching a diminuendo, a soft, gentle coda in which the main themes were gathered together in verbless sentences, creating mood music which sent the audience into a pleasing, soporific reverie. "An economy gaining in strength. Pride from a modern constitution that strengthens the nation.

"We are rediscovering our strength and values. We are uniting those values ... to make Britain stronger..."

And so the listeners left, no wiser but much happier, the music echoing round and round in their heads.

webTitle: A rational response to drugs is beyond Labour's grasp

fields.headline: A rational response to drugs is beyond Labour's grasp
fields.standfirst:
Appeals to common sense fall on deaf ears in the government

New Labour in power: special report
Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: What use is yet another call for sensible reform to the drugs laws? It has all been said time and again. Only consider the futile waste and damage done by arresting and convicting more than 100,000 people a year for possession of very small amounts of cannabis. Downing Street girded its loins for yesterday's Police Foundation report and let it be known in its most acidly laconic style: "To say the chance of reform happening is minimal would be an exaggeration." So all reform talk gets zero tolerance. Ministers who venture a toe out of line on this get zeroed too. Just say no is the gagging order on MPs.
fields.body:
What use is yet another call for sensible reform to the drugs laws? It has all been said time and again. Only consider the futile waste and damage done by arresting and convicting more than 100,000 people a year for possession of very small amounts of cannabis. Downing Street girded its loins for yesterday's Police Foundation report and let it be known in its most acidly laconic style: "To say the chance of reform happening is minimal would be an exaggeration." So all reform talk gets zero tolerance. Ministers who venture a toe out of line on this get zeroed too. Just say no is the gagging order on MPs.

Has this eminent collection of the great and good footled away two years for nothing for the Police Foundation? Certainly not. They have produced a report of great intellectual coherence and good sense, grounded in fundamental principles about how to think about drugs: it may well move the argument into the centre stage at last. Opponents of any easing of drug penalties indulge in a particular kind of "moral panic" train of thought. They see it as a slippery slope to social perdition. Easing up on cannabis seems to them like giving up just because the law is so frequently broken. Why not decriminalise any crime that gets out of hand? But here are wise reasons laid out lucidly should make (almost) anyone pause for thought. This is not about hedonism but harm reduction.

Cannabis does little harm and public opinion has shifted significantly on this. Adults polled by Mori gave cannabis a very low danger rating compared with heroin, cocaine, alcohol or tobacco. But children under 16 polled seem to have been so badly informed by blanket "just say say no" propaganda that they can't distinguish the relative dangers. They list cannabis as equal to cocaine and heroin, with alcohol and tobacco rated far less dangerous. When they first encounter drugs they have no clue as to whether heroin or cannabis will harm them more. It may explain why more under-21s are taking to hard drugs. It may explain soaring hard drinking among the very young if they think whatever is legal is safer than everything that is not.

The report gives a graphic account of the damage done by police harassing the young, with cannabis laws used as "a proxy for the control of public order", an excuse for stop and search. Downgraded to a class C drug, police would not be allowed to arrest people found with small amounts during street searches. The Dutch have done much better than we: their cannabis cafe policy has lead to lower not higher use than in the UK.

But what is the point? The calm, rational and liberal tones of this report are just the kind to make Jack Straw reach for his revolver. He eats reports like this for breakfast. It is not that there is anything woolly about it: on the contrary it is clear sighted and hard headed. But he will seize another opportunity to draw plaudits from the forces of conservatism as he kicks it out of the arena. Drugs policy is the ultimate political football, no interest in facts, only in political symbolism. Mad libertarians see abolishing all drug laws as a symbol of freedom, while Labour and Tory front benches vie for the toughest-on-drugs trophy. Only consider the ravings of William Hague last month when he called for seven-year sentences for supplying cannabis and life for giving ecstasy to a minor. Politicians are contemptible on this issue, a shame since it makes the young so cynical. Would a government sincerely worried about harm have capitulated to the alcohol lobby this week by rejecting a call from police chiefs, the BMA and even the Automobile Association to cut drink-drive levels to one pint, saving 50 lives and 250 crippling injuries a year?

But if the government had a sudden Damascene conversion, it still might make no difference. For what chance would there ever be of passing even these modest reforms to cannabis and ecstasy penalties? The ill-conceived new mutant House of Lords precludes any kind of liberal reform ever passing its doors. With 91 hereditaries still in place and a promise by Tony Blair not to pack the chamber with Labour appointees, we now have reinvigorated muscular Lords as mad and unrepresentative as before but with twice the oppositional vim. The awful spectacle of Lady Young's campaign against the repeal of section 28 makes it quite clear that from now on the bishops, the Daily Mail and the bigots rule on "moral" matters.

Meanwhile appeals to common sense on imprisoning so many people for drugs offences is likely to fall on deaf ears in a government remarkably sanguine about the ever growing prison population. From a low of some 45,000 under Douglas Hurd, we are now at 65,000, with the Home Office itself predicting a rise to around 80,000. New laws just taking effect will help fill the cells with those who breach probation twice. Overcrowding continues despite ever more expensive prison building, with some 12,000 men doubled up in cells built for one. There are two more new prisons for women, many of whom are drug offenders. Prison conditions are better since Labour has spent far more: no slopping out, no stink, a bit more "purposeful activity" (up from 22 to 23 hours a week out of their cages, though much of it still doing useless things). Drug treatment and education are improving, but more and better prisons should not be a Labour boast.

The head of the prison service, Martin Narey, now worries that magistrates are sentencing many more people to custody because the prisons they see now don't look or smell so bad. "They may look at the treatment and classrooms and think it's just the job. But I wouldn't want anyone ever to be sentenced to prison because someone imagined it would do them good," he says with candour. He does the best he can with education, psychiatry and drug treatments for his inmates but he stresses all the evidence shows these programmes work far better in the community, with far less re-offending. There are new schemes to divert drug cases away from prison towards community programmes - but the emphasis is still wildly warped. The government spends 62% of its drugs budget on arresting and enforcing the law but only 13% on treatment. Most drug addicts who are arrested have never been offered treatment, which, says yesterday's report, is an argument for more early treatment not for more arrests. But who's listening?

Labour has made a Faustian pact. It dares to be redistributive towards the deserving poor, but risks no middle England wrath on wrong-doers. However, deserving and undeserving are often the same families, the children of the poor at greater risk of hard drug addiction. "What works" guides Labour's best social policy for the law abiding - but "what the papers say" too often guides its policies on crime and prison. The force and depth of a report like this helps reveal their position as absurd, even to themselves.

fields.headline: Waltzing with the Russian bear
fields.trailText: The final paragraph of David Hearst's article (How Russia was lost, March 27) says that in order to appease Moscow, expansion of Nato should cease "and the problems of Russian-speaking minorities in Ukraine and Latvia addressed".
fields.body:
The final paragraph of David Hearst's article (How Russia was lost, March 27) says that in order to appease Moscow, expansion of Nato should cease "and the problems of Russian-speaking minorities in Ukraine and Latvia addressed".

It is all very well for Hearst to suggest the "selling" to Russia of countries in which he has no interest. He has forgotten recent history.

Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania were "sold" to Stalin's Soviet Union by Nazi Germany in August 1939 when the infamous Molotov-Ribbentrop pact was signed. Britain and the US acquiesced to this deal in the Tehran and Yalta conferences.

During the war, the Soviets deported to Siberia thousands of Latvians and flooded the country with nearly a million Russian speaking settlers.

After regaining independence in 1991, Latvia has given permanent residence to these settlers, but in order to gain Latvian citizenship, an understanding of basic Latvian and some knowledge of the constitution and history of the county is needed.

Moscow wants Latvia (population about 2.5m) to give Latvian citizenship to all 600,000 non-citizens en bloc because it wants an electorate orientated towards Russia. And here lies the "problem" on which Moscow's propaganda dwells.

During the occupation, Latvia had no control over the number of settlers. Britain and the rest of the EU would face the same problem if their borders were opened to all who wished to come.
AV Ozolins
Chairman, Latvian National Council in Great Britain

 Russia and the rest of the former republics are on an uncharted path of independent economics and foreign policies, and some observers are daunted by such independence. Understandably so with Russia's appalling behaviour in Chechnya and corruption running amok through every part of the region.

But David Hearst's suggestions for re-engaging Russia are unwise. They sound a bit like asking a former dance partner to waltz without recognising that not only has the music changed but that the partner has lost several key limbs.

Pleasing Russia by making "a major u-turn in western policy" in order to rekindle a bit of the past, is folly. Thankfully a return to history, as Hearst himself concludes, is unlikely.
Roman P Zyla
London

fields.headline: Thin on the ground
fields.trailText: The phrase John Sutherland says he stole from Philip Larkin (G2, March 27) goes a lot further back.
fields.body:
The phrase John Sutherland says he stole from Philip Larkin (G2, March 27) goes a lot further back.

In The Unquiet Grave (1944) Cyril Connolly wrote: "Imprisoned in every fat man a thin man is wildly signalling to be let out." Connolly may have lifted it from Orwell who wrote in Coming Up For Air (1939): "Has it ever struck you that there's a thin man inside every fat man, just as they say there's a statue inside every block of stone?" Kingsley Amis devised a variant: "Outside every fat man there's an even fatter one trying to crowd in."
Bernard Bergonzi
Leamington Spa, Warks

 I would like to propose that the spare plinth in Trafalgar Square be used for a permanent statue of Ian Dury. A fourth reason to be cheerful.
Gary Williams
London

 Re your Leader (March 28): I think the Americans have prior claim to the popularisation of dual identity, as any Italian-American, Irish-American or African American could tell you.
Mark Speight
New York, US
barney4jarat@aol.com

 The probable explanation is that MI5 and MI6 are nicking each other's computers (MI6 puts ad in paper, March 28).
Don Simpson
Rochdale

 I am having trouble following the debate on cyber-spellings (Letters, March 28). Have I lost the plot.com?
Tristan Clayton
Cambridge

 World wide web has three syllables; WWW nine. What kind of abbreviation is that?
Glenn Baron
Bath

 Why does the female loner in your picture (Are we turning into a nation of loners, March 27) need five glasses?
CE Dyte
Datchet, Berks

fields.headline: School row
fields.trailText: The report that the anti-grammar school extremists in Kent are shelving their plans to abolish the county's successful education system (Grammar ballot petition halted, March 27) is welcome.
fields.body:
The report that the anti-grammar school extremists in Kent are shelving their plans to abolish the county's successful education system (Grammar ballot petition halted, March 27) is welcome.

Egalitarian hooligans who want to destroy some of the best state schools in the country care not a jot how much disruption their activities cause. Why don't they just admit that the view of most parents in Kent is that the county's schools do a very good job and should be left alone?

Furthermore, instead of allowing small and tightly knit groups of politically motivated activists to plot the abolition of selective institutions, David Blunkett should abolish the anti-grammar school regulations that are causing such disruption and uncertainty.
John Bercow MP
Shadow spokesman on Education and Employment

fields.headline: Cambridge doesn't care
fields.trailText: Lee Elliot Major makes out that the colleges of Cambridge are interested in supporting and welcoming those from low-income backgrounds (Poverty rules, ok? Guardian Education, March 28). The truth is they are doing more harm than good.
fields.body:
Lee Elliot Major makes out that the colleges of Cambridge are interested in supporting and welcoming those from low-income backgrounds (Poverty rules, ok? Guardian Education, March 28). The truth is they are doing more harm than good.

Cambridge University continually claims it cares about widening access. But at Cambridge University Students' Union, we are sick of the pleading words of Cambridge tutors about how they "care" about access; their record is astonishingly bad. Half the intake of Cambridge undergraduates is still from the private sector. Either tutors are incompetent or they don't really care about access.

Judging by the massive rent increases of up to 47%, planned for the next four to six years, bursaries are a smokescreen to hide the real story. If it's tuition fees and the abolition of the maintenance grant that are to blame, why aren't they lobbying for the reintroduction of a living grant for all, not just for those at universities with large endowments and generous alumni?

Attempts at Cambridge to introduce bursaries for the poorer students are simply to justify the rent increases that can be seen as top up fees by the back door. This is the start of a dangerous trend towards creating a two-tier Ivy League system, where the poor get an "assisted place," but more truthfully will not get a place at all.
Daniel Blaney
Academic affairs officer
Katie McClymont
Women's officer Cambridge University Students' Union
Cambridge University
dlb23@hermes.cam.ac.uk
