But at Cambridge University Students' Union, we are sick of the pleading words of Cambridge tutors about how they "care" about access; their record is astonishingly bad. Half the intake of Cambridge undergraduates is still from the private sector. Either tutors are incompetent or they don't really care about access. Judging by the massive rent increases of up to 47%, planned for the next four to six years, bursaries are a smokescreen to hide the real story. If it's tuition fees and the abolition of the maintenance grant that are to blame, why aren't they lobbying for the reintroduction of a living grant for all, not just for those at universities with large endowments and generous alumni? Attempts at Cambridge to introduce bursaries for the poorer students are simply to justify the rent increases that can be seen as top up fees by the back door. This is the start of a dangerous trend towards creating a two-tier Ivy League system, where the poor get an "assisted place," but more truthfully will not get a place at all. Daniel Blaney Academic affairs officer Katie McClymont Women's officer Cambridge University Students' Union Cambridge University dlb23@hermes.cam.ac.uk

fields.headline: Ulster: we pay the price
fields.trailText: Ulster is heavily subsidised by taxpayers in the rest of the UK. As a pensioner whose weekly pension will go up by less than the cost of a wholemeal loaf, I wonder what sort of world the Ulster Unionists live in (Unionists deliver ultimatum to Trimble, March 27)?
fields.body:
Ulster is heavily subsidised by taxpayers in the rest of the UK. As a pensioner whose weekly pension will go up by less than the cost of a wholemeal loaf, I wonder what sort of world the Ulster Unionists live in (Unionists deliver ultimatum to Trimble, March 27)?

Clearly they are happy to receive largesse to stay in the time warp they seem to think is their right, without appreciating that the world goes on and many of their fellow Ulstermen actually prefer peace. Where is their offer to disarm?

Here are three simple questions. What is the average cost of the subsidy: 1p off income tax; 2p; more? By how much a week could the pension be increased if the subsidy was removed? How much could the NHS and education receive in extra funding if it were removed?
Frank Osborn
London

 Don't the Ulster Unionists realise that you can't have a police force with the word "Royal" in it in a 32-county republic? Shouldn't Mandelson explain that the only way that republican disarmamament is going to take place is when the British army is totally withdrawn from Ulster?

No matter what rhetoric is uttered by Sinn Fein, the peace agreement is merely a tactical move in their overall strategy. The presence of so many convicted terrorists in their ranks ensures there will be no participation in the government of the Ulster statelet unless that leads to a 32-county republic.

It may be that the people of Ireland want peace, but ultimately the extremists (on both sides) call the tune. Take the continuing friction caused by what appear to be merely symbols, the Garvaghy Road and opposition to a Dublin Orange parade by Sinn Fein. If the republican movement can have its annual martyrs' parade in Manchester, then why can't they allow a peaceful Orange parade down the Garvaghy Road?

Given the arrest of a recently released terrorist caught moving a bomb, it would seem to be a matter of time before we are at the receiving end of another republican spectacular.
T Statham
London

 There will always be a reason why half of the Ulster Unionist party opposes entry into devolved government. First it was decommissioning, now it is an objection to certain reforms of the RUC. But the underlying objection is that they prefer the status quo, ie totally British government of Northern Ireland, to any concessions to the nationalist community.

The population of NI is 46.5% Irish and 52.5% British. A democratic government would recognise this equal split in a government of joint authority, as proposed by the SDLP. NI could be ruled by a joint British/Irish council until agreement is reached by all parties on the implementation of the Good Friday agreement. Westminster's direct rule cannot be regarded as being representative of anything but the British nation of NI and it is certainly not democratic.
Frank Murphy
Coulsdon, Surrey Fmu7@btinternet.com

 Despite being a lifelong republican, I must take issue with your description of David Trimble (Leader, March 24). Even without Ulster (nine counties) scepticism, your assertion that an awkward personal manner would be a barrier to leadership in mainstream British politics is laughable when one considers the manner of the present leader of the Tories or his predecessor. Perhaps you would prefer that Mr Trimble conducted himself like that other "mainstream" political figure described in your columns as "Oooh you amaze me!"
Micheal O'Ruis
London oruis@hotmail.com

fields.headline: Holy wars
fields.trailText: Re David Paton's defence (Letters, March 28) of Pius XII's position on the Jews: according to the Encyclopaedia Judaica, Emilio Zolli became a Catholic only when the Jewish community of Rome refused to reappoint him chief rabbi after the war.
fields.body:
Re David Paton's defence (Letters, March 28) of Pius XII's position on the Jews: according to the Encyclopaedia Judaica, Emilio Zolli became a Catholic only when the Jewish community of Rome refused to reappoint him chief rabbi after the war.

They felt betrayed because he had spent the occupation in hiding rather than sharing their time of danger. Pinchas Lapide wrote praising Pius XII after Rolf Hochhuth's searing The Deputy and other writers first questioned the pope's war record.

Lapide's vigorous defence of the indefensible and unrealistic numbers credited to the Vatican may have stemmed from a desire to cultivate Christian friends in view of his ambiguous position as a Jew who wrote supporting the resurrection of Jesus.

Those who cite the Jews hidden in monasteries and convents should bear in mind the (often forced) baptism of Jewish children and the help given by the church to prominent Nazis escaping Europe after the war.
Rachel Montagu
London rachel@gn.apc.org

fields.headline: Buying sex in Kent
fields.trailText: The last-minute decision by Kent county council to tack on a further £3 per year to Kent's council tax (Dover, no port in a storm for refugees, March 28) was not made to cover the costs of asylum seekers.
fields.body:
The last-minute decision by Kent county council to tack on a further £3 per year to Kent's council tax (Dover, no port in a storm for refugees, March 28) was not made to cover the costs of asylum seekers.

The rise was imposed to cover the costs of Kent's inability to record whether some children were British or foreign. Legitimate costs of looking after asylum seekers in Kent have been met by central government.

By blaming asylum seekers, Kent's Conservative administration hopes to hide the fact that Kent's council tax demands have gone up by a third in three years, though services in the county have steadily declined. That they have encouraged racial hatred does not appear to concern them.
Cllr Mike Eddy
Deal, Kent

 So there is fear of an epidemic of venereal diseases arising from refugees selling sex in Dover? Who will be buying these sexual favours; surely not the decent, law-abiding citizens of the same town?

To complain about a £3 rise in council tax, but cough up for a quick one makes no economic sense. Secondly, this must risk unwanted pregnancies, thus mixing the racially pure blood of the Garden of Eden.

Maybe I'm just confused. Maybe busloads of Hampstead liberals are being brought in to carry out this "charitable" work.
Clarry McDonald
London

fields.headline: The Cuillin are calling
fields.standfirst: A generous buyer should step forward
fields.trailText: The Cuillin of Skye are a treasure of our archipelago, seen from afar or nose pressed close to rocky cliff. But are these fine mountains "ours"? By law they belong to the MacLeods of Dunvegan who, to maintain the castle of that name, plan to sell their land holdings to the highest bidder.
fields.body:
The Cuillin of Skye are a treasure of our archipelago, seen from afar or nose pressed close to rocky cliff. But are these fine mountains "ours"? By law they belong to the MacLeods of Dunvegan who, to maintain the castle of that name, plan to sell their land holdings to the highest bidder. Some say the ownership of this landscape is not relevant. By all accounts the MacLeods have not been bad landlords: no one bar tenant farmers and their sheep actually live on the mountains and much of the terrain is formally recognised for planning purposes as inalienable wilderness. A phalanx of interest groups concerned for plant and beast, let alone climbers and walkers, monitor land use closely. And yet - we have seen this recently as landowners and their Tory allies mobilised against the "right to roam" in England - private ownership is often guilty by association; it is what landlords might get up to.

Among alternatives, those great charities the National Trust and the National Trust for Scotland (separate organisations) are not perfect. And the state's stewardship of large tracts of rural Scotland is blackened by those dark and dreary expanses of fir. Perhaps the fair Cuillin are calling some e-zillionaire to come, by Loch Tummel and Loch Rannoch and Lochaber of course, to buy the tangle of the isles - and immediately entrust the land to public contemplation and enjoyment for all the years to come.

fields.headline: All at sea over Galilee
fields.standfirst:
Syrian failure heightens regional tension

Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: A small strip of land on the eastern shore of the Sea of Galilee is the Middle East's new diplomatic killing ground. Held by Syria before Israel's 1967 seizure of the Golan Heights, Damascus adamantly demands its return.
fields.body:
A small strip of land on the eastern shore of the Sea of Galilee is the Middle East's new diplomatic killing ground. Held by Syria before Israel's 1967 seizure of the Golan Heights, Damascus adamantly demands its return. Whatever Yitzhak Rabin may once have said, Israel now offers only a withdrawal to the 1923 international boundary. These eight square miles unhinged last winter's Israeli-Syrian dialogue. That breakdown was followed by vicious recrimination. At Sunday's Geneva summit with the US, Syria's Hafez Assad could have revived the process. Instead, his grim inflexibility on Galilee dealt a possibly fatal blow to compromise. Israel's Ehud Barak, weakened since last July by coalition divisions, the Knesset's Golan referendum bill, and rising anti-Syrian sentiment, found he had no leeway left. As he trailed home, Bill Clinton's dream of a presidency-capping triumph looked mortally wounded. Fig-leaves flutter: the Syrian "track" is not derailed; Egypt's Hosni Mubarak is coming to the White House! As if that will make much difference. Thus do long-nurtured, much-trumpeted hopes of a peace of the brave abruptly wither and die.

Is all then lost on the Syrian front? Not quite, not yet. But it is a dangerous moment, for now the focus switches away from diplomacy towards the movement of armies. Committed to quit Lebanon by July, Mr Barak may well accelerate the pullout despite the lack of a deal. The UN is already being asked to fill the vacuum. Syria meanwhile is being left in no doubt that it will be held directly responsible for any post-withdrawal attacks, by Hizbullah or others, on Israel proper. This means military retaliation against Syria proper. US officials tell the Ha'aretz newspaper that America will fully support Israeli action in such circumstances, once UN resolution 425 on Lebanon is fulfilled. They will squeeze Arab moderates, promote the Palestinian "track" and, we can assume, jointly do anything else they can to force Syria's hand.

This is the black harvest of Mr Assad's intransigence and, to a lesser degree, of Mr Barak's overreaching and US miscalculation. Perhaps something worthwhile can be salvaged. But various clocks are ticking in Tehran and Baghdad as well as Tel Aviv. For this evolving, post-Geneva US-Israeli strategy raises the stakes very significantly. In the name of an elusive peace, they prepare to run the risk of a regional war. The reason why is blowing in the wind, off Galilee.

webTitle: Nato chiefs faced threat from Serbs

fields.headline: Nato chiefs faced threat from Serbs
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Nato was forced to change the travel plans of its secretary general, Lord Roberston, to Kosovo last week because of fears of a Serb threat to kill him, it was confirmed last night.
fields.body:
Nato was forced to change the travel plans of its secretary general, Lord Roberston, to Kosovo last week because of fears of a Serb threat to kill him, it was confirmed last night.

Alliance sources said that Friday's trip by Lord Robertson and Nato's supreme allied commander in Europe, General Wesley Clark, had to be altered because of a "generalised security alert".

Officially, however, there was no response, with Nato spokesmen insisting that they would not comment on "operational matters".

Reports that the CIA uncovered a Serb plot to assassinate the two as they flew by helicopter from Skopje in Macedonia to the Kosovan capital, Pristina - their original route - have not been substantiated. In the event, the Nato chiefs flew from Mons in Belgium directly to Pristina in a visit designed to underline Nato's commitment to the province on the first anniversary of the start of the war.

Sources in Brussels said last night that the change had been ordered because K-For, the Nato-led peacekeeping force, had inadvertently released details of their itinerary the day before.

But the decision to alter the travel plans was taken by Nato's office of security, which is commanded by an American and has access to US intelligence reports. One US official said there had been signals from Serbian sources that there would be "some type of action against Nato or European allied facilities".

There is no doubting the fact that Nato is braced for trouble from Belgrade, whether in Montenegro, which President Slobodan Milosevic might try to destabilise, or in the divided city of Mitrovice.

Originally Lord Robertson and General Clark were due to visit Mitrovice, but shortly beforehand K-For troops found explosives on a road bridge inside the last large predominantly Serb area of Kosovo.

"Milosevic is in the mood to make trouble," said one alliance diplomat. "He's certainly stirring things in Mitrovice so in a situation like this Nato is always going to err on the side of caution."

fields.headline: Ex-PM and wife face charges
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Israeli police yesterday recommended that the former prime minister, Binyamin Netanyahu, be tried on corruption charges, offering up yet another scandal for the delectation of a public with a thirst for tales of low life in high public office.
fields.body:
Israeli police yesterday recommended that the former prime minister, Binyamin Netanyahu, be tried on corruption charges, offering up yet another scandal for the delectation of a public with a thirst for tales of low life in high public office.

Mr Netanyahu and his wife, Sara, are alleged to have squirreled away more than £60,000 in state gifts, and to have connived with a contractor to defraud the government of tens of thousands of pounds.

The former prime minister, who led the government from 1996 to 1999, said the allegations were baseless, and accused the police of acting at the behest of his political opponents.

"This was a tendentious investigation whose outcome was known ahead of time," a Netanyahu statement said.

Although Mr Netanyahu has been under investigation since September, and was trounced in last May's elections, he has continued to nurse hopes of a comeback. At odds with the inner circle of his rightwing Likud party, "Bibi" remains the darling of the working classes of Sephardic, or Middle Eastern, origin who are the backbone of the party's support.

If Israel's attorney-general accepts the police recommendation for an indictment, Mr Netanyahu could be charged with accepting a bribe, fraud, attempted misuse of state funds, and obstruction of justice, police said. His wife could be indicted for theft. Two advisers could also face charges.

Yesterday's announcement by the police may be sobering for others in Israel's political class who have distinguished themselves in recent months by a propensity for sleaze. The president is among those under investigation.

"Every week we have a new scandal. Half of the establishment is either on trial or under investigation, and it is beginning to blunt the senses," said Uri Avnery, one of the country's best known journalists. "On the whole, it is cheapening the democratic process, and this is a dangerous thing."

The former first couple are suspected of persuading a contractor to provide free cleaning and removal services for three years on the promise that he would get a government contract. By the time Mr Netanyahu was defeated, Avner Amedi's bill had reached almost £69,000. Realising he stood no chance of getting his government contract, he told the police.

The couple are also suspected of spiriting away 700 gifts received while Mr Netanyahu was in office. Most of the gifts have yet to be found. Those recovered are reported to include candelabra, carpets, silverware, and a gold letter opener from the US vice-president, Al Gore.

The aggressive coverage of this story - and the revelations of wrongdoing by other officials - tell of the changes in Israeli society. Generals and prime ministers were once above criticism, but better behaviour is now demanded.

"There were presidents and prime ministers who even stole very expensive, original pictures from the walls of their residences, and nothing happened," said Akiva Eldar, a respected columnist for the Tel Aviv newspaper Haaretz. "But the rules have changed."

Litany of scandal

In January, a police inquiry began into claims of improper campaign fundraising by the One Israel party of the prime minister, Ehud Barak

The president, Ezer Weizman, is under investigation for possible tax evasion

Police are investigating whether a sermon by the spiritual leader of the Shas party constituted incitement to murder. Rabbi Ovadiah Yosef denounced the education minister, Yossi Sarid, as a Satanic figure and asked God to blot out his memory

The ex-leader of the Shas party, Rabbi Aryeh Deri, was forced to resign last year following a bribery conviction

Police are investigating allegations of sexual harassment and assault against the deputy prime minister, Yitzhak Mordechai

Several senior police officers are under investigation for corruption in the murder trial of a publisher

Binyamin Netanyahu's justice minister, Tzahi Hanegbi, has been indicted on corruption charges

fields.headline: Gaza united
fields.standfirst:

fields.trailText: For the Palestinian national football squad, the Asian Cup, which starts this week, is more than a contest. It is the first foray by the intifada exiles into international sport - and, they believe, one more step towards genuine peace.
fields.body:
The last time Ibrahim al-Kurd watched his son Ziad play football was from an Israeli jail, and he nearly caused a riot. "All the prisoners were yelling and crying, and banging on the doors and making a huge commotion," he remembers. "The Israelis came with sticks and gas to see what was happening and I said: 'Look, that's my son on TV.' That's when the guards knew that it was not a revolution."

That was last summer, when Ziad scored the equaliser against Syria in a match that was played in Jordan. By autumn, Ibrahim was home after serving nearly 12 years of a 25-year sentence for the bombing of an Israeli guard post in which five soldiers were injured, his early release granted under the Middle East peace process. Ziad was still soaking up the glory as the leading goal scorer of the Palestinian national football team.

Now during these spring days, when Ziad climbs slowly upstairs after a gruelling practice session before the Palestinian side's international sporting debut - in the Asian Cup in Qatar which starts tomorrow - both father and son have occasion to reflect on the nature of change in Gaza over the past few years.

Since the coming of the Palestinian Authority to this heaving strip of humanity on the edge of the Mediterranean, Gaza has existed in a kind of limbo. It is an entity that has yet to declare itself a state, and where basic freedoms do not include an automatic right to pass beyond the Israeli checkpoint to the other towns under Palestinian rule in the West Bank. For lack of a better word, Israelis and Palestinians call it peace.

Ibrahim returned to a wall of graffiti on the grey concrete of his four-storey home, declaring the science teacher-turned-bomber a hero. After getting reacquainted with his 10 children, he turned his energies to raising pigeons, and has plans to house 100 pairs on the ground floor. The scars from his interrogation sessions - a smashed wrist and broken ribs - have faded as much as they ever will. Ziad, meanwhile, has been undergoing treatment by an Israeli doctor for a dislocated foot.

Neither father nor son finds that strange. But both say the time is not yet ripe for Palestine to play against an Israeli side.

Amid such contradictions, football is a certainty, the one true love. In the poor and densely populated Gaza Strip, where everything is coated with a fine layer of sand, it seems every tiny scrap of wasteland has been occupied by boys kicking around a football. "Every street, every corner in a refugee camp, everywhere they are playing football," says Ismail Mattar, the financial manager of the national squad. "You see kids playing on a beach, with plastic balls, with anything they can find."

So the excitement over the contest in Qatar is intense. By 10am, when practice starts with a slow jog round a stadium dominated by a mural of Yasser Arafat, "the paragon leader", the first supporters are waiting in the stands: truant office workers and pupils.

Everyone in the stands recognises that the tournament is about more than football. "This means the presence of the Palestinian people: that we have our own national team despite all the challenges that we are facing," says Ali Abu Ramadan, a student aged 16. "The team is our ambassador to the whole world. If you are going to make peace, sport has to lead the way. Didn't the Americans and the Iranians play against each other in the World Cup?"

Barring the largely symbolic dispatch of a single long-distance runner to the Atlantic Olympics in 1996, the Asian Cup marks the Palestinians' first serious foray into international sport. Except for Ziad, who says he has no interest in merely serving as a symbol and hopes to play in the World Cup one day, nobody connected with the enterprise pretends the team is actually going to win in Qatar.

"We are a child in the world of football. This national team is just six or seven months old," says coach Azmi Nasa'ar. A resident of the Israeli town of Nazareth, Nasa'ar spent 25 years in the Israeli leagues. When he started, he was one of only three Palestinian players, forced to endure the death threats and taunts of terrorists from the stands.

Now he says it is a matter of personal prestige that the Palestinian side leave Qatar with their dignity intact. Over the weeks leading up to the tournament, the players have been virtual prisoners in the stadium, released only on Thursday afternoons for the Muslim weekend.

"They sleep, they eat, they train," says Ghassan Abdul Ghani, the general manager. He waves his hand towards the white buildings rising from the sand on all sides of the stadium, part of the building boom that has followed peace. "Even if they live over there, they can't go home and sleep. If they have families, we give them two hours to visit their wives and children, then they are back inside. This is their new family."

It's a family that represents a coming together of the exiles from the Palestinian diaspora. From the Gaza contingent, some are from the refugee camps, that sprouted here after 1948, and some from town. Like Ziad, some saw relatives jailed during the intifada , the uprising against the Israeli occupation that began in 1987 and led to the beginnings of the peace process in 1993. Others lost their fathers to the war in Lebanon. One player carries the faint tracings of birdshot on his arm, a souvenir of his intifada childhood.

Along with coach Nasa'ar, who carries an Israeli passport, is a goalkeeper who was born in Egypt, and players who were brought up in Jordan and Iraq. There is Wisam Abdul Razak, who lives in Sweden and signed on after seeing a story about the team on an Arabic satellite station. As soon as the Palestine team is finished in Qatar, he will leave for Germany, where he is to sign a contract to play for Düsseldorf. Two more players will join from Lebanon, when the camp moves to Cairo, and if the Israelis lift their travel restrictions in time, two more will join from the West Bank. It took six months for the Israelis to grant permission to the other nine West Bankers who made the squad.

None of the players is paid. They have volunteered, content to play in return for their bus fare, basic living expenses and a brief moment of celebrity before returning to their regular jobs when this is all over. Several work for the Palestinian Authority as policemen, earning the equivalent of £238 a month.

By international standards, the budget for the outing is minuscule: £90,000 from October until the end of the tournament. There are no television rights for auction, no jerseys or other merchandise for sale to the fans, no government sponsorship, and little money in ticket sales in a stadium that seats only 7,000. Instead, the team organisers have been asking for donations from local businessmen - and, occasionally, from Arafat himself, who has large funds at his disposal. The budget does not stretch to trainers or physiotherapists but Nasa'ar, despite his experience in the more prosperous Israeli leagues, is undaunted.

"All the time I was playing in Israel I had a dream that I would see a Palestinian country, but I never believed I would be the coach of its team," he says. "Maybe sometimes you achieve your dream. But sometimes you get more than you dream about. This is more than I ever dreamed about and I hope I can give my country the maximum."

webTitle: Seen and unseen: a minister's box of tricks

fields.headline: Seen and unseen: a minister's box of tricks
fields.standfirst: Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: What was not particularly secret
fields.body:
What was not particularly secret

 Weekly update on progress to sort out problems in the passport agency;

 A draft reply to an MEP on registering overseas residents to vote in British elections;

 A note on the strategy to publicise the Human Rights Act when it comes into force later this year;

 A note on the arrangements for the awards in honour of the murdered headmaster Philip Lawrence;

 Background papers on two parliamentary questions which were answered yesterday afternoon;

 A draft of a speech on human rights which he will give later this week;

 Progress reports on the bill on the state's powers to eavesdrop on individuals which is being handled primarily by junior minister Charles Clarke.

 What was too secret for the public to see

 Two Foreign Office telegrams regarding countries that were not identified;

 Minutes of a cabinet committee meeting on family policy which he chairs;

 A note on a matter relating to visas for immigrants which is currently under discussion;

 A letter regarding the suspicious deaths of two black men in Telford;

 A note on "people-trafficking", the smuggling of illegal immigrants into Britain;

 Private correspondence with an unnamed MP about unidentified policy issues;

 A paper on the status of benefits to refugees before they have formally claimed asylum;

 Files on whether to release two life prisoners from prison;

 A note about the Saville inquiry into the 1972 Bloody Sunday shootings.

webTitle: Secrecy session with Jack in the box

fields.headline: Secrecy session with Jack in the box
fields.standfirst:
Open and shut case - At work with the home secretary as he tries to reassure the Guardian that the government has nothing to hide

Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: Jack Straw puts the mortice key into his brand new red box and says: "At least this one opens all right." The key doesn't always turn smoothly but the home secretary claims to be a dab hand with WD40 and a jewellery pick. Like many of the criminals he puts away, Mr Straw's talents stretch to breaking and entering when the need arises.
fields.body:
Jack Straw puts the mortice key into his brand new red box and says: "At least this one opens all right." The key doesn't always turn smoothly but the home secretary claims to be a dab hand with WD40 and a jewellery pick. Like many of the criminals he puts away, Mr Straw's talents stretch to breaking and entering when the need arises.

Mr Straw is showing off the contents of his ministerial red box to the Guardian to prove that there is no need to worry about excessive secrecy in government. The meeting is timed for 9.15am and Mr Straw has already taken his jacket off to reveal a pair of red braces.

Sitting in an armchair, the home secretary says: "I really don't know what's in here. Last night I went to a concert at the Royal Festival Hall - so I haven't had time to look."

This provokes a severe look from his private secretary, Angela Pearce, sitting opposite: "Yes, you haven't done your homework."

Mr Straw has assembled a full team in his large office - with at least two of them taking notes. As well as his private secretary, Lee Hughes, the head of his freedom of information division, and Jean Ward, home office press officer responsible for freedom of information, are present.

The box itself is small it is actually only a half box - but it contains four manila folders. The first is marked "for action", the second is "to read" and then a small file marked "action 2" and finally one marked "further reading".

Top of the action list are the asylum laws. There is a briefing on the new procedures under the bill, including the benefits system, and there is a proposal to help asylum seekers who are destitute because they have not put in a claim. He indicates that he intends to be helpful to them. In response to a surprised look from the Guardian, he quips: "You mustn't confuse your parody of me with what I'm really like. You can't have people here who have got absolutely nothing."

Also on the action list is also a briefing on the publicity needed to explain the new Human Rights Act. The briefing prepared by the press office is how to set up a campaign to explain what the changes will mean. To the astonishment of the civil servants present he hands over the memo.

"Can't see anything secret in this," he says. It contains proposals to use the national press to present their case - and some barbed comments about the Scottish media for suggesting there might be problems.

A more surprising item in the action file is a briefing on a Hansard education re form bill debate in 1987-88. This has not been demanded by Jack Straw, home secretary, but Jack Straw, governor of Pimlico school. Evidently, the school is threatening to end music options - and Mr Straw is checking on what pledges were made by the Tories to bolster his case.

The rest of the file contains copies of memos sent to junior ministers, Charles Clarke and Mike O'Brien, on anything from how the government should tackle the trafficking of people to a rather embarassing leak on which town should gain city status during millennium year.

This memo, written by a home office official to advise the Queen, contained comments on some 39 towns seeking the title, including the home secretary's own patch, Blackburn.

"I'd left this to Mike O'Brien because it affected my constituency. But of course after the leak I got the blame for all the derogatory comments - not so much in Blackburn but I made headline news in Ipswich. Now I have got to decide what to do about it."

Also in the file was a letter he had written to the Independent about its story on Monday claiming that he was about to surrender Britain's control over immigration to the European Union. "Absolute rubbish, you can always tell that when no other paper follows it up - no action needed now they have published my letter," he says. "A little knowledge is a dangerous thing," he adds - a gift to freedom of information campaigners.

In his Action 2 file was a letter from a seven-year-old saw him on TV and had written to ask who "the away secretary" is. "I have asked officials to get his name and address and if we get them I will be writing to him personally," he says.

The most serious reading is in the final file - the parole board is recommending the release of two lifers. Paul Boateng, a Home Office minister, has sent him two files. One lifer has served 25 years - the other 15 years, including breaking parole. Tonight he will probably decide their fates; and he asks the paper not to reveal their names.

At the end of the session the Guardian shows the home secretary a sheaf of government documents published by the paper that would all be banned from publication for 30 years under his bill. They have been released under the more liberal US and Irish freedom of information laws.

"What they do in the US is not relevant," he insists. "British politicans are much more accountable to the public than American politicians are to Congress. We will have to discuss that another time." With that, he sped out of the room without a backward glance.

 Campaign for Freedom of Information
 Freedom of Information Unit (Home Office site)

webTitle: Concern as BBC news show falters

fields.headline: Concern as BBC news show falters
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The BBC's leading current affairs programme, Panorama, recorded its lowest share of the television audience this week amid speculation over the show's future.
fields.body:
The BBC's leading current affairs programme, Panorama, recorded its lowest share of the television audience this week amid speculation over the show's future.

Unofficial figures revealed yesterday show that Monday's edition, a programme about the nuclear industry, was watched by 10% of the audience, equal to its lowest.

The BBC insisted that it remained committed to the programme, pointing to a recent cash injection. But insiders at the programme question the BBC's long term commitment to the genre, as more populist investigative programmes such as MacIntyre Undercover and Watchdog gain substantially higher ratings.

"Panorama will be dead in five years," one senior figure working at the programme said.

Some BBC staff complain about the resourcing of current affairs. Panorama's budget is thought to be £100,000 a programme; MacIntyre Undercover is understood to cost at least £350,000.

A former senior figure at BBC current affairs said: "The BBC should be embarrassed about the under-resourcing of Panorama.

"There is no reason why it can not be a popular, agenda-setting programme."

Channel 4 is so worried about the threat from MacIntyre that it has commissioned an independent production company to produce its own version of the show.

The BBC said Panorama represented the "ethos of public service broadcasting".

A spokesman for BBC news and current affairs said the department had received a £1m boost from the efficiency savings identified by the director general, Greg Dyke. It is thought that Panorama's annual budget has been increased by £300,000.

The spokesman said of Monday night's programme: "It was front page news on Sunday, and that proves that Panorama continues to make the headlines and set the news agenda."

fields.headline: Proving their mettle
fields.standfirst: Detector fans turn up trumps
fields.trailText: Metal detector fans, once pariahs of the archaeological world, were heaped with praise by the government yesterday, for the treasury of historical objects - over 20,000 in the last year - they have brought for identification to local museums.
fields.body:
Metal detector fans, once pariahs of the archaeological world, were heaped with praise by the government yesterday, for the treasury of historical objects - over 20,000 in the last year - they have brought for identification to local museums.

The voluntary code, combined with the new simplified law of treasure trove, has unearthed many objects which would never previously have been reported.

The most valuable find, a Saxon inlaid gold cross, was found 30 years ago and put aside in a kitchen drawer.

The farmer only realised it might be of interest when his local museum, in Yorkshire, organised a finds day. He was paid over £60,000 in compensation, and the Holderness Cross, regarded as a national treasure, is now in the Ashmolean Museum in Oxford.

The enthusiasm of the metal detectorists' response is overwhelming the original initiative. The arts minister, Alan Howarth, announced yesterday that the pilot projects, and the database logging finds, will both be expanded.

fields.headline: Families 'mirror' TV sitcom models
fields.trailText: The modern British family may not live up to the happy ideal of the 1950s sitcom, but the truth is closer to the fictionalised families on our television screens than most of us would care to admit, a psychologist claims.
fields.body:
The modern British family may not live up to the happy ideal of the 1950s sitcom, but the truth is closer to the fictionalised families on our television screens than most of us would care to admit, a psychologist claims.

While few households would confess to having any similarities with the couch potatoes in the Royle family or with the clean-cut Waltons, both are remarkably similar to many families in Britain, he says.

Even if your life may not revolve around a comfortable armchair on a Manchester council estate or, indeed, Walton Mountain, this does not mean that your closest family relationships are not mirrored in another popular sitcom.

Guy Fielding, a social psychologist at Oxford University, has argued that there are five basic family-types and all of these are accurately depicted by five of the best known television families.

As well as the Royles and the Waltons, typical British families are also mirrored in the cartoon the Simpsons, the Boswell clan in Bread, and in the Porter nuclear family featured in 2Point4 Children.

Dr Fielding said: "These are extreme family types but most families are sitting somewhere in the middle of that grid. None of the types are better or worse, they are just different."

The Royles, according to Dr Fielding, represent families aiming to strike a balance between the needs of the family and individuals, with strong ties to each other as well as to the daily routine. The Waltons, meanwhile, enjoy routine, always putting each other first while valuing loyalty.

For the Simpsons, who value independence, the needs of the individual always come first, while the disorganised Porter family in the BBC sitcom 2Point4 Children, are optimists who encourage debate within the home and thrive on activity and change.

For the Liverpudlian Boswells, though, family always comes first and they enjoy overcoming problems together - even if sometimes the demands are overwhelming.

Dr Fielding reached his conclusions while researching a guide for Abbey National to help stressed-out families manage their time better.

webTitle: OAPs will outnumber children in 8 years

fields.headline: OAPs will outnumber children in 8 years
fields.trailText: The number of pensioners in Britain will within eight years overtake the number of children, population specialists said yesterday in a graphic illustration of the fast rising importance of the "grey" lobby.
fields.body:
The number of pensioners in Britain will within eight years overtake the number of children, population specialists said yesterday in a graphic illustration of the fast rising importance of the "grey" lobby.

By 2040, one in four people will be a pensioner and barely half the population will be under 45, according to projections by the government actuary.

The figures come as ministers place a growing emphasis on policies for older people. A forthcoming report from the Whitehall performance and innovation unit is expected to call for appointment of a cabinet minister to oversee issues affecting the over-50s.

A study published alongside yesterday's population projections warned it was premature to assume the next generations of pensioners would be wealthier and healthier than their predecessors.

The projections are included in the latest issue of Population Trends, quarterly journal of the office for national statistics. Based on 1998 data, and allowing for the pending change in women's retirement age, they assume that the number of pensioners will pass the number of children under 16 in 2008. As the number of births continues to fall, it will be exceeded by the number of deaths after about 2028. Taking account of migration, the population will start to shrink from 2036.

The figures represent an increase on previous projections, based on 1996 data, because of a higher assumption of immigration and a slightly lower assumed death rate.

Whereas the previous projections assumed net immigration of 65,000 a year, the new set assumes 95,000. This includes a change, based on Home Office advice, from 5,000 to 20,000 in the annual number of asylum seekers approved for entry.

Overall, it is now assumed that the UK population will amount to 62.2m in 2021 - 1.4m more than was previously thought - of whom 12.2m will be pensioners, rising to almost 16m by 2040.

The study of the prospects for tomorrow's pensioners, by population specialists at the London School of Economics and King's College in London, compares the circumstances of people now in their early 80s and their late 60s with the likely profiles of "baby boom" generations now in their early 50s and late 30s.

Many people born in the 1960s boom would have suffered in the economic recessions of the 1970s and 1980s, the study warns.

 Teenage pregnancy figures worsened further in 1998, Population Trends reveals. The conception rate rose 2% from 45.9 per 1,000 women under 18 to 47.0, while the rate among girls aged 13-15 was unchanged at 8.9.

The figures, for England and Wales, cast more doubt on the chances of attaining the government's target, announced last year, of halving the teenage pregnancy rate by 2010. The highest teenage pregnancy rates were recorded in Lambeth, Southwark and Lewisham in south London (84.3 per 1,000).

webTitle: CPS clerk jailed for leaking files

fields.headline: CPS clerk jailed for leaking files
fields.trailText: A civil servant who leaked police and legal secrets to criminals was yesterday jailed for six years.
fields.body:
A civil servant who leaked police and legal secrets to criminals was yesterday jailed for six years.

Mark Herbert, 31, was told by the recorder of London, Judge Michael Hyam, that his actions could have put people at risk and deterred others from helping police.

Herbert, of Twickenham, south-west London, was jailed for six years for corruption and a total of three years concurrently for two offences of disclosing information.

The prosecution at the Old Bailey said Herbert, a low paid clerk at the crown prosecution service's headquarters in London, had passed on information from case files on members of the Adams family - named as one of Britain's most notorious criminal gangs - in return for money.

Herbert had denied the offences but was found guilty by a jury earlier this month. He was cleared of conspiracy to pervert the course of justice.

He copied and smuggled out case files and a list of 33 informers while employed on a team investigating the London-based Adamses at CPS headquarters in 1998.

The Adams family and their associates had formed themselves into a formidable and feared organisation "steeped in the highest levels of criminal activity", Victor Temple QC, prosecuting, told the court.

Herbert had moonlighted as a bouncer at Options nightclub in Kingston upon Thames, where he worked for a friend of an associate of the Adamses.

Herbert had told the court he did not want to get involved, but feared for his life.

webTitle: Bones from ice age yield DNA

fields.headline: Bones from ice age yield DNA
fields.trailText: Scientists have taken the "genetic fingerprint" of a neanderthal child buried in the northern Caucasus 30,000 years ago.
fields.body:
Scientists have taken the "genetic fingerprint" of a neanderthal child buried in the northern Caucasus 30,000 years ago.

It is only the second time scientists have been able to find DNA in the bones of the mysterious humans who occupied Europe through most of the ice age. The discovery, reported in Nature tomorrow, could settle arguments about the origins of homo sapiens. Modern humans and neanderthals did not interbreed when they encountered each other 50,000 years ago, and modern humans do not carry neanderthal genes, the researchers say.

The child was discovered in a limestone cave in 1987. William Goodwin of the human identification centre at Glasgow University was able to extract samples of mitochondrial DNA - only inherited from the mother - important in establishing relationships between individuals or groups.

The DNA tests show that modern humans and neanderthals diverged from a common ancestor more than 500,000 years ago.

webTitle: You may save a few quid on a car from abroad online, but don't hold your breath

fields.headline: You may save a few quid on a car from abroad online, but don't hold your breath
fields.standfirst: Logging on for a change of logbook could mean a wait
fields.trailText: Everyone now knows that if you buy a new car in Britain you are a mug. But then going abroad to get one is so much hassle: there's all that research to do, and miles of red tape to get through. And how do you say sunroof in Norwegian anyway?
fields.body:
Everyone now knows that if you buy a new car in Britain you are a mug. But then going abroad to get one is so much hassle: there's all that research to do, and miles of red tape to get through. And how do you say sunroof in Norwegian anyway?

So the arrival yesterday of www.carbusters.com which imports cars for you, could be a blessing. Launched by the Consumers' Association, which has been banging on about the "Great British car rip-off" for ages, the scheme has been developed and tested since last year's motor show.

And because it's all done online, there is no need to move from your workstation, let alone make any nasty ferry journeys.

Let's give it a go then. Here are some of this month's specials on the home page. An Alpha Romeo 156 2.0 TS is £15,143 - that's a saving of around £5,000 on the list price. But the delivery time is five months.

A BMW 3 series coupe 323 is £22,398.64 (what's the 64p for?), and a Mercedes CLK 230 at £27,898 is £3,692 cheaper than the list price but it will take seven months to turn up. They will have gone out of fashion by then.

How about something a little more modest? Like a Mondeo. Here we go, the Instant Quote Generator. Make: Ford. Range: what's this? no Mondeos. Just Fiestas, Pumas, and Focuses. Oh well, make it a Focus.

A 1.8 three-door Zetec is £10,538 and the delivery time is three months, which now sounds like no time at all. It may even have to go from Britain to Denmark or wherever and back again. (They can't say where the cars come from - but all are to UK specification)

A quick call to the local Ford dealer, Highbury Ford, in Islington, north London, reveals that the list price for this car is £13,000 but Pete might be able to do a special offer. How special? £1,000 off but it would have to be bought before the end of the week.

Pete's been on the phone for all of 20 seconds and he's already offering a £1,000 discount. It must be hard being a dealer at the moment. But that's still £1,500 more than Carbusters.com.

Next step: proceed to Extras Price, and suddenly you are hit with extra costs - a £10 fee for each quote and a £260 arrangement fee - and offered all sorts of extras like a climate pack (£513), a CD upgrade (£119), and a reflex pack (£263).

You then fill out a few details, and within a couple of minutes they've got back with a quote. The Focus is £10,538 plus the £260: £10,798 (of which 15% has to be put down as deposit) and still £1,200 less than Pete at Highbury Ford is offering.

There are drawbacks: that three month wait for a start. And you can't test drive the car, or trade in your old one. But even with desperate dealers around, it does seem to be the cheapest way to buy a new car. Apart from getting on that ferry yourself, of course.

webTitle: Farm must bear cost of church repairs

fields.headline: Farm must bear cost of church repairs
fields.trailText: A high court judge yesterday upheld an obscure law and ordered a Warwickshire couple to foot the £96,000 bill for repairing the chancel of their local church because their farm was a "rectorial property", making them "lay rectors".
fields.body:
A high court judge yesterday upheld an obscure law and ordered a Warwickshire couple to foot the £96,000 bill for repairing the chancel of their local church because their farm was a "rectorial property", making them "lay rectors".

With interest and legal costs Andrew Wallbank, 59, and his wife Gail, 52, face a total bill of more than £130,000. To meet the bill, Mr Wallbank said they would probably be forced to sell the farm.

The parochial church council of the parish of Aston Cantlow and Wilmcote with Billesley sued the Wallbanks, who own the tenented 176-acre Glebe Farm, Aston Cantlow, for the cost of repairs to the Church of St John the Baptist.

In a case watched closely by landowners throughout the country, the church claimed it was the duty of lay rectors to pay for repairs to the chancel.

At the high court in London yesterday Mr Justice Ferris ruled that the Wallbanks, who live at a sheep farm in Powys, central Wales, are liable to pay for the repairs under the provisions of the little heard of Chancel Repairs Act of 1932.

The judged dismissed the Wallbanks' argument that under the European Convention on human rights provisions that "every natural or legal person is entitled to peaceful enjoyment of his possessions" and that "no one shall be deprived of his possessions except in the public interest and subject to conditions provided for by law", exonerated them from liability.

The judge said the 1932 act had been subject to severe criticism. In 1985, the law commission called it "anachronistic and capricious" and recommended legislation under which the liability to repair the chancel would be extinguished after 10 years. The report had never been acted on. The judge made an order for payment by the couple for whatever sum an inquiry found due. They were refused leave to appeal but could renew the application in the appeal court.

The church had claimed that in order to ward off the claim the Wallbanks had to prove that it had been a custom in the parish "since time immemorial" that someone other than the lay rectors had paid for chancel repairs. With one exception, the lay rectors had always paid.

After the hearing Mr Wallbank, who married his wife in the church, said they had known there was something in the deeds relating to chancel repair liability but had not thought it was enforceable. "This was when my father-in-law bought the farm in 1970 but he was not unduly concerned about it. He always thought it was an old custom and regarded it as a purely voluntary arrangement.

"I think that as a result of this we shall be forced to sell the property to raise the money to pay. However, that in itself is going to be a problem with this liability hanging over it."

Lawrence Mortimer, a spokesman for the diocese of Coventry, said: "The parish had to bring this action because until the lay rectorship position was totally clarified, they couldn't get any financial support [for repairs] from any other agency. It's one of those cases where there are no good guys or bad guys. No one can blame the couple trying to sort it out without having to pay huge sums of money."

webTitle: Blair urged to halt 'intimidation of journalists'

fields.headline: Blair urged to halt 'intimidation of journalists'
fields.standfirst:
David Shayler site
Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair was told yesterday that attempts to force the Guardian and the Observer to surrender material concerning the former MI5 officer, David Shayler, amounted to "serious intimidation" of journalists acting in the public interest.
fields.body:
Tony Blair was told yesterday that attempts to force the Guardian and the Observer to surrender material concerning the former MI5 officer, David Shayler, amounted to "serious intimidation" of journalists acting in the public interest.

Bob Satchwell, director of the Society of Editors, urged the prime minister to "use your influence to lift these serious threats to the freedom of expression".

After a request from the special branch, a judge earlier this month ordered the newspapers to hand over any documents or emails relating to Mr Shayler, in particular his claim that MI6 was involved in a plot to assassinate Colonel Gadafy, the Libyan leader, in 1996.

The judge acknowledged that an email Mr Shayler sent to the Guardian contained nothing that had not been published before, and that material Mr Shayler gave the Observer had also been sent to Jack Straw, the home secretary.

The newspapers are challenging the orders.

In a letter to Mr Blair, Mr Satchwell, who represents national and regional newspaper and broadcasting editors, said the application by the special branch raised "important issues of freedom of the media and therefore of freedom of speech.

"In effect we believe the applications amount to a trawl for information which may or may not have bearing on future legal action which may never happen. As a result they amount to serious intimidation of journalists going about their legitimate duties in the public interest."

Mr Shayler is in exile in France. On Monday his girlfriend, Annie Machon, handed over a dossier to Scotland Yard accusing two MI5 agents of being involved in a conspiracy to kill Gadafy.

Mr Satchwell told the prime minister: "You and your colleagues take pride in the freedom of the media and free expression in Britain and would seek to set standards for others to follow.

"These actions set examples that less scrupulous governments in other countries will seize on as justification for intimidation of the media."

Legislation before parliament, including the freedom of information bill, the local government bill and the terrorism bill, had "profound implications" for the media".

Editors accepted that in exceptional circumstances, the "national interest" may require some restriction on the freedom of the media.

"Such restrictions should be applied only when they are absolutely necessary and after the most careful consideration of all the implications. In this instance we do not believe those conditions have been met."

webTitle: Bitter legacy of a term in prison

fields.headline: Bitter legacy of a term in prison
fields.standfirst:
Cannabis: Granny was dubbed a dealer

Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The war on drugs cost grandmother Ingrid Waters the chance to say a proper goodbye to her dying husband.
fields.body:
The war on drugs cost grandmother Ingrid Waters the chance to say a proper goodbye to her dying husband.

She was jailed for dealing in cannabis and the day after she was released from jail, her husband died from liver cancer.

She is now aged 56, and her biggest regret about her first and only criminal conviction is that she lost the chance to care for someone she was so close to. Mrs Waters, from Norwich, was jailed after being caught in 1989 with two ounces of cannabis, which she used to share with friends. She still smokes the "soft drug" 40 years after first trying it when she lived in Swansea.

The court sentenced her to 15 months' imprisonment but the judge suspended the bulk of her term.

Mrs Waters had just become a grandmother for the first time when she served two weeks in Holloway prison.

"I was absolutely terrified, because I hadn't met people from the criminal fraternity before. Because I was that little bit older they treated me as a little bit of a joke. They called me the old hippie."

Neighbours on the other side of the street had told police Mrs Waters was dealing on her kitchen table. "I said I was dealing cards for a bridge game for three other people."

Mrs Waters has raised four children who went on to become a manager for British Telecom, a PhD student in microbiology, a carpenter and an employment service worker.

fields.headline: Shoot-to-kill claims for European court
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Four cases alleging that the Royal Ulster Constabulary operated a shoot-to-kill policy and colluded with loyalist paramilitaries will go to the European court of human rights in Strasbourg next week.
fields.body:
Four cases alleging that the Royal Ulster Constabulary operated a shoot-to-kill policy and colluded with loyalist paramilitaries will go to the European court of human rights in Strasbourg next week.

The cases, which will coincide with the second week of the Saville inquiry into Bloody Sunday, will spotlight other shootings of Catholics between 1982 and 1992, the full facts of which have never come to light.

The families of 12 Catholics killed in four separate incidents claim the deaths violated article 2 of the European convention on human rights, the right to life.

When the Strasbourg court ruled in 1995 that the UK violated the right to life guarantee when the SAS shot dead three suspected IRA terrorists in Gibraltar, there were calls for the UK to pull out of the Council of Europe, which oversees the court and the convention.

The latest cases allege that the deaths of the 12 men were never properly investigated. Next Tuesday lawyers for the families will ask the court to declare the cases admissible.

Case one is brought by Hugh Jordan of Belfast over the death of his son, Pearce, 22, who was shot on the Falls Road by RUC officers in November, 1992, after they stopped his car.

No guns, ammunition, explosives, masks or gloves were found in the car, and he was unarmed.

There was no prosecution and the inquest was adjourned.

Mr Jordan also argues that the decision not to prosecute and the lack of an adequate investigation are further violations of the right to life.

He alleges that his son was denied a fair trial because the shooting was used as an alternative to arrest and trial.

In the second case, Jonathan McKerr of Lurgan, Armagh, claims his father, Gervaise, was intentionally deprived of his life.

He was killed with two passengers when 109 rounds were fired into his car by a five-man unit of the RUC in November 1982. All three men in the car were unarmed.

The facts about the killings remain in dispute despite a number of inquests, three criminal prosecutions and other legal proceedings.

The third case is brought by relatives of nine men shot dead during an IRA attack on Loughgall RUC station in Armagh in May, 1987.

One was a civilian unconnected with the IRA. The relatives claim the authorities planned and executed an ambush designed to result in the deaths of the men engaged in the attack.

They say the authorities, though they had advance notice of the attack, failed to take appropriate care in the control and organisation of the operation, and intended to kill anyone who entered the field of fire.

In the fourth case Mary Theresa Shanaghan alleges that her son, Patrick, 30, shot in August, 1991, by a masked gunman in Castlederg, was deprived of his right to life by RUC collusion with loyalist paramilitaries.

The Ulster Freedom Fighters, a paramilitary organisation, later claimed responsibility for the murder.

The RUC suspected that Mr Shanahan, an active member of Sinn Fein, was a member of the IRA.

Mrs Shanaghan claims that a few months before his death, the RUC warned her son that security force documentation, including a photographic montage of him, had fallen from an army vehicle and was in the hands of loyalist paramilitaries.

The UK government says the RUC told him the photographs had been lost but not that paramilitaries had them.

webTitle: Move to make punishment fit the crime

fields.headline: Move to make punishment fit the crime
fields.standfirst:
Drugs law inquiry: Threat of prison to cannabis users would be removed in reclassification of substances to reflect the risks

Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The Police Foundation inquiry into the drug laws is the first report for many years to recognise that the existing laws and penalties for possession of cannabis cause more harm than they prevent.
fields.body:
The Police Foundation inquiry into the drug laws is the first report for many years to recognise that the existing laws and penalties for possession of cannabis cause more harm than they prevent.

It is also among the first to conclude that tobacco and alcohol are more dangerous than cannabis, although it recognises that marijuana is not a harmless drug.

Opinion poll research by Mori for the inquiry, which was chaired by Lady Runciman, also demonstrates that the public sees the health related dangers of drugs as much more of a deterrent to their use than their illegality, fear of being caught and punished, availability or their price.

"All the evidence suggests to us that the law plays a minor part in deterring demand. It is of prime importance, therefore, that the law should accurately reflect relative harm in terms of current knowledge and prevention."

The report says the recommendations to remove the threat of prison hanging over cannabis users by making it a class C rather than a class B drug, and to reclassify ecstasy and LSD from class A to class B "will enable the law to reflect more accurately the risks attached to different drugs."

Far from sending the wrong signal to drug users, the Runciman report argues that this move would create a more accurate "hierarchy of harm" and would enhance the law's credibility and the support it can offer to education and prevention. It suggests that if they were classified drugs, alcohol would be class A, along with cocaine, heroin and methadone, and tobacco class B, with amphetamines, barbiturates and codeine.

"We conclude that the most dangerous message of all is the message that all drugs are equally dangerous. When young people know from their own experience that part of the message is either exaggerated or untrue, there is a serious risk that they will discount all of the rest. Recent evidence indicates there is a pressing need to refocus attention on the pre-eminent harm of heroin and cocaine."

Cannabis:
The report says that long-term use can cause physical and psychological harm, and intoxication can cause danger to others, but it states that cannabis is less harmful than alcohol and tobacco. The law bore more heavily on young people from minority communities in the inner cities, criminalised them to the detriment of their long-term future and therefore damaged police-community relations.

The report proposes that the threat of imprisonment for cannabis possession - a crime for which 78,000 people are convicted each year - should be replaced by a system of informal warnings, statutory cautions and fixed fines, with a maximum of £500 for persistent offenders. Fines should carry no criminal record. The main effect of reclassifying cannabis as a class C drug would be to remove the police power of arrest for possession, although the police would retain the power to stop and search for drugs.

The inquiry says the international evidence is that this will not lead to wider use of cannabis. It argues that only education and treatment can significantly reduce the demand for illegal drugs, not any deterrent effect of the law.

It also proposes that those who grow small amounts of cannabis for their own use should be fined or cautioned as for possession and no longer treated as traffickers. It proposes changes in the 1971 Misuse of Drugs Act to relax the law on allowing premises to be used for smoking cannabis, and the regulations on the therapeutic use of the drug for medical purposes. But it stops short of backing the creation of Dutch-style coffee shops where 15 varieties of cannabis can be bought.

Ecstasy and LSD:
After taking advice from the Royal College of Psychiatrists about the relative harm of controlled drugs, the inquiry proposes regrading ecstasy and LSD. It says they are considerably less dangerous than heroin and other opiates or cocaine. Although ecstasy deaths are highly publicised, they involve fewer than 10 people a year. Not all are directly related to ecstasy and they compare with an annual death toll of 2,100 a year from other illegal drugs.

Nor are they as addictive as other class A drugs. The report says that classifying them with heroin and cocaine can give the wrong message to regular ecstasy users that other class A drugs will cause them few ill effects. This change is also backed by the Association of Chief Police Officers.

Dealing:
The report proposes much tougher sanctions than the current law on the suppliers of all illegal drugs. It says that despite large increases in seizures there is no evidence that drugs have become harder to obtain or more expensive.

It suggests the creation of a new offence of dealing, which would allow the courts to sentence for persistent dealing in drugs rather than an isolated act of supply (for example to a group of friends). A new national confiscation agency would be set up to seize the drug-related assets of convicted traffickers.

New sentencing guidelines are needed to ensure the courts take account of aggravating factors such as involvement in an organised criminal group, use of violence or guns, supplying drugs to children or using them in dealing. It proposes harsh penalties for trafficking in class A drugs - 20 years imprisonment compared with the current 15-year maximum - and no change in the 14-year maximum for dealing class B, but the maximum for class C drugs should be raised from five to seven years.

Drug treatment services:
The report points to a serious shortage of drug treatment facilities, which receive 13% of the national drugs budget, compared with 62% for law enforcement. It wants to see a rapid shift of resources towards treatment, closer monitoring of private prescribing of controlled drugs to problem users, and new regulations enabling all controlled drugs to be prescribed in instalments to limit the scope for prescriptions to be abused. 'Better than being a beer beast'
Acid: The only problem is getting supplies

Tony Ross, 36, from Bath has been a self-employed carpenter for the last 15 years and throughout that time has taken drugs.

Last March he was convicted of possession and fined £1,200 after police in mid-Wales had caught him with three ecstasy tablets, a couple of grams of cannabis resin and 68 acid tablets named Mandala.

He was angry that the police were spending their time trying to catch people like him, who he said, were harming no one. "We were going to an all weekend rave up a mountain in woodland, four miles from the nearest residents."

He had been convicted twice before for drugs offences, for possession of cannabis and for growing cannabis plants.

He said the only problem drugs had caused him was getting a regular supply: "I've been self-employed for 15 years. I've only lost work through alcohol, just a few days when I've had a raging hangover.

"Alcohol is the worst thing I do without a shadow of a doubt. It's the only drug I have no control over and which brings out the monster in me."

Mr Ross said he had no other criminal offences.

"I believe the law should be there to protect the public from harm or danger. My drug consumption is not a harm or danger to anybody."

He said he contributed to society. "By locking me up they're making me into a criminal. As a result I can't travel to several countries abroad, such as the US."

Mr Ross organised dance parties. He believed his drug of choice was far better for him and society than alcohol. "At weekends we chose to take these drugs as part of our recreational time. On Saturday night we don't go out fighting, smashing windows, as a beer monster does."

'I was just having amazing fun'
Ecstasy: Jailed student still takes drugs
James Humphreys, 25, was a second year biology and geology student at Manchester University when police smashed down his door.

He served 15 months in jail for possession with intent to supply after being caught with 50 ecstasy pills and four ounces of cannabis resin.

During the raid Mr Humphreys telephoned the police believing those kicking down his door were thugs rather than the law.

"I'd never had that amount in the same place before," he said. "Obviously I wasn't a big time dealer. I was just having an amazing amount of fun with my friends in my second year of freedom after school."

He and his friends took it in turns to buy drugs for each other to share.

Mr Humphreys believes there is a phased legalisation of cannabis and that the laws are risible.

"The evidence is that there are millions of people using drugs and the amount of deaths and people screwed up is amazingly low.

"Morally controlling drugs in this way is a joke. It's the most out of control thing in the world."

After being released Mr Humphreys finished his degree and is now studying for a masters.

He still takes drugs, cannabis on a weekly basis and ecstasy on occasion. "I carried on in the same pattern and as you grow up you use a bit less."

Case studies by Vikram Dodd

Drugs and the Law: Report of the Independent Inquiry into the Misuse of Drugs Act 1971, available from the Police Foundation, 1, Glyn Street, London SE11 5RA. £20 plus £2.50 postage and packing.

webTitle: Switch to digital TV in six years 'unrealistic'

fields.headline: Switch to digital TV in six years 'unrealistic'
fields.standfirst: More about digital TV
fields.trailText: The government's blueprint for television is facing a crisis because viewers have no incentive to sign up for the array of new digital services, regulators said yesterday.
fields.body:
The government's blueprint for television is facing a crisis because viewers have no incentive to sign up for the array of new digital services, regulators said yesterday.

Chris Smith, the culture secretary, wants to start shutting down the old-style analogue television broadcasting service in 2006, but the head of the Independent Television Commission suggested that this was unrealistic.

About half the population is not interested in paying more for their television service, said Peter Rogers, the commission's chief executive, at the launch of its annual report. "I don't think we will get there unless we can find a way to persuade the people who are only interested in free-to-air channels to switch to digital. That is a very serious challenge and we are not yet on course."

The advent of colour television provided a strong incentive for viewers to switch from black and white, he said, yet the transition took three times as long as the government's planned conversion to digital. "Despite the huge pulling power of colour, that took over 20 years. Digital has not got the same appeal."

The main problem was that while broadcasters such as ONdigital and Sky had been successful in persuading viewers to sign up for pay-TV services by offering free set-top boxes, the vast bulk of viewers were not prepared to pay any more than the licence fee.

"Somehow or other a much greater appeal must be made for those viewers who are only interested in free-to-air television rather than multi-channel television," Mr Rogers said.

He said the set-top box give away was affecting the demand for new digital television sets, which allow viewers to pick up a digital signal from the free-to-air television channels without the need for extra boxes.

"There is no doubt that the integrated television market has taken a knock from free set-top boxes," Mr Rogers added.

A spokesman for the Department of Culture, Media and Sport said a review would be carried out next year. "Action may have to be taken at some stage. The question is whether we have reached that stage yet," he said.

The industry was producing a publicity campaign, and a leaflet explaining the options for consumers would be ready soon.

In its annual report, the commission said that Channel 5 had cut its reliance on "tacky" sex shows. It was, however, still scheduling too much adult content late at night.

The three-year-old channel was praised for improving the quality of its output in the past year, including news, documentaries, films and religious programmes.

The commission praised Channel 4 for its "freshness and innovation," with controversial drama Queer As Folk singled out, as well as the acclaimed series 1900 House.

The use of Ali G, one of the channel's most high-profile performers, for an alternative Christmas message, had "chimed well with the channel's remit". But Chris Evans's TFI Friday show was "no longer the attraction it once was," according to the report, and Channel 4's leisure and consumer shows "disappointingly" tended to concentrate on cookery, gardening, clothes and cars.

fields.headline: Times editor's 'leave' sparks rumours
fields.standfirst: Times editor's 'leave' sparks rumours
fields.trailText: The future of the editor of the Times was in doubt last night after it was announced that he is to take leave for a "few months".
fields.body:
The future of the editor of the Times was in doubt last night after it was announced that he is to take leave for a "few months".

Hours after it was revealed that Peter Stothard had left the newsroom to work on "special projects" for the Times, there were reports that Michael Ashcroft, the controversial Tory party treasurer who was the subject of a sustained campaign by the newspaper, would receive a peerage after all.

There was immediate speculation that the two events were linked.

Mr Stothard oversaw the newspaper's coverage of Mr Ashcroft's business dealings in Belize, which prompted the Tories' treasurer to sue. The legal action was heralded as the "libel trial of the century".

Later, after the unprecedented intervention of another national newspaper editor and the Times proprietor, Rupert Murdoch, a deal was struck and the legal action was dropped. The affair was seen to be extremely damaging to Mr Stothard.

While the Times's parent company, News International, insisted last night that Mr Stothard "will be back", newsroom staff expressed doubt that he would return.

The timing of the move, so close to the reports about Mr Ashcroft, was viewed as extraordinary. The Times was recently named newspaper of the year at the What The Papers Say press awards. Two weeks ago, the newspaper underwent a radical redesign with the launch of a tabloid section.

There was speculation within News International that Mr Murdoch wanted to reposition the newspaper in the run-up to the next election, and that this could not be achieved with Mr Stothard at the helm. Mr Stothard was said to have looked nervous when he read a statement to staff in his office at noon yesterday.

A spokeswoman for News International said Mr Stothard remained as editor but his current deputy, Ben Preston, would make day-to-day editorial decisions. Staff said Mr Preston would be acting editor in all but name. The Times's managing editor, George Brock, will take over Mr Stothard's managerial functions.

Mr Ashcroft and Mr Stothard both claimed victory last December when a negotiated libel settlement was announced, though few thought both would survive.

The Times insisted it had been vindicated as the Tory treasurer dropped the legal action and declared that he would move his business interests to Britain.

At the same time, the newspaper admitted it had no evidence that Mr Ashcroft had been involved in drug trafficking or money laundering.
