fields.headline: Rebuff for drugs reform
fields.standfirst:
Government rejects inquiry's call to reclassify cannabis, LSD and ecstasy

Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The prospect of Britain's drug laws being liberalised following the release of a landmark independent inquiry yesterday was immediately quashed by the government.
fields.body:
The prospect of Britain's drug laws being liberalised following the release of a landmark independent inquiry yesterday was immediately quashed by the government.

The Police Foundation report said that the penalties for possession of cannabis - among the harshest in Europe - do more damage than the drug itself and called for a reclassification of drug offences.

The government, however, rejected the proposals to reclassify cannabis, LSD and ecstasy. A Home Office statement declared: "The government has a clear and consistent view about the damage which drugs can cause to individuals, their families and the wider community, the link between drugs and crime - and the corresponding need to maintain firm controls."

The drugs tsar, Keith Hellawell, warned that reclassifying the drugs would do nothing to help the fight against illegal substances and said the proposed penalties for cannabis use were nothing more than a "slap on the wrist".

The Association of Chief Police Officers said it did not believe there was a need to relax the drug laws, while the Police Superintendents' Association of England and Wales warned that many of the measures would send out the wrong message to young people.

The report by a Police Foundation team which included two serving chief constables, Denis O'Connor of Surrey and John Hamilton of Fife, and which took two-and-a-half years to compile, called for the lifting of the threat of imprisonment faced by more than 70,000 people each year who are arrested for possessing cannabis, ecstasy and LSD, and for a cut in jail sentences for heroin and cocaine possession from a maximum of seven years to 12 months. The inquiry team discussed their findings with the home secretary, Jack Straw, last week.

Although Tony Blair and Mr Hellawell rejected the report's recommendations for reclassifying cannabis, ecstasy and LSD, it is widely believed that its findings will prove influential in Whitehall eventually, as Britain increasingly finds itself out of step with the trend across Europe towards more liberal drugs laws.

The inquiry, the most comprehensive since the Misuse of Drugs Act became law in 1971, marks a major establishment recognition that alcohol and tobacco are more harmful than cannabis and are so dangerous that they would be classified as class A and class B drugs if they were made illegal.

The halfway "depenalisation" policy of the inquiry also reflects the wide range of views on drugs among Britain's senior police officers, from the Metropolitan police commissioner, Sir John Stevens, who maintains a tough line, to the Cleveland police authority which has called for a debate on legalisation.

Lady Runciman, who chaired the Police Foundation inquiry, said that the most dangerous message about drugs was that they are equally dangerous: "When young people know that the advice they are given is either exaggerated or untrue in relation to less harmful drugs, there is a real risk they will discount everything else they are told about the most hazardous drugs, including heroin and cocaine."

She said the harm drugs caused was not reduced by imposing harsh penalties for possession and criminal records on young people whose occasional drug use could be tackled more effectively by more credible drugs education. Public opinion surveys showed that the health-related dangers of drugs were far more of a deterrent than the fear of being caught and punished.

While the report recommends downgrading ecstasy and LSD from class A status to class B, and cannabis from class B to class C, it stops far short of endorsing calls for legalisation.

"Change is needed but it must come in the middle ground between unrealistic legalisation and an unwinnable war on drugs," Lady Runciman said.

The report argues that for Britain's drug laws to remain credible they must reflect much more accurately the "hierarchy of harm" that actually exists. To class ecstasy as a drug as dangerous as heroin and cocaine was to give the wrong message about the relative harm of opiates to the half a million people who used ecstasy every weekend.

Mr Hellawell's dismissal of the proposed system of warnings and fixed penalties for cannabis possession was backed by Paul Betts, the father of Leah Betts who died after taking an ecstasy tablet at her 18th birthday party. He said the proposals would take Britain down the road followed in Amsterdam where cannabis can be smoked legally in coffee houses.

The Liberal Democrats criticised the government's "kneejerk" rejection of the proposals, but the Conservative drugs spokeswoman, Ann Winterton, supported the government's stance and urged ministers not to bow to pressure to liberalise legislation.

Despite the conventional wisdom that the police are already using a "softer touch" when dealing with cannabis, arrests for possession have risen in recent years, with the latest figures showing 113,154 drug offenders dealt with each year.

Key recommendations

 Cannabis to become class C drug, lifting threat of imprisonment for possession

 Ecstasy and LSD to become class B drugs, lifting threat of imprisonment for possession. £1,000 maximum fine

 Heroin and cocaine to remain class A drugs with penalties for trafficking increased to 20 years

Cultivation of small number of cannabis plants to be treated as possession

New offence of dealing which involves persistent pattern of trade

 Possession of cannabis not to be arrestable offence but police to retain stop and search powers

 Educational materials about main drugs and risks of drug-driving to be made available at entertainment venues

 National confiscation agency to improve ineffective system of seizing drug traffickers' assets

webTitle: BBC braced for row over series on intelligence war in Ulster

fields.headline: BBC braced for row over series on intelligence war in Ulster
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The BBC is preparing for a wave of political controversy over a sensitive new documentary series on Northern Ireland.
fields.body:
The BBC is preparing for a wave of political controversy over a sensitive new documentary series on Northern Ireland.

It revealed yesterday that it is to screen a three-part series focusing how British military and intelligence forces waged war against the IRA. Revelations from security service officers, military commanders and other key figures are likely to provoke renewed debate on the alleged "shoot to kill" policy effectively adopted by British forces during the troubles.

The BBC2 series will be fronted by Peter Taylor, who has a long track record of producing authoritative programmes on Northern Ireland, and produced by Sam Collyns. The pair worked together on two previous series, Provos and Loyalists.

"Shoot to kill is a theme that runs right through," Taylor said yesterday.

For the new series, Taylor interviewed Whitehall officials, security service sources and IRA figures.

The result shows, Taylor said, how both sides eventually concluded that neither could win the military war, and how British policy changed in order to bring the IRA into the political process. "The real war against the IRA was the intelligence war," he said.

The series was developed with the cooperation of No 10, the Northern Ireland Office and the Ministry of Defence. The content of the programmes is seen as so sensitive that it is being kept under wraps until near the transmission date in May, coinciding with the deadline for completion of decommissioning.

 At the launch of the spring and summer season of BBC2 programmes yesterday, the channel revealed that it is heading into a timewarp as it brings back the decade that fashion forgot for a series of 1970s nights.

The channel is reviving programmes, films, and even between-show links for its I Love the 1970s nights, a series of 10 weekly themed evenings. Films will include Get Carter and Love Story.

fields.headline: 'Babes in wood' remand
fields.trailText: Ronald Jebson, 61, appeared before Brent magistrates yesterday accused of the "babes in the wood" murders of two children 30 years ago.
fields.body:
Ronald Jebson, 61, appeared before Brent magistrates yesterday accused of the "babes in the wood" murders of two children 30 years ago.

Susan Blatchford, 11, and Gary Hanlon, 13, disappeared from their homes in Enfield, north London, in March 1970. Their decomposed bodies were found in Epping Forest 11 weeks later

The coroner at their inquest recorded an open verdict because scientific tests 30 years ago could not tell if the pair had died from foul play or exposure.

But the case was reopened four years ago and took a fresh twist last year when the body of Susan was exhumed for further tests.

The pair went missing after Susan called at Gary's home and they went for a walk. Police interviewed nearly 15,000 people.

Gary's body was cremated but police hoped for a breakthrough following tests carried out on Susan's remains after securing the agreement of her family.

Jebson was remanded in custody until April 11.

webTitle: Lost MI6 laptop contained training notes for agents

fields.headline: Lost MI6 laptop contained training notes for agents
fields.trailText: An MI6 laptop computer that went missing contained training material for secret agents, the Foreign Office said yesterday.
fields.body:
An MI6 laptop computer that went missing contained training material for secret agents, the Foreign Office said yesterday.

The computer was left in a taxi on March 3 by an MI6 officer who had allegedly been drinking at a tapas bar near the headquarters of the Secret Intelligence Service in central London.

Richard Dearlove, chief of MI6, informed Robin Cook about the loss. The laptop was recovered 13 days later after MI6 placed an advertisement in the Evening Standard newspaper offering a "substantial" reward, saying it contained vital PhD research notes.

The laptop was taken a day before an MI5 officer had his computer stolen at Paddington station, west London.

A Foreign Office spokeswoman said it was "not established that there was any likely damage to national security."

MI6 and MI5 have said they were reviewing security procedures.

fields.headline: Big fall in meningitis cases
fields.standfirst: National Meningitis Trust
fields.trailText: Cases of meningitis C, the disease which kills about 150 people a year, dropped by three-quarters this winter among babies and young people who were the first to be immunised with a new vaccine, the Department of Health announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Cases of meningitis C, the disease which kills about 150 people a year, dropped by three-quarters this winter among babies and young people who were the first to be immunised with a new vaccine, the Department of Health announced yesterday.

Yvette Cooper, minister for public health, and the chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson, were delighted with the early results, which they hope will encourage all parents to have their children vaccinated.

"This new vaccine puts the UK in the forefront of tackling this devastating disease," said Ms Cooper. "I hope that all parents take up the chance to have their children protected when their invitations arrive."

Take-up has been high, with most parents choosing to have their children vaccinated against a strain of one of the most feared childhood diseases, even though immunisation does not protect from meningitis B, its more common form.

The impact of the vaccination programme has been immediately apparent. Among 15- to 17-year-olds there were 16 cases of confirmed meningoccocal group C disease between the beginning of December and the middle of March, compared with the 70 cases that would have been expected - a drop of 77%.

Among babies under one, there would have been 37 cases expected before vaccination between the beginning of January and mid-March, but 10 were confirmed, amounting to a reduction of 73%.

The drop in the immunised groups has been against the trend of recent years. In other age groups, meningitis C cases - which traditionally peak in the winter - have continued to rise.

"Doctors, pharmacists and nurses in the NHS and in primary care in particular are to be congratulated for the hard work they have done to ensure that as many children and young people as possible are immunised," Prof Donaldson said.

The two groups immunised so far were those at highest risk. Figures are not expected to be so dramatic among other children. All those under 18 are supposed to have been vaccinated by the end of this year.

There were 1,530 cases of meningitis C in 1998, with 150 deaths. These cases amounted to about 40% of total meningitis cases, with the rest made up of the B strain. Although researchers are working on meningitis B, it is thought a vaccine is a long way off.

Public health officials will be relieved at the take-up of the meningitis C vaccine, which appears to be 80-95% among 15- to 17-year-olds and higher among babies, who receive the vaccine with their routine injections in the early months of life.

Public anxiety about the measles, mumps and rubella vaccinations does not seem to have manifested itself in a reluctance to embrace the new vaccination.

fields.headline: Unhappy ever after
fields.trailText: As Al Read never failed to point out, there was enough said at our Edie's wedding. We can only make a lurid guess at what was said as - a bit of luck for Edie this - Paul Watson was not invited.
fields.body:
As Al Read never failed to point out, there was enough said at our Edie's wedding. We can only make a lurid guess at what was said as - a bit of luck for Edie this - Paul Watson was not invited.

Watson, who made A Wedding In The Family (Cutting Edge, Channel 4), is a television original, who usually comes trailing clouds of controversy. A quarter of a century ago The Family, which he filmed over three months, blew all the usual documentary rules to smithereens. There was a wedding in that series too, when Gary, jinking like an antelope pursued by lionesses, was pinned down to a definite date by his fiancée and her mother, Margaret. The poor beast's expiring cry was "I don't feel up to it at the moment!"

Margaret was the hub, heart and powerhouse of The Family, and Sue in A Wedding In The Family is very like her. Sue pumped blood into the film. She made it come alive. Watson seems to empathise well with spirited, extrovert, reckless women who, in another life, would have been doing the can-can at the Folies-Bergère.

Quite early in the proceedings Sue shot a sidelong glance at Watson and said "This is what the men were frightened of, you know. Your wheedling things out of them." Watson, who is often seen, perhaps reflected in a mirror, or heard off-camera in his own films, spoke up in defence of wheedling. "This is a film about relationships at the end of the twentieth century, people going through a marriage, and all round them there are these..." "things falling apart" said Sue.

Though, on the face of it, things seemed to be coming together. Steve's first wife, Heather, and his second, Sue, were invited to the wedding but Sue didn't want to go and Steve thought it would be awkward too. In the event she went, her eyes shaded by one of those obliterating basins peculiar to weddings ("No one can see what I'm thinking.")

The sonorous service was intercut with Sue's fixed face, or the pain and chaos of the traffic accidents for which Steve is always on call as a doctor. Watson's warmth has the same effect on some people as central heating on antiques. The glue softens and, with a little push, ("You sleep on your own, Sue?" "You're obviously not happy") the wardrobe will collapse, shaking the house. And Sue did break down in tears.

It was like walking through discarded rakes in long grass, you never knew when the next one would rise up. It turned out that the groom, like Jake the plumber, had been married before. According to Sue, Steve was an unfaithful husband ("While he was panting and huffing and saying 'Oh, Sue!' he was saying it to all the others as well") though a dedicated doctor. We overheard him on the phone, "Is she taking any pain killers for this?" She certainly is. "You are now", said Watson to Sue, "seeking some solace in drinking, aren't you?"

The groom's parents were faithful, devoted and discreet. Models of matrimony but sahara for the camera.

The bride, a nurse at Harefield, and the groom, a £70,000-a-year whizz kid, were shiningly in love. She said "When I look into his eyes, everything I feel for him is reflected straight back at me." Statistically, their marriage has a one in two chance of success.

"Give it a rest, boy," said the bride's grandmother to Watson, "and have some lunch."

Ape-Man (BBC2) ended with the disappearance of Neanderthals from Europe, probably irritated by the incessant bangs, flashes and background music prevailing at the time. Fossil evidence suggests there may have been limited interbreeding. Professor Jan Simek of the University of Tennessee said: "There are Neanderthal-like characteristics that we still see in modern populations. My father, for example," (and he produced a snap of that hapless man) "was a heavy-set, short-limbed individual. who may or may not have had Neanderthal genes in him."

Simek Sr peered chunkily out of the picture. What a novel and interesting pastime. Whom do we know with robust build, heavy brow ridges, formidable strength and sturdy, little legs, which, bless him, don't quite reach the floor? Apart from John Prescott, obviously.

The groom's parents were faithful, devoted and discreet. Models of matrimony but sahara for the camera. The bride, a nurse at Harefield, and the groom, a £70,000-a-year whizz kid, were shiningly in love. She said "When I look into his eyes, everything I feel for him is reflected straight back at me." Statistically, their marriage has a one in two chance of success. "Give it a rest, boy," said the bride's grandmother to Watson, "and have some lunch." Ape-Man (BBC2) ended with the disappearance of Neanderthals from Europe, probably irritated by the incessant bangs, flashes and background music prevailing at the time. Fossil evidence suggests there may have been limited interbreeding. Professor Jan Simek of the University of Tennessee said: "There are Neanderthal-like characteristics that we still see in modern populations. My father, for example," (and he produced a snap of that hapless man) "was a heavy-set, short-limbed individual. who may or may not have had Neanderthal genes in him." Simek Sr peered chunkily out of the picture. What a novel and interesting pastime. Whom do we know with robust build, heavy brow ridges, formidable strength and sturdy, little legs, which, bless him, don't quite reach the floor? Apart from John Prescott, obviously.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Gabrielle Walker gets down to life's basics in This Snowball Earth (9.00pm, Radio 4). She takes us back 700 million years to the Precambrian age, when an air temperature of minus 50 degrees froze sea water down to 3,000 feet. However, scientists think they have worked out how animal life emerged from this freeze. Single-cell species absorbed excess carbon dioxide and the resulting thaw enabled more complex creatures to evolve. Bingo. In no time (well, 150 million years) we got the Cambrian explosion.

fields.headline: Off the record
fields.standfirst: EastEnders - Coronation Street - The Bill. Every great TV show has one vital ingredient - a brilliant theme tune. But, as  Belinda Archer  discovers, they're often commissioned as an afterthought. And don't even ask about the money...
fields.trailText: Da da da da da, de da. Da da da da da, da da da, de da da.... Sounds familiar? You're right: it's the theme tune to EastEnders, that infinitely recognisable track which drones out into the nation's living rooms three times a week (plus the Sunday omnibus).
fields.body:
Da da da da da, de da. Da da da da da, da da da, de da da.... Sounds familiar? You're right: it's the theme tune to EastEnders, that infinitely recognisable track which drones out into the nation's living rooms three times a week (plus the Sunday omnibus).

Without it, of course, EastEnders wouldn't be EastEnders. The homely strains of the opening bars and the thumping drumbeats at the end of each climactic episode add much to the general deliciousness of the Albert Square experience. Imagine Corrie, too, without its familiar old-style jazz intro, or The Bill, or the Nine O'Clock News without its jangly, upbeat signature tune.

Theme tunes and incidental music can play a crucial role on TV, but despite this, they often seem to be commissioned in a rather hit-and-miss, last-minute way, and the composers are paid surprisingly low sums.

Responsibility usually falls to the producer of each programme to sort out a title track and any incidental music. Depending on budget and time, he or she either commissions a known composer, goes to a music library which supplies off the peg ready-made pieces, or else uses a known song by a famous pop group or musician.

The easiest and most common option is to use music libraries, largely because they are time-saving and usually the least expensive. Richard Preston, an independent music producer who worked with composer Simon Fisher Turner on the tune to the recent BBC drama, Nature Boy, explains: "Libraries commission composers to write pieces of music to specific briefs, such as 'funky with a contemporary twist', or 'millennial', and the end-result is a CD that sits on their shelves. A TV producer will then come along, having just completed, say, a documentary on prisons, and will ask for something 'dark and orchestral'. The library will be able to pull something off for them straight away."

ITV's unforgettable News At Ten intro, by Johnny Pearson (who also did All Creatures Great And Small), is a classic case of a music library piece. The same process was used to score The Bill, Grandstand and This Is Your Life.

Using well known existing tracks can be a frustrating route for most smaller producers, involving endless amounts of time (which they normally don't have) and often vast portions of cash as well as difficult negotations with picky rock-stars via their record labels.

Major broadcasters like the BBC tend to commission a lot of original stuff, directly approaching specific composers with briefs such as, in the case of EastEnders, "something that will bring people in from the kitchen and the garden".

Mike Cobb, the head of music at BBC Worldwide, comments: "The most popular option here is to commission music, especially for natural history programmes or entertainment or dramas, which rely on atmosphere. We are the biggest commissioner of original music in the UK and there is a rough calculation that we actually commission two new composers every day for either TV or radio."

While the process of commissioning TV music is rather complex and seat-of-the-pants, the money that is paid out varies enormously. Known composers can command fairly hefty up-front fees, depending on their perceived worth plus the amount of music required. Current hot names, such as Jim Parker who wrote the theme to the BBC's period drama Tom Jones and the intros to Ground Force and Changing Rooms, as well as Murray Gold, who composed the carnival-style title track to Channel 4's Queer As Folk, can command up to around £20,000 for all the music to a six-part drama series, for example. Unknown writers with no track record have to settle for far less. One newcomer recently did the theme and all the incidental music for an entire Channel 4 gardening series for a bargain £2,000. Another composed the title track to Channel 4's The 11 O'Clock Show for just £3,500, and many musicians will even do it for free in a bid to get known.

The biggest way that composers make their money is through repeat fees, which are calculated on a per-minute basis. A piece of music on BBC1, for example, generates a royalty of £48 per minute, while BBC2 pays £46. Channel 4 pays out just £22, but ITV pays a more generous £86, so if a show is long-running or even sold abroad, cash can come rolling in. But still, the amounts generated are not that huge. Simon May, who composed the EastEnders tune, for instance, estimates he only makes around £10,000 per year out of it. "I'd rather I had a pound for every time I'm asked how much I make out of it than the money I do get", he says.

Writing music for TV idents can pay better. Industry folklore tells of how the bloke who composed the old jingle for Thames TV's logo used to sit at home and watch himself making money, but the overall level of pay seems to reflect how music on TV is generally rather undervalued. Composers and agents complain it is often the last thing that is thought of by the TV production company, when time is running out and money is tight.

As Becky Bentham, production manager at Air-Edel, a major composer agents, sums up: "People are still really considering it an after-thought rather than building it into the up-front production costs, which is sad given how important it is. Music can't make a bad production good, but it can make a good one fantastic."

webTitle: Who's up in front of the judge

fields.headline: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: So, farewell then Charlie Sheen, absolutely, positively, definitely never to appear in this column again, having being given early release from his probation, with the judge claiming he'd made "an enormous turnaround in your life and career".
fields.body:
So, farewell then Charlie Sheen, absolutely, positively, definitely never to appear in this column again, having being given early release from his probation, with the judge claiming he'd made "an enormous turnaround in your life and career".

Since when? Well, partly since snagging the lead role in Spin City, and partly since (apparently) proving he was off drugs and drink, and no longer posed a threat to himself (or, for that matter, his ex-girlfriend, whose battery in 1996 inspired his original conviction). Presumably wiping a tear from his eye, Judge Lawrence Mira told Hollywood's onetime biggest recidivist that while "everyone has their demons... I believe you're winning the battle", before allowing Sheen to walk free with his Fourth Amendment rights back intact.

Deputy DA Martin Herscovitz was, however, less generous after hearing his opposition to ending the probation had been ignored, remarking that "when someone has addiction problems, they are lifelong problems". Not, of course, that the re-ascendant Mr Sheen cared, gleefully telling reporters that "it's nice to have a second chance". Charlie, we're going to miss you (maybe)....

So, after all that, thank God for hip-hop crimewaves DMX and Ol' Dirty Bastard, both of whom wandered back into legal grief last week. For his part, Bastard (real name Russel Jones) is now en route to Chino State Prison for a psychiatric evaluation at the behest of LA prosecutors after - déjà vu, anyone? - violating probation on drugs and battery charges. Meanwhile, the hardest man in rap, DMX (aka Earl Simmons) was notable by his absence this week at Cheektowga Court, New York State, despite being scheduled to appear on narcotics charges. Cue a rather half-hearted manhunt (bearing in mind he's on tour, he wasn't what you'd call hard to find); predictably, he's now due back in court next month...

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText:
World Series Of Poker
9pm, Discovery
fields.body:
World Series Of Poker
9pm, Discovery

Raise your bets or show your cards - it's the high-point of the poker player's year. Each May, hundreds of professional and semi-professional players flock the Bingo room of Binion's Horseshoe casino in Las Vegas, for the annual World Series Of Poker. It's a gruelling competition in which 200 or so people pay a $10,000 entry fee and play poker until every last dollar is in one person's hands. This year, the big guns are knocked early, resulting in a tableful of amateurs, including, to the other finalists' barely concealed distaste, a woman.
Kathy Sweeney

Mrs Miniver
(William Wyler, 1942)
3pm, TCM

Stirring wartime drama, rousing Little England and more importantly the US. Churchill thought it "more valuable than the combined efforts of six divisions". Greer Garson won an Oscar as the eponymous heroine, disarming a German airman who has the temerity to land in her nice village garden; hubby Walter Pidgeon forsakes the dahlias to lend a hand at Dunkirk, and it ends with a sermon in the ruins of a bombed church.

Starship Troopers
(Paul Verhoeven, 1997)
10pm, Sky Premier

This is a very clever updating of 50s sci-fi B-movies. Verhoeven drops Robocop's armour-plated irony in favour of a deadpan picture of a fascist futureworld in which youngsters happily go to war. But the film's real attraction is the violence: pretty kids fighting giant bugs, and despite the state-of-the-art weaponry, this is medieval combat, with screenfuls of lopped off limbs.

Predator 2
(Stephen Hopkins, 1990)
11.35pm, Sky Movie Max

The sequel to Arnie Schwarzenegger's rumble in the jungle with a savage, invisible, eight-feet-tall alien switches the venue to Los Angeles: it's a real jungle out there. Danny Glover is one of LAPD's finest undercover men, hunting the hordes of South American drug dealers infesting the streets - so the predator isn't such a bad trip, except that Gary Busey's Feds want it captured alive (strong Alien influences here). More violent, nasty and tense than the original.

fields.headline: What milkmen watch on TV
fields.trailText: Keith Davis: "The last thing I watched was probably that thing with Grant Mitchell in it - that Hero Of The Hour. I thought it was terrible. The mother-in-law still comes round to watch TV sometimes, and all she likes is EastEnders. I can't stand it. All that shouting, people don't walk around shouting at each other in real life, do they?"
fields.body:
Keith Davis: "The last thing I watched was probably that thing with Grant Mitchell in it - that Hero Of The Hour. I thought it was terrible. The mother-in-law still comes round to watch TV sometimes, and all she likes is EastEnders. I can't stand it. All that shouting, people don't walk around shouting at each other in real life, do they?"

Lionel Foulks: "Porridge is on at the moment, I noticed, and I love that. I think Ronnie Barker's really got style, true comic timing, a pro. It still makes me laugh all these years on. I did used to like those sorts of programmes, I think it's when we were best at doing TV. To The Manor Born, The Sweeney, The Good Life, Butterflies - I watched them when I was a student. Now it's Do It Yourself TV, as if everyone was brought up by robots and never told how things work. Person I don't like on TV? Ainsley Harriot. What a plonker."

Mario Vollier: "I'm addicted to Goodness Gracious Me and all the stuff on Friday night. I love it, rather stay in than go to the pub now. Get a curry and relax. I miss the morning stuff, my girlfriend tells me all about it, she's obsessed with Richard And Judy. She wants to get On Digital too, but I think she'd lose her brain if she watched any more. Loves all the soaps, even Emmerdale Farm. She loves the hunky guys - Steve Owen, the Naked Chef man."

Kevin Benn: "In the 70s you had milkmen on TV all the time, it was commonplace, a comedy classic. I think people don't think we exist anymore. I'd like to do some sort of thing where they follow me round on my float and see what bastards I have to deal with, and how easy it is to cut your hand on the bottles and rip your fingers up. People think we're all jolly but we can be a bunch of grumpy bastards too. I'd love to be on telly, me. I've been to see the Generation Game being recorded, with Bruce Forsyth, yes, nearest I've got. He told blue jokes. I thought he got away with it quite well."

 Sin Pattenden spoke to milkmen around Twickenham, Middlesex

fields.headline: Livingstone's Tube plan 'naive'
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone's proposal to raise the finances to rebuild London Underground with a public bond offering could cost the taxpayer an extra £2.3bn, according to a report published today by Labour peer David Currie.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone's proposal to raise the finances to rebuild London Underground with a public bond offering could cost the taxpayer an extra £2.3bn, according to a report published today by Labour peer David Currie.

Lord Currie argues that the government's favoured option, a public private partnership (PPP), would be by far the most efficient mechanism for repairing the Tube's decaying infrastructure, delivering savings of about 20% on Mr Livingstone's "naive" proposal.

With transport one of the central issues of the London mayoral campaign, Lord Currie's report is likely to be seized on by Mr Livingstone's opponents in their attempts to erode his lead in the run up to the May 6 election.

Under plans announced in March 1998, the government is aiming to establish three PPPs, whereby the public sector retains ownership of the Underground's assets and delivers services to customers, while the private sector takes responsibility for maintaining and renewing infrastructure.

Mr Livingstone argues that the cheapest way of meeting the backlog of investment - estimated at £1.2bn - is to issue public bonds. A key advantage of this option is that the government's status as a borrower at negligible risk of default allows it to raise the finances at a much lower interest rate than the private sector.

Lord Currie, a professor of economics at London Business School, says this claim is misguided. He said: "Although the public sector can borrow at a notionally lower rate than the private sector, this is because, unlike the private shareholders, taxpayers are not compensated for the risk they bear. In other words, properly evaluated, the cost of capital in the public and private sectors is the same if the underlying project is the same."

Lord Currie says the PPP option will be more efficient for a number of reasons, including the existence of stronger incentives in the private sector, the greater ease with which the people involved can be monitored and the existence of clear bottom line.

"The empirical evidence we presented from the experiences of privatisation, contracting out and the [private finance initiative] backs this view," says Lord Currie's report. "In the case of LU, savings from the introduction of the private sector through the PPP are likely to be around 20%, equating to a saving of over £2.3bn over the bond financing option."

 The shortlist for one of the three contracts for operating the sub-surface tube lines was announced by LU yesterday. It comprises three consortiums: Linc (Bombardier Prorail, John Mowlem & Co, Fluor Daniel, Alacatel and Anglian Water); Metronet (Adtranz, WS Atkins, Balfour Beatty, Seeboard and Thames Water); Bechtel/Halcrow, Amey and Jarvis.

webTitle: Councillors may have record allowances capped

fields.headline: Councillors may have record allowances capped
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Wales: special report
fields.trailText: Members of the Welsh assembly will today unite in condemning the record breaking allowances that have been given to leading councillors on Cardiff county council.
fields.body:
Members of the Welsh assembly will today unite in condemning the record breaking allowances that have been given to leading councillors on Cardiff county council.

The Tory-sponsored debate, which is expected to draw cross party support, comes as the Welsh local government minister, Peter Law, is preparing to take action to cap payments that have caused embarrassment and division among Labour party members in the Welsh capital.

Eight Cardiff Labour councillors were recently suspended from the party for opposing the controversial £58,000 allowances of council leader Russell Goodway, before being reinstated on appeal to the Welsh Labour executive. The increased allowances, making Mr Goodway the highest paid council leader in Britain, were recommended in a report that measured the jobs of Cardiff councillors against similar jobs in the private sector.

The huge increases flew in the face of recommendations contained in separate reports by the Welsh office and the Welsh local government association which suggested linking allowances to the average Welsh wage.

Of the 22 councils in Wales only Cardiff failed to take up those recommendations.

Mr Law, who has the power to cap the Cardiff allowances under the 1989 local government and housing act, has been urging Mr Goodway and other senior Cardiff councillors to rethink.

fields.headline: Yesterday day, bad day
fields.trailText: Happy days
fields.body:
Happy days

Cherie Blair was voted Britain's number one mum, beating off the late Princess Diana and Posh Spice Victoria Beckham. Mrs Blair, who is expecting her fourth child, was the resounding choice in a survey by Mothercare. Tony Blair made it a family affair by being voted the best role-model father.

Bad day

Former prime minister John Major underwent a successful back operation after suffering severe pain for some time. Some observers unkindly jumped to the conclusion the lumbar malaise had come from his years being stabbed in the back by his own party. A statement from his office said the oeration was "to correct a prolapsed disc".

Today

Commons: International development questions. PM's questions. Child support, pensions and social security bill, remaining stages. Lords: Debate on changes on tax rules for national museums and galleries.

webTitle: Labour accused of secrecy over special envoys

fields.headline: Labour accused of secrecy over special envoys
fields.trailText: Tony Blair was accused last night of establishing an American style of foreign policy after it emerged that the government has appointed three overseas envoys who are unaccountable to parliament.
fields.body:
Tony Blair was accused last night of establishing an American style of foreign policy after it emerged that the government has appointed three overseas envoys who are unaccountable to parliament.

Downing Street has already admitted - in the face of a series of parliamentary questions - that the multi-millionaire music impresario Lord Levy has been acting as the prime minister's personal envoy to the Middle East.

But amid a growing row over his role, it emerged last night that the Labour peers, Lord Paul and Lord Ahmed, have also been used by the government as envoys to India and Pakistan.

Lord Paul, one of Britain's richest Asian businessmen, who was born in India, has been used to pass messages between London and New Delhi where he is a highly respected figure. His role has been replicated across the border in Pakistan by Lord Ahmed who carries weight in Islamabad as a Muslim as he was born in Kashmir.

One Labour source said that the two peers had played an important role in restoring Britain's relations with India and Pakistan, which were strained over the testing of nuclear weapons by the two regional superpowers. "Lord Paul and Lord Ahmed have played key roles in passing messages back and forth," the source said. "It is a sensible use of excellent British sources."

But the Tories and Liberal Democrats last night criticised the use of the envoys, claiming that the prime minister has been secretive about their appointments and warning that they are unaccountable to parliament.

The shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, who will today table a series of parliamentary questions about the envoys, said: "How many people are swanning round the world, having doors opened for them in foreign capitals on account of being mates with Tony Blair?"

Menzies Campbell, the Lib Dem foreign affairs spokesman, said: "This all smacks of the White House rather than No 10. Britain is different because parliamentary accountability lies at the heart of our system."

The Tories and Lib Dems are angry about the envoys because they have been forced to drag details about Lord Levy out of the government.

Downing Street initially denied that Lord Levy, who bankrolled the prime minister's office before the election, was acting as his envoy to the Middle East. It was only when the Lib Dems and the Tories fired off a series of questions to Downing Street, the Foreign Office and the Ministry of Defence that his wide-ranging role was disclosed.

Mr Blair first outlined Lord Levy's role last month when he said that he paid nine visits to the Middle East last year, outstripping the foreign secretary Robin Cook.

In his most recent trip last month, Lord Levy visited Lebanon and Syria where he is said to have built up a rapport with the one-time pariah, President Assad.

The prime minister appeared to play down Lord Levy's visits to Israel, where he is a prominent charity fund-raiser and a confidante of leading members of the Labour party. Mr Blair said that Lord Levy only visited Israel in a personal capacity where he passed on message on his behalf.

This opaque answer came back to haunt the prime minister this week when the Ministry of Defence admitted that Lord Levy had advised the chief of the defence staff during a visit to Israel last September.

Lord Paul and Lord Ahmed are understood to have played less high profile roles in India and Pakistan.

Lord Ahmed, who insisted last night that he had no official capacity in his trips to Pakistan, said that his background was helpful. "When I visit countries like Iran and Pakistan and say that I am British and Muslim the barriers break down. People are very open and talkative."

Blairites say that the prime minister's use of envoys is typical of his personalised style of government. One admirer said: "Tony Blair is not really interested in the process of government. He's only really interested in results and if envoys help him, so be it."

Prime ministers have frequently bypassed the Foreign Office in the past. Margaret Thatcher was so distrustful of the FO that she ran much of her foreign policy through Sir Charles Powell, a diplomatic high flier who transferred his loyalties to Downing Street.

James Callaghan appointed his son-in-law Peter Jay as Britain's ambassador to Washington, to "get in with the Georgian mafia surrounding President Carter", as his foreign secretary David Owen puts it.

However, the Blairite envoys do not mark a breach in relations with the Foreign Office. Denis MacShane, a ministerial aide in the foreign office, said that Lord Levy had "supplemented traditional diplomacy".

Lord Levy

Tony Blair's chief fund-raiser and sometime tennis partner. The multi-millionaire music impresario, who launched Chris Rea and Alvin Stardust, raised tens of millions of pounds for the controversial "blind trust" which funded the prime minister's office before the general election.

Born in London's East End, Lord Levy, 53, is credited with persuading leading members of Britain's Jewish commununity to abandon their support for the Tories in favour of New Labour. As a leading patron of charities in Israel, Lord Levy has a high profile in the Middle East which has been harnessed by the prime minister who appointed him as his envoy to the region last year.

Lord Paul

Born in India, Lord Paul, 69, is regarded as the standard bearer for British-Asian businessmen. He founded the £420m Caparo steel and engineering group in 1968 with £5,000 soon after moving to Britain. A passionate supporter of Labour for the past 25 years, Lord Paul was nominated to the House of Lords by Tony Blair in 1996. As a graduate of Punjab university, Lord Paul is highly respected in political and industrial circles in India. After a recent hiccup in Anglo-India relations, Lord Paul is seen as the ideal candidate to pass messages between Delhi and London.

Lord Ahmed

Underlined his role as one of Britain's leading Muslims earlier this month when he led a delegation on the pilgrimage to Mecca. Born in Kashmir, Lord Ahmed, 42, was appointed by the prime minister to the Lords in 1998 as part of a concerted effort by Downing Street to increase the number of Asian peers. Since his appointment he has campaigned against forced Asian marriages. He has also intervened in Lords debates over Kashmir, the principal area in which he has passed messages between London and Islamabad.

fields.headline: Tycoon offers £1m for section 28 vote
fields.standfirst: More about section 28
fields.trailText: The row over section 28 re-opened in Scotland yesterday with the news that the Stagecoach tycoon Brian Souter is willing to pay £1m for a private referendum on repeal of the controversial clause.
fields.body:
The row over section 28 re-opened in Scotland yesterday with the news that the Stagecoach tycoon Brian Souter is willing to pay £1m for a private referendum on repeal of the controversial clause.

More than 4m Scots voters would be polled on plans by the Scottish executive to replace the clause, which bans the promotion of the acceptability of homosexuality in schools.

In a newspaper article, Mr Souter said Scots were becoming more and more uncomfortable about repeal. "A referendum ... will force the government to fully explain their policy and create the climate for a proper debate, for and against repeal," he said. The Scottish Conservative leader, David McLetchie, said Mr Souter should be "commended" for his plan.

A Scottish executive spokesman said the bill to repeal section 28 was in committee stage and would be ready to go before the parliament in a matter of weeks. "We are committed to repeal," he said.

fields.headline: William Rollinson
fields.standfirst: A lifelong devotee of the Lake District, he mapped its geography, history and culture - and spread the word in books and broadcasts
fields.trailText: William Rollinson, who has died aged 62, was the leading historical geographer of the Lake District - probably the best there has ever been. He published a number of books, one of which, Life And Tradition In The Lake District, is a classic which will endure as long as anyone is interested in Wordsworth's patch of ground. He was an outstanding lecturer with a substantial personal following in the north-west. In an area carefully combed and commented on over 250 years, he made an original and substantial contribution. He spread the word on local radio and Border Television, never lowering his standards.
fields.body:
William Rollinson, who has died aged 62, was the leading historical geographer of the Lake District - probably the best there has ever been. He published a number of books, one of which, Life And Tradition In The Lake District, is a classic which will endure as long as anyone is interested in Wordsworth's patch of ground. He was an outstanding lecturer with a substantial personal following in the north-west. In an area carefully combed and commented on over 250 years, he made an original and substantial contribution. He spread the word on local radio and Border Television, never lowering his standards.

Bill Rollinson was born in Barrow-in-Furness in 1937. His father was a bricklayer at the Barrow iron and steel works. After Barrow Grammar School for Boys, he took a first in geography at Manchester University. In 1962, he became a lecturer at Liverpool University, eventually moving to the department of continuing education, from where he retired in his late 50s. He continued to lecture to local societies in the far north-west, increased his published output and found a niche in local broadcasting.

Rollinson's first public work was an article on the Lost Villages And Hamlets Of Low Furness. His last, a trio of booklets on Making Charcoal, Making Drystone Walls, and Making Swill Baskets. Between those typically local and particular concerns came several outstanding works on the landscape, traditions and language of Cumbria. These were what fascinated him, particularly the Scandinavian connection.

Although he was, in a very competitive field, supreme in his work on the Lake District, there was perhaps an even deeper pull to Norway, especially to the Fjord Mundal. Probably Rollinson's best television documentary, and most charming book, compares Mundal and Wastwater - uncannily similar in look and history. Bill was entranced by the connections and, year after year, hauled boatloads and busloads of hardy audiences to Iceland and Norway to examine the origin of the folk who, more than a millennium ago, became the core settlers in the lakes, giving it its unique language and character.

I first met Rollinson more than 30 years ago, when he came to see me at the small, half-derelict cottage in north Cumbria in which I was hoping to live. I was hopelessly digging out some obstinate raspberry canes. Bill rolled up his sleeves - literally - gave me a hand, stayed for tea, then for supper, and from then on he became a closer and closer friend of the family.

He was an old-fashioned, unreconstructed bachelor. Doctor Watson would have recognised a fellow spirit. My family, especially our children, welcomed his kindly, adult, wise presence, and were as shaken as I was when they learned that an early death was inevitable.

I worked with Bill on several television and radio programmes, most ambitiously a series of six one-hour docu mentaries on the history of the Border Television area - the lakes, the borders themselves, and the Isle of Man. He was determined that images - of which he had a robust distrust - should not eclipse content, and his incisive interference was often a pain in the neck, but one which the whole crew genuinely appreciated because we knew he was aiming for something that mattered. The result, I think, was a series that is both authoritative and lively on a subject that lends itself too easily to scenery, lush music and undemanding thought.

When you walked with Bill along, say, Buttermere to Haystacks, you walked through millions of years of geology, centuries of history and, above all, a landscape of language. He had a deep pleasure uncoupling words and showing where they came from - usually from Norse; if this sounds boring, believe me, it was gripping. Sometimes, when he chatted on as we concentrated on getting up something steep, it encroached a little too much, but even that was memorable.

Bill was a man who gave. He never came to see us without bringing gifts of some sort, but when you gave back to him, he was abashed. Although he was as welcome as spring, he had to be importuned to stay overnight, even after 30 years. This was shyness, perhaps a deeper loneliness at the heart of a man abundantly endowed with friends and always true to his Barrovian working-class roots. His politics were Labour, his characteristics were north British, yet he enjoyed meeting the great and influential in the county, as he did in the course of his comprehensive scaling of the lakes.

It is difficult to see Bill Rollinson being replaced - that devotion, that scholarship, that happy "narrow cell". Whenever I thought of the lakes, I thought of Bill, and that will not change. His ashes will be scattered on Westmoreland Cairn Great Gable.

fields.headline: Artem Borovik
fields.trailText: Artem Borovik, who died aged 39 when the plane taking him to Kiev crashed shortly after take-off from Moscow's Sheremtyevo airport, was one of Russia's most prominent investigative journalists. His demise was thought by many to have been the result of foul play rather than human error or mechanical failure, although crash investigators found no evidence of a bomb.
fields.body:
Artem Borovik, who died aged 39 when the plane taking him to Kiev crashed shortly after take-off from Moscow's Sheremtyevo airport, was one of Russia's most prominent investigative journalists. His demise was thought by many to have been the result of foul play rather than human error or mechanical failure, although crash investigators found no evidence of a bomb.

Borovik came to prominence in the late 1980s, when he wrote a series of articles for Ogonyok, the leading magazine of the glasnost years, on Afghanistan. He went on to found Sovershenno Sekretno (Top Secret), a newspaper which continued the tradition of uncovering the "blank spots" in Soviet history, and reporting the scandals which surround contemporary Russian political life.

Borovik was born into the Soviet elite. He attended the prestigious Moscow English School, then went to New York, when his father, Genrikh, a correspondent for the Novosti press agency, was posted there. On his return home, he entered the Moscow State Institute for International Relations, a training ground for Soviet diplomats, and on graduation in 1984 was posted to the embassy in Peru.

However, he soon forsook diplomacy for journalism and joined Ogonyok, becoming foreign editor. He travelled widely, writing on America and the west, but it was his series of frank and honest reports from Afghanistan that attracted attention.

Interviews with top Soviet generals conducting the war, and Babrak Karmal, the Afghan communist puppet leader in Kabul, as well as reportage from the frontline, brought home to Soviet citizens the brutality of the fighting and the hopelessness of attempting to bring the country under Soviet control. Borovik returned to Afghanistan to cover the withdrawal of Soviet troops in 1989, a decade after the invasion. A book of his reportage was published, appearing in English in 1990 as The Hidden War.

That year, Borovik founded Sovershenno Sekretno, becoming editor-in-chief, and in 1991 a television programme of the same name began on Russia's main state channel. The Yeltsin years provided Borovik which a rich seam of stories about crime, scandal and corruption among the political elite.

Like any successful Russian newspaper editor in the 1990s, Borovik needed a political protector. He wisely chose the powerful mayor of Moscow, Yuri Luzhkov. While Luzhkov was in favour with the Kremlin, Sovershenno Sekretno could satisfy its readership with stories of corruption in high places. Last summer, however, official attention turned to Borovik and his growing publishing empire. Russian state television dropped Sovershenno Sekretno from its schedules after the government accused it of dealing in kompromat , collecting material to smear politicians.

Borovik had also begun investigating the mysterious bomb explosions in Moscow, which were blamed on Chechen extremists and used as a pretext for Russia's renewed campaign against Chechnya. Despite repeated assertions that the bombing was the work of terrorists, no conclusive evidence has been produced and no arrests made. Many believe the bombs were the work of the FSB, Russia's successor to the KGB.

In the paranoid atmosphere of Russian political life, and with growing fears that under the newly-elected president Vladimir Putin, a former head of the FSB, the press will be subject to increasing censorship, Borovik's colleagues are sure that his death was no accident. According to an account in Versiya, the sister paper of Sovershenno Sekretno, a highly-placed politician ordered the murder last summer.

Borovik was a colourful character. When interviewed for the International Herald Tribune, he boasted of his opulent lifestyle - a grand flat in Moscow, fast cars and fast living. He was also a fearless critic of Boris Yeltsin and his entourage, once daring to say that it was easier to criticise Mikhail Gorbachev during communist rule than it was to discuss the failings of his supposedly democratic successor.

Borovik married Veronika Khilcheskaya, who survives him, together with their son.

 Artem Genrikhovich Borovik, journalist, born September 13 1960; died March 9 2000

However, he soon forsook diplomacy for journalism and joined Ogonyok, becoming foreign editor. He travelled widely, writing on America and the west, but it was his series of frank and honest reports from Afghanistan that attracted attention. Interviews with top Soviet generals conducting the war, and Babrak Karmal, the Afghan communist puppet leader in Kabul, as well as reportage from the frontline, brought home to Soviet citizens the brutality of the fighting and the hopelessness of attempting to bring the country under Soviet control. Borovik returned to Afghanistan to cover the withdrawal of Soviet troops in 1989, a decade after the invasion. A book of his reportage was published, appearing in English in 1990 as The Hidden War. That year, Borovik founded Sovershenno Sekretno, becoming editor-in-chief, and in 1991 a television programme of the same name began on Russia's main state channel. The Yeltsin years provided Borovik which a rich seam of stories about crime, scandal and corruption among the political elite. Like any successful Russian newspaper editor in the 1990s, Borovik needed a political protector. He wisely chose the powerful mayor of Moscow, Yuri Luzhkov. While Luzhkov was in favour with the Kremlin, Sovershenno Sekretno could satisfy its readership with stories of corruption in high places. Last summer, however, official attention turned to Borovik and his growing publishing empire. Russian state television dropped Sovershenno Sekretno from its schedules after the government accused it of dealing in kompromat , collecting material to smear politicians. Borovik had also begun investigating the mysterious bomb explosions in Moscow, which were blamed on Chechen extremists and used as a pretext for Russia's renewed campaign against Chechnya. Despite repeated assertions that the bombing was the work of terrorists, no conclusive evidence has been produced and no arrests made. Many believe the bombs were the work of the FSB, Russia's successor to the KGB. In the paranoid atmosphere of Russian political life, and with growing fears that under the newly-elected president Vladimir Putin, a former head of the FSB, the press will be subject to increasing censorship, Borovik's colleagues are sure that his death was no accident. According to an account in Versiya, the sister paper of Sovershenno Sekretno, a highly-placed politician ordered the murder last summer. Borovik was a colourful character. When interviewed for the International Herald Tribune, he boasted of his opulent lifestyle - a grand flat in Moscow, fast cars and fast living. He was also a fearless critic of Boris Yeltsin and his entourage, once daring to say that it was easier to criticise Mikhail Gorbachev during communist rule than it was to discuss the failings of his supposedly democratic successor. Borovik married Veronika Khilcheskaya, who survives him, together with their son.  Artem Genrikhovich Borovik, journalist, born September 13 1960; died March 9 2000

fields.headline: Al Grey
fields.standfirst: Letting the jazz trombone talk to its audience
fields.trailText: After Charlie Parker, Dizzy Gillespie and the other young iconoclasts of the 1940s invented the intense and melodically circuitous jazz style of bebop, many trombone players set themselves the task of trying to sound as much like trumpeters, or even saxophonists, as possible. The New Yorker critic Whitney Balliett once described the average bop trombonist as sounding like "a fat man trying to run uphill".
fields.body:
After Charlie Parker, Dizzy Gillespie and the other young iconoclasts of the 1940s invented the intense and melodically circuitous jazz style of bebop, many trombone players set themselves the task of trying to sound as much like trumpeters, or even saxophonists, as possible. The New Yorker critic Whitney Balliett once described the average bop trombonist as sounding like "a fat man trying to run uphill".

Al Grey, who has died aged 74, was one who heeded Balliett's caution. He preferred the salty, talkative vigour of the earlier trombone practitioners in a New Orleans style, like Duke Ellington's "Tricky" Sam Nanton - and, like Nanton, Grey made very expressive use of the plunger mute. This device got its name from the sink-plungers that early trombonists used to elicit a distorted, quirkily talkative sound from the bells of their horns, and Grey was a specialist in producing a personal, conversational sound with it - much of his improvising would sound as if he were telling the musical equivalent of a funny story.

It would also sound engagingly as if he had all the time in the world; Grey liked slouching behind the beat, and his tone was comfortable and cushioned. But if he was predominantly urbane and easygoing as an improviser, he was also a player of great warmth and feeling, and his blues playing was superb.

Grey's name was always associated with Count Basie, even long after he had ceased working in the orchestra - and he was frequently invited to recall that legacy in club performances, where he and a fellow Basieite, saxophonist Buddy Tate, could make a handful of players sound exactly like the Basie band.

Born in Aldie, Virginia, Grey was taught to play the trombone by his father, who ran a youth club in Pottstown, Pennsylvania, and had enjoyed a successful jazz career for a decade before the Basie connection was forged. He joined saxophonist Benny Carter's group after playing in a wartime US navy band, then came a variety of swing bandleaders, including Jimmie Lunceford and Lionel Hampton.

The trombonist's style and sound were distinctive enough by the beginning of the Basie engagement for him to quickly dominate the sound of a smaller Basie group, rebuilt in the light of postwar frugalities. From 1957-61, taking time off only for a brief stretch of co-leadership with saxophonist Billy Mitchell, Grey and saxophonist Eddie "Lockjaw" Davis were the principal attractions of the Basie line-up, and such plunger-mute features as Blues In Hoss's Flat would be a showcase for his skills. He was the ideal Basie sideman - secure, alert and restrainedly creative as a section player; bold, witty, lyrical and smoothly swinging as a soloist.

By the 1960s, Grey was a widely-respected virtuoso in his own right, having built a reputation on such solo albums as Thinking Man's Trombone. Though the frequency of his appearances with Count Basie reduced as his own career expanded, Grey did appear with Basie on many memorable occasions, notably the 1966 album collaboration with Frank Sinatra, Sinatra At The Sands.

After the Basie years ended, Grey was constantly in demand as a freelance. He worked in the studios, toured with George Wein's popular Jazz At The Philharmonic package and continued to develop as a solo artist - giving his instrument as personal a signature as a saxophone or trumpet.

He led a band with the Basie saxophonist Jimmy Forrest, a man with as strong a penchant for the blues as he had himself - and, after Forrest's death in 1980, began touring a strongly Basie-flavoured repertoire with Buddy Tate. Grey also frequently worked with Lionel Hampton, and sometimes with his trombonist son Mike, a musician who has as vigorous an approach and as punchy a sound as his father.

Grey embodied the most lyrical, freewheeling and cliché-free spirit of mainstream jazz. He is survived by four sons and four grandchildren.

 Albert Thornton 'Al' Grey, trombonist, born June 6 1925; died March 24 2000

fields.headline: Sig Mickelson
fields.standfirst: US media chief who shaped modern TV news
fields.trailText: Sig Mickelson, who has died aged 86, was one of the most influential executives in American television. In the early 1950s, he brought ideas to the infant medium which continue to shape television news presentation to this day.
fields.body:
Sig Mickelson, who has died aged 86, was one of the most influential executives in American television. In the early 1950s, he brought ideas to the infant medium which continue to shape television news presentation to this day.

In his years with the Columbia Broadcasting System (CBS), Mickelson developed the notion of one familiar face anchoring the news reports from multiple correspondents. He also pioneered the use of computers for election results analysis, and devised hard-hitting current affairs programmes which were widely imitated.

His early experience was as a radio reporter in his home town of Minneapolis, where he joined the local CBS station in 1943. By 1948, he was providing detailed coverage of that year's political conventions for the national network. In 1949, his skills brought him to the company's New York headquarters to inject some professionalism into its nascent television news service. News bulletins were pretty gruesome at the time. In 1948, CBS had been first in the field with a 15-minute nightly offering called Douglas Edwards With The News but, essentially, it was a rip-and-read sequence of news-agency material, occasionally padded out with newsreel. CBS's entire reporting staff numbered 14. In later years, Mickelson acknowledged that he inherited "a hybrid monstrosity", a public service programme lurking in a world of showbiz commercialism. In 1951, he was made head of news and public affairs and told to sort out the mess.

There had already been indications during 1951 of a potentially lucrative audience for news. Live coverage of Senator Estes Kefauver's hearings on the mafia had occasionally achieved 100% ratings for the then 108 local television stations. There were similar results when General Douglas MacArthur made his regal progress across America after President Truman sacked him for nuclear brinkmanship.

Mickelson's first coup came the following year, when he managed to get enough commercial sponsors for CBS to broadcast gavel-to-gavel coverage of the US conventions. The choice of party candidates had been televised experimentally in 1948, but transmissions only went out on three stations and the audience was minuscule. Now the halls were alive with cameras and, much to the sponsors' glee, attracted a nationwide audience of 60m.

The presidential election of November 1952 brought what can be seen as Mickelson's most fundamental gift to television news presentation. Remington Rand had told him about a machine it claimed would predict the results. "I knew that wasn't true," Mickelson recalled later, "but I knew it might speed up the analysis".

On inspection, he was unexpectedly impressed by Univac I, and sent a couple of staff to Philadelphia to sit with it on election night. The opinion polls had run heavily in favour of the Democrat Adlai Stevenson but, as the first returns came in, Univac predicted victory for the Republican Dwight Eisenhower. Initially, Mickelson was too dumbfounded to broadcast the prediction.

In the end, the machine forecast 438 electoral college votes for Eisenhower and 93 for Stevenson, just 1% away from the actual result, 442 to 89. Univac also calculated the popular vote to within 3%. Since then, no news organisation has dared forswear computer analysis in its election coverage.

One of Mickelson's early decisions after taking over the news division had been to hire a reporter called Fred Friendly (who eventually rose to run CBS News). His job was to work with the network's star correspondent, Ed Murrow, on the documentary series See It Now. Their collaboration, backed by Mickelson in the face of corporate anxiety, resulted in one of the most famous programmes in American television history.

At the height of Senator Joseph McCarthy's anti-communist crusade, when even the White House was afraid to confront him head-on, See It Now mercilessly dissected the senator's campaign, exposing the half-truths and lies on which it was founded. It was not the cause, but it certainly galvanised enough public support to secure McCarthy's downfall.

But, like everyone in commercial television, Mickelson had to live with the medium's financial realities, and its implicit belief that the dearest must be the most desirable. Having built Walter Cronkite into one of America's best-known faces, and expanded his nightly appearance to 30 minutes, Mickelson persuaded him to hire an agent. Cronkite, then earning about $150 a week, began the trend which now brings huge salaries to people of pretty average talent who can attract a large audience.

Mickelson, who left CBS in 1961 to work for Time Television, told an interviewer in his later years that things had not worked out as he had hoped. "We were hoping that we'd get more voters to the polls, that we'd have better-informed candidates, and that the X-ray eye would expose all the charlatanism. I don't know whether we have better candidates, but certainly we don't have more people going to the polls, and surely there is no exposure of the charlatans anymore".

Mickelson is survived by his second wife, Elena, two children from his first marriage, and two stepchildren.

 Sig Mickelson, journalist, born May 24 1913; died March 29 2000

webTitle: Jail for white hardliner in South Africa

fields.headline: Jail for white hardliner in South Africa
fields.trailText: Eugene Terre'Blanche, the neo-Nazi leader of the once feared Afrikaner Resistance Movement (AWB), has been ordered to begin a prison sentence today for racist assault.
fields.body:
Eugene Terre'Blanche, the neo-Nazi leader of the once feared Afrikaner Resistance Movement (AWB), has been ordered to begin a prison sentence today for racist assault.

The 56-year-old AWB leader - who once threatened to wage war rather than allow black rule in South Africa - was among the most popular, colourful and virulent opponents of the transition from apartheid to democracy.

But his credibility as a political leader collapsed after the anti-black threats voiced by the extreme white right proved to be little more than bluster. Revelations of his extramarital affairs did not sit well with religious Afrikaners either.

Terre'Blanche was yesterday ordered by the Pretoria high court to surrender himself to begin a one-year jail sentence after he lost his final appeal against a conviction for beating a black petrol attendant, John Ndzima, and setting a dog on him in 1996. The AWB leader told his victim he was punishing him for reporting a break-in by a white boy.

Terre'Blanche faces an additional six years in prison if, as seems likely, he loses his appeal against a second conviction for the attempted murder of one of his employees, Paul Mothabe, four years ago. Terre'Blanche bludgeoned the man over the head with an iron bar so severely that he has permanent brain damage.

It is unclear where the AWB leader will serve his time, but his lawyer said Terre'Blanche would ask for an isolation cell for safety's sake.

But Golden Miles Bhudu, a spokesman for the South African Prisoners' Organisation for Human Rights, said the AWB leader had nothing to fear: "We are very optimistic that a person with Mr Terre'Blanche's calibre will easily [get] along with prisoners, who are very friendly human beings."

webTitle: Anger at French plan to cull wolves

fields.headline: Anger at French plan to cull wolves
fields.trailText: A government plan that could lead to a wolf cull in the southern Alps has angered environmentalists who reject accusations that the animals are being smuggled into France to re-establish packs across the south-east of the country.
fields.body:
A government plan that could lead to a wolf cull in the southern Alps has angered environmentalists who reject accusations that the animals are being smuggled into France to re-establish packs across the south-east of the country.

Animal protection societies, including the World Wide Fund for Nature and France Nature, have been told by the agriculture minister, Jean Glavany, that the animals' hunting ground will be strictly restricted from May and that farmers will be allowed to shoot animals that stray from authorised areas.

More than £500,000 has been paid in compensation to farmers who claim that 5,200 of their sheep had been killed by wolves during the past five years.

Bernard Sigard, spokesman for the Groupe Loup-France, said that plans to restrict the wolves' territory would end efforts to re-establish the animal before they had begun.

"The authorities say that a maximum of 150 animals will be tolerated, but this figure is only a starting point for us," he added. "We are going to fight a plan which amounts to killing animals just because some people see them as a nuisance."

A final ruling on the wolves will be announced next month, but an environment ministry adviser, Patrick Legrand, said that wolves could only be tolerated after "exclusion zones" were set up to enable shepherds to protect their flocks.

fields.headline: Whopper sinks 'Olympic' swimmer
fields.trailText: A disgraced Australian television news anchorman who lied about being a former Olympic swimmer for 15 years said yesterday he was glad the truth had come out, even though he had lost his job and his reputation.
fields.body:
A disgraced Australian television news anchorman who lied about being a former Olympic swimmer for 15 years said yesterday he was glad the truth had come out, even though he had lost his job and his reputation.

David Fidler, 49, fled his home in Darwin and resigned after a newspaper revealed that his detailed stories of representing Australia in a 100m event at the Mexico Olympics were complete fiction.

It emerged that Mr Fidler, in fact, had never swum for Australia at any level, but that did not stop him from attending several dinners and fundraisers and giving interviews about his experiences, complete with details of the water temperature, lane ropes and starting blocks.

"Probably the most amount of pride I have ever felt was taking the Olympic oath for Australia," he said in an newspaper interview two years ago.

Only last week he spoke at a pre-Olympics function, which his own station broadcast, even though he knew his speech to be false.

Olympians expressed shock at his lying, with the four-time gold medal swimmer Dawn Fraser claiming that such a fraud was no better than a drugs cheat. "Falsifying a history as an Olympian, I think that is as bad as sports people taking drugs," she said.

Mr Fidler claimed the whole pretence started when he was introduced as a former Olympian at a fundraiser in 1985 by a now deceased public figure he will not name.

"I went to the guy afterwards and told him it wasn't true, but his attitude was 'no one's going to know, tell them you are a Kiwi or a Pom'," insisted Mr Fidler.

The Channel 8 newsreader, who hopes his charity work will help his public to forgive him, said that once the lie began he could not control it. "I didn't know how to unsay it," he said. "I wished I could, but I just didn't know how. For 15 years, there wasn't a day go past when I didn't want it to stop. It was like the sword of Damocles hanging over my head."

webTitle: Dying boy helps heal island's wounds

fields.headline: Dying boy helps heal island's wounds
fields.standfirst: Turkish and Greek Cypriots put aside years of enmity in the desperate hunt for a bone marrow donor
fields.trailText: The plight of a young boy in Cyprus dying of leukaemia has sparked a show of unity not seen on the island since its Greek and Turkish communities were divided by war in 1974.
fields.body:
The plight of a young boy in Cyprus dying of leukaemia has sparked a show of unity not seen on the island since its Greek and Turkish communities were divided by war in 1974.

Hundreds of Turkish Cypriots have given blood samples in the hope that someone will prove to be a compatible donor for a bone marrow transplant desperately needed by six-year-old Andreas Vassiliou, a Greek Cypriot.

In one three-hour period, the Turkish Cypriots crammed into the disused ballroom at the former Ledra Palace hotel which lies on the UN-controlled Green Line dividing Nicosia. The zone is inhabited by British peacekeepers.

Among the volunteers providing blood samples to Greek Cypriot nurses was Serdar Denktash, the son of Rauf Denktash, the president of the breakaway Turkish Cypriot state in the north.

After being tested, he was introduced to the boy's father, Vassos. The two men, who came together in a bear hug, were both close to tears, along with many bystanders.

"This goes beyond politics, religions, nationalities and any hatred," said Mr Vassiliou,a 38-year-old businessman. "When the Turkish Cypriots see my son, they just see an innocent child who desperately needs help. He could be one of theirs."

Some 50,000 Greek Cypriots have so far given samples and additional testing equipment has been shipped in. So far, 4,000 samples have been tested, and extra medical staff are helping clear the backlog.
