webTitle: Avalanche sweeps skiers to their deaths in Austria

fields.headline: Avalanche sweeps skiers to their deaths in Austria
fields.trailText: Twelve ski instructors were killed after a ski slope near the popular Austrian resort of Kaprun was struck by the country's fourth lethal avalanche in just over a year.
fields.body:
Twelve ski instructors were killed after a ski slope near the popular Austrian resort of Kaprun was struck by the country's fourth lethal avalanche in just over a year.

A local police officer said that 11 bodies had been recovered.

Two people had been found alive and were flown out injured, but one died on arrival at Salzburg's regional hospital.

At least one person was still missing and, as daylight failed, hopes faded for the skier's recovery.

The Austrian authorities said nine helicopters and 80 rescuers were scouring the area around the Kitzsteinhorn mountain. Twenty specially trained avalanche rescue dogs which can sniff out people buried in snow were also being used.

The victims were said by police to have been skiing off-piste on the slopes of the mountain when the killer slide roared down in the early afternoon.

Witnesses said the avalanche was about 150 yards wide and that it had begun away from the Alpine resort's prepared slopes.

Avalanche warnings have been posted in many parts of the Alps in recent weeks as temperatures have risen. Kaprun had seen rain earlier in the day, then sunshine - a combination which is often the prelude to a snow slide.

Lying 35 miles south of Salzburg, Kaprun is among Austria's leading ski resorts, with accommodation for 14,000 visitors. All-year skiing is possible on a nearby glacier.

The rise in the number of avalanche deaths is a subject of heated debate in Austria. As a general rule, the higher the slopes, the greater the risk from avalanches. Environmentalists have accused the tourist industry of endangering holidaymakers by building resorts and facilities in ever-higher locations to extend the tourist season and circumvent the consequences of global warming.

Last December 11 people were swept to their deaths by two snow slides in Austria. Ten months earlier, the country suffered its worst skiing disaster in decades when a series of avalanches claimed the lives of 38 people in the high-Alpine area around Galtür in Tyrol.

Yesterday the bodies of the dead were flown by helicopter to the nearby Niedernsill sports centre, where they were put in the basement awaiting identification.

The Red Cross opened up a counselling centre for victims and their families. Injured people were taken to Zell am See hospital.

Avalanche experts warned that the survival chances for anyone caught in the avalanche sink dramatically after 15 minutes.

"More than 90% of victims die through suffocation," said Rudi Mair from the Tirolean avalanche warning centre. "Access to air is quickly lost and only in the case of a quick rescue does one stand any chance."

Experts said they believed that two snowboarders had triggered the avalanche. A group of ski instructors from Denmark, Austria, Czech Republic and Germany were caught in the mass of snow as it thundered down the mountainside.

One of the injured, a 34-year-old Danish ski instructor who had been working for the skiing season in Austria, died after being transported to Salzburg's regional hospital.

According to initial reports, a woman skier whose friends were buried by the avalanche was the first to alert the rescue teams.

Wolfgang Fizek, one of the heads of the rescue operation, said: "Two people were able to free themselves from the snow, and we have a constant stream of rescue workers arriving at the disaster site."

Mr Fizek confirmed that the search had been extremely difficult because of a bad radio connection between the rescue centre and the volunteer rescuers.

The avalanche was unexpected. Earlier in the day experts had estimated the avalanche risk to be very low, at number two on the scale.

Those caught in the avalanche were very experienced, and were taking part in an Austrian-led international course for ski instructors.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Turkish activist returned to jail
fields.body:
Turkish activist returned to jail

Turkey's leading human rights activist, Akin Birdal, was sent back to prison in Ankara for the remaining six months of a prison term yesterday, after a state medical institute rejected a report that he was unfit to spend more time in jail.

Under strict laws that limit freedom of expression, Birdal was found guilty in June of inciting hatred in two speeches which called for a negotiated end to the Kurdish conflict in south-eastern Turkey. There are up to 20 other cases pending against him for similar speeches made during the past few years.
Chris Morris, Ankara

Jordan to try Bin Laden allies

Jordan's military attorney general said yesterday that he had indicted 28 followers of the suspected terrorist, Osama bin Laden, for planning attacks against American and tourist targets in the kingdom.

Brigadier General Mamoun al-Khasawneh said Jordan's state security court would hold its first session in the public trial of the men, 13 of whom remain at large, in mid-April. All suspects are members of the al-Qaedah faction of the Islamic Front and those at large include Omar Abu Omar, a Muslim fundamentalist living in Britain.
Reuters, Amman

Soldier fined for beheading angel

A Rome court convicted a Canadian soldier of vandalism and gave him a one-year suspended sentence yesterday, two days after he broke the head off a marble angel when he tried to scale a column near the Spanish Steps.

Robert Keenan, 30, who serves with the Nato-led force in Kosovo, was also ordered to pay $750 in legal fees, police said. Mr Keenan, who arrived in Rome on Sunday on a 15-day pass, broke the angel's head off when he used it as a foothold to climb higher on the 1857 Column of the Immaculate Conception. Passers-by called the police.
Reuters, Rome

webTitle: Grim evidence of worst cult slaughter

fields.headline: Grim evidence of worst cult slaughter
fields.standfirst: Up to 1,000 followers feared dead as more graves found in Uganda
fields.trailText: Up to 1,000 members of a fanatical sect who were persuaded by their leaders to hand over their possessions in preparation for the end of the world, are feared dead in south-west Uganda, in what could prove to be the world's worst cult killing.
fields.byline: Anna Borzello  in Rugazi and  David Hearst
fields.body:
Up to 1,000 members of a fanatical sect who were persuaded by their leaders to hand over their possessions in preparation for the end of the world, are feared dead in south-west Uganda, in what could prove to be the world's worst cult killing.

Investigators yesterday said there were five more suspected graves, after digging up 28 bodies from under the freshly cemented floor of a cult leader's home, the fourth mass grave to be uncovered in a week.

As nightfall stopped the excruciating work of pulling the decomposing corpses out with ropes - labour undertaken by prisoners on release from a local jail - many more bodies appeared to remain. Most of the victims had been strangled.

Assuman Mugenyi, Uganda's chief police spokesman, said that five other compounds belonging to the sect were still to be examined. The sect had up to 1,000 members and authorities fear most may have been murdered.

The latest mass grave was uncovered at the home of a defrocked priest, Dominic Kataribabo, who died in the fire which killed at least 330 followers on March 17. To date, nearly 600 bodies have been found.

Police initially treated the deaths at Kanungu as mass suicide, believing followers set themselves alight in the belief that the church was Noah's ark and the Virgin Mary was coming to take them to heaven.

Later, when six decomposing bodies were found in a pit latrine inside the church compound, police decided to treat the deaths as murder and rumours began to spread that several of the leaders had escaped.

The man believed to have organised the mass slaughter, failed politician Joseph Kibwetere, called himself the head apostle of the Movement for the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God.

One police theory is that Mr Kibwetere and a former prostitute turned principal prophetess, Cledonia Mwerinde, persuaded followers to sell their belongings and hand over their money in return for a place in heaven when the world ended, on the eve of the millennium.

When the world did not end, it is thought that the followers began demanding back their money.

Some now contend that the cult's entire existence was a gigantic fraud designed to enrich its leaders - Kibwetere and Mwerinde - who lured the gullible and inadequate into the church with promises of salvation.

Cult followers did not mix with their leaders and led a harsh life. They wore a uniform, ate sparsely, refrained from sex and were not allowed to speak for fear of bearing false witness. They also believed their leaders received direct messages from the Virgin Mary and Jesus.

Among the bodies recovered yesterday in the pit under the house of Kataribabo in Rugazi, were 20 children. Police said they expected to find many more bodies when they resume work today.

A further 74 bodies were found in the garden at the back of the pretty brick house, which overlooks gently rolling hills, a shining lake and the plains of the Western Rift valley in western Uganda.

Prisoners wearing plastic gloves heaved the bodies out of the pit, and spread them on the ground for examination by police.

"They look like they have been here about a month and at least half the bodies have been strangled. We will have to wait for the results of our tests before we learn how the others died," said police pathologist Thaddeus Barungi, bending over to point out a twist of rope around the neck of one corpse.

A total of 255 bodies - most of them women and children - have been found so far on the Rugazi sites and behind a house used by the Ten Commandments cult in nearby Buhunga. The Buhunga site revealed 153 bodies.

Local people, pressed in silence against the wire fence of the Rugazi compound, watched in silence as the bodies were brought out yesterday.

"They were religious people. We would never have expected them to kill," said local council chairman Gregory Katurebe.

"They told us they were digging a pit in the garden to build a latrine. It was hard to see what was really happening because of the fence which meant we couldn't see inside. And they kept to themselves."

Kataribabo was a Catholic teacher in the early 1980s. Cult members had been using his home for the last few years.

However, in early March followers began leaving the house for their headquarters at Kanungu.

Kataribabo was the last to leave, on March 12. His body was one of only two to have been identified by police inside the church: his charred remains stretched out by the door, his dog collar seared into his neck from the heat.

fields.headline: No: 1604 Vandrea
fields.trailText: Appearance: Dead ringer for Andrea Catherwood.
fields.body:
Appearance: Dead ringer for Andrea Catherwood.

Who she? Kirsty Young's replacement on the Channel 5 bulletin that pioneered, er, standing up to read the news.

Does she know she's got a doppelgänger? Yes - and approves. Vandrea is the world's first virtual newsreader, created by scanning Ms Catherwood with 3D cameras.

Kinky! Not at all. "One day," says the corporeal Andrea, "I was reading the news and the next thing I knew there was a 3D scanner in the newsroom. It was a little strange".

I'm not surprised - I thought Channel 5 remained stubbornly two-dimensional. Cheeky.

So can Vandrea replicate the unmistakeable charisma of the real Ms, er, whatsername? "Not only does she look like me," says Catherwood, "but they were able to watch my newsreading and transform my movements into Vandrea."

Blimey? Where can we witness this marvel? The completed cyber-Catherwood was unveiled in the Millennium Dome's Talk Zone yesterday. She's been designed, using technology developed by BT, to read the news headlines on the internet.

andfinally.com? Vandrea may indeed represent a final curtain for mere mortal newsreaders. The byte-sized broadcaster is being groomed to take over on C5 proper. And after that . . .

You don't mean? Adios Anna Ford, toodle-oo Trev and hearty farewells to Huw Edwards.

Doesn't the public prefer real people? You might think so. But a virtual newsreader is being developed by the the Press Association comprising the best features of Posh Spice and Carol Vorderman.

Can anything stop the march of the artificial anchormen? Nothing - save a blown fuse at C5HQ.

Most likely to say: "Welcome, I'm Vandrea. I'll bring the headlines to your computer 24 hours a day."

Least likely to say: "Did you threaten to overrule him, Mr Howard? Did you threaten to overrule him?"

Not to be confused with: Van Morrison, Andrea Dworkin, Lara Croft.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In a report headed Minister lifts green belt limit, page 13, yesterday, we described Ruth Bagnall as Labour leader of Cambridge city council. She is the leader of the Labour group on the council. Labour lost control of Cambridge after a Liberal Democrat by-election win in February.   A picture of a Leeds Rhinos player, page 12, Sport, March 27, captioned Darren Fleary in fact showed Anthony Farrell. Apologies.
fields.body:
In a report headed Minister lifts green belt limit, page 13, yesterday, we described Ruth Bagnall as Labour leader of Cambridge city council. She is the leader of the Labour group on the council. Labour lost control of Cambridge after a Liberal Democrat by-election win in February. A picture of a Leeds Rhinos player, page 12, Sport, March 27, captioned Darren Fleary in fact showed Anthony Farrell. Apologies.

At the end of a review of Boss Cupid, new poetry by Thom Gunn, page 8, Saturday Review, March 25, we referred to James Campbell's interviews with Thom Gunn but gave an outdated internet address. The correct one for the series is www.interviews-with-poets.com/thom-gunn/

In a piece headed Time travel, page 14, Guardian Education, yesterday, we drew attention to the possible consequences if English literary manuscripts continued "to migrate eastwards into the archives of US university libraries". That would be westward.

French department: in a piece headed Norman wisdom, page 16, G2, March 27, we wrongly referred to Haut-Normandie and Bas-Normandie. Normandie is a feminine region. Thus, Haute-Normandie, Basse-Normandie.

The county in Scotland is Fife, not Fyfe; and from the same piece, page 3, Guardian Education, yesterday, St Andrews University has no apostrophe.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: The stock market is definitely getting that end-of-the -quarter feeling. The FTSE 100 share index was down 37 points on the day, hardly likely to set pulses racing in a market which has grown accustomed to far more violent mood swings.
fields.body:
The stock market is definitely getting that end-of-the -quarter feeling. The FTSE 100 share index was down 37 points on the day, hardly likely to set pulses racing in a market which has grown accustomed to far more violent mood swings.

Trading volumes reflected the lacklustre tone, with a modest 1.3bn shares traded. As the first quarter draws to a close most fund managers are looking towards their second quarter strategies.

A dearth of company announcements contributed towards the sombre tone of the market while Wall Street hardly helped lift the mood, drifting lower during the trading overlap with London. The oil sector looked a touch better, despite the absence of news from the Opec talks in Vienna before the close of business. Shell added 5p to 477p while BP Amoco was 1p higher at 515p.

Vodafone AirTouch was the most heavily traded stock on the day but all the activity left the shares virtually unchanged at 364p.

webTitle: Signet saviour makes room for new blood

fields.headline: Signet saviour makes room for new blood
fields.trailText: The man who steered jewellery group Signet - previously known as Ratners - back from near bankruptcy is stepping back from day-to-day running of the store chain after eight years in the top job.
fields.body:
The man who steered jewellery group Signet - previously known as Ratners - back from near bankruptcy is stepping back from day-to-day running of the store chain after eight years in the top job.

James McAdam, executive chairman of Signet, has appointed Terry Burman as chief executive and yesterday announced that he intended to step up to non-executive chairman next year. Mr Burman is now head of Signet's successful US operation - which provides two thirds of the company's turnover - and will run Signet from his US base. But Mr McAdam said the new chief executive's appointment contained "no hidden messages" that Signet was planning to relocate to the US.

When Mr McAdam, an accountant by training, took over Ratners it was on the verge of extinction. The year he arrived the group had been expected to make a £130m profit. By the time the results were finally published it had lurched to a £122m loss.

However, yesterday Mr McAdam announced that pre-tax profits were up 43% to £127.7m last year and underlying sales rose 9%.

The shares have outperformed the embattled retail sector by 60% in the past 12 months and gearing is down to 20%. Mr McAdam even hinted the group was ready to hit the acquisition trail if opportunities cropped up.

"We have the firepower and the message is that we are well placed to finance the growth we have planned and also to infill our portfolio in the US if the right opportunity arose."

In Britain the group is concentrating on extracting more sales from its 427 H Samuel shops and is ready to expand the number of Ernest Jones outlets from 179 to up to 220. Mr McAdam said the British chains were "not a drag on the business" and produced a return on capital of 26%.

In the US the group is now the second biggest jeweller with 5% of the market. In the past two years it has opened 28 out-of-town superstores in America where 70% of sales are diamonds.

Mr McAdam said he believed the chain, called Jared, could expand to 200 outlets with a turnover of more than $1bn (£630m).

Signet's shares declined 2p to 57p as some investors took profits.

webTitle: House of Fraser claims high street victory

fields.headline: House of Fraser claims high street victory
fields.trailText: Department store group House of Fraser yesterday insisted it is one of the winners in the battle for high street fashion shoppers .
fields.body:
Department store group House of Fraser yesterday insisted it is one of the winners in the battle for high street fashion shoppers .

The 51-store chain, whose shares hit a low of 42p last month, unveiled flat full-year profits of £17.8m. But they closed up 3p at 58p as chief executive John Coleman revealed a better than expected start to new trading year, with sales up 5.7% and gross margins up 0.7%.

"We are one of the winners", said Mr Coleman, whose brands include Army & Navy, DH Evans, Rackhams and Dickens & Jones as well as HoF. "The board anticipates the current year being one of strong progress".

Analysts believe the backroom improvements to the supply chain made by Mr Coleman may soon bear fruit and that HoF is now stealing market share from rivals.

webTitle: Post Office needs chance to deliver

fields.headline: Post Office needs chance to deliver
fields.standfirst: Government policy, foreign invasion and email rivalry reduce industry to turmoil
fields.trailText: The Post Office is an organisation in turmoil. Government policy is wrecking its network of sub-post offices. The incoming postal regulator is threatening to abolish its letter monopoly at a time when email has created a fast alternative to letters.
fields.body:
The Post Office is an organisation in turmoil. Government policy is wrecking its network of sub-post offices. The incoming postal regulator is threatening to abolish its letter monopoly at a time when email has created a fast alternative to letters.

Foreign companies are making inroads into its parcel business while its ability to compete overseas has, until recently, been hamstrung by the government's preference for PO profits to end up in the treasury's coffers.

Attempts to privatise the PO have been vigorously opposed by MPs, the public and the unions.The postal industry is changing rapidly and requires quick commercial decisions, but government has been reluctant and slow to give the PO the commercial freedom it needs to compete effectively.

On top of all this, the public wants to retain the comfort and convenience of daily mail deliveries and local post offices.

Successive government have sought, without success, to find a solution which matches the commercial imperatives and desire for competition with the social needs. Report after report on the PO has been prepared, but little action has been taken.

The government's plan to start paying benefits direct to bank accounts is one of the biggest threats to the future of sub-post offices, which are already struggling to make ends meet. Sub-postmasters expect to lose at least a third of their income as a result of the change.

More than 200 local post offices are going out of business every year as self-employed sub-postmasters and mistresses decide to retire or pull out and are unable to find anyone else prepared to carry on the business. This is expected to accelerate in the coming years when the loss of benefit income starts to bite.

The government believes that the lost income can be offset by using the new computer network linking post offices to provide a wider range of government services. But PO plans to provide such services have met with lukewarm receptions from individual government departments and agencies.

The network could, for example, be used as a way of informing all government departments of a person's change of address at a single stroke. But departments are reluctant to give up any part of their individual systems.

The battle for the local post office will ultimately be won by public pressure, as in the past. Already Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, has hinted that the government might be prepared to subsidise the 18,000 post offices to keep them open.

The biggest threat to the PO itself is the move towards scaling down its letter monopoly, which covers all letters costing £1 or less to send.

The Labour Party has indicated that it would like to see the monopoly threshold halved to 50p, but the government ducked the issue by saying that the level of the monopoly should be decided by the new postal regulator, Graham Corbett.

Mr Corbett, who starts work as head of the new postal services commission on Saturday, said this week that he wanted to see the monopoly reduced or possibly abolished.

He admitted that this would force the PO to slash its costs by taking the axe to its 160,000 strong workforce and said: "The Post Office will be incentivised to cut costs and ensure a more efficient system. The most effective way it could do this is through the labour force. That is its highest cost."

The PO is resigned to seeing the monopoly scaled down, not least because the European commission is seeking to reduce postal monopolies in all member states. But PO managers want to make sure that its monopoly is reduced in line with - and at the same time as - those in other European Union states.

They believe that for Britain to go it alone would be an open invitation for for eign postal monopolies to carve up the UK market at the PO's expense. They have already seen foreign post offices set up operations in the UK and buy British logistic businesses.

The European commission has also asked national governments to file separate accounts for state-controlled postal services in an effort to find out whether profits from monopoly businesses are being used to subsidise commercial activities. "At the moment it is unsatisfactory to have some countries liberalised and others not," said Frits Bolkestein, the EU's single market commissioner.

The British government has only recently begun to untie the purse strings to allow the PO to counter the foreign invasion by acquiring overseas companies. The PO's overall spending limit on such deals is still capped, though the government has said it is prepared to consider approval for any big deal the PO might want to make.

The PO would like to expand its logistics business and become internet retailers' distributor of choice. It foresees a time when an order placed via an internet retailer's web site is directed to it for execution. The retailer's stocks would be held in a PO warehouse and be distributed from there. The PO would handle the invoicing, receive the payment, deduct its commission and forward the balance to the retailer.

But developing such a business will be hard if senior management's time and effort is focused on rescuing the remains of its traditional business - not least that part which enables customers to send a letter anywhere in the country for just one price.

webTitle: Hyder admits to bid talks as shares rise

fields.headline: Hyder admits to bid talks as shares rise
fields.trailText: Shares in Hyder, the Welsh water and electricity business, rose by nearly 50% yesterday, forcing the group to rush out a statement that it was in bid talks. The group stressed, however, that the talks were only part of a wide-ranging review of its operations.
fields.body:
Shares in Hyder, the Welsh water and electricity business, rose by nearly 50% yesterday, forcing the group to rush out a statement that it was in bid talks. The group stressed, however, that the talks were only part of a wide-ranging review of its operations.

It said it was talking to a number of parties about a range of strategic options, one of which was a bid for the company. "Hyder is actively developing these discussions so that the board can decide which course of action produces the greatest shareholder value," a spokesman said.

He played down expectations of an imminent announcement, saying that analysts were not expecting the review to be completed until the summer.

Since the group bought the Swalec electricity business, it had been hit by a double whammy of the windfall levy and the more recent water price review, he said.

The heavily indebted group has cut its dividend and announced 1,000 job losses in an attempt to reduce costs. Under the new price regime, it has to reduce its domestic water charges by 10.5% this year.

This year it agreed to sell its electricity supply business to British Energy for £105m, though it retained its electricity distribution network. In the past two years the group's shares have plunged from a peak of £10.32 to a low of 179p. Yesterday its shares closed 90.75p up at 275.5p.

Ian Byatt, the director general of Ofwat, has resolutely opposed mergers between water companies during his 10-year term of office.

He is due to step down in July, however, and industry experts believe that his successor may be less opposed to consolidation within the industry.

Mr Byatt has, though, indicated a softening of his position. He said that encouraging competition by giving up market share might be an alternative to the swingeing price cuts he had previously insisted on as a condition of any merger.

fields.headline: Edwards' United hopes thwarted
fields.trailText: Martin Edwards' ambition of becoming chairman of Manchester United plc has suffered a setback after news that Sir Roland Smith is to remain in the role for at least another year. Sir Roland, 71, who had been due to retire at the end of this month, has signed a one-year extension to his contract after encouragement from the United's three newly appointed non-executive directors.
fields.body:
Martin Edwards' ambition of becoming chairman of Manchester United plc has suffered a setback after news that Sir Roland Smith is to remain in the role for at least another year. Sir Roland, 71, who had been due to retire at the end of this month, has signed a one-year extension to his contract after encouragement from the United's three newly appointed non-executive directors.

The news is a blow to Mr Edwards, who has made it clear that he wants to vacate his position as chief executive and become chairman, and follows criticism from supporters who were unhappy to read tabloid allegations about his partying during United's participation in the recent World Club Championship in Brazil.

Sir Roland played down talk of a boardroom rift saying: "Martin led the proposal for me to stay on for another 12 months." Analysts believe Mr Edwards is now likely to become a non-executive of the plc but retaining the chairmanship of the football club.

In the six months to January 31 United reported a 10% increase in pre-tax profits to £12.2m and a turnover of £64m. The figures were towards the top end of analyst expectations. However, player salaries and transfer fees forced operating costs up 30% to £33.8m.

Television revenues as a percentage of turnover jumped from 16% to 24% with the club predicting further increases after the renegotiation of the Premier League broadcasting deal in the summer.

Mr Kenyon said United would "at the minimum" look to gain control of delayed highlights rights, allowing the club to broadcast them on its loss-making television channel MUTV and its internet site manutd.com. Shares in United closed up 3.5p at 403.5p.

In a separate move, American cable TV company NTL is to make an undisclosed investment in Middlesbrough football club in return for a 5.6% stake.

fields.headline: AstraZeneca
fields.trailText: Shares in AstraZeneca enjoyed a good run for much of March but, over the last couple of days, enthusiasm has waned. Yesterday, for example, the shares slipped just over 2% to £26.78.
fields.body:
Shares in AstraZeneca enjoyed a good run for much of March but, over the last couple of days, enthusiasm has waned. Yesterday, for example, the shares slipped just over 2% to £26.78.

One explanation is that sentiment was dented yesterday by the news that the US authorities have tentatively approved a generic form of AstraZeneca's ulcer drug, Losec.

Now anything touching on Losec is likely to be sensitive in the short term. The drug is not just a best seller, it is the best seller - generating sales of some $5.7bn last year alone.

But two points should be made: Losec's US patents do not expire for another year at the earliest, and the company is hoping for a six-month extension.

Second, even when the generic rival hits the market, it is unlikely to wipe out Losec's sales at a stroke. Market estimates reckon the generic version could generate sales of $500m-plus a year compared with Losec's current sales of $3.5bn.

In the longer run, the key to the outlook for AstraZeneca is not so much what happens to Losec as the potential of the drugs emerging from its development pipeline.

Concern about how the company would respond to the expiry of Losec's patents has been around since the time of the merger. But there are signs of the shape of things to come.

The company has European approval for its next generation ulcer drug, Nexium, and analysts were reportedly impressed by the company's research and development update at the end of last year.

Nor is AstraZeneca likely to stand idly by as the pharmaceuticals industry continues to consolidate.

With a market capitalisation of £47bn, the Anglo-Swedish group is probably chunky enough to resist a hostile bid whilst having sufficient strength coming through the development pipeline to be able to pick and choose from the available partners.

Not risk free, but probably a little more to go for yet.

fields.headline: Lucent gives Geo the tremors
fields.trailText: Few companies have ridden the surge in investor interest in hi-tech companies over the past few months as spectacularly as Israeli software firm Geo Interactive.
fields.body:
Few companies have ridden the surge in investor interest in hi-tech companies over the past few months as spectacularly as Israeli software firm Geo Interactive.

As recently as November punters were buying into Geo, a maker of streaming video technology for audio applications, for less than 200p. By the start of this month those shares were changing hands for almost £35 each after the announcement of deals with Samsung and Energis to put its Emblaze technology in their products.

However, in true dot.com style the shares have since lost more than a third of their value. Yesterday they dipped a further 160p before recovering to close down 112.5p at 1897.5p. The source of the market's nervousness was an announcement from American company Lucent Technologies that it is planning a new venture aimed at making video easier to send over high-speed networks.

The service will initially focus on business to business communications but be rolled out to consumers as broadband technology becomes more widespread. Its compression software is believed to be capable of delivering high-definition video images quickly over the net.

Until now Geo, even though it is still in a fledgling state, has generally been considered the leader in video and audio compression. To date Geo has concentrated on getting its compression standards onto mobile devices but has its eye firmly on the fixed line broadband market.

Hence the concerns when a player such as Lucent, with a global reach, significant customer base and deep, deep pockets enters the fray. "The possibilities are pretty much endless in terms of applications" said Lucent spokesman Chris Pfaff ominously.

Investors in Geo should take notice of Lucent's arrival but not necessarily panic. Microsoft and RealVideo have already said they plan similar offerings and Geo's share price has not collapsed. The Lucent offering is so far unproven and one of a number of alternatives in an increasingly crowded market.

Those companies who were first into the marked should still be at an advantage.

As recently as November punters were buying into Geo, a maker of streaming video technology for audio applications, for less than 200p. By the start of this month those shares were changing hands for almost £35 each after the announcement of deals with Samsung and Energis to put its Emblaze technology in their products. However, in true dot.com style the shares have since lost more than a third of their value. Yesterday they dipped a further 160p before recovering to close down 112.5p at 1897.5p. The source of the market's nervousness was an announcement from American company Lucent Technologies that it is planning a new venture aimed at making video easier to send over high-speed networks. The service will initially focus on business to business communications but be rolled out to consumers as broadband technology becomes more widespread. Its compression software is believed to be capable of delivering high-definition video images quickly over the net. Until now Geo, even though it is still in a fledgling state, has generally been considered the leader in video and audio compression. To date Geo has concentrated on getting its compression standards onto mobile devices but has its eye firmly on the fixed line broadband market. Hence the concerns when a player such as Lucent, with a global reach, significant customer base and deep, deep pockets enters the fray. "The possibilities are pretty much endless in terms of applications" said Lucent spokesman Chris Pfaff ominously. Investors in Geo should take notice of Lucent's arrival but not necessarily panic. Microsoft and RealVideo have already said they plan similar offerings and Geo's share price has not collapsed. The Lucent offering is so far unproven and one of a number of alternatives in an increasingly crowded market. Those companies who were first into the marked should still be at an advantage.

fields.headline: News 24 wins reprieve
fields.standfirst:
Review of controversial channel put back until after next election

The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: Culture secretary Chris Smith is facing renewed anger from the commercial television sector after it emerged that the proposed review of the BBC's News 24 channel will not take place until after the next general election.
fields.body:
Culture secretary Chris Smith is facing renewed anger from the commercial television sector after it emerged that the proposed review of the BBC's News 24 channel will not take place until after the next general election.

The delay appeared to backtrack on comments made by Mr Smith at the announcement on the future of BBC funding in February when he said the round-the-clock news channel would be subject to immediate review. The station which has a £55m annual budget has caused a stream of controversy due to its low viewing figures and has been at the heart of the debate over the BBC's role in multi-channel television.

News 24 was dismissed as a waste of money by the Commons select committee chaired by Labour veteran Gerald Kaufman in its report into the BBC's demands for more cash.

A spokesman for the Department of Culture, Media and Sport yesterday confirmed that the review could be delayed for what could be up to two years depending on when the government decides to call the next election.

Mr Smith, he said, had never intended to begin the review until after the election. "It is not felt appropriate that a review of a news channel should take place in the run-up to a general election. It could be misconstrued and, in reality, it is simply a matter of common sense."

The package of measures announced by Mr Smith when he agreed a £3 increase to the licence fee included cuts of £1bn from the organisation, details of which are expected to emerge on Monday.

Its digital services, starting with News 24 and moving on to BBC Knowledge, Parliament and Choice, were to be reviewed to gauge their success against the public service model Mr Smith said.

Any new services, such as the proposed children's channel would also be thoroughly examined, while the possibility of the BBC launching digital channels devoted to either sport or films was ruled out.

At the time, the commercial television sector hailed the decision as a victory after intense lobbying against the introduction of a digital licence fee. But BSkyB executives are understood to be furious over the perceived delay of the review of News 24.

The broadcaster took its case against the channel to the European commission last year, arguing that the station created a distorted marketplace because the BBC offers its channel to cable and digital operators free of charge.

BSkyB argues that News 24 competes directly against its own service Sky News.

"We are very surprised given that it was stated this would be a priority," a BSkyB spokesman said.

Shadow culture secretary Peter Ainsworth said he was baffled by the government's decision. "It looks as though they are letting the BBC off the hook. That the review shouldn't take place until after the election certainly was not what the House was led to believe."

Mr Ainsworth, who opposes the BBC's funding of News 24, is preparing a written question to be put to Mr Smith to clarify the timetable.

A BBC spokesman said the timetable for any review was "a matter for the government". The BBC maintains that the news channel complies with its public service requirement.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Schröder urges share buying
fields.body:
Schröder urges share buying

German chancellor Gerhard Schröder urged rank and file employees yesterday to take a greater part in the country's booming equity culture.

"I'm glad when the Dax [index] goes up," Mr Schröder said, adding that more of his countrymen should adopt his attitude.

He said Germans should view share buying as a means of saving up for retirement and that legislation should be drawn up to that end. Greater stock holdings would help Germans better understand changes in the overall economy.

IMF calls for changes at BoE

The Bank of England should be more "upfront and explicit" about the future direction of interest rates and inflation in its quarterly report, says a report published by the International Monetary Fund.

IMF economists say the system of inflation targeting and an independent central bank provide a suitable framework for a focused and credible monetary policy. But they identify several potential weaknesses, including the fact that the Bank's inflation forecasts are based on the assumption of unchanged interest rates.

To be more transparent and credible, Britain should copy New Zealand's central bank and consider publishing a range of possible forecasts for borrowing costs and inflation. "In principle there are many interest rate profiles that could deliver an inflation of 2.5% two years ahead," says the report.

Syringe firm optimistic

Safety syringes company NMT yesterday said it was "only a matter of time" before laws are introduced across Europe preventing doctors from using traditional needles.

Six US states have already passed legislation requiring doctors to use alternatives, because of the risk of contracting infectious diseases from accidental jabs.

NMT's chief executive Roy Smith said: "Awareness is growing about the issue in Europe, particularly in Italy and the UK. It may take one country to put some kind of marker down, then the rest will follow."

He was speaking as NMT, which makes syringes that pop back into a plastic case after use, revealed full-year losses of £7.06m - an increase of 118%.

VW offers more stock options

Volkswagen said yesterday that it would offer its 104,000 eligible employees a stock option scheme this year. It said that last year about half the eligible employees participated in the scheme.

webTitle: Workers are insular, Ford tells minister

fields.headline: Workers are insular, Ford tells minister
fields.trailText: Ford yesterday accused workers at its main Dagenham plant of being "backward looking" and "insular" with the result that managers had little confidence in the workforce.
fields.body:
Ford yesterday accused workers at its main Dagenham plant of being "backward looking" and "insular" with the result that managers had little confidence in the workforce.

The outburst, made during a meeting between Ford executives and local MP Margaret Hodge, an education and employment minister, comes at a time when the future of the plant is in doubt.

Ms Hodge was told that Ford believes workers are aggressive and fail to support the company while the unions resist change.

Ford is planning to restructure its European operations and union officials believe it may decide to cease car assembly at Dagenham. This could result in the loss of almost half the 8,000 manufacturing jobs at the plant, which also makes engines for other Ford operations.

The management's view of the workforce is unlikely to help it to retain continued car production at the plant.

This year Ford announced that Dagenham would switch to single shift production, with the loss of up to 1,500 jobs, because of low European demand for the Fiesta.The new Fiesta was to be built at both Dagenham and Cologne. Union officials believe that the car will now be made initially only in Germany.

The unions believe Ford intends to go back on its promise to build a new car at Dagenham.

fields.headline: Clarity is the missing link
fields.standfirst: A little light from hole in the wall
fields.trailText: One small cheer for Link. At least the threat of customers facing a double charge for making withdrawals from bank and building society cash machines has been averted. But the system agreed at Harrogate by Link members yesterday is hardly a model of clarity.
fields.body:
One small cheer for Link. At least the threat of customers facing a double charge for making withdrawals from bank and building society cash machines has been averted. But the system agreed at Harrogate by Link members yesterday is hardly a model of clarity.

Though customers using another bank's cash machine will not have to pay both a "disloyalty" charge to their own bank and a surcharge to the institution whose cash machine they use, it is not clear which of the two they will have to pay.

The best that Link could come up with is to establish an order of priority - surcharges will take precedence over "disloyalty" fees. Nor is it clear how much customers will pay. Barclays has suggested a surcharge of £1. Don Cruickshank who recently wrote a critical report on the banks thinks 30p sufficient. Others have yet to commit themselves.

Though the question of how much to charge will be for the individual banks - with attendant risks of lost customers for those whose charges stray too far out of line with their rivals - it is important that customers are not asked to pay too much and that the charge relates to the cost to the banks and building societies of providing the service.

One other question is whether new internet banks should be granted access to Link. It would help stimulate competition if they were allowed to hook up to the system but the institutions which have invested in providing the network are entitled to protest about free riding. The banking industry might take a lesson from the telecommunications sector where new entrants have been allowed access to existing networks at a price.

If the two sides can not agree they could easily call on the good offices of Mr Cruickshank. He used to be the UK's telecoms regulator and so would have no trouble advising. But given what Mr Cruickshank thinks the banks should charge for cash machine transactions there may be a touch of reluctance to ask for his guidance on other pricing measures.

Top coat tarnish

BMW's divorce from Rover looks to be rather more damaging to its reputation than to its balance sheet. The final bill - purchase price, cumulative losses and exit provision, less the money from the sale of Land Rover -looks likely to be less than £1bn. That might seem a tidy enough sum, but remember BMW still keeps Cowley and the new engine plant at Hams Hall.

Elsewhere the picture looks even less rosy. BMW's says it was forced to act because of continuing, indeed increasing, losses as a result of the strength of the pound and the weakness of the Rover brand.

When BMW bought Rover six years ago the pound was around DM2.50. Few would have imagined that sterling would rally to around DM3.20. But if BMW can argue the exchange rate factor was beyond its control, it cannot shrug off the blame for the standing of the Rover brand onto anyone else.

Whether the initial decision to buy Rover was wrong or whether the way in which BMW subsequently sought to manage the UK carmaker was to blame is a moot point. There are arguments for suggesting both factors contributed to the demise of the English patient, as Rover came to be called in Germany.

The fact remains that while BMW's balance sheet has been dented, its strategy is a wreck. Its efforts to rebuild centre on the BMW marque, which will be extended to include a new model at the bottom end of the existing range, the new mini and, from 2003, Rolls-Royce, most of which it could have been had at much less cost in time and money without getting involved with Rover. The Munich based group is going to have an uphill battle to rebuild its reputation as a smart operator.

Nor has BMW escaped undamaged from the row with the British government - which was prepared to back the group's plans for investment in Longbridge with hard cash - over the way in which the dismemberment of Rover was handled. It is adamant that it did not mislead the government over Rover's future, arguing that it gave a series of warnings about the impact the strength of the pound was having on its Rover arithmetic.

Though sources in Whitehall yesterday backed up BMW's claims that it gave the government every indication of the seriousness of the situation, the car maker does not appear to have learnt much in terms of public relations from recent events.

On Monday the Hungarian government said that talks about BMW investing in Hungary had reopened. Yesterday BMW acknowledged that it had previously looked at building a next generation Rover in Hungary and yes, the same facts should be valid for BMW cars. At this stage, however, the group had no plans to go to Hungary.

Perhaps Hungary's prime minister Viktor Orban should prepare himself for a degree of disappointment when he turns up in Munich next month.

webTitle: Wegg-Prosser may publish Slate in UK

fields.headline: Wegg-Prosser may publish Slate in UK
fields.trailText: A former special adviser to Peter Mandelson is understood to be in talks to become the British publisher of Slate, Microsoft's online magazine.
fields.body:
A former special adviser to Peter Mandelson is understood to be in talks to become the British publisher of Slate, Microsoft's online magazine.

Benjamin Wegg-Prosser, 25, is believed to have flown to Seattle last week to persuade executives at Microsoft's corporate headquarters that they should allow him to establish an offshoot of its high-profile internet publication in London.

Slate is a wholly owned Microsoft venture in the US but it it is understood that Mr Wegg-Prosser is in the process of raising venture funds of his own that would leave Microsoft with a minority stake in the British firm. He has a team ready to run the business and list of columnists he would like to sign. Mr Wegg-Prosser last night said he was not prepared to comment.

Slate was launched by Microsoft in 1996 to much fanfare and caused a stir when it signed up Michael Kinsley, a highly respected former editor of New Republic, to oversee editorial operations.

It subsequently recruited a series of high-profile columnists including Michael Lewis, author of Liars Poker, the seminal book on Wall Street corporate greed in the 1980s.

However, Slate struggled to build a user base. In February of last year it scrapped its subscription fee and internet research firm MediaMetrix says that since then its unique user numbers have grown from 250,000 to almost 2m. Revenues come from advertising, sponsorship and e-commerce.

Mr Wegg-Prosser was approached by the Sun after Mr Mandelson resigned in 1998 from the government. He declined to join and went to Pearson. In January Mr Wegg-Prosser quit his job as corporate communications manager at the media group after just seven months. He said he was going to look at opportunities in journalism, business, the internet and politics.

webTitle: AEEU chief hits out in ferries row

fields.headline: AEEU chief hits out in ferries row
fields.trailText: Government plans to place a £1bn Ministry of Defence order for six roll-on roll-off ferries with a foreign shipyard were attacked yesterday by Sir Ken Jackson, the leader of the AEEU engineering union.
fields.body:
Government plans to place a £1bn Ministry of Defence order for six roll-on roll-off ferries with a foreign shipyard were attacked yesterday by Sir Ken Jackson, the leader of the AEEU engineering union.

Sir Ken also attacked an MoD claim, reported in yesterday's Guardian, that British yards were no longer capable of building the ferries.

In a private letter to defence secretary Geoff Hoon, Sir Ken said the MoD claim was un true and irresponsible."We do indeed have the necessary engineering and design expertise to build roll-on roll-off ferries to the degree of quality that the MoD requires," he said.

"That's why this sort of speculation is so unsettling and damaging to the industry."

The union leader, who is regarded as a government supporter, is furious about the potential job losses at Rover.

If the MoD places the ferries' order overseas, thousands more engineering jobs will go in Britain. The Govan shipyard, which had been counting on winning part of the contract, would face closure.

Sir Ken told the defence secretary that building the ferries in Britain would safeguard thousands of jobs.

"It would also demonstrate the government's commitment to the future of the industry," he said. "Closure of these yards would result in the loss of irreplaceable and strategically important skills."

He told Mr Hoon that the criteria the government was applying to the ferries order were different to those it applied when it decided to build two aircraft carriers in Britain. "It is disappointing that speculation about government contracts is allowed to undermine UK-based industries and the employees within them," he told the minister. "The MoD should, along with other departments, set a clear example that the government is prepared to support companies that operate within the UK."

The government will be concerned that the recent spate of bad news for manufacturing industry is starting to turn even moderate union leaders against it.

webTitle: Volatile. Risky. But Ofex stills the sneers

fields.headline: Volatile. Risky. But Ofex stills the sneers
fields.standfirst: Big boys start to buy as market capitalisation doubles to £4.5bn
fields.trailText: Big investors have long sneered at Ofex, the fringe stock exchange best known for trading the shares of football clubs such as Arsenal and Rangers.
fields.body:
Big investors have long sneered at Ofex, the fringe stock exchange best known for trading the shares of football clubs such as Arsenal and Rangers.

But in a classic game of two halves, Ofex has in the space of a few months reinvented itself as a mini-Nasdaq and doubled in total market capitalisation to £4.5bn. The big boys still sneer, but are quietly beginning to buy. Later this year they will be able to buy Ofex itself, which is expected to pip both the London Stock Exchange and the futures market Liffe to a market listing.

Trading volumes on Ofex have exploded since dot.com share dealing mania took off in November last year. In December 1998 only 895 trades took place on Ofex. Last month there were 20,551. Barclays Stockbrokers says that last year it handled barely 10 trades a day on Ofex-quoted shares. Now 100 trades a day are not uncommon.

Ofex began in 1995 as a home for companies which were too small for a full market listing, or, as in the case of Arsenal, had only a tiny proportion of their shares available for trading. Set up by John Jenkins of market maker JP Jenkins, it is not technically a stock market, but a facility for stockbrokers to trade "off exchange" in the shares of companies that cannot meet the strict requirements of the LSE.

If the LSE is the premier league, Ofex is the second division behind Aim. It makes no bones about how risky and volatile the companies quoted can be. Spreads are enormous - 10% for starters, and often much more. Liquidity can be non-existent. Company information is sparse at best. "Research" is limited to penny stock tipsheets that are often no more than promotional puffery.

But it costs only about £20,000 to list, compared to the millions that it can cost to hire blue-chip brokers and bankers for an LSE listing. Little wonder that technology start-ups are queueing up to join Ofex.

Next week sees the listing of Cybertec, an internet incubator fund looking for £2m. At the end of April EC2.com, another incubator, will join Ofex, valued at about £8m. In all 37 companies are seeking to join the existing 200 on Ofex. More than half of them are dot.coms.

Not every stock is tiny. The biggest is Turbo Genset, a Heathrow power generator company that has soared in value to about £700m, ousting Weetabix from the top slot in the Ofex market. fields.headline: Heathrow delay
fields.standfirst: Government fudges Terminal 5 decision
fields.trailText: The government has ruled out taking a decision on whether to approve Terminal 5 at Heathrow airport before the election because of the political sensitivity it would arouse in London marginal constituencies. Government sources last night confirmed that a decision had been put "on the back burner" since the election was likely to be held next year.
fields.body:
The government has ruled out taking a decision on whether to approve Terminal 5 at Heathrow airport before the election because of the political sensitivity it would arouse in London marginal constituencies. Government sources last night confirmed that a decision had been put "on the back burner" since the election was likely to be held next year.

The government's view is that this is a planning decision the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, can delay until after the election, although this will have consequences for its airports strategy.

The view of most observers who followed Britain's longest running public inquiry, which finished a year ago, is that the government will eventually approve Terminal 5.

It is almost certainly bound to do so in view of the increasing number of people who want to fly, demonstrated by the 5% annual growth in air traffic.

But limits will be placed on the number of aircraft, such as the one preparing to land above, able to use the terminal and on night flights. Even so, it would bring hostile reaction from a public sceptical of past promises. It was told that Heathrow's Terminal 4 would be the final extension to the world's busiest international airport.

webTitle: We need to be bigger, admits Kingston

fields.headline: We need to be bigger, admits Kingston
fields.standfirst: Kingston Communications, the Hull-based telecoms group, has signed an alliance with BT Cellnet which will add mobile phones to its collection of fixed line-to-interactive television product offerings.
fields.trailText: The mobile phone arm is expected to make £500,000 in profit for Kingston next year. The announcement was made as Kingston confirmed it would need to consider acquisitions or alliances if it were to survive in the converging telecoms, internet and media environment.
fields.body:
The mobile phone arm is expected to make £500,000 in profit for Kingston next year. The announcement was made as Kingston confirmed it would need to consider acquisitions or alliances if it were to survive in the converging telecoms, internet and media environment.

Ross Cope, Kingston's chief financial officer, said: "We do need to be bigger."

He refused to comment on whether wireless telecoms operator Atlantic Telecom would be a suitable partner. Analysts said the main factor preventing an alliance between the two companies would be a clash of cultures. And Mr Cope said that any merger was unlikely to take place in the near future as British telecom groups were already "highly priced".

The alliance with BT Cellnet will see Kingston, which joined BT in the FTSE 100 index earlier this month, offer mobile phones to business and residential customers. Internal estimates suggest that up to 200 of its 1,000 company clients would take up the mobile package along with Kingston's fixed-line offering in the first 12 months.

Mr Cope said Kingston would probably lose £500,000 on the new mobile business this year but recoup that in the following year.

fields.headline: The next big adventure
fields.standfirst: The news that Adventures in Motion Pictures will inhabit the Old Vic is a triumph for the dance world
fields.trailText: Modesty has never been counted a virtue by Adventures in Motion Pictures, the modern dance group that emerged from London's Laban Centre back in 1987. While similar small troupes were content to struggle around the touring circuit, AMP, under choreographer Matthew Bourne, started on a course of restless expansion from which it has never deviated.
fields.body:
Modesty has never been counted a virtue by Adventures in Motion Pictures, the modern dance group that emerged from London's Laban Centre back in 1987. While similar small troupes were content to struggle around the touring circuit, AMP, under choreographer Matthew Bourne, started on a course of restless expansion from which it has never deviated.

At first the audiences grew. Bourne's outrageously entertaining shows drew on traditions of showbiz, classical ballet and film, and rapidly attracted a public far wider than hard-core dance fans. Inevitably, the scale of the productions grew too. In 1992 Bourne was commissioned by Opera North to create a radical version of the Nutcracker, and went on to choreograph lavish rewrites of Swan Lake and Cinderella. With stars from the Royal Ballet guesting in his shows, sell-out seasons in the West End and on Broadway, and a clutch of awards, Bourne's company redefined what an independent dance theatre group could aspire to.

Now AMP has outdone itself with the announcement that it will be moving into London's Old Vic theatre as company-in-residence from 2002. With privileged use of the stage and permanent rehearsal and administrative facilities, AMP is set to become the only major British dance company apart from the two Royal Ballet companies with its own base and theatre.

AMP's producer Katharine Doré had been looking for "a permanent relationship with a theatre" for the past couple of years. "I'd been trying to settle Matt down for a while," she says. Until now Bourne and his dancers have rehearsed in gypsy conditions, "three weeks in one studio, three weeks somewhere else" - a huge waste of time and energy.

By the end of this decade Bourne plans to have six to eight of his works playing in repertory at the Old Vic. These will include Highland Fling (his lager-fuelled update of La Sylphide), Cinderella and the Nutcracker, the new work Car Man and at least two other new productions. The all-male Swan Lake will occasionally be revived at larger venues. When the company is in rehearsal or on tour, other dance and theatre events will be programmed (though Bourne hopes to have some input into their selection). Essentially, AMP will have the same connection to the Old Vic as English National Opera does to the Coliseum.

This plan guarantees Bourne a fabulous showcase for his choreography, yet he's more excited by what it will do for his dancers, since AMP will at last become a full-time company. As Bourne has only ever worked on a project-to-project basis, many of his dancers have been inactive for weeks each year. Now he's able to offer every AMP member a career. "I can really bring on the younger dancers, and use everyone properly. We can also start holding workshops and summer schools, so that AMP can feed back into the dance community."

Bourne and Doré also plan to stage a musical version of Edward Scissorhands. "AMP is just me and Matt and whatever we want to do," says Doré.

The Old Vic will keep them grounded, though, and Bourne says it's perfect for most of the company's needs. "It has an intimacy that suits our work, plus it has all the facilities we need, like an orchestra pit. It's like a mini opera house. I love it."

But if dance has gained a major venue, isn't it at the expense of straight theatre? The Old Vic has for decades been associated with high-class drama, most recently when Peter Hall attempted to launch a repertory company there. When the Arts Council failed to back that venture, many mourned the loss of a rich opportunity. Since his departure, says Guardian critic Michael Billington, the Old Vic "has just been lurching from one thing to the next. It needed something with vision and money to fill the gap, and AMP will certainly bring in those."

Theatre fans may feel that an illustrious tradition will die when AMP moves into the Vic, yet for the dance world this is a homecoming. The Royal Ballet gave its first seasons under Lilian Baylis and Ninette de Valois there, and Bourne is thrilled by this. "Sitting in the office where Baylis and de Valois once sat really appeals. For me the Old Vic is full of ghosts. I hope to become one myself - eventually."

fields.headline: Queen for a night
fields.standfirst: In the days when acting was a disreputable profession, boys were kidnapped to play women on stage. Nicholas Wright's new play Cressida recreates the world of that base trade.
fields.trailText: Boys will be boys - or girls, or women, or grown men. We have Elizabethan tastes to thank for some of theatre's greatest moments. Without the fashion for teenage boys in frocks, Shakespeare could never have offered us a boy playing a girl playing a boy playing a girl (As You Like It) or, more simply, a boy playing a girl playing a boy (Twelfth Night). Nicholas Wright's play Cressida, which opens this week with Michael Gambon as a trainer of boy actors for the 17th-century stage, casts adults as adolescents to depict a world in which adolescents played adults. Are you keeping up?
fields.body:
Boys will be boys - or girls, or women, or grown men. We have Elizabethan tastes to thank for some of theatre's greatest moments. Without the fashion for teenage boys in frocks, Shakespeare could never have offered us a boy playing a girl playing a boy playing a girl (As You Like It) or, more simply, a boy playing a girl playing a boy (Twelfth Night). Nicholas Wright's play Cressida, which opens this week with Michael Gambon as a trainer of boy actors for the 17th-century stage, casts adults as adolescents to depict a world in which adolescents played adults. Are you keeping up?

Cressida's title refers to the role in which its young hero, a 13-year-old actor called Stephen Hammerton, makes his name. The play describes an acting culture best summed up by Lee Ingleby, who plays juvenile star Alex Goffe: "When your voice starts to break, you're buggered." It's a culture that we've lost, and that 24-year-old Ingleby and his co-stars, Michael Legge (21) and Daniel Brocklebank (20), must now reanimate. Stealing out of rehearsal a day before Cressida's previews begin, the trio reflect: how different are their characters' professional lives from their own?

Cressida's dramatis personae can be found in the footnotes of any theatrical history. Gambon's character, John Shank, starred with Shakespeare's troupe, the King's Men. He was a clown, a wheeler-dealer - and a proto-drama teacher. Young recruits were assigned to specific players within a troupe, often those with a respected profession - Shank was a weaver - that could cloak the illegal apprenticeship.

A company's means of acquiring infant talent was not always honourable. Four hundred years ago 13-year-old Thomas Clifton was kidnapped by the proprietors of the Blackfriars Boys to practise "the base trade of a mercynary enterlude player," as his disgruntled dad Henry alleged. "Acting wasn't a choice then," says Brocklebank, who plays the 18-year-old John "Honey" Honyman. "You were assigned to it, sold into it."

Cressida's young stars have been acting for the better part of a decade. Brocklebank was the boy-player in Shakespeare in Love; Legge starred in Angela's Ashes. Ingleby is perfectly qualified for his Cressida role: "I don't think I've played above 20," he says. "The older I get, the younger I seem to play. It's quite good - it means you get to forget about all the shit that comes along with being an adult."

Legge arrives fresh from having his chest waxed. "They've taken your sideys off too, mate. You're bald!" hoots Brocklebank, who, playing an 18-year-old, keeps his hair on. But for him, "the whole dress thing is so uncomfortable. My female costume is so huge, they've had to add five minutes to my call time just so I can get in and out of it. I keep reminding my agent that I'm a bloke, and that I'd quite like to play some gritty roles for a change." Ingleby has complaints too: "It's the clothes: the stockings, the hooped skirt, the corset"

Boy-players and all-boy companies flourished in the Elizabethan and Jacobean eras for many reasons: they were cheaper and easier to manage; acting wasn't a respectable activity for an adult; audiences developed a taste for children enacting adult crises. Boy-playing was a convention, a style; psychological credibility had little to do with it.

The cast of Cressida has tried to reconnect with that more formal style. There's a scene in which Shank teaches Hammerton "where to put your hands, and so on". "We still use stuff like that," says Brocklebank, "but you've got much more freedom now to make the character your own." It's apt that, even in this age of formal free-for-all, the young actors have aped their characters and turned for advice to an expert. "Michael Gambon makes it look so easy," says Ingleby.

"I worked with John Gielgud," Brocklebank recalls, "and he was very 'Whooaaa!' [a melodramatic moan]. I was expecting Michael to be a bit like that: the old school."

"I'm still shocked by how dead-on he is," says Legge.

The trio are determined to avoid the danger that Cressida dramatises: that an acting career that begins brilliantly has nowhere to go but down. "You're like a soldier on the eve of battle," says Brocklebank's character in the play's most sensitive passage. "Every night could be your last." And then what? "Men bred from boys are damaged goods," says Shank. The ranks of burned-out child stars in our own time testify to that.

Ingleby, Legge and Brocklebank should have a good few years left in them: these days, the fleetingness of fame depicted in Cressida applies less to actors than to actresses. But they're still doomed, or blessed, by theatre's unique selling point, as evoked in Cressida: its magic is elusive, brief, irrecoverable - and exquisite. Or, as Lee Ingleby, bestriding the West End stage as a boy dressed as a queen, puts it: "It's good to feel the wind between your legs."

Cressida is at the Albery Theatre, London WC2 (0171-369 1740), until June 10.

fields.headline: A better class of rubbish
fields.standfirst: An auteur goes slumming
fields.trailText: Imagine it's an average soft-core Friday night on Channel 5. The femme fatale du soir is a French vamp called Jessie. In a swanky Seattle nightspot, Jessie lures a businessman into the toilet, presumably for a torrid encounter. Instead, he emerges from the cubicle clutching his bullet wounds, for Jessie is a professional assassin.
fields.body:
Imagine it's an average soft-core Friday night on Channel 5. The femme fatale du soir is a French vamp called Jessie. In a swanky Seattle nightspot, Jessie lures a businessman into the toilet, presumably for a torrid encounter. Instead, he emerges from the cubicle clutching his bullet wounds, for Jessie is a professional assassin.

Or is she? Jessie wakes on a plane to realise it was all a dream. She is en route to her honeymoon in Jamaica with her husband. But wait - back in Seattle, Jessie the assassin wakes, having dreamed she was a bride on honeymoon in Jamaica.

It's usually at this point that a screenwriter pitching a story is ushered out of the producer's office. But Shattered Image, although ludicrous pulp, is no ordinary pulp - it's a film by the Chilean avant-gardist Raul Ruiz. Ruiz claims that Shattered Image was the dry run for his unimpeachably classy Proust adaptation Time Regained. Next we'll learn that Alain de Botton limbered up for his Proust book by writing a pamphlet called How Mickey Spillane Can Improve Your Sex Life.

Shattered Image is an anomaly for Ruiz. It has a relatively coherent plot, or rather two: an assassin falls for her latest target; and a woman suspects her husband is out to kill her. Both women are called Jessie and played by Anne Parillaud; both men are called Brian and played by William Baldwin. Each woman dreams the other, or thinks she does.

Dream, reality, questions of identity: it's a moot point whether Jessie's tawdry tale(s) is/are ennobled by such lofty metaphysical resonances, or whether Ruiz is debunking the intellectual subtext by dragging it down to the idiotic level of the story. The film cultivates extreme tackiness - the fetishism of bead curtains, sweaty sex viewed through fishtanks. Then there's the plywood acting: Parillaud, replicating her monster-vamp from Luc Besson's Nikita, and Baldwin supplying his usual cheap-cologne machismo. Here are all the signs of a very bad film indeed.

But this is less a bad film than a contemplation of the pleasures of cheapness. Shattered Image is now available to rent on video (Metrodome), with Ruiz's name dwarfed by the tag-line "Mad or Bad?" (Jessie, presumably, not the film). Rent it and you won't get quite what the package promises.

Shattered Image is a prime example of that mythic class of films in which directors subvert a script with their own stylistic preoccupations. I don't just mean the classic Hollywood tradition by which auteurs use off-the-peg material to make personal statements; I mean film-makers so completely flouting a film's premise that it looks like a grudge match against both public and producers.In reality, this rarely happens, but there are a few famous cases. Jean-Luc Godard, obliged by his producers to put more Brigitte Bardot flesh in Le Mépris, introduced a scene in which Bardot deconstructs the commercial appeal of her nudity.

Few directors go so far as flaunting their contempt for a project, as Robert Altman seemed to in his 1997 version of John Grisham's The Gingerbread Man - a ramshackle narrative corroded by Altman's distinctively loose rhythms. Grisham fans and Altman faithful despaired, but it was a fabulous display of perversity. Younger directors would be ill-advised to try such tactics.

However, Raul Ruiz, a wild card who could knock off three features for a fiver if pushed, is game for anything. Either Shattered Image is meretricious tat, or it systematically subverts all certainties about genre cinema. Or both. Or perhaps it's an art movie dreaming it's a genre movie dreaming it's an art movie.

fields.headline: Cancer treatment zeroes in
fields.trailText: A new radiotherapy technique, which allows tumours that are wrapped around healthy tissue to be targeted more precisely, may save the lives of patients suffering from many types of cancer in situations that at present are hard to treat.
fields.body:
A new radiotherapy technique, which allows tumours that are wrapped around healthy tissue to be targeted more precisely, may save the lives of patients suffering from many types of cancer in situations that at present are hard to treat.

The problem with radiotherapy has been that it destroys everything in its path, cancerous and healthy cells alike. But the Institute of Cancer Research yesterday unveiled a far more delicate form of treatment, called intensity modulated radiotherapy. The institute's scientists have found a way to create three-dimensional beams which curve around the tumour and limit the collateral damage.

The treatment has been designed to tackle tumours in the pelvic region, which tend to be irregularly shaped and are tangled around healthy tissue. It has been very difficult to treat prostate cancer which has spread to the pelvis without giving high doses of radiotherapy to the bowel at the same time. Once prostate cancer has spread to the pelvic lymph glands, it is often the cause of death.

Clinical trials will start at the Royal Marsden hospital in London in the spring with 90 prostate cancer patients whose disease has spread to the pelvis. But scientists believe IMRT will also make treatment more effective not only in other cancers in that part of the body, such as cervical, bladder and rectal cancer, but also in cancers of the lung, head, neck, thyroid, oesophagus and pancreas, which curve round healthy tissue.

The technique could be particularly helpful in treating children.

The treatment is an advance on conformal radiotherapy, in which beams are formed around irregularly shaped tumours. "Now we are developing the even more advanced IMRT techniques, we will be able to mould radiotherapy to convex shapes, to target those tumours precisely," said David Dearnaley, director of the clinical trials.
